content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												I like Armello. I like it a lot. It looks fantastic, it's a beautifully-crafted world, it's got a great deal of variety both in aesthetic in characters. The world and its characters are fascinating; even with little character development, the animations alone are enough to convey each character's personality, and aspects like the Rot are mysterious enough to be captivating. I'd absolutely love to see this world explored further in other games or media - it's a world I want to spend more time in. However, I've put a good deal of time into the game, and while for the most part I've enjoyed myself, the game has two critical flaws that make me uncomfortable recommending it. So while this review is negative, please understand that in the context of "it's great until you start taking it seriously."The two major issues the game has are as follows: first, attacks are easier than defenses. When you are in battle, barring any of the rare modifiers, three sides of the six-sided dice result in an attack, one of which rolls an extra die (which can chain infinitely), while only one side will give you a defense. A defense will block one attack and no more. The issue this presents is that combat has extremely high variance; you could roll 12 dice against 6, and there's still a large chance that you will die in the process. Your opponent is far more likely to roll enough attacks to kill you, than you are to roll enough shields to ensure your life. Even when you roll 20 dice against 4, you could very easily watch a long chain of rerolls build on your opponent's board that quickly eclipses your shields and remaining health. Rather than feeling like an exciting and rare moment, it feels like the norm. The conclusion may be, therefore, to avoid combat entirely; but there are also an abundance of ranged cards that let you do large amounts of damage, and rarely requiring you even be close to the target. There is no way to "safely" play a game of Armello. When paired with the variety modifiers for the dice rolls, the simple fact is that surviving is far more difficult than killing......which leads into the second issue: there is basically no comeback mechanic. It is ridiculously easy to fall into a situaton where you can't progress further towards any victories or character progression because you keep dying, and you keep dying because you can't become any more powerful. This is not just a common occurence, it's basically standard: in every game aside from AI matches, one person will always end up in a situation where they literally cannot compete because they have to go for their quests, but they can't get to those quests because it becomes too easy for them to die along the way and start way back at the beginning. And even if they get to stack the odds in their favor - they get a few lucky spells that buff their attack and die and weaken their opponent - once again, the game is so high-variance that they are still very likely to get set back to square one. The problem here is not that you can be screwed over at anytime; it's that you are less likely to be screwed over when you're already in the lead. Not just on the basic premise that players who can stay on the board get more powerful and have more opportunities (rich get richer), but there are other game mechanics to support this: The Prestige Leader gets to pick one of two laws to be enacted every dawn, meaning they can always choose the card that benefits themself or threatens other players; and also, once you die, you can't play any cards to the board until you leave your spawn on your next turn. You can also only move after you've drawn cards, meaning you may will be unable to toss the cards you don't want in order to draw better ones that might actually help you win. And once a player realizes they are in that pit they cannot climb out of, there's hardly any reason to complete the game - I've never played an online game where a player hadn't tapped out by the halfway point. I wouldn't even call it a ragequit; after all, acceptance of defeat does not have to involve anger any more often than disappointment. And once one person has left, the remaining players generally follow shortly after.So, I also play a lot of Blood Bowl. I've stared the worst that RNG can offer straight in the face, and occasionally managed not to cry. But Armello is rigged in such a way that makes Blood Bowl seem almost forgiving. If Wyld rolls (the ones that reroll) were shields instead of attacks, the game would likely be significantly more fun to play, as it would encourage trying to stack the RNG in your favor; rather than always needing the best luck possible to get anything done, no matter what you do. Blood Bowl is a game of calculating risks and managing your actions to maximize your chances of success. Armello is a game of swearing because the game will leave you in positions where your only hope for victory is that everyone else starts aimlessly wandering into swamps and suiciding constantly for the remainder of the game.I still recommend the game for a few hours' worth, if you've got friends to play with. Don't play online, because you'll never finish a game with as many people as you started with. And don't stress over trying to get better at the game, because you'll eventually realize that the skill ceiling was underneath the building's foundation all along. But yeah, it's a pretty fun experience for a period of time.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
												This game is a real treat for those looking for something unique, visually attractive, and challenging. It is very well produced blend of strategy, role playing, and board gaming. The producers have comitted great attention to detail. Every element of the game; characters, story line, events, spells, equipment, flavor text, and even poetry, create a true sense that this is a fully imagined world that you have entered.Before I go into the gameplay, a little bit on the game lore would be helpful: Armello is a kingdom of animal clans ruled by a lion (king). Unfortunately, the king has been infected by a creeping, evil disease called the "Rot". It has driven him mad and slowly ebbes his health. Each night the Rot grows in him, and each morning he loses health. His madness is evident in his daily decrees, that create chaos around the realm, affecting the heroes and inhabitants of the kingdom. The time then has come to depose the king and for a new hero to take the throne.Armello is a turn based 4 player board game (you can also play against AI). At the beginning of a game players choose a hero, a female or male character, that is either a bear, wolf, rabbit, or rat. Each character has unique stats (Fight/Body/Wit/Spirit), and also a unique ability. The hero's creature clan type provides a trait that provides a boon for that character as well. From there players select a ring and amulet that provide additional abilities or benefits to their hero.Players take turns drawing cards, moving their heroes about the game board, casting spells, and completing quests. Completing a quest improves hero stats, and rewards them with equipment, followers, or treasures. As heroes adventure they will encounter perils, both randomly placed, and ones placed by other players and the king. They may also attack other players and cast spells on opponents to hinder their progress or even kill them. There are King's guards and evil creatures called banes that wander about the board that will attack players and generally get in the way.The object for each player is to aquire the means to dethrone the king and become the new monarch/matriarch themself. There are 3 ways to win the game; by defeating the king in straight one on one combat, by gathering 4 spirit stones to destroy the "Rotting" king, or by having the most prestige points when the king finally succumbs to the Rot after 10 turns.So here's the take away for Armello:Pros:       Beautifully imagined and rendered world. From the artwork to the storyline to the general atmosphere, you know that this game was a labor of love for the very competent makers.        Unique. Armello borrows from several genres and merges them into new gaming experience that is a welcome break from the copy/paste fodder that has cluttered the online gaming selection.        Fun and addictive. Even if you don't win you'll have tons of fun tripping up your opponents and discovering new ways to use heroes, board tactics, and spells.        Replayability. The variety in characters, abilities, and win conditions make each match unique and provides tons of replayability. Achievements will unlock new rings and amulets that give players even more opportunities to expirement with heroes and win conditions.Cons:        Waiting. Armellos is a turn based game so this may turn some people off. In addition each night and morning there are non-player creatures that must move and decrees to resolve. One consolation is that you can still play spells, perils, and equip items during another players turn.         More waiting. The player base is still small and you may have to wait a while, sometimes longer than a while, to get a full group of opponents. (best bet is to invite your friends to a game)         Random. "The best laid plans of mice and men....". The randomness of card drawing, dice rolls in battle, decrees, and questing, can sometimes wreck your strategy. It can be frustrating since you have little control over this element of the game. But the more you play, the more you learn how to mitigate this factor and/or adust your strategy in midstride.          You can't win. Ocassionaly, at some point in an Armello match you'll realize that you can't win. Kinda like in Monopoly when you own Mediterranian and Baltic Avenues and your opponent owns everything else. It just ain't gonna happen. Sometimes as early as midgame you come to this realization. Many online players drop out at this point (the game inserts an AI player to take over when this happens). And you'll feel like your just going through the motions, hopelessly. But, you can still get some enjoyment out of messing with the leading player or even by helping another player steal the win!In closing this is a great game that's different and enjoyable. It deserves to succeed. So get it, play it, and definately tell your family, friends, neighbors, and enemies to give it a try.

content:
Posted: January 10
												I really enjoy this game. I have some cons and pros though which I'll include below.For many years I've followed this, it had a successful kickstarter which brought it to steam.It was quite popular, and I'd say still is, probably. I never have too many issues finding people to play with.PROS:---------- nice music- REALLY GOOD ART- the cards in game have art which are painted and ANIMATED!- the cards in game have bonuses, or curses which you can play on yourself, tiles, or others- NICE >> you can't harrass each other in chat, as the responses are specific to each character. (For example, my rabbit will say 'salutations' instead of just 'hello', where as another may say 'Hiya!' etc., It depends on personality of the playing character. You cannot type to talk. (Maybe a con to some, see below)- Dice are tradeable, easy to get. Just play and it throws boxes/keys at you.- Can play with friends. (also a con, see below)- 8 characters to start, tons of dice, rings to unlock (benefits), cards, and map is completely randomized- Events happen at random in the game which makes for good gameplay.But I have a few complaints, not with the game, as it's quite fun, really balanced and random.But with the community.CONS:==================================- Can't type to talk. This is fine for me for the most part, as I'm less anxious about joining a game knowing I can't be verbally trolled, but at the same time, I wish there was a 'nice dice!' button, or something, I'd really just like them to know that they have nice dice!- Why are you allowed to invite 3 players? I would say a 2v2 or inviting for a full match is okay. But when playing a 3v1, honestly I always feel pressured, a 2v2 would be okay, but a 3v1 is difficult. Whenever I've played against a 3v1, some of them will hunt you down and block you in your base, while letting one other character win the game for them, then they will often give each other reccomendations to level each other up. It's not fun. AT ALL.- Same with above, but instead of hunting you? They go afk. They'll just fill a space and not move from their clan base ( they're immune to attacks there) so theres less players to fight against for their friends and they can farm.- Bot Farming > people will join the game, go afk in the base, and just get chests when the game is finished. You can't even kick them. Some of the items are worth £2+ so it's a big problem. :(**** NOTE Reporting is easy to do. Please report these players. ****You press escape when in game and just click the bug icon on the right corner. I did it there a few times now, but I don't know if pushiments are ever taken.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												There is a lot I like and do recommend it;  HOWEVER, and there is a lot I don't like about this game.The good parts:just love the graphics!  Love the audio!  Love love love the concept behind the whole premise of the game!  It's genius!  Almost everything about it is just fun.  The different characters being animals and their traits. etc.   This has so much potential for expansion it isn't funny.  The whole game as it is now could be one small room in a whole castle or kingdom. and jsut a small part of the story.  (sorry in game development so get too excited about the potentials.. feature creep)  Anyway, the like part of this is so broad that it's hard to put it in a few words and I don't have time or the finger durability to write it all down.  I love the fact that it's difficult to master. ... but the game is too random card wise to get really good at it or turning situations.  I love that you can win in different ways.  like I said .. this game has so much genius in it. However, in the hopes that the dev team sees some of this I will detail a little more in the "don't like" side of things.  Because I want to keep playing!First of all, the games are not short most of the time, and that is good, but there is no way to save a game and come back to it later.  If you have to stop and quit due to life, you loose all progress.   I don't need a bunch of saves to cheat with. I just want to save to come back to later.  It took me almost 3 hours to play one game.  Sometimes I don't have that long to play but don't want to screw myself out of playing because I don't have 3 hours.  Online play, well doh, no need for it there but locally, that is a feature I'm frankly appauled isn't in there yet.  That is an industry standard for any tabletop or turn based game. ... in fact most all games.A couple of times I played a card, for example, one that takes one prestige from each player.  palyed the card no problem, and everyone still had all their prestige and I got 0.  There are a few cards in there that are similar that seem to be buggy in general or buggy to one character.. but it isn't consistant enough to give you a bug report with any helpful info in it to track it down. The randomness of the dice and cards are a bit too random. characters really don't get to build and use their strengths and weaknesses.. wait... Thane has no weaknesses (for example)... and always has money and prestige even if you take it all away.  Even if he has an item of some sort.  doesn't matter the game, whether he has city income or not or hasn't even gone treasure hunting, etc.  Even if he gets killed 4 times in a row with no source of income , he's always got plenty of gold and presitge. LOL!!  That kind of needs to be looked at.  Makes for a great challenge if you got the right attitude, but even if you do, after a while it gets old. I know unlocking jewelry and stuff helps you customize it a little bit but honestly, it's in areas that don't help that much in most characters... not all.. but most. What good is stealth in the city at one part of the day when it's likely they saw you go in there.. >,<  It's just an example of the many things.  Sure it might come in handy a sliver of the time but it really doesn't make you feel compelled to unlock much of anything... and there is no progression at all in any way to make you feel like you are playing more than a same scenario board game. In the game you have to stay almost completely rot free to survive or go full rot.. you can't really play the middle of the road and have much of a chance of winning anything other than prestige or by stones.I will have to say though, even with all the "dark side" comments, it's worth 15 dollars... but if improvements aren't made soon, honestly I wouldn't pay 10 for it even as beautiful and artful as it is.  The flaws are big gotcha's .. something as simple as a "sorry you can't save your game and come back to it" is HUGE!!I really hope this keeps progressing I love it and do recommend it. Edit:  It will save your progress in single player, but be aware there is no message that it will do so.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												After days of gathering Spirit Stones, my time had come to infiltrate the castle and cleanse the King of the Rot, at last bringing an end to the madness that had plagued Armello for so long. Twice I was thwarted, twice I lost precious time as the King fell deeper into his sickness, but on my third attempt to slip past the sinister curses, I made it beyond the palace walls. Soon we would be free!But it was not to be. The other powers of the realm, drunk with lust for the throne, would force me out, limping, bloodied, back to my home. It became clear that I would never be able to save the King before the Rot claimed his life.And so I began a swift campaign of political treachery. I schemed, I connived. I did things that whittled away at my soul. To my dismay, it was not long before a rival house entered the keep and slew our once great King. But they sacrificed their own life in the process. In the turmoil that followed, I slipped through the web of liars and conspirators to occupy the vaccuum of power left in the rivers of blood that now freckled our land.I could not save the King, nor could I save my spirit. But by the gods, I would save Armello.(Stories like this happen EVERY time I play. This game is PHENOMENAL.)

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								+ BEFORE YOU BEGIN +  Know that you will forever have 1/3 of the games cast unaccessible to you, and most dissapointingly, by far the most interesting characters of said cast. This is due to a unadvertised kickstarter which was participated in by about 3,000 people. Being part of said kickstarter got you access to the "Bandit" clan permenantly and exclusively. So let's just get that un-advertised thorn of dissapointment right out in the open.The Pros: -The game is fun, the gameplay is solid, and it feels like exactly what it was meant to be- that beer and chips roleplaying, dice throwing, card slinging board game you've likely played with your friends before. -The graphics are smooth and there is plenty of depth to keep gameplay engaging.It is also worth mentioning that the single player AI doesn't feel lacking like some games of these genres do, and have an amusingly nasty habit of punishing the player and other AI's mercilessly. It feels nearly complete if not acceptably so as a base boardgame in it's current state to be frank; though not all cards are incorperated in the game yet, nor are the characters. -The full game will double the (dirty steam players) roster from 4 to 8. So there are more characters to come. and assuming the community doesn't take the secret kickstarter issue too personally, likely more to come in future expansions, assuming there will be expansions.The Bad: -As a pre-release it does have its share of  bugs. Occasionally, but not often, the game will hang on an AI's turn and require you to restart the game. This can be bothersome, but it has only happened to me 3  times out of about 14 matches so...it's par for a pre-release in terms of technical difficulty.-The game does not explain in any way it seems, the ability mechanics obtained through spells and equipment yet.Example, the abilities "Scout" as provided by "Mariners Lantern" and "Evasion" as provided by a spell who's name I can't remember, are discussed nowhere. You can refer to a wiki...but I feel there shouldn't have to be any sort of question on this. Especially with a large tutorial-esque digital pamphlet to read to get the rules down, there should be an effects tab there to clear up any confusion at the least.- People can and do ragequit if they are losing mid game. These games mind you can last anywhere from 30 minutes to 1 1/2 hours. This being said, a poor sport could waste a good chunk of your day with no sense of satisfaction to be had. It is also worth noting that there is no system in place to punish this type of poor sportsmanship, and thusly, you can keep your win/loss ratio as high as you want it to be as long as you never let yourself lose...by ragequitting.The Ugly:- Overall; I love this game and hope to see it succeed... but I will tell you this as well. Anyone who gets into this game will eventually feel a creeping frustration regarding the 1/3 of the character cast they will never have access. Especially given that they are easily the best designed and most interesting characters so far as to be seen of the lot. This is a real shame in my eyes.Being meant to be played online, the average player will likely get fed up or agitated seeing these sacred cows they will always want to play with, but ya know... NONE FOR YOU!Also, it is worth mentioning this will likely cause tension regarding the competitive gaming community as well regarding the legality of these characters in any sort of tournaments, which will likely insight endless bickering and hostilities between the filthy steam players and the obscure kickstarter community.Final Verdict:+The Grade I want to give: 9/10 - As a pre-release game it shows a great deal of polish, care, and attention to detail. The gameplay is balanced and there is enough to be done to remain engaging; including trash talking in chat mid game. I love the way it looks and feels very much and could spend many countless hours tooling around a game like this casually, however...+The Grade I have to give it: 6.5/10 - As stated above, this is a fun game that is hard to find fault with, even in its early stages, but with the ability for poor sportmanship to ruin any chance of an accurate leaderboard, and the high probability a "Good" player may actually just be a man child hellbent on wasting your time and robbing you of that satisfying victory you started the game seeking, I can't fully endorse the multiplayer just yet in a competitive sense.Furthermore, I personally found out about the game only after it was released in its early release phase, but by the time the steam community was made aware of it's existance, they were already damned to forever-never play 1/3 of the games cast; more regretably so, the most appealing 1/3 of the games cast.Maybe seems like a small detail to some out there, but I personally won't ever be able to fully dismiss this as a "Tough luck" kinda thing. Because nothing spoils a good meal like eating by a great meal, especially when you never knew it was going down accross the table from you.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2015
												Armello is a skirmish boardgame-like computergame set in a relatively grim setting, featuring anthropomorphic (read: Furry, if so must!) characters. 4 players (and/or bots) are competitively trying to win the game within a set number of rounds, through one of multiple victory conditions.More specifically, the goal of the game is to either defeat or cure 'the king' from his cursed state, before the rot that has afflicted him takes his life. Players will draw random cards every day/night as chosen from 3 types of decks, be it equipment, magic or trickery in order to increase their chance of succeeding in one of the multiple victory conditions - Meanwhile questing, fighting off corrupted beings or dealing with your other opponents trying to hinder your success.The game delivers absolutely gorgeous  artwork and modeling, with every card containing animated artwork brought by a wide selection of skilled artists - I might personally be biased enjoying an anthropomorphic setting like this, but its undeniable that the designers spend a great deal of time focussing on the aeshethics of this game to grant us an immersive experience.For me personally, a total recommendation - If there would be anything I would like to see changed in the feature, it would be a slightly more attractive balance between the multiple victory conditions, as I consider some of them to be drastically harder to achieve.As for additions: This game needs more lemur!

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												My overall rating for Armello: 85/100Armello brought us a board-game-like adventure-strategy  where four heroes are racing for the throne of Armello ruled by corrupted king. Strategy here is a key element, though luck factor is also important, as fights are being resolved with dice rolls, but a good player may ensure that odds will be on his or her side. Lets see this title in detail.GAMEPLAY+ Variety of heroes with unique abilities+ Hex tile design+ Day/Night cycle+ Huge replayability+ Four victory options+ Interactive turn-based system+ Cards+ Story-driven prologueo Fair multiplayer (host leave may crash the game)o Luck and random number generator- May be frustrating sometimesGameplay is cute and lovely. Heroes are moving on hex based tile, and trying to get prestige, magic, coins or even rot sometimes. With four modificable stats via quests - Fight, Body, Wits and Spirit - the amount of strategies is huge and also it adds more replayability to Armello.There are basically four victory options. Firstly we have a Prestige victory - gaining prestige for quests, killing heroes and banes. Second one is a Spirit Stone victory, after gaining four stones through quests and stone circles, the king is banished after engaging him. Kingslayer and Rot victory are very simillar, you have to kill the king, survive, when trying for Rot, your Rot has to be higher than king's.Day and night cycle also brings important aspect, as heroes have affinity to day parts and also other creatures too. During the day Guards move, during the night Banes are spawning and moving. It may be an advantage or disadvantage, heroes may also become corrupted, which changes their strategy.Good strategy may bring the odds to player side, yet still luck plays an important factor here and after several unhappy rolls players may get frustrated. It is a risk, that needs to be taken. There are six kinds of cards - Items, Spells, Trickery, that may be drawn, Treasures, Followers, acquirable from dugneons or quests, and Palace cards, which player simply has to encounter. Questing is important, as it may deny the palace perils, which are really difficult and nasty.Multiplayer is fair and it is up to the player, if they decide to team up or not, victory may belong to the best one. Also mechanics are good againts leavers or delaying players, though, when the host drops it might result to game crash.Last addition to good points is a story-driven prologue, that is not just a simple tutorial, but the beginning of story in Armello. Also easy to understand and explain game mechanics.CHARACTERS+ Traits and affinities, variety of themPlayer may choose so far from eight heroes and adjust the strategy accordingly.Rabbit clan is represented by Amber, the Far Seeker, who is excellent in dungeons seeking, thus has a higher chance of get a reward. Another member is Barnaby, the Screwloose, who collects equipment and when changing equipped items, cards are not burned.Bear Clan offers Sana, the Forest Sister, who uses Spirit instead of Fight, when dealing with corrupted creatures, and Bran, the Oakbreaker, who gains temporarily Fight after each successfully casted spell.Rat Clan has Mercurio, the Grinning Blade, who steals gold from previous settlement owners and Zosha, the Whirlwind, who is alwasy stealthed at night and may ambush other creatures.Finally, we have here the Wolf Clan. Thane, the Winter Wolf pierces burned cards with swords through enemy's defense, River, the Howling Arrow, shoots before fight, inflicting one hp injury to target.King is always corrupted, whose healthe decrease and rot increase through the game. Banes get additional rot each night, guards are dealing with them, or with heroes, who have bounty on themselves.New heroes are announced, review will be updated after release.VISUAL+ Nice art style+ Animations+ Dices+ SEASONS- Few graphic glitchesArt style is lovely and suits the nature of the game. Also combat animations with dice rolls are amazing (there are four different dice styles so far with animations), differing whether the dice explodes or not, also hit to the hero differs from a blocked attack. There were some graphic glitches, but very rare and not affecting gameplay.It si good to see, that developers still keep this game changing and alive. Newest addition is about year seasons and it is great. The war of the throne keeps going through the whole year. And nou players have that impresion.SOUNDTRACK+ Stylised+ Lisa Gerrard performance+ Changing accordingly to the atmosphereSoundtrack is very well created and composed. Songs are underlining the dark-fantasy atmosphere and course of the game. Also Lisa Gerrard participated and her voice well known from Dead Can Dance or Gladiator suits melodies and game very well. I am glad that developers released soundtrack, that may be also purchased even by non-early-access players.SUMMARYTo sum it up, Armello is well driven adventure-strategy game with dice rolls and a bit of luck, that resembles the style of board games. With a plenty of cards player may react to changing course of the game and adjust the strategy perfectly. This title alsom offers much to the people outside the genre, so for a reasonable price you may get a huge amount of fun.I have been playing this game from 0.3.5 "Pride's Fall" patch and game made a huge progress since.Strongly recommended.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												Thumbs skyward, ladies and gents.To clarify just what Armello is--it is definitely a boardgame come to life in digital format. The card-drawing, the dice-rolling, the playing field all remind you of those cutting-edge games at the hobby store that nobody's ever heard of. The mechanics of the game are dreadfully simple, so you don't need Coordination Level: Dark Souls to play. If that's OK with you, then play on.I'd also say that this is first and foremost a multiplayer game. Single player had me for about 10 hours, but there's no campaign or complex progression or anything that will drive you to play solo all year. The AI can seem a little tricky at first, but it eventually becomes fairly predictable. At some point, you're gonna wanna branch out and go into the multiplayer queue.The game's simplicity allows even a sub-par connection to keep you hooked up, which means matchmaking can reach farther afield and keeps moving even though the game doesn't have a mega-roster of players. I live in central US, and queue times are about 30sec-2min. On rare occasions when the queue exceeds 5min, the game lets me dabble in single player while waiting and informs me when the match is ready.You've also got one of the best communities I've seen, so it's not hard to find peeps to play/get acquainted with. Chat is restrained to a selection of speech options like you'd see in Hearthstone... At first it unnerved me a little, but then I went 20 straight games without reading a single homophobic slur or N4z1 slogan and I decided that that was OK with me.As important as I feel multiplayer is, I don't think you'll ever suffer from the population problems that crash giant multiplayer-only titles. Low connection requirements, community, and ability to sub in an AI slot in a pinch mean you can always find a game.The one thing that initially drove me nuts about the game is the same things that bothered some other reviewers here: Dat RNG. There were times when I first started playing the game where I didn't just curse fate--I wanted to take all of the kittens in the world and punch each one of them in the face. Yes, I was that angry. But I've come to realize the error of my ways.There are a couple aspects of the game that take getting used to.First--the mechanics... Managing cards and dice rolls can have a subtle but powerful effect on how the game plays out. You have opportunities to affect what kind of dice you roll, how many, and even whether or not the game comes down to a dice duel at all. Waste these and you'll be constantly at the mercy of RNGesus. You can't control the dice--but you CAN influence them an awful lot.The second thing is that there are multiple victory conditions. This, I think, is one of the ways in which the game truly shines. Contrary to the most popular negative review on here, I'd say that your path to victory is NOT obvious in the first few turns. It's constantly changing, and you need to pursue multiple paths simultaneously or make some titanic shift in your favor at just the right moment so that no one can counter you.Get a strong start and someone will pull the rug out from under you. Let someone else draw fire and you might slip in the side door when no one's looking. You have to be flexible and play it loose because you won't even know what the winning combo IS until that perfect moment arrives. Push down one path every time instead of going with the flow = 75% chance of Doom.Lastly, the statistical hurdle: 4 players. You'll lose often enough, because 3 people lose EVERY game. Maybe you can whoop the AI, but against random Interweb goons even a 75% win rate means you're semi-pro. If your sense of self-worth is centered around executing consistent strategies and earning consistent rewards... then Armello may drive you to madness. Get used to feeling like everyone else is trying to drag you down--they are.The devs support their game with multiple weekly events. What's already here is good, but with this support the game also seems to be on a good long-term trajectory.I'd rate Armello as a $30+ game masquerading as a $20 title. Since I can't retroactively pay them $10 I'll probably just buy the new DLC.And the Guppy plushy. Guppy is the next big thing in video game mascots.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
Like A Song of Ice and Fire! With Animals!-----Version 1.0 Update is finally here and this game has become everything it set out to be. My review still holds, please read below. As for those complaining about RNG, yes there is a lot of randomness to aspects of this game, but as the store page says "Difficult to Master". Learn how to utilize what is dealt to you. Once you learn the ins and outs of this game you can see the light in what you may consider bad luck of the draw or dice roll. Cards have more functions than to just be played. You may go into a game with one strategy in mind, but be prepared to change things up. I've had plenty of games where I was seemingly at the bottom but would rise to the top to finish strong and win the throne. Don't give up like some of these negative reviews that only have 0.2 to 2 hours played. They barely scratched the surface and do not see the potential.-----As a kickstarter backer, an alpha and beta tester, I can say without a doubt that this game is truly a gem. Even in its alpha form it was very well built and fun to play. You can see how much love LoG puts into their game in every single detail of this magnificent world. The story is deep, and engaging. The basic idea is that a Mad King is cursed and slowly dying. The goal is to over throw him and become the new King/Leader of the land.Each character has their own backstory, bonuses, and generally a typical way they should be played, with room to wiggle: After selecting a character you get to choose from Rings and Amulets, both of them giving you more bonuses and traits that will allow you to help shape your strategy for winning.The game plays like a board game, with many mechanics and elements added with the cards, but simple enough to play casually if you'd like. However, in my opinion, the fun really begins when you really try to strategize to win. There are several methods of winning, Prestige (having the most prestige at the end of the game), and over throwing the Mad King in several different ways starting with overcoming the trials placed around his castle. If you pass those trials you can then enter into combat with him and over throw him, or you can present 4 Spirit Stones (Aquired by exploring dungeons, encountering druids, or taking them from the other players) and banish him from the realm with their magic. You can even win by becomming more rotten/cursed than the king and being able to over-power him.The cards in the game are wonderfully crafted peices of artwork. They move, and flow, showing off the talent this team has even further. Each card's picture faithfully represents what the card's gameplay function is. There are spells to cast, traps to set, tricks to play, equipment to wear, and followers to join you. You can play cards with either your Magic, or Gold. Some cards even make you more Rotten when you play them or take your Prestige, so be sure to read the card carefully if you are going for a certain strategy to winning (Sometimes you want the Rot, and sometimes you just don't care about Prestige!).I haven't covered many mechanics this game has to offer, but to quickly throw out a few there are Perils, Quests, Dungeon exploring, Settlments, Terrain effects/bonuses... not to mention the incredibly engaging Dice rolling and Card burning system during Combat and Perils!Well, to sum it up, I think this game is amazing, and I highly recommend it to absolutely everyone. Especially those who enjoy a strategic board game, a love for animals, a beautiful world, and most of all when actual HEART is put into a game!Thank you!PS) Be sure to read the Quick Start Guide (along with the many others) in the Community Hub by Alvorn and 8BitProxyI play in 4k with two 980ti STRIX in SLI. Overkill. Runs nice and smooth. My iMac late 2015 model also runs this at max settings, although not in full 5k resolution like the screen is. Still runs really well.

If you're a completionist, some of the achievements are going to drive you bonkers, in a good way.Even if you're not really into strategy games, check Armello out. I'm not big on strategy games either and I have lost so many hours to this game.

Posted: November 17, 2016
												Armello is a video game for folks who enjoy the pace and randomness of dice-based board games, and tend to play online with friends. It isn't for folks who enjoy the pace and skill-grind aspects of PvP video games, and tend to play online with strangers.I imagine most people don't sit down to spend an hour-plus playing a board game with random strangers in total silence. I imagine most people play board games with friends, and they chat while doing so. I imagine a four-friend team with an open Skype call is the ideal way to enjoy Armello. I wouldn't know, because only one of my video gaming friends bought it, and he stopped playing before I did.I gave Armello just over 40 hours, and stopped playing in late August. It was taking too long to find matches in the wee hours EST, or I'd find one, then fall asleep at the PC waiting for it to finish. I dropped into the forum recently to see what people were having issues with. It's the same as it was 3 months ago: length of games, multiplayer problems, lack of chat.I admire the aesthetic and ambience of Armello tremendously. I wish the gameplay were up to the same level.

												Once a time, there was a wolf, a rat, a bear and a hare…And they all fought each other, as well as the bad lion king!While being beautifully drawn and animated Armello is not necessarily a childs play.Indeed it is beneath the beautiful exterior, quite a complex board game variant, which mixes board-game with card-game and rpg elements. While you act as champion of your clan, liberate towns and followers and fulfilling quests as well as fight the other champions and the kings forces. Fitting to the scenario though, you also have different ways to win. For example you can even become corrupted by the dark forces.On the negative side i would add though, that there sadly is not much of a story, besides the tutorial, so it really is more preferable to play this in multiplayer.Conclusio: Armello is a beautiful board game, which is best experienced with friends. Would have loved a real single player campaign though.Point Scale: 7/10

content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												+ 500 Hours. High time I did a review for ‘Armello.’ Here goes.Armello (Lets keep this brief)Armello is an adventure-strategy board game. Follow four heroes as they race for the throne of Armello, ruled by a corrupted king. There are basically four victory options. Prestige victory: gaining prestige from completing quests (unless you fail), killing banes (unless your corrupted) and heroes. Spirit Stone victory: banish the corrupted king using four spirit stones which you’ve gained through quests and stone circles. And finally, Kingslayer and Rot victory are very similar, you have to kill the king via combat and survive, when trying for Rot, your Rot needs to be higher than the king's. (Just play the game, the mechanics are engaging and easy to pick up.)Gameplay+ 4 different clan containing heroes with unique abilities (Always increasing variety of heroes) + Hex tile design+ Day/Night cycle+ Huge replayability (+ 500 Hours in fact)+ Four victory options+ Interactive turn-based system+ Cards+ Story-driven prologue – including the tutorial. Really easy to understand and explains the game mechanics.o Multiplayer (host leave may crash the game)o Luck and random number generator (can be frustrating at times)Based on the games originality, artistic design and the games narrative style, has kept me hooked to this game for so long. With heroes moving on hex based tile, and trying to get prestige, magic, coins or even rot sometimes. Quest to increase your hero’s stats, whether that be towards Fight, Body, Wits or Spirit, all depends on your game play. The amount of strategy within this game is huge which adds to the replayability of Armello.Multiplayer, create a party or lone wolf against other competitive players, you decide. Host quit? Don’t worry, the games mechanics are good against leavers or delaying players and the AI’s still oppose quite a challenge, although, when the host drops it might result to game crash, with constant up-dates, the developers are working hard and fast to resolve this.Visual+ Amazing art style+ Animations (Including the cards – nice touch)+ Dices- Few graphic glitchesArmello is visually stunning, and with the addition of the new seasons DLC, each season has its own glorious allures. Also combat animations with dice rolls are amazing, differing whether the dice explodes or not, also hit to the hero differs from a blocked attack. There are still some graphic glitches, but very rare and doesn’t usually affect the gameplay.Soundtrack+ Stylised+ Lisa Gerrard performance+ Changing accordingly to the atmosphereSoundtrack is very well created and composed. Songs are underlining the dark-fantasy atmosphere and whilst also creating a place of serenity. Lisa Gerrard participated during the composure of the sound track, her voice well known from Dead Can Dance or Gladiator suits melodies, really adds to the music’s ambience. The soundtrack is also released and made available to all, including the non-early-access players.Story Time! (It’s important fun to role-play) In game chat is disabled, this eliminates the possibility of players encountering toxic or hateful language, as this game is designed to suit players of all ages. However, the use of chat emotes allows players to communicate, regardless of their language, and to fully immerse oneself into the world of Armello, whilst retaining the character’s demeanour and tone.Furthermore, the developers are receptive to new idea and suggestions on how to expand and improve the current chat tree.With a little creatively, the current chat emotes can be used to forge alliances, taunt your enemies or simply express your characters emotions. Narrator: With the addition of Usurpers, 3 heroes’ gazed dumbstruck towards the castle, as a seemingly out of place bear, continued to idle around the castle battlements. Confused? Perhaps the bear was bewildered by his good fortune, or perhaps he shared the other heroes’ sentiment. Elyssia: Ow! That. Ow.Magna: No! I can’t believe it!Elyssia: Speechless.Narrator: The heroes’ stared in disbelief as the bear continued to marvel at his new heritageSargon: Ill fortune.             Fate is fluid. This is but a minor setback.Elyssia: Who’s fault was that?! (Elyssia snapped, accusingly)Narrator: Resentment and bitterness blossomed between those whom had lost the race to the throne, however, despite the squabbling, carried the distant cries and whoops of delight. Ghor: Woooooaaaaaahhhhhh……..          As King, will I ‘have’ to live in the palace?.Magna: I don’t want to be part of this. (Magna concluded, hefting her shield)             Until we meet again!                               ……….. To be continued!This is only one potential outcome, How will you play?!? Would you play fair? Or team up to crush those who oppose your claim to the throne. Strategy or luck, you decide, but a good player will always ensure that the odds are in their favour. This is going to be dramatic. (*Popcorn at the ready!*)Take a Hint!Hero’s traits, rings and amulets are extremely important in determining your play style during early game. An experienced player will also take tile advantages/disadvantages into account, as well as, the Day and night cycle also brings an important aspect to the game. Never attempt fate if you can help it, luck is a risk and can be terribly frustrating. Minimise the risk and ensure you equip item cards which best server your play style and repeatedly burn your cards to ensure you have the hand you want, remember, each card has a unique symbol – sword/shield/rot/wyld/sun and moon, burn these cards during combat or perils to ensure the outcome is in your favour. Finally, be sure to watch an opponent’s move: (Cannot express how important this it!)Money and Magic usage:  Is a good indicator of the sort of perils your up against. States and Equipped items: Will help indicate whether you need to play aggressively or defensively.  The community! (It’s worth a mention)The game is constantly going through bug fixes. The community is always kept up-to-date with patches and with any new additional content to the game. The developers are very friendly and receptive to any great ideas found though the Amello community, that be through steam, facebook, twitter, youtube, twitch or the forums. Members of the community also show no lack of passion, creativity and empathy. However, this is only maintained thought the developers zero tolerance to hatred and discrimination. Overall, the community is very welcoming, just be respectful and mindful of your opinions as it could potential be harmful to others.Diagnosis!Infection, query sepsis ?!, Potentially infectious. Refer these animals to their GP; for a prescription of antibiotics. (Penicillin, Amoxicillin + Fluoroquinolones) My overall rating for Armello: 9/10 – Would put the King out of his misery again!Also got my vote for ‘Steam Awards Nomination 2016’ – Keep up the good work!On a final note, are the DLC’s worth paying for? Yes they are, the developers have never asked for anything, with free up-dates and content being constantly added to game, this is a way for us to help show our support. Armello is a truly inspiring game, let’s not lose it.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
This game was reviewed using a code sent by the developer.“Imagine Magic The Gathering meets Final Fantasy Tactics, and Game of Thrones meets Kung Fu Panda,"Armello is a turn based strategy game that was released in September 2015 on PC – being developed and published by League of Geeks.  The game was originally an iPad title that was released in mid-2012 before going through a successful Kickstarter project to get the game onto Steam. The game play in Armello feels is almost like an actual board game. There are lots of different dice involved, and hex squares in which you can move your character. You take control of one of eight anthropomorphic animals and plot to oust the corrupt king from power. You can do this in many ways, either by becoming even more corrupt than the king, winning by coming the most prestigious character in the game by completing certain tasks, or killing the king yourself in battle. The game has a day/night cycle, you get two turns per day to carry out your actions. The game lasts for 10 nights usually. Each turn the king will lose one health but becomes more corrupt.   Your character has about 3 action points, moving, attacking and casting spells all cost one point, meaning you can only do so much in one turn – planning your turn is key to this game. The game has a card game element to it all be it a very small one. You have an unlimited deck of cards; the cards consist of equipment, spells and traps. Each turn you draw the amount of cards you used in the previous turn. One way in which you will be able to win a game of Armello is to become the most prestigious character on the board. You earn prestige by killing other characters in combat, killing corrupt “Banes” which the King summons, or by completing various quests. Each character will have one active quest at any time; this will involve traveling across the map to a specific hex square. The quest will always be completed, but you can take an extra risk by taking your chances on a dice role in order to get extra equipment or stats; failing this will mean you lose stats. I personally found the questing system in this game really fun – the flavour texts of each quest is a nice addition and the simple resolutions keep the game flowing. Graphically Armello is a really pretty looking game. All of the characters look like they have been drawn in a children’s story book, and they just look gorgeous. My personal favourites are the rat characters; they get the animation nailed down on their run. Even though there is only one map in Armello, it has various different weather effects to keep it looking fresh. The game’s UI is OK. I would have liked to have seen a few extra information boxes on screen to see the rest of the characters stats/points, but this can be accessible in a few button clicks if you want it anyway.  Although the game does have a fairly lengthy tutorial that does actually do a good job of explaining the rules of the game; it still took me probably two full games worth for me to just get the basics of the game down. Even now there are parts of the game that I don’t understand; it would be been nice to have a little bit of maybe a tooltip with a lot of the buttons and card effects for you to easily understand what is happening without throwing you in at the deep end and letting you click random stuff to see what happens.  The game can vary in difficulty; sometimes you can be completely screwed over by pure randomness of the cards you are dealt or the dice roles – such is life when you play board games. I think I have got about a 60% win rate at the moment which is fairly good I would imagine. Like I said before, there is only one map to play on, but the game does a good job of creating a different landscape for you to fight on every game, the randomness of what each hex square can have on it differs from game to game, such as dungeons and settlements all being scattered across the map to keep things fresh. There is plenty of replay ability in Armello, I have been playing for almost six hours now and I still have a strong desire to keep playing. There is no “story” mode to be exact; it is just a case of skirmish battles. The game has its own unlock system where you can unlock special equipment for your characters by completing specified tasks in game, meaning it gives you a reason to keep playing to unlock things. The game has eight characters for you to play, each come with their own set of tasks and unlockables. Not to mention the games online mode – whilst there isn’t many people playing it online, hook up a few friends on the game to play in the four player mode for some real competitive action. The game runs perfectly fine with no technical hitches at all; being able to play at 4k resolutions on ultra-high settings makes this a really well optimized PC port. I did try to play with the Steam controller, but it just felt better with the mouse, as you would expect from a strategy type game like this. I personally think this is quickly turning into one of my favourite turn based strategy games; it is highly addictive, and the learning curve keeps you on the edge at all times. Matches can be completed in twenty minutes or so meaning you can get a couple in when you only have an hour to spare. If you are looking at getting into a strategy based game, I can wholeheartedly recommend Armello to you. I do think it is maybe slightly overpriced at £14, 99 – but still it is a quality game with endless amounts of replay ability.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								I work retail at a board games + gifts shop and Armello captivated me right from the get go. With redwall-esque anthropomorphic animals, deadly rot vultures called Banes, and a solid board game behind it to boot; this game was a no brainer for me. But is it for you?Well, I've logged about 40+ hours in the first week of owning it and here is what to expect if you add it to your steam collection.It's a bit much to dive into if you have no previous experience with board games, but if Puerto Rico, Settlers of Catan, Power Grid, and Lords of Waterdeep are names that are familiar to you, then you shouldn't have any problem. There are currently 4 characters (with extras for the folks who kickstarted it) each with unique starting stats. Players will balance things like fighting skill to be able to beat other players/banes, wits to increase hand size and solve challenges, health to survive longer on the game board between turns, and spirit which dictates how many spells you can cast.You'll also be collecting gold, influence, and magic while also trying to limit the amount of rot or corruption you garner. Or will you...That's the best thing about Armello. The way to win in any given game isn't immediately obvious. In fact, there are 4 win conditions. There are turn cycles, day and night, and with each passing day the corrupted King at the center of the board grows weaker. So your options are 1: collect the most prestige points and hope he dies. 2: Collect 4 spirit stones and bring them to him to cure/exorcize the king 3: Fight him in battle and survive to claim the throne. 4: Purposely allow yourself to be corrupted by the Rot and obtain a Rot Victory. The last seems the hardest, but it gives each of the characters an interesting advantage over one another. Mercurio is great at scheming in the background stealing gold and settlements, but you can build him almost as bruisery as Thane, the wolf who is the pen ultimate of fighting. Each game can have random stuff set you back or catapult you forwards into the lead. And sometimes that can be frustrating because it's not necessarily through any great strategy of your own, or even an opponent doing something annoying. Then again sometimes it is. So I feel like any board game it tries to balance luck and randomness with solid player strategies and tactics. The communication at present is done through emotes alone and it's hard to really convey much to the other players. It certainly isn't the same as chatting with your friends around the game table, but it's still so damn fun without the option to chat. And the art/videos/concept is simply amazing.There is no single player campaign, so don't fool yourself into thinking this is anything but a board game. Now, it's still in early access and with the success of it who knows what they do next, but my assumption would be, more characters, new items, plot cards, perhaps new perils or monsters, eventually even new game boards or modes. But it's a board game in virtual form. Nothing more, nothing less. If that's your thing, then I hope to see you in a game soon. :)

Posted: June 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is a must-have for anybody that loves board games.  Armello features a different board each playthrough and randomly spawning evil and good mobs to help terrorize your opponents; these things make every run a unique experience.Due to the random nature of the game, I don't feel discouraged if I'm losing halfway through.  There are enough weapons, armor and followers to ensure my character at least has access to tools that'll turn a losing game into a winning one.I'm a huge fan of Talisman and Elder Sign: Omens.  A game of Armello can be played in under an hour, and there aren't any characters that can just roll over other characters by default (such as the Assassin in Talisman).  Although dice rolling can be brutal, there are plenty of ways in Armello to "fix" your dice results and improve your chances; the game rarely feels unfair (unlike Elder Sign, heh).Before purchasing this game, I did feel the price was a bit steep.  I'm glad to announce that I have no buyer's remorse; Armello is worth every penny.

content:
Posted: April 3
												As mentioned by many, the bugs ruin what is otherwise a great game.  They are unbelievble to be frank (game breaking in many cases).  Good example, sometimes the game won't even shut down.  Or the main logic loop will freeze up and the gameplay halts entirly.  For the technically inclined, this is likely due to bad IPC or multi-threading.  That's an educated guess, I did not spend time dissembling,  However, great art and game design with gameplay that's very unique and a breath of fresh air.  But not one of those companies willing to own up to their downfalls.  Instead releasing new content (which costs extra, fyi).  This is coding 101.  Bugs first, everything else second.  But that mantra does not appear to exist here.Is the game good?  Absolutely.  Is it stable?  No.  And that will kill your otherwise fun gaming mood in a heartbeat.  If there ever was an abandonment or the code open sourced (unlikely IMHO) then they could easily be fixed.  Until then I would stay away.  I'd create a community patch but I would likely be met with hostility, where other companies would welcome it.Hats off to the game designers and artists.  Credit goes where it's due.

												Armello is an enchanting boardgame about taking down a mad king before any of the other players can.The gameplay is pretty straightforward - go on quests, fight other players, avoid traps, and get to the king. Admittedly the gameplay is a little too random for my tastes, but while frustrating, I still find myself having a fantastic time playing with friends. I would compare it to Catan meets Risk. You can plan for the future, but dice rolls will screw you over at some point or another.Other than that the sound, art, and gameplay are very well polished and well executed. Definitely feeling like Redwall meets Game of Thrones in that essence.Definitely a solid 4/5 stars.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Update 11/11/2015Thought I'd refresh my review yet again.  1.1 is out, and while the Ranked mode was pushed to a later patch, there's been other great additions.  Connections between people in multiplayer are more resilient while pirates seem to have been booted from Steam's network.  More item cards were added, font size is bigger for better readability.  Single player mode is now lightning fast with fast-forward mode on: you can finish a game in 15-20 mins instead of 40.  The new house rules also let you tweak aspects like turn times, character max HP, or King's starting life.Sharing of the Bandit characters is functioning, with their full release still planned for Early 2016.  Things the community is hoping to see in the near future:Full reconnection to games when a player drops accidentally.Cross Multiplayer between Steam, PS4, IOS, and DRM free.More Houserules.Ranked Mode.Even More characters post Bandits.Update added 8/2/2015Addressing concerns found in negative reviews that are no longer accurate:When this game first annouced early access, there was a controversy about a set of 4 characters being limited to only people who backed the Kickstarter.  This "Bandit clan" has since been declared open for purchase as a paid DLC to be released a few months after the official release.  Those that were backers will get to play their "Beta" a bit before release, but only in single player and friends match games.  Prestige being the only victory: Early on, there was no way to raise stats and thus beating the Palace gates required luck of dice or card draws.  Now you can weaken the Perils with trickery cards, raise your Peril beating stats by 2 points each (4 total points to spend, no more than 2 per stat), and the act of finishing your 5 quests gives you the ability to automatically pass the Palace Peril closest to your home.  Without other players acting to stop you, Facing the King happens quite often.  Spirit stones are much less luck driven in acquisition and there's no way to lose them like there used to be.  Acquiring Rot is more sensible too, it's easier to gain rot after corruption when before it used to be very difficult to find Rot past 5 points.A few corrections in my review below: Winning by spirit stones changed.  Now instead of heroes starting with stones, and stealing from each other, stones will appear on the map to be picked up as an alternative to pursuing your quests; once you have them you can never lose them.  You can also chose to quest with sprit stones as the reward.  Questing also helps you get Rare Treasure quality gear or followers.The new builds are on break until release, but they've already annouced 1.1 for a month after release to implement Ranked Public multiplayer games.Card library is complete for trickery, missing just 1 spell, and then a handful of items/treasures/followers.  Around 100 distinct cards with a Rarity system so some cards appear many times a game and others just once.Original January Review below this point.Short version: The Art is beautiful, the mechanics are solid and unique, the Dev team actively engages the forum and spits out new builds at least every 3 weeks.  If you like complex boardgames that handle all the rules themselves very efficiently, you are going to like this game.  If boardgames, fantasy kingdoms, or walking talking animals are not your thing, you wont like this game.Long Version:Do you like fantasy boardgames?  Armello gives you a cast of Anthromophic heroes on a quest to succeed the throne of Armello as its Dying King goes mad from the Corrupting disease "Rot".  You can perform quests, slay monsters, and even dispatch your Rivals to earn prestige and become the people's hero for when the King dies of supernatural causes, the King will even ask you for advice in his new laws.  Or perhaps, you can just kill the king yourself and take the throne before his increasing insane laws harm the populace, but the King is powerful and well guarded, you'll need to explore deep dungeons or collect tribute from towns to gear up and wield wyld magic spells to make yourself stronger.  Perhaps you'll find more of the sacred spirit stones that have been told might Save the King from the horrible disease; the heros of the other clans each have 1 (See update correction).Or perhaps you'll fight darkness with darkness.  Sink deep into depravity and the darkness will grant you all the power you desire to take the throne.Each Hero has variations of 4 stats: Fight (how many dice you roll in battle), Body (your max HP), Wits (your ability to draw cards each turn, sneak into the palace walls, solve many of the quest's dilemmas and avoid Trickery's set by other players, and Spirit (amount of MP you reset to each night and ability to dodge harmful spells.)  In combat you roll sword, day or night (matching whether the game round is night or day) or the Wyld symbol to hit (Wyld symbols even reward you with extra dice for critical hit like effects); shields to defend, and the Rot symbol just revels in your failure.  The 3 to 1 offense defense ratio makes combat vicious.  You can use unwanted cards in your hand to force Dice to be the symbols you want.The map is randomley generated from hexagons.  Forests let you hide at night, towns pay you if you own them at dawn, swamps injure those who ford them, mountains take extra time to cross but give you the high ground in battle (extra defense), and stone circles let you heal your wounds.Each round you draw until you have your Wit stat in Hand size.  You can pick item cards that cost gold to play and can equip 3 non consumable items.  You can pick spell cards to cast from your nightly regenerating mana to buff yourself, teleport, or harm your rivals.  You can also spend your gold and reputation on Trickery cards to raise your public standing or harm your rivals.  Usually, you have 8 days and 8 nights to make your claim, but animal sacrafice to the King's evil can prolong his dark reign.The game is still in early access, so the card deck is only about 70 of the planned 130, some odds and ends of mechanics is open to feedback like the effects of some spells and the slight customizations each character has (would you like bonus magic from waking up in forests, or become invisible when you enter towns?).  Each game takes about 30 minutes versus the AI (Turns over in 15 second) or 90 minutes versus 3 other humans (turns given a max of 2 minutes).  You communicate to other players via a hardcoded list of chat phrases.  Or you can use Steam's friends/chat room functionality.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												When I first saw Armello, I thought that with the old Disney style animations it would be aimed for a younger audience, and I didn't put much thought to it. I thought it wasn't my kind of game. Then I eventully bit the bullet and bought it.And damn, this is actually a remarkably good game.Armello is a board game set in the Kingdom of... well, Armello. You play as one of several animal heroes who are all vying for the throne of the kingdom. The King has gone mad with a disease called the Rot and when he dies, the most prestigous hero will become the next monach... unless someone kills him first.It's quite clear as you look deeper in that despite the Disney style animation and the colorful graphics, this is a much, much darker game than it seems at first glance. The events that take place in the game, along with the dialogue and info on the cards tells a mucher darker story than what you would expect in the lore.You can select upto eight heroes, one from each of the four animal clans, being wolf, rat, rabbit and bear with the vanilla game, though one additional DLC grants you four new heroes and there are four more as part of a new Bandit Clan on the way. Each of these heroes has different stats and a unqiue perk to start off with and you can mix and match different rings and amulets to change up how that hero handles in game.The gameplay itself is easy to learn but is remarkably complex. Four players take turns moving around the board, taking settlements, completing quests, dealing with the King's Guard and Bane NPCs, the perils and of course, the other Heroes themselves. There is a day and night cycle which changes the conditions on the board and makes some Heroes stronger than others. As you play through the game, you can complete quests which allow you to level up your characters stats as you go along.You have a selection of cards to pull out of three decks, Item, Magic and Trickery, which lets you equip items or you can use them with their varying affects. Such as damaging another character or putting on one of the perils on the board.All combat and peril solving is done with dice rolls, any cards you have equipped or effects that have been applied to you can alter how much attack or defence you have guarenteed or how many dice you have amongst other things. Dice in the game aren't just RNG either, they are physically rolled much like real dice, although this can be a small pain for lower spec   PCs.This mix of dice and card based gameplay allows for varied tactics and approaches which often vary depending on who you play as. You can either enhance your character's strengths or remove the weaknesses to balance the character out. Each board is different each time and it offers varying oppitunities to play your game in different ways, and with four different ways to win, each game can be quite different.Now, the only con I've noticed is one you can't really eliminate with this kind of game with dice and cards. Luck is a big thing. There is a good chance someone is going to get all the good cards at the right time or get through without a scratch and go on to dominate the game. Others might not get anything good at all and fall behind the curve. Since there is no comeback mechanic other than getting lucky, this could leave one player just dominating and another player just left to wonder around the board unable to challenge someone or deciding to quit.Or those damn card players who get all the attack cards and keep killing you before you get close or slowing you down. It's really frustrating.Likewise, luck can quickly change the tide of the game quickly and as the game begins to draw to a close you can feel the tension as you try and play your approach and hope your luck holds. It's a little bit annoying but it's also what makes the game catch your attention and keep you invested.Regardless, tactics and strategy still apply, which can carry you through a game. The games can be quite long though, easily coming upto an hour or more, so keep that in mind.The game has quite a few things in it, singleplayer and multiplayer is both around, you have a card collection to see all the well drawn and animated cards you have come across in the game. All the games you complete will also give to a chance to get a chest or a key, combining the both together can give you dice you can use in the game itself.Both singleplayer and multiplayer offer numerous options to change up the standard gameplay, which is a nice touch.Now, some content you have to buy, though none of it's pay to win and it's not ridculously priced whilst adding additional heroes and new map styles, so it's worth the extra dosh.All in all, Armello was an unexpected little gem, it's a bit rough around the edges but whetever you are a furry or not, this game is certainly worth your while, with additional content on it's way. It's definitely worth your time.

content:
Posted: January 15
												I really want to like Armello, but I have to say it has a few very large flaws, including one that has inspired me to write this review.Simply put, it is a lengthy multiplayer game. A game can take about 2 hours to complete. Should anything happen to a player's connection, there is zero ability to reconnect. Which means if you are playing the game with friends, you may find yourself having to start over after investing over an hour in a game, or you have to finish the game against AI. As a single player game, its fun but ultimately limited. And the lack of any ability to deal with disconnections/reconnections is a dealbreaker for multiplayer games. If I'm going to spend the time in a match, I want to know that I- and my friends- will be able to finish it.There are technical issues as well- notably I couldn't get the purchased DLC to actually work. The game can be fun, but I can't recommend it.

Posted: May 15, 2016
												There is about two things that annoy me on negative reviews here. And that's complaining about the game being "too random" and "long wait times". Guys, seriously. Have you ever played a Board game? I don't think so.Also, unlike other Board games you actually CAN DO stuff while the other's are at turn. You can manipulate the enemy with your cards, you can set traps to avoid enemys approaching you or their goals. You can study their inventory and their goals.  Rethink your strategy if someone is much further ahead of you with the same strategy.All these things you can do while the other's are at turn. And I think it gives this game a more strategic element that you think.Games are about luck as soon as there are dices or cards in it. Have you ever complained about Yathzee or any card game being a stupid boring game because you have to be lucky? Then it's just not for you.Overall I think this game is really fun, even with just a 25% win chance (because only 1 of 4 players will win)These negative reviews are mostly by people who are afraid of losing.I know this isn't a real review about this game but there are plenty of good reviews out there already so it won't matter.
