content:
Posted: February 2
												I wish there was a "I am neutral to this game"-button on Steam, or a rating-system using numbers or stars or whatsoever. Because all in all - while I would lie if I'd say "Oh no, I NEVER had any fun in playing Armello!" there are a few things that spoil the fun. Armello makes a wonderful first impression. It is a board-game with cards and dices, unique heroes which you can equip with different rings and amulets to suit your playstyle. The first trailer is nicely done (the soundtrack to that trailer is also wonderful), and the the following trailers (Horrors and Heroes / Ursupers) are quite enjoyable as well. The setting is also interesting - reminds me of the Redwall-series (with the benefit that the rat-clan seems to be the intelligence network, but not necessarily the evil guys), and that there are actually different ways to win the game sounds also quite cool. Most of the card-illustrations are quite well done, too - even having a flavor-text (though it took me a little until I found that out).  I can see and feel that indeed a lot of love went into the concept of the game. The tutorial consists of four little chapters; each of these is played with one of the "classic" four heroes (Thane, Mercurio, Amber and Sana), and teaches you what you need to know to play the game. A little tweak could be made here: you have the "Burn"-symbol for challenges and battles before the tutorial tells you what card-burning is. And unless the game told you what it is you cannot burn cards. I was a bit confused at the beginning, so I would recommend to make the burn-symbol invisible until the tutorial reaches that stage. Sadly one of the most enjoyable parts in the tutorial is NOT in the "normal" Armello-game. As your hero wanders the lands, goes dungeoneering and questing (s)he can recruit followers. In the tutorial those little rascals say a few lines here and there, sometimes to explain things, sometimes just to create atmosphere. Which is really cool. Unfortunately - in normal games only "The Stranger" talks. I am not saying that my followers should babble endlessly. But for instance if The Bard gives you the prestige for escaping from a peril he (or she?) could say something. For players who find that annoying - including an option to shut the followers off should not be that difficult. Also the theory that you can win the game by 4 different approaches sounds better in theory than in reality. For the Rot-Victory you need more luck than for any other approach. Yes, of course you can equip the Rot-Amulet (once you unlocked it, which might end in a grind, even if you unlock it by battling the A.I.). But whenever I tried to go for a rot-victory I usually was not lucky enough to get my paws on cards which gave me rot (not even with Sargon, though it's a bit easier with him). So I am usually trying to commit suicide on a Bane a few times in a row, hoping that no other player (or no king's guard) is killing the Bane until I am done with it. Most players will go for Combat- or Prestige-Victory. If you find yourself carrying 4 Spirit Stones you could as well walk around on a mine-field, because everybody is trying to keep you from getting to the King by any means necessary. Yes, that is part of the game. If I got my 4 spirit stones basically by accident (because they spawned in a circle where I was standing, or I went through a circle with one, because I needed to quest, or I got it via a dungeon) I found myself having decent gear often, so I could defend myself. If I tried to gather them deliberately I neglected quests which would have given me gear/followers, because I wanted to gather my spirit stones faster... but then I seldom made it to the palace anymore, because every other player could beat me. Do not get me wrong - I KNOW combat is part of the game, and I behave COMPLETELY like that, when I see others having 4 spirit stones in their pockets, too. But that does not make the last 5-10 minutes of a game less frustrating. I do not know if it's possible to "balance" the 4 ways of winning the game a little better. After all, for every approach there might be a hero suited a little better to do this and that, but so far it feels a little... "meh" to know that basically combat- and prestige victory are the easiest way to play the game, when there are 2 other options as well. The next thing that keeps me from enjoying Armello throughoutly has something to do with League of Geeks themselves. Yes, I know they are a small company. Yes, I know the market out there is worse than a shark-tank. I have been there myself, and - though in another field - I am still freelancing. I am not hitting at the infamous "laying their eggs into too many baskets"-topic (at that point I think they just overdid themselves, and people do that at times), but the way they are talking to the community reminds me of companies such as Riot or Blizzard. Yes, they are having somewhat of a "dialogue", but to me it does not sound like a dialogue, instead it reminds me of parents patting their kid's shoulder after the kid told them how much (s)he got bullied, saying "There, there, it's gonna be alright, we'll think of something" - and then they give the kid a sugar-cane instead of actual help. (Yes, that's really not the best example, but the best I could come up with right now). The Bandit-Clan is screwing the community. About a year ago it was said the clan would be released in Spring 2016. Then it got delayed and delayed, until we got told they would come with the iOS-version of the game. This version, however, would not be released around Christmas-time because of the huge competition on the market. Fine with me. But that was the last thing we heard. If you ask you get the same answer over and over: "Hold tight for news." Last time I heard that was last summer when I tweeted on a patch something like: "I hope it [] comes to GoG, soon, too". Well, I know how that turned out. I heard rumours about the Clan being released on spring 2017, but maybe that is just wishful thinking. The biggest annoying thing for me, though, is the server-instability. I get kicked from a game so often, and often enough when it's almost finished. Especially with the new amulett that you can only unlock once you reach player-level 10 it's one hell of a grind.So yeah, while I DO have some nice time with Armello, and I simply love playing games where I can feel all the love and effort that went into a game from the very scratch, I would recommend Armello only to people with a high tolerance to frustration (because it IS frustrating when you spend 40 minutes in a game and you achieved nothing, because the game just crashes). Still I have high hopes that the problems will get solved in the future, and I wish LoG still all the best.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												Armello is a fun, addictive online board game for up to four players.  My friends and I have been playing it since it came out, pretty much non-stop.  And while we may scream in anguish after a particularly unlucky die roll, we always end up coming back for more.  An extremely tight and polished game.Pros:-Authentic Board Game Experience-Incredibly addictive-Beautiful Artistic Style-Four paths to victory, giving options for each player to always have *some* chance of pulling out a win, even if it's from someone else failing at the last moment-Multiple character types with unique traits and starting stats-Three card types (Items, spells, tricks) that work very differently to achieve the same goals, allowing for more diverse strategies-Dozens of unlockables with additional unique traits-Easy-to-set-up multiplayer, especially with friends-Relatively short but satisfying games (30-45 mins single player, 60-90 multiplayer)-Excellent tutorialCons:-A fair amount of luck involved, some of which can be significant enough to foil the most well-thought-out strategies-Can get heated in multiplayer, when someone chooses to attack/interfere with another player unprovoked-The random terrain might slant the game for/against certain people from the start-A lot of (often random) events can provoke excess frustration, such as getting a teleport/bane from a ruin, having wandering guards/banes move into your path, being hurt by the daily declaration, etc.-Getting across the map (usually to reach your quests) can feel painfully slow-One victory path (Rot) significantly more difficult and luck-based than the others-All followers and treasures (ie, the best gear) can only be attained through ruins and quest bonuses, and both of these are entirely luck based.  This can lead to gear disparity between players based on what are essentially coin flips.-No way to get back in after a multiplayer disconnect (though an AI will take over for you)-Some finicky, non-obvious rules are not covered by the tutorial, especially when it comes to gaining/losing influence and rot-Like most board games, will eventually get repetitive

												Pros: * Amazing visual style. Pretty much the strongest point of the game.* Simple enough combat system* Fairly good tutorialCons:* Balance. Attack/defense balance is cranked all the way towards the former, which means that even if you can kill your opponent thrice over, they are likely to kill you too, throwing you back to square one.* Way too much is left to chance. If RNG hates you, you can't do anything about it.* Matches are too short - 20 turns, 24 at custom rules, and any attack that wounds the King cuts that further down.* Next to no settings, specifically graphics, language (it always takes the setting from steam), ans such.Overall, the game has great potential but it needs fixing. Right now it has little to boast aside from the good looks.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								Armello presents a true personal experience each new time it's played. From personal experience I can say each new match is unique - the map has procedural generation (which plays for the reach of resources such as settlements to conquer and dungeons to loot), the player starts each new match with random cards in hand, and this adds to the opponents being placed in different base camp locations (for example, if opponent A was placed on northern base camp in a match, there is a chance you can find it placed on the eastern or western base camp on a next match) plus the strategy you're thinking about running.As the game truly is a legitimate digital board game, there is the possibility a player's strategy may be entirely destroyed in only a single turn, or it can turn on this player's favor as well - and this is the true beauty of Armello. The playing of cards - at any time - adds an interesting dynamic to the experience, not to mention the rot, the quests mechanic, the rings and amulets chosen before the match that help the player on his/her strategy and more elements to list.Additionally, the environment, the lore, the graphic design (character's and even the cards' illustrations), the sound effects of this game, they're all great.As a more personal note, I'm reading the Redwall series and, as in my opinion making a proper Redwall game wouldn't have a good result, I must say that when I want to effectively "play" Redwall, I go play Armello. This is really an amazing experience.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has come quite a long way since I first got my hands on the Alpha build and has made great strides going to Beta and now Early access. Lot's of little improvements to the UI have been made to make keeping tabs on what goes on in-game much easier. Cards have been added and balanced as needed with the current total so far being 60 out of a planned number of over 100 cards. The game mechanics have been all put in their place to produce a decievingly deep strategy board game that can have you at certain victory only for someone or something to quickly dash your hopes and make you lose everything. Armello overall is a game that involves a good mix of luck and skill to win. The luck aspect comes from what cards you draw, dice rolls, and dungeon exploration among other variables.  Skill on the other hand comes from knowing where to move, using the terrain to your advantage, and how to use those cards to give yourself an edge. Gameplay itself may last anywhere from about 40 minutes to an hour for multiplayer matches, depending on how long players take on their turns, and at about 30 minutes for matches against the AI. Currently there are a series of tutorial pop-ups present when you play your first game to help guide you through everything Armello has to offer since it can be a little daunting to first time players. Plenty of this game itself is seemingly done, but there's still plenty of polish to be added and feedback to be given. This in turn is where any prospective Early Access player will be able to help make this game even better by providing a fresh perspective on everything already in game plus new ideas for the future.League of Geeks still has lots of work ahead of them, but I already know from what I've personally seen that they will get it done and do a damn fine job of it at that.

												I am somewhat getting addicted to this game slowly. Out of all of the games i own, Armello is the only other game besides the Fallout series to get me to go in depth into it. The concept is very great, simple to grasp gameplay (learn how to play in roughly 5-20 mins) is awesome, every game you play is totally different than the one your friend will play. The list goes on for this game, but just like a lot of games they do have some drawbacks. For example there is no custom characters for yourself, though it be great to see it in the future to have a custom character that you can make (only one) and see him/her progress in the game. Though the only other thing that i see as another downside is the map size. The map size never changes, it is great that it is like smallworld where the tiles changes every game, but there should be at least one or two different map sizes other than one. Because game map size is somewhat small for me, and at least they should offer a bigger mapsize too for people, like me, who like extra long games.Thanks for reading my review, though all my reviews are not as detailed and pretty as some, i do try to give you all my own thoughts of the game to help your decision to buy a game or not. This game gets a 9/10 in my book, and i do highly recommend this game to anyone who like GOT (game of thrones), Table Top Games like Small world, or anything that is RPG related. To devlopers of this game, you guys did a very good job with this game and for that i am glad to play Armello.

content:
Posted: April 26
												Armello is one of the most enjoyable, addictive, and engaging games I've played in a long time - among video games and tabletop games alike. The characters are charming, the artwork is wonderful, the concept and mechanics are both unique and easily graspable, while still offering a tremendous amount of depth and complexity for experienced players to delve into. I would love above anything to praise this game and recommend it to anyone and everyone, because it's brought me hours of excitement and enjoyment.But I cannot, in good conscience, do so - rather, I feel compelled to do the opposite, because of the attitude that the developers have come to display.The actual game is priced at $20. Hundreds of cards, eight characters, thee entirety of gameplay, along with the collectible dice system and all - $20, more than a fair price. But then, character skins, purely cosmetic changes, costing $7 EACH - I could buy THREE SKINS, or another copy of the ENTIRE GAME. Packs of four playable characters costing $10 - half the price of the entire game - the latest of which are characters who have existed (in some form) in the game code already installed on my computer for months, now hidden behind a paywall. And persistant bugs, affecting connectivity, matchmaking, and gameplay so significantly that people have stopped playing altogether because they've found it THAT difficult to remain connected to a playable game long enough to actually see it all the way to the end. Clearly, the real value in Armello - as far as the developers are telling us based on their pricing - is not in the gameplay, not in the experience, not in the fun, but in the assets: the ENTIRE GAME is literally worth less to them than three character skins which functionally affect gameplay in no way whatsoever.As far as the developers seem to be concerned, Armello is not a game anymore, it's a money farm - a platform for microtransactions that consistantly prove overpriced and underwhelming. It is, in a word, tragic, to see such a wonderful experience being used not to create fun but to line pockets.

number of helpful: 45 of 64 people (70%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												For the artwork, atmosphere, music and writing I would wholeheartedly reccomend this one. The way the game's systems are designed, speak to the imagination, requiring dedication to a theme and they are presented in a way that is exciting and satisfying. Things like day/night and your character's purity/corruption, cause great differences in mechanics. The world has enough character and colour for you to believe there's an entire world of wonders out there to discover and indeed there are amazing details and happenings to be stumbled upon in the forests and in the mountains. The way a stoic guard dog's tail wags when he defeats someone brings a smile to your face. Armello is a wonderful, intriguing world to visit. Since I'm a sucker for such things, I'm happy with my purchase and getting my money's worth.However, as a game and compared to other boardgame, it has shortcomings that obligate me to give it a thumbs down and leave a few warnings.Part of the problem is that this is a very short game, the standard ruleset used for sittings that count for achievements and multiplayer, shorter than 9 full turns (counting both day and night cycles, as you'll only get new magic points and cards after a single day). That alone isn't enough of a flaw. I'm fine with quick, satisfying games that don't take a lot of time.There is also quite a bit of random luck involved. Certain events are incredibly rare, certain quests only carry certain rewards at random and the spawn points of certain mobs and objects are hit and miss. This alone, isn't a fatal flaw either, as I'm fine with the luck of the draw if at any moment, fortunes can turn with good RNG. However, the combination of short game WITH a lot of luck involved, coupled with victory condition that require a solid fall-through, is a definite flaw. Luck and Randomness can only give players a balanced experience when given enough time, which Armello doesn't allow for. The result is that you'll need to make the best of your starting cards, location and quest and that the likely victory condition out of 4 (and most of these condition pretty much exclude the others) is already apparent from the first few turns. You need to follow through quickly, or lose the game before turn 3. There's no writing your hero's story, thinking on your feet or realistically hoping out for late stage game changers. The gameplay design messes with the game's ability to tell a story and your ability to create one.Want to go for the "dark ending" by corrupting your sneaky rodent character? Not likely when you're not getting any corruption cards and Banes spawn too far away.Want to heal the kingdom by gathering spirit stones as the bear priestess? Not so when all your Spirit stone quests just so happen to fall in statistics that you're low in, or all the naturally occuring stones fall in the wrong hands. Prestige and Kingslayer victories then become the most likely options, but the both of them are so reliant on combat skill that it leaves half the game's potential superfluous. The best of the people on multiplayer can carefully min/max their way towards consistent victory, but this sort of ratrace seems oddly incongruent with how Armello presents itself.All of this is hallmarked by me avoiding multiplayer competition somewhat and just wanting to do all the single-player achievements to see all that the world has to offer, but constantly restarting the game while doing so in the idle hope that this time, the game gives me what I require to properly progress on my chosen path or see the things I want to see. Again, reccomended for the atmosphere and storytelling should lady luck allow it, not so much as a smooth, flexible game.EDIT: After a small discussion with one of the game's developers below, I'd like to humbly propose Gremlins Inc. as a game that - despite being a looker but not nearly possessing Armello's art direction - also has karma, money and politics mechanics, but is as a boardgame, far better and more closely designed around revelling in RNG and making positive use of it. When going for victory, especially in multiplayer, Armello's RNG either keeps you on the track to victory or pushes you off it permanently, facillitating the kind of anguished min/maxing that goes - in my opinion - against the game's atmosphere. Gremlins Inc.'s sense of universal chaos is shared much more evenly, creating equality, and its cutthroat setting makes it a better competitive title in both body and heart.

number of helpful: 36 of 49 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												After being in both the early access and experiencing the first week of the ful release, I like to think I understand Armello a bit. It is fun, but feel somewhat poorly tuned. Lets start with the bad:- There are four victory methods, but one seems entirely based on luck (Spirit Stones) and the other feels as if you are attempting to push a boulder up a mountain with a toothpick (Rot). - The stats of the characters seem as if they were intended to be "balanced" but fall short of the mark. Some characters have inordinately amounts of advantage compared to others. If you intend on attempting a Rot or King kill victory with a character like Sana, you are in for a bad time. Whereas characters like Thane seem excellently tuned, and capable of Prestige, Fight, Rot, and Spirit Stone victories due to their natural ability to fight other characters.- Most of the game feels random. Cards you draw and dice rolls create a frustrating sense of the need for luck, despite your best laid plans and strategies. Cards seem to appear in poor ratios, with common useless cards getting stuck in your hand because you cannot burn them off on perils or battles.Now the good, and honestly, this does make up for the bad on most days:- It is EXCEEDINGLY beautiful. The characters all are colorful and interesting, the map gorgeous, and the card art is superb.- The music is relaxing and engaging, which is helpful while waiting for your turn. It was a pleasure to hear that early access players would receive the soundtrack for free, and I find myself listening to it frequently.- The varied methods of victory make an interesting game. Not everyone is always going for the same goal, and there are different reasons that a character may fight another. Maybe they need to get to a quest, or can see your quest and want to prevent you from getting to it.All in all, it is a joy to play, but it does not feel entirely complete. I hope to see more from the development team, and I would be more than happy to see DLC for this game. 7/10

number of helpful: 47 of 69 people (68%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												I really want to love this game. I got it in early access, and awaited eagerly as more elements were added. It has many elements that appeal to me. A tabletop feel, fantasy world, anthropomorphic characters. Throw in gorgeous graphics, especially on the animated cards, and a great soundtrack, and surely we're onto a winner.Sadly, I have to say the full release has disappointed me. The game just feels empty. But unlike many early access games, which end up as buggy unfinished excuses to take your money off you, Armello feels like it had a lot of love and effort put into it, which makes what we are left with a let down indeed.There are four ways to win in Armello, and only two of them seem worth pursuing unless you like a self imposed challenge. The 'prestige' and 'spirit stone' victories are fairly straightforward, but the 'kill the king' victory is an exercise in masochism, fail at it (which you will most likely, as the king is an absolute beast of a fighter) and you'll be too far behind to try for the other methods. The 'rot' victory is identical to the 'kill the king' victory, except you have to punish yourself even more to get it.You can play many cards during an opponent's turn, but good luck finding them: the mouse scrolling gets stuck very easily, and if you zoom out to see the whole map, an inexplicable layer of cloud obscures the whole map! Compare this to a true tabletop card game, where you can play cards against your opponent sitting round a table. Imagine if you had to get out of your chair, chase them around and physically hit them with it before they played their hand. In Armello Seeing as you don't know a card has been played until it's effect kicks in, there is very little one can do to protect against it. Most of the time, you will never have enough resources to ever use that card that's been in your hand for the past 2 turns.Once you've won a few games, repeat plays become a chore as you watch your 3 opponents slowly take their turns, then watch the king's guard take their turns, THEN watch the banes take theirs. Games become incredibly drawn out for all the wrong reasons. I think the developers could have added more settings to change gameplay rules, define what type of victory conditions are active and so on, give the player some customisation options to add longevity. Currently the only reason to replay is to unlock the many beautiful cards.The game is beautiful, and fun for a little while. It's just a shame it leaves you wanting more so badly.

												A beautiful game ruined by excessive RNG.  It feels as though every strategy is trumped by die rolls, random map resource spawn, and card draw. If the HEAVY reliance on RNG doesn't turn you off, then you may find it much more enjoyment here than I.  If, like myself, you need more of a sense of agency in a game, I would give this one a pass.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								(This was written while the game was still in Early Access)Armello is a board-game RPG type of game with beautiful graphics, awesome mechanics and proper diversity: this is a game that really feels completely different every time you play it. Though some cards may appear more frequently, I've really had to adapt a different strategy every game I've played.This is also because of one of the best parts of Armello: the victory conditions. There are 4 different ways to beat the game, and the four conditions are able to be reached by anyone in the game, provided they plan for them. This helps keep the game interesting for everyone: it's hard to have a completely hopeless game, you can always try to fulfill one of the different conditions, regardless of the other player's status.The game takes a little to learn and understand, and (at the moment) some tooltips aren't always easily readable, but it isn't a particularly hard game to learn.There is ONE big problem with the game at the moment: lack of local multiplayer. This is a boardgame kind of game and the lack of local multiplayer is a big oversight. The developers have said they may add it in the future, but at the current moment it is sorely lacking it. Keep this in mind, because this lacking feature and the somewhat high price tag compared to other board-games, makes it hard to fully recommend.If you consider buying it, watch some gameplay videos first. Then, think about how you would want to play the game more: Do I like playing these games online with strangers? Can I wait for a local co-op that may not come? Do I have friends that play online and are willing to buy their own copy for $25?Armello is an amazing game and should be given a try, but at the moment the multiplayer options have a few bothersome conditions.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
Great artwork but a disappointing board game.Armello has some similarities to Talisman, in that a way to win is in the middle of the board, but you need to improve your character's stats and gather useful equipment before you have any chance at it.However, killing or curing the king hardly ever happens as you have to be incredibly lucky for either to be feasible, so pretty much every time the game will run out of turns and the player who happens to have the highest prestige wins.Winning or losing is almost entirely based on luck. Meaningful decisions don't really come up, each player will tend to do their own thing, clicking on the next 'quest' and hoping to randomly have the most prestige when the game ends.Quests and encounters consist of a random die roll. Most of your time is spent waiting for the other players to take their turns, more so even than most other board games thanks to all of the neutral units taking their turns.In general it is just rather shallow, dull and repetitive.I love board games but there are many other board games, both physical and digital, that are better and cheaper than this one.However the 2D artwork is gorgeous and the in-game graphics and animations are nice.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												Frustration simulator 2015.A beautifully designed and drawn bcomputer board game. Entirely charming, addictive, easily played through fairly quickly per session.But Oh My God. It's so frustrating. It seems like every die roll is stacked heavily against you.Need some money? Well explore a dungeon! From the icon wheel that spins up when you do, it appears more likely that you'll get a coin result, but no. Four dungeons in a row you'll spawn a bane. Not just that but despit there appearing to be only one bane icon on the wheel, you'll tick past it only to stop on another striaght afterwards.Got 7 fight dice and great gear? Think you can beat that other character who has 4 fight dice and poor gear? You'd think so, but no, you wont. In fact you'll roll worse than him for all three actions of your turn and get the snot kicked out of you.Got a handful of cards and want to deal with that peril? No I'm sorry, all the icons will be mismatches for your cards and you'll fail all the die rolls you couldn't cover with your cards.Oh and do you have a quest with a 70% success chance? Well you'll succeed... As long as the reward isn't an item that you really want, because if so, your success chance is actually 0%.I really don't know how they have coded chance into this game, but failure at almost everything is the norm.I keep playing it, so I really have to recommend, but for the love of god, if you don't deal well with frustration, if you are prone to mouse or keyboard beating... Perhaps choose another game.

number of helpful: 22 of 27 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23
												To be honest, I have mixed feelings about this game. This is one of those games for which "neutral" opinion is perfect. So, what Armello is all about?It's a mixture of a board game, card game and strategy wrapped in gorgeous graphics and very nice soundtrack. Audio-visuals are very good and immersive. It feels like a fairy tale, every character is unique, likeable, and has a very cool design. Atmosphere is warm, nice, and calm... under one condition, and that is, if You have luck on Your side. Because this game can turn from a family friendly game to a table flipping rage fest. Why? Answer is simple, and to many people it's a turning point in buying a game or not. RNG! This game is so filled with randomness that sometimes You will feel You have no control over what's happening on the board.-Card picking at the beginning of each turn? Kinda random, except in one case if You have Usurpers DLC. One character can see what cards he's choosing.-Quests locations? Random. And the game is programmed that every time You complete one quest, next quest starts at the opposite side of the map/board.-Villages, main source of income for Your equipment? Random. So, it can happen that one person can have two villages nearby his clan grounds while another player has none and has to walk further to intercept it.-Exploring dungeons? Random. While exploring You can get many different outcomes, like finding gold/treasures, recruiting companions or The Stranger, spawning a wraith or even being teleported to another dungeon. The annoying part is that it isn't being determined by any factor at all, You just have to be lucky to get what You want.-And now the worst part. Battles with another players or npc's (knights and the king) are based on throwing dices, and although it's understandable it is random (since in real life throwing a dice is also random obviously) it presents a very, very nasty problem. The outcome of the fight isn't determined by Your playing skills but by sheer luck and the amount of dices You hold. The amount of dices depends on Your battle stat but even so there will be times when You're overpowered, having 7 or more dices and You still lose because RNG "decided" that You will roll 6 Rots and 1 Sword while Your opponents will roll 3 Wylds which gives them 3 additional rolls... and that can lead to another Wylds, and so on until You end up getting rekt. This can be very frustrating, to the point where You just quit the game. I would rather see some other mechanic that involves You as an active player more. You can burn Your cards to force symbols to appear, but that doesn't help much. At least not in my case.But despite all these flaws and rage inducing moments, I still enjoy this game for the most part. It may be because I am a calm person in general, but I can see how some other players will hate this type of gameplay. I wouldn't give this game a negative review, but positive one is also a little bit of a stretch, because that depends heavily on what kind of a player You are. If You are a rage quitter, You won't like this. But, if You're chill and aren't taking games that seriously, You can definitely enjoy Armello.

number of helpful: 18 of 21 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												This is a beautiful game, graphically and mechanically. Armello mish-mashes several things I enjoy playing: card-based games, strategy, and tactics. This isn't just a "beat your opponent to the King and layeth down the smack", it's got far more depth than that. The methods of winning the game are part of the draw here: individual play styles can shine and are rewarded for the effort. Pacing your gameplay will depend on your play style.Artistically, the game draws me back to the worlds created by Richard Adams in Watership Down and The Plague Dogs, and the Redwall stories of Brian Jacques, all of which I enjoyed in my youth and still enjoy now. I actually like the disconnect from human-rendered characters as animals can offer similar, but much more mystical histories. As far as the story goes, there's not much more than a few simple bases: you're part of one of the four animal clans, you're attempting to dethrone the King, and each character has a special skill that can be used to essentially envision them within your own imagination. I like games that allow me to sort of "flesh out" a character for myself rather than having some contrived backstory forced on me, it makes each game more interesting and kind of intense as you're able to invent something for your character to be working toward upon taking the throne.Cons, I suppose, would be some of the things that I consider pros. Not everyone enjoys turn-based games, and waiting for the King's guard and the Bane to take their turns can become tedious (especially if there are a large number of them on the map), and not everyone enjoys card-based gameplay. However, if you don't like turn-based and card-based games, this one shouldn't even be on your radar. Luck is also part and parcel to this game, as it is with any dice-roll game, and if you don't like raw deals from Lady RNG, stay away; stay far, far away.One of the pros that I particularly enjoy is that each game can't just "drag out"; the King has diminishing health and will eventually just keel over, ending the game whether anyone's breached the palace or not (no, you cannot heal the King other than one specific means). This keeps it from becoming stale, and since there's that added sort of time limit, it encourages progressive gameplay techniques that are learned from playing the game and understanding its tactics more.Another pro is the "chat" system in multiplayer games. There is no "press-enter-to-type" chat function, rather a series of basic dialogues available through the chat tab (like Hearthstone). I've long disliked chat systems in most competitive multiplayer because it seems like some people spend more time "chatting" (rather, trolling or raging) than they do actually playing the game. In the future, I hope that this minimalistic "chat" function is not replaced by a press-enter-to-type system; personally, I feel that it would hinder more than accentuate multiplayer. So far, the only basic way for someone to rage out and quit a match is to simply leave the game. I like this, I don't need someone's vitriol about being behind or ganged upon clogging up my screen. So, if a dev ever happens upon this review, please know that at least one fan of the game likes the "chat" system as it is; it keeps things far more civil in game.In all, Armello has an aesthetic that will either appeal or dissuade players in its art style, mechanics, and gameplay. It's easy to sink several hours into this game without noticing (or sometimes caring) that time has passed.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												A 4 player fantasy regicide board game.Update v1.0 is a massive improvement on the beta build. All the cards have been animated, annotated and even have sound effects. The card book got the same treatment, it also now highlights new cards so you can easily view them. The world map now has much higher level of graphical detail with each clan getting its own unique starting location and rotten ruins reciving a sinister purple glow during night turnsAs for the new heroes, the wolf ranger arrow offers safe first strikeRabbit tinker can swap items cheaply allowing you to rapidly shift tactics as the turns unfolds.Ninja rat is fragile but gains ambush advantage at nightBut the second magic bear...wow. He channels magic into smash-gic, every magic card used ups his attack. This synergises outrageously well with his clan signets and any spirit treasures/followers you pickup along the way.The devs will respond to any bugs you report with the bug report tool ingame or on their forums and are a friendly bunch.Games only last 18turns at the moment but id expect options for custom rules in a future build. If you like board games and fancy something new, give this a shot.It contains magic bears.

Early Access Review
								The latest update- still pretty early in Early Access- really made this game click for me. Clever mechanics that tie into the themes well, plays like the board game it's supposed to be while taking advantage of digital in all the right ways. Armello is good at forcing tough decisions on you, and the range of routes to victory tend to make for a desperate finish. Art is absolutely beautiful. Amazing use of animation on the cards.It just feels RIGHT, y'know?

												Do you wih you like board games ? Do you wish you had one to play with anybody at any time ? If the answer is yes, then get ready to buy one of the best board game online !Good points :- Amazing graphics, with wonderful looking characters- Easy to learn gameplay, takes only 1 game to understand the basic, after what you'll want to discover all of the cards- Start a game with a weak character, and slowly watch yourself becoming a true warrior, with equipments and party members- 8 playable heroes (12 if you then buy the DLC), each with its own stats and a unique special ability, and customable with small artifacts- Different strategies, with different winning conditions, you never know what the next game will be like- Awesome community, just give a look at the forum and ask any question regarding the game, players and even the devs answer and help - Get gogeous looking dices, and if you don't need them, sell them on the store to earn your money back on the game :p"Meh" points :- A game with dice and cards, so there is rng. Just be sure to have some time before starting a session !Would i recommend Armello ? If you're not afraid to spend time on a board game, learning new things after each victory or defeat, trying new compositions and strategies, always improvising with what the rng gives you, then stop reading and BUY IT !Ps : Did i mention that Armello has the best devs of any game i know ? content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												Honor and courage. Trickery and deceit. Adventure and quests. Armello is a multiplayer strategy game that embraces several different styles of play and has a colorful cast of characters to choose from. With four different paths to victory, every game is challenging and requires you to pay close attention to your enemies each turn, and each game will be different. When I first read about the game, I thought it would be fun and interesting, but I didn't expect it to be so addictive! Reminds me a bit of Game of Thrones, but with anthropomorphised animals instead of Sean Bean. Whether you want to play versus the AI or with friends, Armello is worth the $20, and the community is friendly and helpful. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys strategy board games. A+, 10/10.

Posted: January 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								First off, I'm quite pleased for a game that breaks the archtypes of animals, meaning that a rat isn't necessarily a bad or evil character. Really, it seems that YOU are the one who determines the alignment of four characters, a Thane (wolf), Sana (bear), Amber (rabbit), and Mercurio (rat). Each character is trying to become the next lord of Armello, and it can be done with intrigue, murder, or muscle. The game is a card/board/dice game so each play is different. Cards can be used to make your ascension easier, or more difficult on your rivals. And all the while Banes, something like a corruption elemental, are spawning and wreaking havoc on the land while dungeons are ripe for exploration. Declarations can be used to make thing easier on you, harder on others, or just a touch of randomness when nothing else is beneficial.This is one of the most unique games I have played and I enjoyed it, it's easy ot learn and isn't a game that is all to lengthy in play. You can play alone with computer players, or you can get some friends together and compete for the throne in multiplayer.

League of Geeks did a great job with this one, I look forward to other ventures they have, whether it's in Armello or beyond.

												Armello is one of those games that makes me think I'm sitting around the table playing board games with friends in college again. The game seems to follow the age old quip of "Easy to play, hard to master" as there are so many different strategies revolving around all of the different characters and win conditions.The first few games were easily played with a friend as we both learned the ins and outs of the game. With four different kinds of victories capable, I have come to find that the Prestige victory is one of the easiest to obtain if you play your cards right (pun intended). The Rot victory is one of those victories where you can't start a game and go, "I'm going to go for the Rot victory right off the bat." I know this review doesn't help in terms of convincing you to buy the game, but it's just a few minor thoughts. The DLC is well worth the price, the game is fun to play alone, with friends, or even online. The lack of a chat function is kind of disaapointing, but I suppose it's like Hearthstone in that it does help avoid all of the toxicity filling today's games. Grab Armello, grab a drink, and get ready to feel the nostalgia of board game night!

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												Beautiful animations, beautiful artwork, hypnotically immersive soundtrack, fluid game mechanics and overall gameplay that just oozes originality while also being ridiculously fun to boot. Armello is a turn-based RPG/Strategy Card game which is honestly more of a Virtual Board game than anything else. You pick a Hero, each possessing their own strengths/stats/abilities and proceed to compete against 3 other players while trying to win the game through 4 different methods (kill the king, gather 4 stones and confront the king etc etc). All the while, you have random events, dictations from the King (player-chosen events), and even an evil race of monsters (called Banes) that are trying to kill everything and everyone. Sometimes you will work together with other players but it's important to remember there can only be one winner, so backstabbing is friendship killing levels in this game. Final opinion? This game is a hell of a lot of fun and I highly recommend it even if it's just for the Aesthetic alone... Now excuse me, I'm going to go maul a few animals with my Spirit Bear.Gameplay and Review:


YouTube™ Video: Armello Gameplay and Review 

			Views: 409		

			Absolutely beautiful TBS/RPG "Board" Game. I love it and I hope the devs are able to put out some more content for the game (more characters, terrain types, etc etc).

number of helpful: 14 of 16 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												The TL;DR version: It's Redwall Mixed with Game of Thrones in electronic boardgame format and is exactly as awesome as that sounds. Buy it!The Proper version: Armello is a strategy game that blends both strategic, tactical and luck based mechanics into a very well-polished package. Your typical game lasts about an hour (Longer for Multiplayer) and has you in a race for the crown. During each game you compete with both your opponents and AI controlled entites like Banes and Castle Guards to progress to one of four victory types. The variety of characters (8 in total as of launch) ...each with their own unique starting stats and special abilities and the variety of victory types (4 in total) means that every game plays out differently, especially since the map is randomly generated every game. Even when playing the same character, you might find that the terrain and early game events might make one type of victory better than another.The main victory in the game is a Prestige victory. This follows your standard victory point progression like other board games. The other three victory types are ways for players who are behind to "Steal" the win from the prestige leader. This is good as even if you fall WAY behind, you are still able to claim victory, yet it isn't unfair to the prestige leader as the prestige victory is the lowest-risk victory, and players trying to 'steal' it from you must take a riskier and more difficult path. It also means that a game isn't won or lost until the final turn, so every player is still engaged even if someone takes a very early prestige lead. The Single Player AI is competent, most of the time. However, the true challenge and fun comes from multiplayer games. With ranked multiplayer coming in 1.1, this could absolutely be a good game to play against other people. And while there is still luck involved, more skilled players can pull off wins much more readily than novice players... thus demonstrating that skill and strategy play a signifigant portion in how well you do and that luck is merely *a* factor, not *the* factor in determining how well you do. The price point is spot on and worth every dollar. If you compare it to a physical board game of the same scope, complexity and nature, this is about 1/3 the price that a physical board game would run you, and is a lot easier to setup and play than one. Even if you aren't a big computer game fan, if you love board games like Agricola, Carcaconne, Settler's of Cattan and the like, you'll love this game. In all, highly reccomended!

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												This is probably one of the best strategy games I have played in a long time.  It brings to the table a sense of RPG, TCG and PVP like no other "board game" videogame I have ever played.The Multiplayer is pretty cool.  I can see why the developers wouldnt want a chat in the active multiplayer game, because it would lead to all sorts of things that derail you from enjoying the game, BUT I would add a chat in the Lobby, because waiting for players to appear, well its tedious.As far as the characters you can play go, I have been playing with Zosha, which is a complete steal and I think it's the most OP character in the game due to it's night time advantages.  Still no character is better or worst than any other, so they are pretty balanced.  You just need to be good at strategizing your moves, and have a little bit of luck :) But it is doable to win out of an irrecoverable position in the game.For example, during my last multiplayer game for example, I wasted too much time reading the amulets and I didnt get to pick one, which is a bit of a disadvantage.  Then I got hit by Rot, which kills your health on a turn by turn basis, I spent most of the game without any prestige... I honestly thought I was going to lose.  But as luck turns out by following the quest line, I was able to get rid of the pesky Rot, gain enough fight to have 10 dices of it, and eventually made my way to the castle where I brought the poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ king well deserved tears.  I really have to tell the devs that this game has truly gone beyond my expectations.  Boardgames brought to video games usually turn one dimensional (take for example Smallworld2, which had an excellent opportunity to be a great game and it ended up sucking...) but in Armello, the board is simply gorgeous, I love the minituarized effect when you get really close with your mouse wheel, the animations are pretty solid, the gameplay is fluid and never boring.  The game has an excellent balance of cards, which bring to play fight, defense, items, magic, etc.  The AI is fairly competent.What I can expect from this game in the future, perhaps is different settings for the boards, and more characters, although the current 8 that come with the game are pretty cool so far.Bravo for the devs.  This is the type of game I wish I had been able to kickstart because you guys did an amazing job.So if you havent bought it yet, then you should go right now and buy this game.  $20 is cheaper than hookers and blow or a date... which are overrated anyways.  What are you waiting for... go buy it... now dammit.

content:
Posted: January 15
												Have only played Singleplayer so far against AI but its been great. The enviroment of this game alone makes it a must have. Disney like characters and a very detailed map with Cards that have amazing artwork. Different victorys, multiple people to play each with unique traits, various items like rings and amulets that add different stats all add to this games replay value. If your the type that likes theorycrafting and having a ton of ways to approach victory this is deffinitly a game for you!The board itself is fairly small and the king slowly dieing does add a little feeling of being rushed at first. But once i got the hang of it i really started to enjoy it. The games actually can take a fair amount of time and you have ample time to play out your strategys and explore the map. Ive already got 7.5 hours played and i havent even entered Multiplayer. I am the type of person who likes to know as much as i can before entering a PVP situation(Years of theorycrafting for WoW :D) and this game is actually taking some time to learn all the ins and outs. Honestly i still feel like a noob! Very fun haha.You cannot receive any chests/keys in singleplayer. They give skins to dice which are purely cosmetic so not really an issue. Just a nice long term goal for some people to look fowards to. I honestly am pretty excited to start multiplayer and face some real challenge!I bought this game 100% for Singleplayer though, full price and bought the usurpers DLC(the one with the 4 new people)and deffinitly say i got my moneys worth. And all the hate against the DLC and microtransactions is the same old typical hate you find on every game with it. They arent gamebreaking in anyway and most are cosmetic. Deffinitly giving this game a 10/10!!!Update: Have now dumped 20+ hours into multi-player and love it. Cons: There are a few cases where i ran into a Bot or afker who would sit in base all game skipping turns(to make the games end fast as possible  to farm chests). And of course the rage quiter who would leave after slightly falling behind.Other times a team of 2 or 3 would gang up on me completely making it imposible for me to win, which is very annoying.  However this rarely occured. Most of the games I had friendly players who played till the end, Still a 10/10. Cant wait for more future updates :D

content:
Posted: February 20
												I had mixed feelings when starting Armello.  However I am a big board game fan. That tag got me interested in Armello.However I was rather concerned by the fact that it never was a real board game.  In the board game world that is the equivalent of a strait to DVD release.  They tend to be kind of poorly done.  I purchased this intending to use steam refund.However the game is one of the better games in the non-RPG adventuring genre.Like most games in that genre there is a ton of dice.  However Armello, unlike most, give a player a choice in what they want to do, instead of mandating go here fight this, etc.  It provides a variety of things to do and avoids a grind.But were Armello really shows its glory is the card play.  The game has great hand management.  There is definitely some tactics to when and how you play your cards. I even found myself debating if I should wait for optimal use or just play the card to get another draw.The game is competitive and does it correctly.  Most let you either just race or perhaps slow your opponents down.  In Armello you can actually hurt your opponents, but never remove them from the game.The theme for Armello is fine and I like the graphics.Now for the weakness --The game requires you keep track of the other players (at least to play on the top level). However what a player is doing is sometimes done so fast that if you blink you'd miss it.  Other times another players turn can be painfully long while you mostly sit there.  The game needs to speed its turns but also keep a log or make it easy to see what they did.In conclusion. This is a good game.  It is relaxing and crafted with a professionalism you do not normally see in this style of computer board game.  Solid graphic, solid game play with a solid recommendation.  Although sometime I wonder if my opinion is inflated due to low expectations.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								The only strategic game I play on steam. As a Kickstarter backer, my opinion is somewhat beholden to the money I've given to the project. That being said, Armello had one of the fastest Kickstarter turnaround times I've ever seen. The proof is in the pudding: Armello is one of the most beautiful games available on Steam, with a strong sense of artistic self. Its parts create an ideal whole.With over 100 cards and a total of 12 playable heroes (4 during the Beta, at least 4 more at launch Sept. 1st 2015, plus 4 additional ones for backers and eventually, late adopters) there is enough variety to keep you coming back for more, to see how each game plays out. Randomized gameboards and multiplayer support only further this. The additions of quests and storyline are icing on the cake, and I expect the full release to be even richer in terms of how the story is told. I've taken to playing the game just to unwind; the mix of beautiful art and serene, appropriate music is enough to please the senses for every moment you play.In short, you owe it to yourself to experience the world of Armello, which in itself is so compelling that even without the exemplary game system it would serve as the basis for a series of best-selling fiction.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												  I had backed Armello for $150 on kickstarter, and I had been playing it since beta.  I have, on record, 200+ hours meaning I am experienced in Armello (and I have won a fair amount of games.)  I have seen the changes made to Armello as it progressed from beta to early access to full release and now patches.  I had high hopes for Armello in the kickstarter, and I really wanted to enjoy it; but I feel Armello suffers from having too much RNG.   RNG is fine in video games, infact it's what makes a game.  The complaint is the AMOUNT of RNG this game has:  dice, cards, coin flips, percent chances.  It takes out the skill of anything that could be done.  There are some other key elements that also make it an even more unpleasurable experience:•RNG -Dice Rolls:  The dice roll chances come out to | 3/6 attack | 1/6 shield | 2/6 miss |  not exactly balanced -Card Draws:  Adds to the RNG aspect with obtaining random spells/equipment -Movement:  Dungeons can spawn banes (obstructing your path) or teleport (sets you back further but can help in very few situations) -Quest Rewards:  Three sets of quest with rewards (spirit stone, random follower, or random treasure,) even a chance to fail the quest depending on your stats•Community -Griefing:  Partied up players like to gang up and bully the fourth player (LoG has took initiative to ban these players from what I've heard) -Quiters:  Some players quit games due to their favorite characters being picked or leave because of unfortunate events in the game -Aggression:  Uncalled-for aggression from other players, even unprovoked (On other negative reviews there seems to be die-hard fanboys defending the game blindly and aggressively) -Unfriendly:  Some spiteful players tend to emote laughs and other emotes after being extremely hostile in-game•Gameplay -Battle:  Fights tend to end in a stalemate with both players dying due to 3/6 chance of rolling attack (unless luck is involved) -PvP:  No allegences between players except between friends, everyone stabs you in the back eventually -Strategy:  There's almost no strategy, everything's situational; and the game's too random for there to be any kind of set strategy (the only strategy is knowledge of cards and what the opponent could have/do) -Crashes:  There are constant freezes and NMAs which seems to happen more frequently as the game updates•Design +Art:  I do love the designs of this game, but really that's the only positive thing I have to say about Armello ○Sound:  Nothing too impressive, but it's not necessarily bad Even in private full lobby friend match there's no enjoyment to be had.  Everything feels like a matter of chance with no skill required.  There's no rewarding feeling you get when you win a match, because it's all luck-based.  After doing a good amount of private matches, we agreed to either playing a different game or just stopping all together.  Armello has plenty of potential to be a fun game, but with the randomness of everything it just kills any enjoyment.  Winning sessions comes down to luck (almost every game ends with being really lucky, or really unlucky.)  Armello could be more of a strategic game if the random elements were toned down.  For now, this will be a negative review, unless several mechanics of the game are revised.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												Armello is a board game... of sorts.  You play as heroes of 4 animal clans who fight to save their kingdom, or to destroy it. That is entirely up to you, the player. You have a choice of 8 characters (currectly, more are being added!). Each clan is represented by 2 heroes. They have a variety or special abilities which make them unique, and you need to adapt to their playstyle to win. Some character might be too weak but strong in battle, yet other might lack in battle but win with magic and amounts of health.But as I said, Armello is a board game! It is not the best, but not the worst either. It has its flaws. For example the game relies too much on RNG. Which means you might get really good drop and on the other hand you will do so miserably and ask yourself: why? The gaming board represents the kingdom or Armello, its procedurally generated, so the game will always be different, although the shape of the board stays the same. The board is filled with villages, dungeons, enemy mobs, forests and mountains, and also with traps.The goal of the game is to defeat the king, who has been taken by a Rot. (Rot is a special condition in a game that drains 1 health every 2 turns) The king is slowly loosing his health. You have many options how to win. Be a fighter, a diplomat, the one who purges the darkness away from the king or a corrupted hero who decides to rule with even darker hand than the king himself.You can play alone with AI controlled players, join up online with friends or online against random players to have a chance to drop some sweet loot that can be sold on Steam market (really, free, no microtransactions!), or be kept for you to admire. (Seriously, a dice that sparkles... count me in!)Although the game is really clinging on randomness and it sometimes feels like its more based on luck than actual skill (which might and might not be true. If you are really lucky you can win, but if you think about your moves, you can win just as much) its very fun, matches might take over 60 minutes sometimes, but with its randomly generated maps the games are never the same.

number of helpful: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Wow!What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said? As a huge fan of real-life boardgames, there is often a bit lost in transition between the tabletop and the digital realm. Rarely has a game of Settlers of Catan or Magic the Gathering felt nearly as compelling online as it has in person.However, Armello seems to meld just perfectly the best aspects of both real-world boardgaming and videogaming. The card art is gorgeous (and wonderfully animated), as is the world and the lore that is set up. Each character is unique, while still remaining viable and seemingly balanced. With four different possible paths to victory, players must adapt quickly and cobble together a winning strategy from whatever comes their way.It must be said that no game has ever had the level of collaboration between developer and player that Armello has. As a successful Kickstarter, the game has grown past anyone's expectations thanks to the free exchange of ideas from the community. I can only hope that Armello, and the League of Geeks team, serve as models for what future videogames can accomplish!

Posted: April 15
												So I wont be saying much new here, but at least its worth having the key points reiterated:- Fun idea for a game, major problems with connectivity, pacing and sociability.Basically you get a board game thats interesting to play and varied enough that luck and tactics are well-balanced for fun, but its like going to a party where at any point you or your copartiers will be pulled out by a bungee rope and not allowed to return, and you'll be replaced by a Stepford party-goer. (i.e. if you lose connectivity, you're gone for good. No returning to the last 5 minutes of a game you were about to win).Also you have to wait for ages for everyone else to take their turn, requiring just enough concentration that reading a book is not possible, but not so much concentration that its engaging or challenging to follow.2/5. There's better things out there for sure.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Very beautiful game, especially with the new board skin DLC, which I heartily recommend! This game is quite simple at its core, play one of 12 heroes(if you're not a founder) which are all unique and guide them on your chosen path to defeat the King and become King or Queen of Armello. There are four ways to win, some a little less tasking than the others. However, while this game is straightforward, the world can be perilous and certainly deceptively complicated under its simple face. It allows you to plan ahead, despite the randomness of most events. This same randomness can be considered a blessing or a curse, as it may impede or boost your fight for the throne. Something that might intrigue some players, is that no matter how poorly you may think you're doing, there is always a way to become the ruler of all Armello.There's really not much to say about this game anymore, it's a masterpiece in its own right with very few bugs. Look forward to future and past content from the wonderful developers!

number of helpful: 13 of 16 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												Armello is a computer boardgame set in a fantasy kingdom of Armello, a world filled with antropomorphic animals of various kinds. Rot has corrupted the good king of the land, making him erratic and mad. This of course will not do and the clans of the kingdom set out to solve the problem, some of them harboring a solution more sinister than the other. It falls to the player's clan to either cure, kill or replace the king by being the hero of the people.The game starts by the players picking their characters from a bunch of eight different heroes belonging into four different clans as well as the starting trinkets which the player can use to get and advantage in a specific situation on board and a statboost of their favourite stat. The board is then randomly generated with the King's palace in the middle. The map is made of a bunch of different tiles such as high mountains, dangerous swamps, periless dungeons, busy villages, lush forests etc. etc. Almost every tile has a special purpose, giving the player either a defence boost, health refill, invisibility, wound or something else. For example Dungeons give various rewards from money to magical items and Villages pile the heroe's purse with shiny, clinky, coin at dawn. The tiles can be further changed by various cards and events.The goal of the game is to either kill the mad king and take his place. Cure the king with four magical stones or wait till the king dies by succumbing to the rot (or being slain by another hero with both the king and the hero dying) and claiming the throne as a prestigeful hero of the good people of Armello. By completing quests each hero increases their attributes and prestige.The player heroes all have a handful of cards they can play any time they want. Even when it's not the player's turn to act provided the player hero has the money or magic and the proper conditions to use the card. These item cards range from beneficial items to magic to shady deals to spring traps and other evil things upon the unlucky contestants.Attributes include Fight which determines how good your hero is in combat, Body that servers as your hero's hitpoints and health, Wits which lets you draw more cards to play later and Spirit which measures your magical prowess. Each of these stats are used in either combat, questing or when facing a peril. Naturally the higher the attribute the more chances your hero has winning the encounter.Secondary attributes are Gold which is used to play various types of cards to enhance your own hero or make the life of other heroes more difficult. Magic which is the fuel for using magic cards for the same purposes as above. Prestige which helps you winning the game and Rot which... measures how much you rely on the dark evil. Prestige and Rot both require some attention here.Prestige measures how famous your hero is. Having the highest prestige at dawn has the benefit of letting your hero give the mad lion king advice on which of the two new rules he's going to enforce for the coming day. This can be used to make the life more difficult for the other heroes but the choises aren't always beneficial for the prestige leader. When the king dies, either by succumbing to the rot or when killed by another hero unsuccesfully, the player whose hero has the highest prestige wins the game. Players can also lose prestige by killing the royal guard or by dying. Some events, such as certain quests when failed, also drain prestige. Player can increase their hero's prestige by killing opposing heroes the evil banes and by completing quests.Rot is the dark influence heroes gain by dabbling into evil magic or being corrupted by rotten creatures. Having rot can make your hero stronger, but it comes at a cost. Each dawn a corrupted hero takes damage and if your hero is very badly corrupted, the normally beneficial healing shrines will kill the hero instantly. Having rot makes your hero more potent in combat, but only if you fight against other corrupted creatures. If the hero's rot value is bigger than the opponents, the player may add the opponents rot in dice to their dice pool during combat. Also each time a rot corrupted character slays somebody they refil their health by one point and is not hunted by banes. Having rot is a very aggressive strategy towards winning the game.When a fight breaks out the player gets to roll their Fight dice. There are several items and abilities such as shields, armor, weapons and magic which add or reduces from your or your opponents dice pool. Players try to roll as many hits as they can as well as blocks to negate enemy hits. Fights can end in a several ways but dying doesn't punish the player too much. The defeated hero will respawn in their clan's starting ground and is back in the game as soon as the player's turn is up. The player can also burn the cards in their hand to get a guaranteed result on a single die.The game has one nasty flaw though, if you can even count it as a flaw. The game is very random. By having a poor luck with the tiles near your starting zone or a bad starting hand of cards you may find your hero's chances of winning being very low from the get go. Bad card draws and unforgiving dice can also completely ruin your game, but that's given, considering the game is closer to a board game than a what you normally have on a computer. But besides that I find the game very enjoyable. The presentation is great. The game has some really fine artistic style, fitting music and it's just a joy to play. It's a bit boring alone, but with friends the game really shines. Armello is not for everyone but I believe anybody who's into board games will probably enjoy this one immensively.

number of helpful: 14 of 18 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								My review for Armello as posted on: http://www.grabthegames.com/preview-armello.htmlA digital board game like no other, it really feels like Game of Thrones but with animals.  The first aspect that I loved about this game is that is not a simple board game but it has a solid and interesting story that makes the game experience even better! Moreover, the game features beautiful graphics and a really captivating soundtrack and in game music as well. The game is also fast with a high replay value. The day and night cycle is a great addition to the game with both of these cycles affecting the game play. Everything is also so beautiful in this game from the animated cards that will be more than 100 in the game to the captivating board of the title. Furthermore, the game has a lot of heroes to choose from that each one represent a different clan. Each clan representative has different set of skills, advantages and weaknesses with more to come when the final version of the game will be out. The heroes are also highly customizable with rings and amulets with impressive attribute. The title also features a dynamic sandbox. This means that every game you play will not be the game as the previous one because the maps and the quests are randomly generated. However, there are some negative aspects that I should mention. The biggest one for me is it lacks a good tutorial; I found it hard to get used to the title but after two or three games you will be able to learn it easily.  To sum up, if you love gorgeous games and tabletop title this is the game you must pick up without second thought. Totally recommend it despite the negative aspect. It has a great feature and more content will be implemented in the near feature. Verdict: 8.5/10 +graphics+customization+sandbox aspect+day and night cycle+100+ animated cards-desperately needs a better tutorial

content:
Posted: April 17
												This is one of the games I wish we had the option for a neutral review, but since I feel the pros slightly outweight the cons I'll go with a positive one even with its issues.The game itself is rather fun. Think of a Studio Ghibli movie meeting Game of Thrones. It's a board game where you and 3 other people or AI roam a beautiful board trying to complete objectives while fighting each other and the board pieces or making alliances. There's 4 ways to win a game and all of them require the King to die or get banished so you become the next King/Queen, the thing is the vast majority of games it's gonna be one of two ways, either a Kingslayer or a Prestige victory.There's 4 clans, each of which has 3 possible heroes for you to choose, 2 if you don't have the Unsurpers DLC. Every one of them is a viable choice for competitive play and uniquely built with their strengths and weaknesses.The game has a good enough mix of strategy and RNG. Sometimes you can find yourself in a corner because RNG screwed you in a game or ahead of the others because it favored you. Building your hero in a way that minimizes the RNG effect on you is also a core part of the game.The queues always felt good to me. I see a lot of complaints about people waiting too long for games yet I never had to wait over 2-3mins. I don't know if it's a timezone thing but for me this never was a problem.The real problem with the game is the stability issues. If you get disconnected in Multiplayer that's it, there's no way to rejoin the game. And more often than not this can also cause the match to completely freeze, forcing everyone to abandon a 1h+ game. And it can really freeze at any time, without anyone leaving too. In my experience this affects 25-35% of the matches I've played.Also LoG has decided to milk their customers by going down the DLC and microtransactions route. First there was a character pack which let's say it's okay. Then a 5€ DLC that just adds 2 more color palettes for the board map. And with version 1.6 came ridiculously overpriced Hero Skins as well. At least besides the character pack everything is purely cosmetic and does not affect your game experience.Lastly the community seems to be a rather decent one in my experience of Multiplayer. There are the occasional trolls and afk farmers but they're much more uncommon than pleasant people you meet during your matches. The problemtic thing is the AI that takes the place of someone leaving the game. They are really not the brightest ones around. They're generally quite bloodthirsty even when the odds are really stacked against them and will rush breaching the palace quite often(that's the last phase of the game).tl;drPros-Beautiful artwork-Balanced-More than 1 victory type allowing you to play in different ways-Enjoyful experience(when it works)-Good variety of cardsCons-Multiplayer Freezes sometimes-No way to reconnect in an ongoing game-cosmetic microtransactions and DLCs-a bit prone to RNG -Horrendous A.I.All in all I'd say if you enjoy board games and don't mind some RNG involved it's a good choice for you, it certainly was for me!

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's a great game--a combination of a traditional tabletop and board game, but two things that are crippling the game, or at the very least, are proving to be worrisome, are online play and DLC.Currently, if one person even remotely disconnects during the game, it completely ends the match and returns you to the Menu Screen.   On several occasions, I played game nearly to their completion, only to have a player, whether intentional or not, disconnect, completely ruining the match and wasting whatever time you devoted.  Something as simple as a screen for the remaining players to decide whether to wait or continue with an AI would have sufficed, but as it is, there's nothing more furstrating than to figuratively have a player throw the game and table.Second, between their Kickstarter page and their Wiki, there are currently 4 playable characters with 8 additional characters being released as DLC--four of which are slated to be paid DLC, and other four only available if you donated at least $45/$55 to their Kickstarter.  While I can appreciate something being special or exclusive, for what is supposed to be a casual stategy game, I can't help but feel a bit sleighted of being denied content simply because I happen to be late to the party or don't have a fat wallet.  Maybe if it was one or two characters, or even vanity items, but to devote a whole faction--literally a third of the currently planned playable characters, with a time and money requirement, I can't help but feel this game is pay-to-win even before leaving the gates.
