content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												This game is a simple delight. Once you get a grasp of the basic concepts of the game, it's a fun strategic, yet simple, game you can play against friends, people or AI in a relaxed environment. The art style and characters are charming. There is enough variation with the characters strengths to take different approaches to gaining victory over your opponents whether that's attaining prestige via questing, bane slaying, hero killing, alliances, etc. or trying the alternative ways to victory such as collecting spirit stones to cure the king or preparing for a final fight to kill him either with good gear and stats or becoming more corrupted than him.The game does have a heavy dose of luck involved but you can try to play around the odds smartly to avoid bad rolls. It won't always work out and sometimes it works out in your favour.Unless you are playing with friends who have backed the game and bought DLC, the full character roster is hidden behind barriers to entry. I play with a backer and with another person who owns the DLC. So in our games, we get the 4 bandit characters and the additional 4 DLC characters in our game's roster.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								As a long time board gamer and video gamer, I really appreciate Armello in so many respects. This was not a board game adapted into a video game or vice versa, this game truly is a standalone experience on the computer. You could not have the high quality cards, dice rolling, or opening cutscene in a cardboard version of this game (though honestly, I wouldn't mind owning one).I'll be honest, I saw the gameplay and I was like, "I guess it looks like a game I would try out" but then I saw the two videos produced for Armello and my mind was blown. I appreciate the deep lore and story that they put into a turn based board game. I am in love, please produce a movie!As far as gameplay goes, I find it to be a very well balanced board game that is very down to the wire! I appreciate when a game gives you interesting decisions and Armello does just that. There are 4 different victory types but only 1 winner, breaking the possibility for a runnaway leader. One improvement which many board games have incorporated is alternate turn order to prevent unbalance based on when you go in a given round.The game looks good, plays good, and has my heart. Would definitely recommend.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Armello is an online multiplayer board game (although there's an offline single player option against AI, too) set in the Kingdom of, you guessed it, Armello, ruled by a mad lion king who's infected with Rot. It's your job--as one of eight (twelve with DLC) heroes from one of the four clans--to reclaim Armello by winning the throne, however you choose to do that. You can kill the king with pure strength or healing spirit stones, gain the most prestige in the land to usurp him when the time comes, or become even more corrupted than he is.The gameplay itself is based predominantly on dice and cards: cards grant you skills or bonuses on the field or in battle, while dice are rolled in battle itself to determine your attacks and defence. Of course, this means that luck--or the RNG--can disadvantage you, even in your starting hand, and the AI can utilize rings and tokens (which modify your character's stats during a game) that you have to unlock. In the couple of games that I've played thus far, I've felt a little as if the AI had more opportunity than I did, but I was still able to win.My only real complaint would be that, although beautiful (as is the rest of the game's graphics), the maps are fairly similar and feel a little small to me. I'm sure this is to keep the game moving and to force players into conflict, but it's a little annoying when you're trying to get to a certain square and all of your possible movements are blocked or risky to take. The game rules themselves are customizable, but not so much the maps.I would definitely recommend Armello if you enjoy a mix of strategy-based board games (with a hint of luck thrown in there thanks to dice rolling!). It's a beautiful game with a simple but clear story that wouldn't be out of place in Brian Jacques' Redwall series, and it's entertaining to play.

number of helpful: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												I really like it, as a big fan of Redwall and Miyazaki films and board games. It's really pretty with beautiful animations that ooze character, and easy to learn, and tough to master. There's a nice element of randomness that keeps it fair for people of all skill levels and makes it fun to come back and hope to see new things.So yes, I'd recommend it. That said, I have to complain about the fact that this is a "board game" where people can't have local co-op or hot-seat multiplayer; everyone has to have a separate computer and copy of the game to play, which is tough to organize and pay for. I would, for instance, really like to play this with my brother's family (my nephew would love Barnaby), but sixty more dollars for three more copies is prohibitive. I was also looking forward to playing this with college friends and their children, and can't, which saddens me. For a "board game" this makes very little sense to me.On a related note, please note that chat in multiplayer in this game is limited to a set of canned responses. I understand why this would be done (moderating chat is tricky) but it makes it near impossible to discuss strategy with other players, which can be unsatisfying when another player takes your "Greetings" as a threat rather than the intended friendly gesture and decides to hit you with an Immolation.Despite these absent features, it's still worth checking out, and I don't regret buying it, but those features would make it absolutely perfect.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												I realized I've sunk over 400 hours into Armello and never bothered to review it... probably because I was too busy playing Armello!Armello is a digital board game where you quest to improve your hero's stats, with the ultimate goal being to overthrow the king with one of four victories (prestige, combat, spirit stones, or rot). Given that there are decks of cards and dice rolls, there is quite a bit left to chance, but there is also a LOT of strategy involved. The game requires equal amounts of planning several turns ahead and improvising.Having been playing since the beta (or alpha?), I've benefitted from learning each component of the game as they were gradually implemented, but for a new player it could all possibly be overwhelming. The basics are fairly easy to grasp, but there's a lot of deeper gameplay to master. There's a brief tutorial and also single player bot matches for practicing, but the best way to learn is to dive on in! You're going to lose your first few matches, but stick with it!If all that hasn't scared you off, then you're going to enjoy it!See you in Armello!

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												If you love those interesting tabletop board games, then you'll enjoy this game.Armello is an original digital media IP that has everything you'd expect from physical board games!Bottom line: Do I enjoy this game? Do I think its mechanics work well?Yes.I've played all 4 of the prologue (tutorial) chapters, and also played 4 regular games. I enjoyed playing, and each game was a bit different since the map is semi randomized, each character has different strengths, there's various quests to choose from when you start or complete a quest, and there's several different win conditions.The art in the game for the cards is very cool. Each of the cards has some little bit of animation like blinking/shifting eyes, or a forest whooshing by as a person runs through it, or a bit smoke moving. The art style of this game is wonderfull, but you can see that in the screenshots.The rules/mechanics:It has its own 6 sided die with symbols instead of numbers.It has 8 different characters, each with a unique special passive ability and slightly different stats. This means each character will play a bit different as one might be better at battle, but another might be able to cast more spellcards or more expensive spells.Each character has 4 main stats:Fight- Determines # of die you roll during battle.Body- Essentially is your max HPWits- Determines # of die you roll during Perils, a negative event card played on a space you entered. It also determines your maximum card hand size. You draw to this amount each turn.Spirit- Essentially your max MP, you restore to this number each nightAll 4 of these are also used in quest challenges where 1 stat point x10 = % chance to succeed.You also gain/lose Gold used in equipping Item cards / hiring (equipping) follower cards or playing Trickery cardsThere's Prestige that you gain/lose through certain actions like completing a quest, and some few Trickery cards will cost Prestige instead of Gold. There's a thing that is basically your current MP for the day. Finally there's Rot. If you are infected by this, you lose 1 HP per day and there's other mechanics surrounding this. The king is infected by this setting the turn limit for the game.There's a card system as mentioned as well. There's Items (including equip-ables, one use, and followers), Spells which can be buffs / debuffs/ or even direct damage to other characters, and Trickery (You triggered my trap card, Yugi! Sorry I'm unoriginal). Trickery cards most of the time are played as traps that can be set on certain tiles and when anyone enters that marked space they must pass a challenge by rolling the # of die equal to their Wits.There's a bit more to the game but that's basically it.The king is dying and mad (crazy/evil) due to Rot infection. You must have the highest Prestige when he dies to win, or you can kill him yourself and become King/Queen, or you can gather 4 sacred stones and attempt to cure the king and the land of Rot.

Early Access Review
								Never really been into board games, and despite this, I love Armello and consider it one of my favorite games. It's fun, strategic, and beautifully detailed. The atmospheric visuals and music really draw me into the world, and the cards are gorgeously illustrated and animated. It's hard for me to pick a favorite hero since they're all well-balanced, have great designs, and deep backstories. The heroes have different stats and abilities which can end up being helpful, but this doesn't mean they have to use a certain strategy in order to win.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												Armello did something for me that no other game has been able to do effectively. It made tabletop strategy seem accessible and fun for me. The tutorial does its job well. The way it presents the various gameplay concepts, staggered through different characters to show different approaches to the game, really helped make the ideas stick. While Armello has some fairly complex aspects to it, I was never left feeling intimidated as I often am by other games in this genre. The art style is gorgeous and I feel this is one of the most beautiful games I've played in a long time. Despite basically being pawns on a board, each hero has its own distinct personality, which I personally find necessary for a game to be engaging and to have any longevity.Though I'm only a few games in and can't comment on it at length, I do like the inclusion of a progression system. Being able to unlock items for my characters that allow me to alter their play style gives me more incentive to keep coming back. The pace of the game can be a bit slow at times, since you not only have to wait for other players' turns but also the king's guards as well as any banes that have emerged on the map, but I feel that's really a minor issue. Overall, I'm really happy with Armello so far and look forward to trying out the upcoming multiplayer ladder.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												This game deserves more attention from it's developers as the universe they created with this small game contains a lot of character. It's a fun universe to discover.After my 30'th hour playing I still have more unlockable to achieve however I wish I could unlock more, including Skins / Characters / Cards and more.The staleness of the game comes from the small maps and single game mode with single player and multiplayer options, leaving the desire for DLC game modes such as: Story Mode, Adventure, or even a co-op.The Decks used in the game seem shuffled in the beginning however because the decks can include a vast varity of cards it makes playing what can loosely be called a 'class' is difficult as there is no ~build a deck~ mode.I have been unsuccessful with contacting the developers directly in regards of the direction of the game or to leave feedback. I find this not normal for an indie developer.Lastly performance: I play on an i5-4300 machine (Surface pro 3 - 4 gb ram)The game is playable, manageable via touch inputs.The performance is not, feeling always at a low 20's in fps on low setting at any resolution it feels like there is a lot of un-optimized code. Testing this game on my Desktop rig caused the temp’s to climb to the high 60’s in a machine that can render starcitizen in the high 50’s.Overall 8/10

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Armello is a game that you can see the roots and passion for boardgames shine through. From the character traits to the perils you locate as you wander the 'board' you can feel the designers admiration and devotion to the tabletop genre. The art is beautiful. The trees manage to bring forth the feeling of dark and deep adventure, the dungeons do the same. Honestly the amount of atmosphere created from such little space is truly extravagant.  The attention to the detail is something you'll be noticing with each game you play. The only major drawback is that is falls short of enjoyment when wanting to play with strangers via the public games. There are very few people queued up to play and when you do play there is no way to communicate to each other. This means that the hilarity and competitive fun that you get when playing with friends is lost. If you are looking for a game that blends the polish of many modern day games and the mechanics of old style tabletop boardgames where the dice play a huge part but your strategy and wits is what truly separates you from your competitors then I'd recommend Armello 9 times out of 10.I would suggest inviting a few friends along for the fun though!

content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
												I enjoy Armello quite a bit, and I've had my great moments, my dismal moments, and my meh moments over the course of time that I've put into this gem of a game. The world is beautfiul and aethestically pleasing, the characters diverse and full of life in their designs and battle animations, unique movements for each one I must say. And for those who enjoy lore, one can find it in the form of cards, quests, or a certain follower known only as the Stranger. He adds an interesting depth to the game, but I'll won't elaborate on him. Armello is a simple enough game to understand, but it's very difficult to truly master.Armello is a digital board game with hexagonal tiles that can favor those who have put a considerable amount of time into it, but it doesn't mean that said players, myself included, will win. I have been a part of many a game where someone with far less time won or ruined me, even though I was employing my knowledge of the game to try and win to the fullest. How did this happen you might ask? The answer is simple and is partly why I enjoy Armello so much. RNG. It will make or break your game depending on your dice rolls or on the cards you draw. Sometimes you get fantastic rolls or draws, others are terrible, and often they're a mix. The beauty of this is that it makes players think strategically about their moves on the campaign map, and how they can utilize their hero skills and the cards they've been dealt to the best that they can in order to win. Furthermore, when one is in battle or facing a peril, then they can burn a card provided it has a matching symbol, though the question is should one save a certain card for later or not. In terms of combat, it makes the player think about the risk versus the reward for killing a player or a bane; in that said hero could die, come out victorious and gain a prestige, or both combatants could die depending on the die rolls. What this means is that you can seek out combat or avoid it to the best of your abilities, and know that there are cards in the game that can increase your chance at a succesful combat by taking away health or delay an enemy player if they're pursuit. Provided RNG gives you said cards.Now, there are some factors that people claim are major issues with the game; one is the combat system attack die rolls, another is the comeback system after you die, and then there are those who claim some heros are more powerful than others. In all my hours of Armello, I have seen many a die roll that either brought me victory or ended those hopes. Now, it is true that there are four sides of the die that favor attack, three in reality due to two of these sides being dependent on the time of day. And, yes, there is only one shield side, but that shouldn't get your hopes down. Rather, it causes you to think and plan how you'll play a round. Now, you can have a massive hand of say 13 dice and you only get three defence from them, or you can get 10 defense sides from them. It's all dependent on RNG. I've seen many a battle that netted a massive amout of attack, or defence, or even rot (Much to the benefit or detriment of the player depending upon their current status) and I can say that although attack is favored by the die, that doesn't mean you'll get attack die. As I said, it's all dependent on RNG. Furthermore, if one is worried about defense, then there are plenty of defence item cards that grant automatic defense die without subtracting from your hand that can be aquired, provided you have the gold. Furthermore, you can burn cards with a defence symbol on them to boast your defense, though you must think tactically on the possible results and if they'll be better or worse.Now, there are those who complain that the comeback system is detrimental to players, but I say it causes one to rethink their strategies and pursue either the same old goal, or develop a new one to win. If you can't get to a quest because other players keep killing you, then change your tactics and focus on something else, say a dungeon or spirit stones. One does not need the quests to win a round in Armello, they simply provide benefits that increase your chance to win or even fail. I have lost plenty of games to people who never completed their quests but focused on other aspects of the game that caused them to win, be it rot, prestige, spirit stone, or combat victories. What's more, one can use this system to land them closer to their quest, if it's by their clan grounds, and that causes other players to think about the benefits or negative of killing a character in that sure you'll get prestige if you succeed, but what if it turns put you simply put them next to their quest which resulted in them winner. Choices, choices, choices.  Some people say that some of the heros in Armello are overpowered, and that is only true if you let them be overpowered. Otherwise they're in a similar boat you, the player. If you know how a certain hero works, then you can utlize the cards in your hand to either deny of benefit said hero if they are an opposing player. What's more, there is a certain cost in regards to supposed overpowered hero abilites in that there are certain restrictions on them that can easily break someone's attempt to win. Let's take Barnaby for example, his power allows him to add or remove item cards and not dispose of them as what happens to other heros. Problem is, the amount of cards Barnaby can hold is entirely dependent on his wit level, and the only way he can dispose of said cards, outside of two very early decrees, is either burning in a peril, or in battle. And that's not even counting if RNG grants him decent or good cards.Mulitplayer wise, Armello can either be quiet or bositerous depending upon the time of day and on how many people are playing. Granted, this is a bit of annoying area if you don't have friends or have not yet discovered the Unofficial Offical Armello community where one can often find a game instead of waiting a time for a random match. I will state that the vast majority of people who play in the random mulitplayer matches stay through to the end of a game, I rarely see someone quite because they couldn't do what they wanted, and most people who do leave simply DCed is all. Multiplayer Armello is utter joy with friends in that you can test your friendships, watch salt meters build, or determine which player RNG does not favor that round. One of my friends is noted for chasing the rest of us down if we are too annoying to him even if it means he's risking his attempt to win. One more little morsel of information for you to sample. The community of Armello is wonderful from what I have found and there is a place where you can meet fellow Aremllians for a possible game. What's more, you can have a chance to face the devs themselves in a game of Armello pretty much every Sunday at 6 PST/PDT depending upon the year. Perhaps we'll see some of you there, and if so, then good luck. If you've read down this far, then have some Bubble Tea or Hot Rot Wine on the house and know that I wish you a good time. In the end, only you can decide if Armello is right for you by playing it, trusting the word of others only gets you so far and is open to possibly damaging interpretations of a game.

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								Here are some quotes that sum the game up better than i can.This is a hard game to categorize, but extremely fun to play. An RPG with board game and strategy game influence, a very unique combo! Great purchase." - Original Traders Group."Because it was made in Australia" - Australian Made games.Now for my review bare in mind i haven't play thing game much. *don't know why really*Armello is hard to put in a group. It's a turn based RPG with boardgame elements while having a dash of card games in it's DNA. Some including myself have labled this game as Redwall (a fantasy novel series with animals as the characters) crossed with Game of Throne. Now this may not be fully accurate but that's the vide we get.Gameplay is simple. You have Action Points (AP) which is used as you move on a hex tile base. Combat is Diffrent, you can "burn" cards in your hand to get extra icons that either help or hinder you in the fight. Now for the cards. How many cards you get in a hand is based on your will. Cards are split in three groups. Items magic and a thrid one that's more will based. They either help you or hinder the enemy.The objective of a match is to usurp the throne. The king has taken ill and his illness is effecting his mind making bad descions. the Clans, Rabbit, Wolf, Bear and Rat(?)  belive that now is the time to take the throne. The king himself is had to beat early on but as his sickness goes on it weakens his health. His castel also has several trap/challanges you'll have to overcome in order to face him.Overall i'd give this game a 8/10 with my recommendation.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
  Save your money, buy a better strategy game.  I've been playing this game for about 100 hours and I think it's time that I write my reviewFirst of all I'd like to say that this game is VERY RNG based, the only "strategy" there is to this game is knowing what the cards do, and even then drawing the right cards is based on RNG (you'll most likely draw a scouting card). I'd also like to point out how bad the tile placements are in this game, usually I end up getting 2 swamps next to 2 mountains  in the general area of my clan grounds completely blocking off one side of the board. On more than one occasion I've had 2 dungeons next to each other and ended up spawning 5 banes (3 of which I managed to roll for in their RNG based dungeon system and kill) and the last 2 just straight up spawned from the dungeons at night targeting me and ultimately killing me.Another thing I want to point out is how badly broken this game is, most of the time the game just freezes up when I enter the palace to find the king loosing about 45 minutes of gameplay this is VERY frustrating, another common bug is the Menu straight up not working, on occasion when it asks me to ready up the ready button dissapears kicking me into another lobby and punishing me for leaving the game because I couldn't ready up, even the main menu breaks to the point where i'm just stuck looking at a blurry background of the king sitting on his throne.Another issue I have with this game is the online lobby completely not working at all, when i play with my friends we all ready up and suddenly it just throws us out of our lobby swaping fast between multiple lobbies of people waiting to play the game (I have no Idea how they plan to implement ranked mode with the current lobby system being garbage).Finally I'd like to finish this by saying that I had high hopes for this game but ultimately it ended up just being next to just another shovelware game, maybe the developers will fix it but probably not, I see people on their forums complain to them and the usually they respond with a snarky comment followed by people whiteknighting them. All I can say to LoG is Maybe next time.

number of helpful: 13 of 19 people (68%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												Oh, Armello!  Shall I compare thee to a summer's night of Munchkin?  No?  Risk, maybe?  Dungeons and Dragons?  Alright, perhaps that's pushing it too far.  It is an excellent party game for up to four friends online and with a somber atmosphere and interesting level of lore and immersion.  Even if you're on the losing side, every game feels fun and compelling--the tables are always ready to turn and even in the face of utter hopelessness, you can always take on the role of a vicious saboteur.  Some will say it is too dependent on chance, but I would argue otherwise.  It is a game about choosing a path and then leveraging your odds.  Every move matters and it's possible to turn even a game fraught with terrible luck into a last-minute victory.  Game length varies a bit; single player games last me around an hour, but it's about twice that with friends.The King is corrupt and marching toward his death.  Take on the role of one of several heroes representing the clans of the kingdom, each with their own unique traits, tricks, and motivations for claiming his throne.  Will you play the pacifist and build rapport within the kingdom, elected to power when he inevitably succumbs to his sickness?  You could fight your way through the competition with guile and brawn to slay the monarch yourself, taking the castle by force, or perhaps the Rot has found a more powerful host in you and he is but your final meal before your dark ascension.  With so many paths to victory and the freedom to devise your own strategy, you're guaranteed to find plenty to explore within the world of Armello--especially when you adventure with friends.

												Engaging card or turn base strategy game, but with some teething issues with regards to multiplayer skirmish maps. You will control a Hero Avatar from 1 of the 4 main clan (Wolf, Rodent, Hare or Bear) in which you will strive to achieve victory (Different victory objectives) againts the Corrupt King. Game play is smooth and the controls are straightforward, was able to grasps the game by playing a few matches. Wide varity of cards, ranging from Equipement cards (1 use / Equiped to Avatar), Spell Cards (Uses magic points to cast instant spells to aid your hero's objectives), Trickery Cards (To saboutage / diplomatical achieve your hero's objectives), Treasure cards (Powerful item obtains from completing quest and challanges around the map), and Follower Cards (A trusty sidekick with useful abilities). By using the different cards with your hero, you have to complete quest to clear victory objectives before your opponent to win the game. With New DLC unlocking new heros and cards there is sufficent replayability at the moment.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												UPDATE:11/18 -  My feeling and opinion on the game itself have not really changed from what I wrote before. I still find the game to be underwhelming and the enjoyment of it disproportionate to the love I see it getting. However, the community on the whole here has been EXCELLENT. I mean I have been pretty adamant (though respectful) in stating my opinions and I have to say with one or two excepetions the reaction has been civil. That does not happen on the internet. Except for here apparently. So if you are okay with taking the community health into consideration I am actually gonna go ahead and say I would Recommend this and move up my rating to a...5.1/10I also have to take into consideration that my expectations for the tile may have been too high. More frustarting is that many other people that like simliar games seem to be completely satisfied with the experience and delivery. Its pretty unusual that I wind up an outlier in satisfaction when I am (or felt like I was) a part of the core demographic. Armello seems to be enjoyed by people like me. I barely enjoyed it for 5-6 hours before I found myself searching for reason to like it but I just can't quite figure it out. Anyway if your on the fence I say give it a shot. 11/9 Was pleased to see that with the new update the speed of the AI controlled players was adjustable. I would have to say that experience for singlplayer has been streamlined and improved dramatically. Sadly, I still did not enjoy the game. I only realized this after playing for another few games and realized I was searching for reasons to switch this game to a recommend.In response to Kletian's comments to my review:I agree that picking your deck can influence the outcome however there are just too many random variables that are outside of your control. Is this game strategically superior to chutes and ladders? Absolutely. Risk? Not even close. Monopoly? Probably the best comparison. The random or uncontrolled variables in this game include:3 other players turns1 King turn (King's Guards)Banes TurnPlacement of Quest MarkesCard Draw (Mitigated by choice of card type but still random)Dice RollsBoard ConfigurationThat's alot of randomness to contend with. I am in no way opposed to RNG or believe that it should be a left out of any serious strategy game. However the way this game is structured leaves little room for interesting choices as the game evolves. The randomn elements seem to dictate the way you should be steering your strategy and trying to go in another direction is almost always going to put you in the losers bracket. Armello offers you choices in your strategy but the design of the game itself hamstrings you into playing one way or the other and its just a tough pill for me to swallow.The game is still gorgeous and I agree with Kletian's comments that game is more similiar to Rouge-likes in progression type. However, I would argue that old-school rouge-likes rewarded you for measuring chances and taking risks which is something I found lacking in my time with Armello. The end result was that were often (not always) rewarded for taking those risks to gain advantages and overcome challenges. In Armello you are rewarded for understanding which path to victory is most likely to be successful and than gearing your startegy towards acheiving that goal. Abberations to this formula do exists but they seem far to infrequent and unintentional to be considered a part of the strategy.For a game that involves startegy and measuring risk I would recommend Chaos Reborn.I would take a pass on Armello unless you really love the art and animation (both are excellent).5/10OG REVIEW:I have very mixed feelings for this game. I'll keep this review short and update it as I play for longer.Current Playtime: 6-8 hours (5 games total on a friends account during early access)Pros- Original and creative concept for a game- Ran Smooth on low spec computer with med graphics setting- No bugs encountered - Beautifully Crafted World (card art and animation are my personal highlights)- Limited Game Modes at Launch (ranked coming soon per forum post)AC/DC-RNG Heavy from a double down effect of having card draws and dice rolls as random factors-Universal Card Selection (no deckbuilding element if you are expecting a more typical CCG experience)Cons-Repetition of Game Board Means it all looks the same after awhile-Some progression exists but a overall a little light on the RPG element promised-Balance - Several ways to win a game but two of these are extremely difficult to achieve-Long playtime for each game especially Multiplayer-RNG + Balancing Issues + Long Playtimes = Frustrating ExperienceEven shorter review: 3-5 hours: Sweet! An Online Digital Board Game with RPG progression.5-8 hours: Slooow Moving Game (3 turns other than yours to contend with) and disappointed to find that a strategic approach is smaller element is secondary to dice rolls/card draws.I will keep playing as I still love the premise and several of the issues I have with this title have been acknowledged and are being worked on by the developers. Priced out at $20 US dollars in its current state I am going to have to give it a thumbs down for the time being.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								Been following this game's development for a while, and after getting my hands on the early access (finally) I can see that everything is as it should be.I'm a huge board gamer, and this game's tabletop roots show through. But the developers went a step further here, and took advantage of the game engine to mediate things in ways no tabletop experience could replicate as smoothly. This not only takes all the boring round by round management, tracking, upkeep, and calculating out the experience, but allows for hidden movement, trap placement, and other subtle elements that would not be possible at a table.Because of this, the developers made a REALLY smart move by allowing Armello to be played at a table with a single device, because at its heart, Armello is still a board game, and being able to play it face to face will enhance the experience tenfold. I cannot wait til September when the full version comes out, and I can sit down with my family and friends, a few beers, and have an evening of Redwall-styled treachery and high-adventure.

								Man, I actually regret not backing this on Kickstarter now. I wanted to because the art style and unique Bedknobs and Broomsticks-esque fantasy setting is definitely of a high caliber, but watching the gameplay videos it just looked slow and honestly quite boring. The mechanics and four different victory conditions centered around the King are particularly interesting.I'd like to see some diversity added to the Banes (AI minions that spawn on the map) and I'm generally not a fan of anything being dictated by dice rolls, but overall this is already a very solid and polished game. I'll have to play more before the cracks start to show through, but the quality of the game as is and the dev team seem to indicate any major issues will be addressed over the course of the six month Early Access.

content:
Posted: February 1
												Love this game!  Always been a big board gamer, and have played a lot of Talisman with friends.  Armello is the perfect balance between RNG and strategy.  Sure there is dice rolling (beautifully rendered dice rolling), but you DO have to weigh the chances of success over those of failure, and then go for it if feasible.  Sometimes you win, sometimes not.   So much charm in the characters, and different strats for each one.  You move, play cards, equip items on your own turn, but you can also strategize on your off turn, look at other players, and play cards to thwart them.  I also love the chat lines for each character, keeps the multiplayer civil and adds a delightful flavor to the game.  The endgame is fantastic, sometimes you've cleared all your quest to gain automatic entry into castle, other times you have to knock out another player, and still other times you sit with that banish card in hand to protect your prestige lead, a lot of paths to victory to contemplate, always tense!  To top this off, the developers challenge you to play them each week on Twitch, and they are such a fun group of people!  Join me in multiplayer!

												I have played a couple of single player games to learn the mechanics. and 15-20 multiplayer games.  Some of those have been with friends and some solo and all of them have been fun.Pros:-8 characters (more on the way?) with different skills and playstyles-Multiple win conditions 3 fairly easy ones and 1 that is kinda difficult to set up if you want to give yourself a challenge-If you can't win play the spoiler and just mess with others for fun. If the game gets stuck and doesn't progress you don't get the chest/key at the end.-No ranked yet (hope its coming soon)-Playing against a group of 3 in solo queue is fairly awkward when 3 work together. 1 person clearing out the castle and moving away so the player with the stones can just walk in and kill the king while the other 2 play bodyguard just isn't all that fun.   has happened a couple of times.Overall the game is very good and certainly worth the pickup.  Reminds me of Talisman a bit and can see where the inspiration could have come from and thats not a bad thing.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												I backed Armello on kickstarter (something I almost never do) based purely on the visuals, and boy am I glad I did. Aussie devs League of Geeks have done a exemplarary job - even the earliest build was a great deal better than most finished games, and they have continued to polish and refine the game, and built a thriving community of Armello enthusiasts that they have really listened to - this is kickstarter done RIGHT.The final release reflects that polish, with love and attention to detail oozing from every pixel. It's unique mix of turn based strategy with RPG and card game elements is backed up by lush, Studio Ghibli inspired visuals, gorgeous music and inspired (and in multiplayer excceptionally devious) gameplay. There's a engaging story - a mad king, a kingdom under threat from the Rot, and now eight playable heroes attempting to either hold the kingdom together, take it over or destroy it. Each hero is unique, can equip different gear, and hold traps, hard won followers or spells for battle against the opposing players - some cards can not just snatch victory from defeat but change the nature of the game or the victory conditions if played well. Combat is via nicely animated dice rolls (themselves modifyable by the cards in hand) and often deadly - it's not uncommon for two heroes to kill each other in the same bout, there's the creeping horror of the Rot to fight (or allow it to possess you) and then there's the mad King with his strange edicts affecting all players who eventually will destroy the Kingdom if players allow it. Multiple victory conditions abound here, and the wily player may need to change their overall tactics multtiple times in a single play through.The single player game against AI oponents in engaging enough, but it's in multiplayer that Armello truly shines. there are some utter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ moves available to the canny player, and interplayer communication, while cleverly limited, is more than enough to form (and break at a opportune moment) alliances. New players are well catered for, with excellent tutorials, and Armello is one of those rare games that's relatively easy to pick up but difficult to master. Cross platform support (it's available on PC and PS4 at launch, with ios and android coming) means you'll never lack for oponents. With it's sheer beauty, devious tactics and engaging gameplay Armello offers something different, and the incredible beauty of the game is made more astonishing by the fact it was created by such a small team - only 5 people who literally risked everything to bring the game to life. League of Geeks have to date offered unparalleled support, and knowing their devious minds I imagine ther'll be more than just tweaks and bug support in the future - the premise certainly lends itself to further expansion in the form of new heroes, extra cards snd perhaps bigger DLC.If you're a fan of board games, story driven RPG or strategy it's a must purchase - even for those who are more into other genres should definitely give this a go. I really can't recommend this superb game highly enough.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												If you like boardgames, or you just want to try a good one here on Steam, I suggest adding Armello to your wishlist.Here is a small list of the things I appreciate the most, that may help you decide if it's worth your interest:. different ways to win (adapt your strategy as you play). characters and stats modifiers (lot of combinations to experiment with) . dice (in great quantity with nice skins and effects). cards (to equip, use or "burn" before dice rolls to mitigate results). missions (to upgrade your stats, get better equipment and find followers). rules alteration (game changes if you are corrupted or not). prestige points mechanic (if you have the most you can influence the game). hand management, area control, stealth mechanics. random board generation, great art and nice soundtrack. well... there is more, but I think you should experience it ;DI find in Armello a great variety of elements I enjoy, so I keep coming back for more. I like trying a different strategy everytime and the fact that other characters will be added, definitely keeps my interest high. You can't play it hotseat, but that's because some mechanics don't make it possible. Even if I'm not playing with friends, my online experience is totally fine (no one ever left the game or purposely made the game end faster). If you have problems finding opponents, just keep an eye for special events organized by the LoG devs. Have fun Armellians!

number of helpful: 13 of 20 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												Pretty disappointing.I'm a big fan of board games, and was recommended this by a video reviewer I put good faith in.The game is gorgeous, and has a lot of charm, however the gameplay just doesn't hold up.Maybe it's because I listen to a lot of podcasts on game design, but this game was a fail. There's way too much luck involved, and most strategy you can conjure up hardly matters. The first two games I played I just happened to win because I was doing quests and playing cards when I could. A good game boils down to making interesting decisions, but when playing this game there's very few to be had. Most of it doesn't even matter. Do I pick the quest that gives me a 30% chance to get a Spirit stone and a spirit that I won't use, or do I pick the quest that gives me a not useful companion that gives the health I'll probably need? Do I win by killing the king because I happened to get some rot cards and died to the birds? Or do I kill the king because I got lucky enough to get two spirit stones from the dungeons and it was super easy to get the rest? It's just horribly dull.Gameplay boils down to. "Pick a character, use amulets/rings to give them small advantages." This gives you the illusion that there's strategies to explore, but in actuality it ends up more like this: Go to quest. Hopefully get something good out of it, or don't 'risk' it. (But good luck having any sort of a chance if you don't.) Explore dungeons, get random stuff, or don't. Get into fights. Win/Lose them depending on what equipment you happened to get and how lucky you were on your rolls. Someone on the board gets enough Rot/Spirit Stones/OP equips to kill king. Very little you can do to stop them. They fight the king and usually win. Sometimes they'll die in the process and someone else who did nothing all game will win instead. Game's over.I hope more people explore the interesting design space there is in a digital board game in the future, but this game felt like all style and not substance.If you're looking for a super casual game and have a high tolerance for swingy gameplay to play with a few buddies, then this is the game for you.If you want something anything deeper than that, look elsewhere.2.5/5

Posted: April 21
												This game is awesome!Armello is a board-type game with emphasis on the long game. The game's graphics and art style are incredible, with every card having a little animation bound to it and every character flaunting a personality without needing to say a word!The game shines when it comes to the long game. Stats that players have focused on for the entirety of the match often turn tables when it comes to the endgame, and gunning for repeated 'little victories' often ends badly. This is especially well done with the oddly satisfying combat animations, where you can see your plans play out perfectly.A frustrating part with this game is that it's very possible to be uttlerly screwed by RNG. If you're essentially untouchable, there's always some ridiculous 'win game' card that seems to apply to different scenarios of nearing victory.I'd get it if you don't mind being blue-shelled in Mario Cart; pretty much every game is memorable.

Posted: October 11, 2015
												If you enjoy board games, you should take a look at Armello -- it's a computer game that plays just like a board game.  It certainly can use a bit of tweaking of the AI.  Although there is some truth to the fact that the game is set up to favor a prestige or combat victory, that's not a huge issue.  And with some tweaking by the devs, that can certainly be adjusted.  It's not a big issue, but it's one that others have mentioned.  The only actual bug that I've encountered since release was one related to an achievement, and the devs were able to fix that issue.  It's fun, and light-hearted, and I definitely recommend it.  Check out any of the Let's Play videos on You Tube, to settle any doubts.

content:
Posted: April 26
												An excellent game that just keeps getting better.I have been playing this game with friends online for months now.  The games last about an hour, and are filled with cute, furry animals, backstabbing galore, and engaging strategy.  While frustrations can arise and luck can turn decidedly against you, we've found that even characters who suffer crippling misfortune early on can (and often do) bounce back to take the win.  However, you need to know your strategy, because a bad choice can lose it for you even when you are ahead.The nature of the game and relatively short duration of the matches allows players who normally have trouble with competatively backstabby games to enjoy this, making it a game we all have fun with.The multiple paths to victory make for a lot of fun.  You always have to keep an eye on the other player's progress towards other victory types even as you pursue the one you have chosen, and you often find yourself trying to keep as many paths open to you as you can.The game is cute as hell.  The characters are adorable.  And the fights are a lot of fun.  (I'll admit, I have spent an unreasonable extra amount on skins for characters and dice just to customize.  I don't play with random online groups, so I am not concerned about getting them through random drops.  It's easy enough to just buy exactly what you want in the steam community.)Instead of interest waning over the last couple months, we find ourselves still playing regularly and eagerly looking forward to content updates.  (We all can't wait for the eventual release of the Bandit Clan!)The only complaint that we have had is the occasional difficulty in first connecting to a group game.  Sometimes, one of the players will have to restart Steam and be re-invited in order for their connection to be stable enough to start the game.  But that is an extremely minor inconvenience, and once the game starts, everything is fine.  I know that those playing random online groups have had lag or connectivity issues, especially when the group includes people on opposite continents.  But if you have friends on Steam, I find there is no need to look to random groups to play.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 26, 2016
												Flowery review:I would have a hard time distilling what about armello makes it so great. There is the enchantingly crafted art style, the beautiful music, the fun varied strategies of differing hero's and victory types, it seems to really have it all. The only fault I find is that it is such a complete package and yet you are left simultaneously satisfied with the experience, and wanting more. Nuts and bolts review:Armello is a digital board game,  unlike most of its kind it seems distinctly aware that it is in fact digital and takes such advantage of its medium from the animated battles to the day/night cycle of turns, they really knew what they were doing with the tools afforded them. That said the game is not without fault mainly your problems will arise from sometimes excruciatingly long queue times to the fact that if a player disconnects for any reason there is no way to rejoin the game you were in. These slights are unfortunate and like many board games matches run for around an hour so you have to allot time to play a match and really hope you don't have any issues towards the end of a particular session or else you can lose all that time you spent. There is also an element of luck involved with winning in any particular match and some of the victory types are easier to achieve than others, however the variety they afford the games strategy overshadows the seeming unbalance of their ease. Pros:- music, art, and subjectively gameplay  are extraordinary- masterful execution of a digital board game taking advantage with animations and even important functions like the day night cycle that just couldn't be replicated on a traditional tabletop.- wonderful game to play with friends.Cons: - connection issues while not extremely common can really be a big bummer.- there is a fair amount of luck involved in actually winning the game.- speaking of winning some victories are far easier to achieve than others.- queue times can be abysmal at times added to the fact that matches run long and it could take one and a half to two hours to get from queue to finishing a match.ps. I don't normally write reviews more than a couple sentences long so I am aware this is a little disjointed and not the best but this game really deserves a longer explanation in my opinion let that serve as a recommendation in and of itself.

number of helpful: 24 of 42 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												I really wanted to like this - it's gorgeous, generally well-polished, and I really like the idea of a strategy game where you only have one character (avoiding the usual problem with something like Civilization, where turns get longer until the game isn't fun).Unfortunately, the strategic depth just isn't there.  The game has harsh coin-flippy rewards and a terrible snowballing potential, meaning your result on the first challenge (where it is most like a coin flip) determines the course of the rest of the game.  This, and some of the supporting systems, lead to the best strategy being to simply stack your highest stat as high as possible.  Three of the four stats eventually lead to a massive pile of prestige, which lets you win by default a few turns before any of the other victory conditions are possible (without extreme luck).  Better balance between the victory conditions would help, but ultimately the problem is that the game's randomness can only be steared when you're ahead.There are other problems with the game - cards are samey, lots of useful information is animated away before it can be read, and the UI has some serious rough edges (burning cards has a pile of issues, in particular).  But the core problems with the strategy are what kill it.

												Gameplay video + Impressions below


YouTube™ Video: Armello: For The Throne #1 

			Views: 379		

			I check out Armello from League of Geeks which just released on Steam. This is a great RPG mixed without board game elements. I'm addicted to it right now!		

This game is a new addiction for me. The game has a surprising amount of layers to it's mechanics.Games last roughly up to 1 hour so it's a nice short table top feel. 4 possible victory conditions which you need to try and acheive while also hindering others as best you can. Combat is dealt with via dice but you can swing it in your own favour more by clever use of terrain, stealth, followers, equipment, spells and traps. The animations during combat are pretty damn beautiful. 8 characters currently in game (hopefully more in future) each with a special power you can make use of to help you find success. Love this game to bits worth every penny and highly recommended.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												Was skeptical about getting this game about 5 months back, but then the steam summer sale came by and I decided to try it out, not many board like games come to interest for me. This one changed that, but this review isn't going to be a thumbs up for a handful of reasons.Pros:The game has a good tutorial on showing the mechanics of the game. (Compared to others I've played)It has various victory conditions which keeps it from being a dull (kill everyone else) game.Characters with different stats and equipment that can change the flow of the match in a single turn.And many others.They did not implement an actual chat system into the game. This is actually good because I'm sure you all know how kids online act when they can't get their way in a game. Instead, the chat in-game is by pre-set commands that can be used to praise a player for a good move or to warn players etc etc.Cons:When learning the game from a few AI matches, the AI doesn't seem overall challenging, they don't set many traps or use cards to boost themselves sometimes.Online matches will never be fun unless your playing with friends you know or they fix the current issue. For some reason online skirmishes allow you to invite your friends to fill slots if need be. This is what really breaks the game. In my case I had a 3V1 match because one player had 10+ Prestige, the other 2 players played most of their trap cards on me and prevented me from getting to quests by sitting near each other near it, but let the 10+ prestige player wonder about getting to dungeons to boost themselves. So the match ended with the prestige leader winning by favor of help. The game is good, but can be better with a few simple fixes, until then I can't give this game a good review because online matches is pretty much what this game is all about.

number of helpful: 56 of 104 people (54%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												I first noticed this game when it was up for a possible free PS+ game a number of months ago.  I voted for it without hesitation and have been telling myself to buck up and buy it ever since it didn't get the votes needed.    After purchasing the game and spending a few hours in it, I realized that I probably didn't know what everyone else knew when they didn't vote for it.I want to talk about the positives first.PROS:-Great graphical style.  This game really is beautiful in an indie game sort of way.-Brilliant setting.  I was immediately immersed in the setting and the world.  A pretty substantial feat for such a small game, with such little information.  I found myself wanting more and more setting and story information.-A unique take on the classic "Talisman" boardgame.-Variety of intriguing characters to play.-Variety of unlocks and gear to modify your charactersYou'll notice that nowhere in the "PROS" section was there anything to do with actual gameplay.  Gameplay is atrocious.  The sheer amount of lack of control you have is absurd.  You will spend the majority of the game just watching random terrible things happen to your character, that you have no control over, which can very easily chain react and spiral out of control.  The game also punishes you at every opportunity.  You get to draw cards at the beginning of your turns, up to a hand limit, but most of the time those cards are useless for both their icons and abilities.  You are also not able to simply discard cards.  You have to either use them or burn them (trading a die roll for a guaranteed result depicted on the card).  Which means that you will end up losing multiple "Perils" or events just to get rid of cards that you don't want, hoping to draw new good cards, and then invariably drawing more bad cards.  That is just one aspect of the game.  Let's look a possible sequence of events.  And when I say "possible" I mean common.-King presents two laws for the current leader to choose from (random)-Draw cards at the beginning of your turn from three different piles, of which none are useful to equip or burn (random)-Encounter a Peril in which you roll dice to succeed at (random)-Fail the Peril because it is a Wits challenge and you are a Fight character and don't roll well enough (random)-Get warped to the farthest Dungeon away from that Peril-Encounter the Peril on the Dungeon, in which you roll dice again (random)-Fail the peril and suffer the consequences-Encounter the Dungeon (which is essentially a die roll where you can get gold, treasure, a spirit stone, magic points, a parasite (that takes control of your character and moves it), or a "Bane" which is a Rot-stricken enemy.  End up with a Bane, from the die roll (random)-Get moved off the dungeon (possibly even further from where you were trying to go), because you encountered a Bane.-Bane attacks you and initiates Combat which is a bunch of dice rolls (random)-Lose the combat to be killed and warped back to your starting location.Seven of those steps heavily involve random draws or dice rolls, and that doesn't even include the random Quest attempts, and those steps that did not involve a random element were simply suffering the consequences of the previous random step.There are those who will defend this game saying that it is a board game and you can't do a board game without excessive random elements.  That's wholly and completely incorrect.  I am a boardgamer more than a videogamer with an absurd collection.  There are plenty of boardgames that reduce the amount of luck you have to endure in order to increase the amount of strategy you can use.Instead of dropping money on Armello, go take a handful of dice and throw them around your kitchen table for a while.  You will likely have more fun, have less wasted time and money, and can move onto something better.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												Armello, or Furry Chess, is a turn-based strategy game modeled on tabletop games of old. You'll find it whimsical and charming, I'm sure. STUFF WOT I LIKED AN' THAT  Lots of fun, nice variation of characters, eight in the base game and four more in the DLC. Plenty of replayability thanks to the characters, the unlockables and the new Custom Match option GORGEOUS art style, I honetly can't stress enough how beautiful this game is Nice integration of diceroll and card-based mechanics into the structure Perfect in terms of complexity: This game has enough depth to be continuously interesting and challenging without being as beardy and convoluted as games such as Civilisation. It's very easy to understand the basics. Tutorial is very well done, broken into four short, modified game sessions that introduce a character and a couple of key mechanics at a time. There's also a great guide to the gameplay available in game, even in the middle of a match. Sure beats having to pull up the wiki in a pinch. Doesn't drag on too long - The nature of the game means the timer runs down, so matches won't run on for hours on end. This is perfect for more casual players who don't want to dedicate three hours to one single playthrough,  like me Be warned, though, multiplayer matches will take a while longer. NOT SO GUD M8  Public multiplayer is a bit of a♥♥♥♥♥ Since there's such a tiny playerbase matchmaking can take a pretty long time sometimes. However, the devs were canny enough to pre-empt this, and you are able to play offline games while you queue Don't hold your breath for the Kickstarter DLC, since it's only going to be available when the mobile version launches... whenever that may be.Overall, I'd say this game is definitely worth your time, whether you're a fan of strategy games or not. It would make a good gateway into the genre, with its excellent balance of depth and simplicity. It's a very unique little game with a lot of charm and effort put into it, and it's obvious the devs really care about this game working.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
												Armello is a beautiful but relatively simple board game.Armello excels in aesthetics and music but for some gamers (even tabletop gamers) the gameplay can be a bit lacking. How and if you win the game are heavily dependent on RNG. This can be very frustrating to players who want a more strategy based game.RNG determines the outcome of dice rolls, dice rolls determine the outcome of battles, battles determine the outcome of the overall game. To be fair, dice rolls can be manipulated by cards in your hand and by your equipped cards. However, what cards you get is up to RNG and you may end up with poor equipped items or a lack of the card type you desire for any particular battle. Also, the amount of cards you can hold is determined by your wit stat, which always seems to be lacking unless you are a rat (at which point you have very little of any other stat).Aside from RNG, my one qualm with this game is the speed. Waiting for turns to go through can be excruciating. While I recommend watching the characters (as you may find ways to trump them), there are times when all the characters are in stealth... So you will sit there, listening to them rummage around for a bit, waiting for your turn while almost nothing happens visually. I HIGHLY recommend turning on 'Quick AI Encounters' after your first game. This will speed up the turns quite a bit.There are 4 victories you are capable of attaining: prestige, kingslayer, spirit stone, and rot. By far, the easiest victory to attain is the prestige victory; it depends more on strategy than any other victory. Rot is the hardest victory to attain; it is highly reliant on RNG. If you are a completionist, or even just want to attain all the victory achievements, you will be kept busy for quite a while. However, if you are fine playing it once through, it will maybe keep you occupied an hour or two.I recommend the game if you like to fight against the odds and have decent luck with RNG.I do not recommend the game if you hate RNG dependent mechanics (for which there are many).

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20
												A great little role playing strategy game with cute graphics, excellent mood music and lots of replayability including online multiplayer.Armello is a well designed game whose main game mechanic revolves around traversing a fixed map of varying terrain and obstacles with your player character.  It is a turn based game which allows you build deceptively complex strategy with a little bit of luck.  Any person familiar with table top role playing will understand the mechanics of Armello well.  Gain cards in your hand and play them with the appropriate resources (money, magic and in some circumstances prestige or even health).  Move through the map gaining resources and doing quests (by landing on the quest tile and passing a short game of chance).The story behind the game is simple.  Armello's ruler, the king, is dying of rot, an evil infestation making him go mad.  4 seperate factions are vying to take control (wolf, bear, rat and rabbit) through their agents.  The base game comes with 2 agents for each faction.  They are well balanced and will require unique game play strategy to win.  The gameplay is relatively short when you get the hang of it.  Online mutiplayer is not a mode I have tried therefore I can't comment on this aspect of the game.That said I very much like this game.  It isn't an expensive game but the developers have contunually been adding elements and tinkiering with game play.  There are expansions which add 1 new agent for each faction and a soundtrack, but these aren't neccessary to have many hours of fun playing the game.

( literally i haven't seen any updates that did cause any hiccups or dissheartening changes! )The Dev's do listen to their backer's and any of their customers, finding the best solutions into improving this game as a whole.Honestly, this game holds a special place in my heart as it has been very humbling to watch this game come alive and grow. I can't thank them enough for doing such an amazing job, while many many other indie titles out there currently aren't living up to their expectations. a few come to mind but i shall not name any of them sense they're not part of what we're here to talk about!honestly i don't see very many cons to this game. the only things that can come to mind is that well.. it's characters are animals? ( if you really aren't into that style of characters )that's all that comes to mind really. it's an extremely fleshed out game. everything is there for a reason. every step can mean life or death. Why haven't you gotten this game yet? go get it.

												NEW and Updated Opinions on the game Armello...I started off with some pretty low expectations and rushed a review out displaying my first impressions of the game as fast as I could.... This needs to be balanced out.- Because prestiege is the easiest, even with different cards, the game can get repetitive sometimes- Even though there are alot of cards, I would like to see more, like you would see in card games... But this is a personal gripe of mine.- Would like to see bandit clan sometime soonThe UglyNot really much that wasn't allready mentioned in the Bad SectionOverallI do enjoy the game alot more than before, but at times it leaves me wanting more content in this game...

content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												I've played quite a lot while this game was in early-acces and finally decided to create a review since it's just fully released. So here's my quick review :DPros:- A lot of strategy: There is a time limit of around 1.5 minute online per turn. You really need this time to complete your turn properly. Every move is a decision. - Great artwork: The game just looks absolutely amazing. Especially the cartoonish artwork in the 'fight scenes'.- RNG: The game works with random cards you get in your hand, this makes every match a different experience. The fight system works with dices, so you can get lucky or very unlucky, but overall, the player with the best odds wins most of the battles.The RNG part is something you may or may not like. I personally liked the RNG part, because the winner of the match is still mostly decided by skill, not RNG. Cons:- Slow: In an online game you are waiting most of the time. This isn't that much of a problem since you can still play cards while it's not your turn, but still, one game takes about one hour. - Matchmaking: Getting into an online match can take some time.EDIT: As of now, the wait timers are very reasonable.Overall this game is worth your money if you like Strategy games and can enjoy the RNG parts.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Having been a beta backer and following this since it came out on Kickstarter I've been playing a few games of Armello and I'm impressed with what's come out so far.The world is immersive, the animations are smooth, the artwork is stunning and the characters feel balanced. It's a very high quality creation. League of Geeks have created something very unique in execution and deserve plaudits for that.That being said, I want to point out that League of Geeks are making a "digital board game" and that shows. If it was a physical board game, I'd recommend it in a heartbeat without a second thought. As a video game though it suffers from a short game time and a lack of rewarding play. With friends it's a lovely experience, but the single player feels very quick and lacks the level of strategy that is expected of a modern strategy game. The AI also feels basic and a little suicidal at times, attacking higher level opponents or players despite little chance of success.There are bugs, but it's in Early Access, and I've only had 1 total crash in around 10-15 games some multi-player some single player. The only noticable other bug was I retained Magic when I should have lost it. League of Geeks have got the fundamentals of a board game down and added so much prettiness on top that I definitely recommend the game. Go into it thinking "I'm buying a digital board game to play with friends" and it's worth it. But if you plan on playing it entirely solo I'd hold back for a little more content

content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												             As a digital board game Armello’s goal is clear. It tries to be casual enough to allow the players to get into the game with ease, but tries to be complex enough not to let its mechanics become boring after a short period of time. The game tries to reach for a wider audience and as a competitive game it deserves one, despite some of the more annoying problems that the multiplayer has to offer.As a newly born world and lore, Armello only teases the players with its potential leaving them wanting more. The story options are limitless and I can’t stop myself what a positive influence a story mode could have on this game.                Armello has the enchanting atmosphere of a fairy tale with the brutal gameplay of a deathmatch and the tactical decision making of a strategy, but with its fate trapped in the cage that comes with small budget indie development.Pros:+ Charming world+ Awesome heroes+ Lovely 2D animations, art style and UI design+ Great music+ Easy to learn+ Good enough mechanics to stay interesting for a whileCons:- A small map with no configurations available- Victory conditions aren’t properly balanced- Slow multiplayer- No chat- The game is crying for a story modeRead the full review at:http://thegameslashers.blogspot.ro/2015/09/armello-review.html

Early Access Review
								In this 4-player competetive board game you take the role of one of four heroes from the great animal clans (wolf, bear, rabbit and rat) each having their own strenghts and weaknesses. I could use a lot of words describing the game mechanics , but then again, just watch this video from Pinstar: 


YouTube™ Video: Pinstar Plays Armello (Evil Rat ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Run) 

			Views: 514		

			Armello is an early access turn based strategy game. Feels like Redwall, plays like a board game. Very fun. Take a look! Skip to 7:00 to jump right to the action.		

Pros:Play online in public games, against friends in private games, or offline against AI opponents.Four different win-conditions allows for various strategies.Gorgeous graphics style and sound.Very well thought out card and dice system.Playing time is approximately an hour, so you can easily squeeze in a match in your busy schedule. Cons:Although strategy is involved, so is a lot of luck.No hot-seat mode (the game mechanics won't allow this, because cards are hidden from other players and it's possible to perform actions when it's not your turn).No LAN- or dedicated server-mode, which is really a shame. Dependency on a central server is never a good thing. Hopefully the devs will fix this.

content:
Posted: March 21
												This game is easily one of the most well done digital board games made.  That's not to say I don't have my small issues with it, but they're easy to over look.  With 4 victory paths, the game has the potential to be very interesting with every new game.  The reason I say "potential" is a lot of the matches tend to have mostly people who will just try and cheese their way to a win through prestige.  It's understandable as it's the least risky way to play, but it leads to a more boring match.Down to the brass tacks here, Armello is, as mentioned, a digital board game for 4 players.  Featured as of writing are 4 seperate factions each with their own focus on seperate skills, and 3 unique playable characters in each faction.  A quick example, The Wolf Clan focuses more on combat abilities, while The Rat Clan focuses more on subterfuge.  Each of these clans have 1 goal, become the new ruler of the land of Armello.  There are multiple ways to accomplish this goal:Killing the blighted King and taking the throne;Banishing the King and his corruption through the gathering of 4 sacred Spirit Stones;Having the most Prestige Points when the king dies from his Blight (or if another player kills the king and also dies in the same combat);or corrupting yourself even more than the King and seizing the throne.Throughout your turn-based adventure through the land of Armello you'll own villages, explore dungeons and fight both monsters and players.  Every turn, if not at a full hand, you'll draw cards from your choices of three piles until your hand is full.  These include equipment cards, followers, trickery and subterfuge, items and magic.  These add a lot of strategy to your play and help to alleviate the RNG elements of some parts.  On top of this, these is also a meta game before the game starts where you can select different rings and medallions for your character that offer small stat boosts and passive abilities, mostly specializing you towards a certain type of victory.There's a lot left to describe in terms of gameplay elements, but I've done my best to touch on the major factors here.  This game is easily worth the asking price, and it's always been a blast every time I launch it.  There's a certain depth to the game that keeps it fun, but it's still accessible to new players.  Great art, and the light touch of lore for those who look for it is a nice treat.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												Armello is a beautifully crafted game with easy to learn rules/controls, gorgeous and vibrant art and a soundtrack that could calm the nerves of raging bull. There are still a few minor bugs with the gameplay BUT this is easily forgivable since it is still an Early Access game.Speaking as someone that does not play many tile based and turn based games, I was a little hesitant when jumping in for the first time. The game, however, is very charming, not overloading you with books of dialogue about the characters or the kingdom. It feels more like an emergent narrative that allows the player to decide there own fate during the game play. It's very replayable as there are many unlockable items that can change your strategy when in game. There are also more characters confirmed for later release which looks very exciting.The Art, as mentioned, is amazing and consistent all the way through. One thing that I do love is that they have 3D animations for tile game play and traditional 2D animations for combat. Any fan of 'Redwall' or 'Mice and Mystics' will be able to jump into this with no problems.Definitely worth a look for anyone that enjoys tabletop and roleplay games!Update: I still find myself coming back to this game. It's still replayable and with the extra content that's being added in new patches it guarentees theres always something new to try in each game.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												Armello is beautiflly crafted, well thought out digital board game, which is NOT like Catan, but more like Arkham Horror, including the horror. However, instead of real teamwork, you race towards your favored method of winning and achieve it, before someone else slays the king.Armello looks and feels gorgeous. On the mechanics part, they are easy to understand and use and, as soon as you get the hang of it, you will find burning cards is a wonderful feature which you should use often to get many different cards. On the "bad" side, even though the maps are randomly created, there are not enough features to make a map feel special. For a boardgame, this is no problem, but a digitalized one could add more spice. I remember the digital Catan game, where you could zoom into the lands and see people work. But this is a minor nitpick, as the cards and effects do more than enough worldbuilding for themselves.After a few games versus bots I will try myself against humans, to see how they play the game. Maybe there is a cooperation element I did not yet discover, since it seems as one winner takes it all.A map editor for custom maps, rules and restrictions would be a great addition, as the one single mode with random map and enemies can grow old rather quickly. House rules and stuff, so to speak. But let us give the game time to settle and gather input.
