content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												Played several hours in offline mode, as some of my achievements will show. If I were to sum up this game, I would refer to it as a "fixed" Dokapon Kingdom. Dokapon Kingdom is a fusion of board game and JRPG that - while immensely fun - was simply too long, too random, and encouraged players to jerk each other over far too much. Despite these flaws, Dokapon Kingdom is probably one of my favorite games despite the few situations where I find time to play it.Armello brings down the randomness quite considerably as battles are no longer a roshambo match and instead focus on dice and card usage, all determined by stats. The complicated class system is replaced by heroes that determine your abilities. The game length feels to be around 30 minutes a game as opposed to the 20 something hours that Dokapon Kingdom can take. While you can certainly attack the other player, no one ever feels the need to quit since the game is so short. But these changes take out some of the charm of a game like this, if you're going to make a direct comparison to Dokapon Kingdom. There's less a sense of an adventure, the board is really small and you never feel invested in your towns since they change ownership so quickly. The lack of global objectives and the use of personal ones can also lead to the sense of a lack of interaction sometimes and your teammates become more random encounters rather than opponents if everyone goes different victory routes. Armello is nice, a nice light game to pick up your day. Probably not a game I'll invest 100+ hours in its current state, but a game I'll play every now and then.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												A visually stunning and impressive game. The game is a sort of adventure game of intrigue, combat, and politics. 8 characters across 4 clans of animals are playable in a game to either kill, or cleanse the king.Each clan has their own ring set to expand upon their playstyles to alter how you play. Amulets allow you to give a bonus stat at the start or a head start on some of the winning conditions in the game.Gameplay follows a lot of your adventure board game stylings such as super dungeon adventure. The map is essentially a big diamond with various tiles for different effects. Each player has a quest to start with from 3 pickable ones. If you get to the tile you can either risk a roll for a bonus item but if you fail you will lose things such as health, magic, prestige, etc. This is all the while fighting off banes brought from void dungeons, other players, and occasionally the kings own guards. Each day has two turn cycles of day and night. Each day the king loses 1 of his 9 health until he dies on his own and at night his rot level grows by one. This means there are 18 turns in total until he dies. In that time you have 4 ways to win the game. The first is that you have the highest prestige when the king dies on his own or by someone killing the king who dies by the kings hand in that same fight. The second is that you kill the king without dying to him. The third is to kill the king with more rot than him (Rot victory). Lastly is the cleansing victory which has you gathering 4 spirit stones found across the map occasionally or by finding one in the dungeon tiles.Combat in the game is an interesting concept as well. Each character has 4 stats to work with, Fight increases the number of dice you can use in combat/defending, Body determines your characters health points, wits increase card carrying capacity and peril dice, and spirit determines how much magic points you get at night to use on spell cards. Upon entering combat you roll dice equivolent to your fight stat against your targets fight dice. Any bonuses from equipment are considered as well. rolls determine your attack and defense numbers and are compared against your targets. Fights can end in double KO's.Each turn you can draw cards up to your wits number. Cards come in 3 flavors: Items come in the form of equipment, or useable one time items that require gold to equip or use. Magic cards allow you cast the spell on them for it's magic cost. The last card set is trickery, they allow you to alter events or cause trouble for a gold cost.The soundtrack enhances the mood of the game quite well. It suits the fantasy medieval setting very well.Now there are some gripes with the game in some aspects. For the most part each character has a unique playstyle that doesn't have a glaring detriment. However there are two characters who's specific abilities aren't all that helpful to you in progressing towards a win condition. The first is the rat mercurio, whose ability of taking a gold from a settlement owner when he takes it himself starts becoming useless in the later parts of the game. The second is the bear Sana, her ability is that she can use her spirit stat as her fight stat when she fights anything that's corrupted. This is a big loss for her in the early game as the only thing that's corrupted early are banes (rot birds that spawn from dungeons), so unless someones going for a rot victory or you are going to try and fight the king, her ability is practically useless until the very late game.A second issue i have with the game is that you have a visual range of about 8 tiles of the board for clear visability. If you zoom out, the game gives a kind of through the clouds look which blurs your vision a bit. For a game that's supposed to be board game like, it would be nice to have an option to view the entire board clearly (outside of stealthed enemies). It is mitigated by quick keys to jump to certain sections of the board, but it would have been something nice to have.The last one i have is that the online is a little to be desired. As a whole it functions, but you can't host an online match until you get a friend in your game nor is there a list of available games. Your options are look for randoms which with the low player count can take some time, or invite a friend then you can have others join you or fill with AI.I would recommend the game for anyone who enjoys adventure like board games but don't want to spend the 70-150 dollars it costs to buy them. The average game length is about 50 minutes to an hour and no suspend feature for online so make sure to have some time to play through to the end.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								Update after the 1.5 Patch: With the constant game updates since release (new cards, changed mechanics, multiplayer progression...) and the new heroes, this game only improved! A fantastic digital board game!---Armello is a digital board game set in a medieval fantasy world inhabited by animals.The king is afflicted with a dark curse that slowly drives him insane and eventually will kill him. The 4 clans (Wolves, Rats, Rabbits and Bears) now try to gain the upper hand (or paw) and fight each other for the throne of Armello.You play as one of the clans' heroes, like Thane the wolf warrior or Sana the bear druid. (4 heroes available right now, 4 additional heroes + 4 Kickstarter backer-exclusive heroes already confirmed)Traveling over the board in a turn-based system, you draw cards (items, spells, trickeries/traps, followers...), conquer villages and explore dungeons for gold (to play your cards) and treasures, complete quests related to your hero's backstory, fight monsters and other heroes for gold and prestige in a dice-based battle system and try to raise your stats (like number of dice, life points, etc).In the end, you can face the king in battle. Or banish him with magical spirit stones. Or just collect the most prestige and wait for him to die. There are many different ways to win the game.A special feature of Armello is the rot. Your hero can become affected by the same curse as the king, completely changing the course of battles. If both you and your enemy are affected by rot, the hero with more rot gains the other hero's amount of rot as bonus dice. If your rot is high enough, it makes battles against other heroes or even the king way easier (when you suddenly roll 5 more dice than your enemy). On the other hand, you lose health every turn and can't use the healing stone circles anymore. Managing your rot  is an important part of the game.There is no best hero or best way to win the game. Some lucky dice rolls, bad card draws or finding a good follower in a dungeon can and will make you adapt your strategy.Maybe you were the prestige leader the whole game and lose everything by accidently attacking a King's Guard. But then, a quest and some dark magic increase your rot and you suddenly have more than the king. Now all you need is more fighting power. With a bit of luck, you'll find enough gold in that dungeon over there to equip the expensive battleaxe you found two turns ago. Or wait until next turn and try to draw a card that lets you steal the rabbit's morning star...No game is the same as the last.The game has come a long way since the beginning of the Backer-Alpha and lots of things have been improved during the Backer-Beta (like a complete rework of the rot system). Now, with some of the things added and changed in the latest build, this Early Access version definitely is the best version of this game so far. If everyone keeps submitting bug reports and suggestion to make the game better and the developers at League of Geeks keep up their great work (and I'm sure they will), this game can become one of the best digital board games in years.------Pros:Great artstyleLikeable charactersBeautiful animated cardsEasy to learnSurprising strategic depthInteresting dice battle systemGreat 4 player Online-Multiplayer (maybe still a bit unstable, but steadily improving)Cons:Bad luck can make you lose in a single turnAI sometimes too easy to beat/no difficulty settingsSome heroes/strategies actually ARE stronger than others right now, but with more cards and balance changes, I'm sure this will be fixed after Early AccessIf you like board games, fantasy settings or animals, or you're just looking for a relaxing game, I can definitely recommend Armello!

												Armello is an awesome game and I will definitely recommend it to my friends if being asked. In the world of Armello, you're going to act as one of the four clans, fighting for the crown while the lion king is creeping to death.I love this story and the various goals for winning, it offers you multiple ways to achieve your success, besides that, you can play Armello with AI or with different human players, which means a lot of possibilities in the game, and you can play it for many rounds without feeling bored.Armello is easy to pick-up, but hard to master. 												What I liked:- Addictive- Easy to pick up (easier if youve played tabletop games before)- Art is wonderfully vibrant, all cards are beautiful and animated!- Plenty of players online- Fast Download Time (Game is ~1.1GB)- Character progression and customization- Many different playstyles, all viable.What I disliked: - As with all card and some board games, luck of the draw can make your day or break it.- Some hands in the beginning of a match can end your chances of winning- The amount of furry porn this game made me download (~1.1 TB)- No reconnect button if you lose connection- Chat system is comprised of pre-selected communications (Nice! , Bad Luck! , Thanks!)If you like board games, buy it. content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												This is absolutely a board game.It has a tiny 9x9 hexagon map. Single player games generally last an hour for ~16 turns. It does a few things you couldn't do in a physical board game, like hide player units when they're in stealth and change the writing on cards.I was somewhat disappointed at first because I prefer my turn based strategy/RPG hybrids to be sprawling fantasy 4x empire builders. This is so good I'm very happy it isn't. The game mechanics are really fun and well balanced, while the artwork and character design is absolute top notch excellent. One of the things I didn't notice in videos for this game is the card artwork. It's by far my favorite part. The cards are all animated. The animations are short, but they give a lot of life to the cards. Check out teleport, it's one of my favorites. Can you find the frog?Singleplayer has a lot of longevity, there are so many neat steam achievements to get. One thing that could be improved is the single player AI. There's nothing obviously wrong with it, it seems competent. but the simple fact is I end up winning the vast majority of games played against it, even though I'm usually just achievement hunting without much care to weather I win or lose. It would be nice if it got a tuneup.Update July 11th, 2016: I've played a few multiplayer matches. I've been able to find a game quickly even late at night, and the game worked well without much lag. The game is well paced even when a few players were slow to take their turns.

content:
Posted: January 15
												This game has potential but it hasn't been reached.There is a bug in here and certain mechanics that merits from me recommending this game even after playing it for about 80 hours.A major bugWhen a player leaves a game in the middle of an "action" taking place, it can ruin the whole game for anyone playing that game. The NPC have no idea what to do. Once the player leaves, the npc stand still forever. That round of a game is gone.This bug has been hanging since the beginning of the game's inception but it has improved over time.But don't let that stop someone when you do them wrong. They would abuse it for the chance to ruin your game.Order of TurnIf you are the first to go in any game, you have an advantage over the player going last. In fact, going last leaves you at a bigger disadvantage to anyone going before you.This is due to how some of the cards are balance. There are "Spells" card that put some players at a disadvantage. Some of them that  hinders movement on the board.If you are first, you will NEVER be hindered. The day and night cycle will always give you the advantage to be reset your status. You will always go the maximum distance and no one can do anything about that.You will also have the advantage of casting these spell to hinder the players as well.PlayerMost of the game is played online for a better experience.However, that can be turn against you when this game is suppose to be a free for all.You will find games where it is 2v1 or 3v1! It is not a enjoyable experience to be bullied.There is no Soloqueue.And also not to mention the AFK botter who are farming the keys and chest of this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Aloha Steam-ers and Stream-ers,Warning: The following will be presented first by a short blurb about my thoughts on the game, followed by a very dense reflection on the aspects of the game and all the nuances I have come to find during this Early Access Period. If you just want the short and sweet Review, Look only to the first paragraph. If you want the Essay...continue ^_^--Blurb--Currently Early Access: Not all features unlocked, not everything is in final game form, soul of the game and it's potential is immediately apparent. Play with a friend or by yourself.Game of Thrones meets Redwall for an epic ride through the lands of Armello in the format of Settlers of Catan...without all the tradingThis turn based strategy desktop gaming with a furry overtone will have you forming secret coalitions, laying deadly traps, braving forgotten dungeons, hunting deadly creatures, and praying to the RNG gods for their blessing. With multiple methods to achieve victory and only having 16 turns for you to accomplish one of those conditions, this mad dash for the crown will leave everyone scrambling till the last second.Goal of the game: Become King....sounds easy right?How to reach that goal:Kill the King and take the throne by forceBanish the King with magic of the WyldWin the loyalty and support of the peopleEmbrace the Rot and become the new Dark LordPros (imo)-Achievement System: Good long term investment if you wish to discover different strategies of play-Card and Dice combat: Good Planning is countered by Good Luck and vice-versa, makes sure everyone has a chance-Questing System: RPG style of character building along multiple routes to aid you in your victory path-PVP and PVE Adventuring: Fight other players or monsters to enhance your chances of winning-Graphics: Beautiful art with minimal animations subtly draws you into the game as you play-Not a "Winner's Game": you've played them before. Everyone who spends 15 turns to attempt to achieve victory has a chance to achieve victory. Lovely aspect of the luck based combat system.Cons (imo)-Combat Log: When first learning the game, you'll be swamped by a feeling of "what just happened" a lot. The combat log is small and hard to keep track of since every turn is packed with so much information.-Early Acces Bugs: Not completed yet, so if you're looking for a finished and polished game, you will not be getting that right off the bat. Community and Developers are working to iron them out and plan on improving the game throughout it's life span-Hidden Information: Lots of things about this game I don't know about. I don't know what the goal is, payment plans, development schedules, etc. Putting a lot of trust into the developers. However, considering how much they've done with the game already, I don't think that trust is misplaced.-Addicting: This is just me.....I put it as a con cause you may have a life....I love being addicted to this game.Overall Impression: Love the game, can't wait to see what else they do with it. More characters, cards, etc. So much more is planned for this game and I am enjoying seeing what comes down the pipe.--End of Blurb-- (Yeah...THAT was the short stuff ^_^)--Beginning of Rant and Praise--The once beautiful land of Armello was ruled by a wise and benevolent King. The inherent animosity of the Bear, Rabbit, Rat, and Wolf clans were tamed under his rule. With fair hand and heart, the King provided a place where all would be welcome and war would cease. All was well and right in the world...until the Rot came. Dark magic permeated the land, spawning terrible creatures that roamed the night, preying on the innocent and frightened. With the King's guard called away to confront this evil, another evil arose to line their pockets with gold and wet their blades with blood. Without their protection, the citizens were terrorized by criminals and bandits who thrived in the chaos abound. The once peaceful coalition between the clans have been torn asunder and fear for the future has called the clans to call out for heroes, namely YOU, to claim the throne of a Mad King.The writing in this game, when I take the time to look at it, is simple and straight forward. There is enough spirit and wit (there is a pun there) in this game to give it a kind of life that seems like the next generation of "board game" feeling. Growing up with a large family, we had lots of chances to play board games with each other and the once powerful alliance of one game quickly became a bitter rivalry the next. With the dawn of video gaming (that should indicate how old I am that I witnessed this transition), that tabletop game feeling seems to have died out. Why bother playing with such a static field when the bells and whistles of computers and consoles are so much more appealing. Somehow, this game has found a balance between those two aspects. With the graphics of a console game with the core mechanics of a tabletop board game. What's improved is that nobody is saying "that's against the rules" and digressing into a 30 minute discussion about what the manual means. The rules are programmed in, and everyone is always subjugated to the same ruling. Maybe that will change in the future when they allow us to create our own games with "house rules", but it doesn't change the fact that the rules are always going to be implemented fairly.That's another big part of this game. Fairness. Although there are some things that need balancing still, the goal is to legitimately allow every player a chance at victory. Emphasis on "Chance". The luck system in the game keeps it so that there isn't really a "sure way" to win every time, you need to learn and adapt to the cards being played, how the board is laid out, and what your opponents are doing. Despite this, a "good player" who has strategy and executes their goals effectively will have a distinct advantage over a player who relies completely on luck. So there is a way to be a "good player" in a game and reduce the chances of someone sneaking a victory over you by being "just lucky". That being said, there are a few aspects of the game that could use improvement. Many of them are mentioned and developed by the discussion boards and forums. The developers seem to be actively interested in the concerns of their gaming community and address each presented problem in some way. Again, the game is still in early access, so there is much to be done, but I have yet to feel like this is a game that is already set in stone, and I am going to just play it. From the time I heard about the game to the time I started playing it, which was only a few weeks, the YouTube videos are already showing that what was mentioned has been addressed and fixed thanks to the watchful eyes of the gamers. It's a very rewarding experience to be a part of.One of the sad things is being forever in Queue to find a public game. Hopefully that will change when more people find out about the game and it begins to hit a larger audience. Playing with the AI, though easy to get a victory out of, allows you to polish and attempt strategies to see how the random luck player would do against you, but I am dying to test out my strategies on other players and interacting with them in this environment. The chat features are somewhat limited, but considering just how cut-throat this game is, perhaps it is best that players are not allowed to rage at each other with harsh words and foul language. This game really is "you vs the world", and though sometimes it may seem like every other character is just bashing you, you can still win. If 3 players decide to pick on only one person, and trolls will be trolls, there is still the chance that one person can sneak into the castle and Kill the King. Hopefully, if they change the Rot Victory prerequisites, if one person is being bullied in game, they can get ROT and win!..(am out of space)

												VERY well done game.The combat, graphics, story... Basically EVERYTHING works with this game.That being said, its lacking a certain kind of polish.In my brief time of playing, I have been constantly plagued by audio bugs, such as crackling audio, delayed audio, doubled and sometimes tripled audio, certain sounds not muting when the sound sliders are set to 0 (mainly the life-stones and the banes noises).Another grievance I have with this game, is the lack of a proper graphical options menu, instead you have the choice of, "Very Low" to "Very High" settings. I am aware that this is a duel launch game also made for the Sony PlayStation, but this does not excuse this. ALLLL of that being said tho, do I hate this game? No, far from it, I adore this game, to the point that in my brief time playing, it has managed to work its way into my heart,  topping off my favorite games, at least for the time being. On a side note, they really nailed the, "board game" aspect with the Dice roles. 90% of them resulting in your face being melted by the pure hatred of the dice, but the other 10% turn out to be as if some divine figure reaching down and giving each of them a soft kiss. TL;DR: If you like board games and can deal with a bad options menu, get this game, you will NOT regret it.(Also, no I did not just buy this because it has anthro characters...)

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												If you're a board gamer, or have sunk hours into Dokapon/100% Orange Juice - this is probably going to scratch your itch. The rules were easy enough to pick up after one game, and any other questions we had were quickly answered by the game manual (which is hidden in the escape menu). The characters seem relatively balanced, and thankfully, not pandering to furries.The game has solid depth, and I could see myself replaying it for the forseeable future before it gets stale (I'm estimating about 60 games). Playing around with different characters and pushing yourself for the more difficult victory conditions is a riot while everyone scampers around the map jumping on each other to prevent everyone from doing the same. While there's a healthy element of randomness to it all, much of the luck can be mitigated by smart plays, so generally the more skilled players win. That said, the card element is a little tricky to control, and I do wish there was a way of influencing your draws other than by card type.Just note: this is a short game that's meant to be replayed. There is only one 'map', and the game lasts around 40 minutes; even though the trailer would seem to have you believe that it's some kind of sprawling epic. The map itself is relatively small, but that serves to keep everyone running into each other consistently, which is point.Make sure you have a friend along for the ride, because the amount of banter you're about to get up to on Skype is worth the price of admission alone.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												This game is pretty amazing, but it suffer somewhat alittle bit from the RNG-devil. I mean you can have high prestige at the end of the game(talking in multiplayer) and loose like 4 prestige at the last round because there's "anti-cards" to your strategy and stuff. That makes for a pretty interesting and fun gameplay(for those that get those cards).Multiplayer suffer in other areas too:1. Matchmaking is also suffering from the "someone picked my hero, so I'll go and rejoin another game". There's no penalty for leaving, and the ones that ragequit mid-game will get an AI instead. And yes, it has happened, the AI won that time :P2. There's no proper chat, it's all predefined lines you can say, like in Hearthstone. It opens for console of course, but it's kinda annoying that you can't "talk stragegy" at all. You can't say exactly what you want. But you can try add them on steam as their steam ID is the ingame one.3. You can sit awhile and wait for people to join the extremely simple matchmaking in like ONE lobby room. Games can take long maybe up to an hour or hour'n'a'half.Lastly, I want to apologize to the one player that we kinda made a pact from the start of the game against the two other players. Some cards allow you to gain resources as long as one of you don't die. And that I had to kinda "backstab" him in the end, I had 10 prestige and was closest of the two of us to win, I had pretty good shields and I knew he had loads of +fight. And the quickest way I could get to the one about to attack the king was to get killed in order to go back home(and it was closer to the winning guy, due to perils blocking of the quickest path. And so we still didn't make it, but that wanted me to explain myself and my tactic after I attacked him and tossed ALL I had at him(had to maintain the prestige if I happen to win), but you can't.. Can't say anything, and he kept using the treathen lines at me.It's a pretty addictive game over all,unlocking stuff as you win matches and gain "XP" for starter "items" and "favors" I guess they're called.And I'm really looking forward to future DLC of new characters, new cards, new rings and favors as well as new maps(? -because the maps are randomized every game) or new texture-set for current map. I'll buy it all! :)

content:

												EDIT2: I finally got to playing some mp games and I must say wasn't very impressed so far. Firstly, I barely managed to play them because every time I found other 3 players and we started up the game it would disconnect. I verified several times that the problem is not on my end. - After finally connecting to a game it turned out to last veeery long because players don't have immediate actions like AI (and even AI seems slow after several games).- players can leave the game when they like without any consequence and then AI replaces them- there is a huuuuge amount of luck involved in the game (a bit too much for my liking)- I still recommend this game because it needs more players to get better and it has quite a bit of room to be better, especially because these are some very nice foundations, but I wouldn't call it a final product because it kinda lacks content.I kinda bought this game on a whim not knowing what it's all about. I just like board games.This will be a limited review based on just my first few hours and I didn't even play the multiplayer yet.I was only disappointed in one aspect -  there is no real campaign mode or something similar, but I should've expected that since this is, primarily, a multiplayer game.Tutorial was really nice and I think single player serves only the purpose of teaching you the game so you can get into multiplayer. That purpose is served well.The setting, art, gampleay are all very nicely made and as I said, this will be a limited review since I didn't yet play the biggest aspect of the game.EDIT1: I thought cards had to be collected for mp, but I was corrected by Goon for Hire (thanks). This makes it even better since you are immediately ready for mp.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												EDIT:Forget what I said below... Im editing this review because I still come back to play this game, I still love this game, and Its still just as enjoyable as it was.I dont know what all the DLC related negative reviews are about... you dont have to buy any of it to play, but considering this developer is still updating after all of this time (and dont pretend you dont know the lifecycle of games on here or how quickly theyre abandoned), paying $6 for a cosmetic skin seems like not only a fun visual treat, but a nice way to keep the updates coming.This is still a really good game.___________________________________________________________________________I Love It!Dont be dissuaded by the (few) negative reviews, this game is very much a dice and card based tabletop boardgame, and it does that quite well. There are multiple ways to win, and certain animals have a slight advantage depending on the way you plan to win, not that you are AT ALL limited in choices due to the creature you chose as your avatar.Dying is a part of the game. You WILL DIE. But depending on the strategy youre using to win, you may find that an occasional death is helpful. There is a lot of strategy involved, and as other people have mentioned, one roll of the dice may see you needing to completely revamp your strategy... but as a tabletop gamer, I'm used to that, and find it to be part of the challenge.Single and multiplayer modes available, and I find the AI on single player to be challenging and enjoyable... you can invite friends to multiplayer games or just queue up for a pick-up.  I got it for 25% off ($14.99), but it is definitely worth the $19.99 full price.As I write this, I have 18.0 hrs of play time, and that is in two days... so yeah, I kind of like it. If Settlers of Catan, Risk and Hayao Miyazaki had a baby, this would be it; and it is adorable!

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Armello is a turn-based game with cards and cubes with 4 different heroes, with different stats and abilitys where you have to win the kings trust and get retribution of citys while defending your self agens 3 other players either locally with AI or online, while deadly banes sneaking close to you to stand in the way.We have 4 heroes to play as. Thane the wolf, Mercurio the rat, Sana the bear or Amber the bunny. Each hero has it own stats and what their specialty is. Every player has 3 Ap start points (Points to move around the map). When you have picked a hero, you can choose a ring which will give +1 in a stat. When you're in the game, you can choose between 3 quests, and after that there wil be displayed your flag over a area you need to take care of to also recieve your quest items etc. Besides this, there is instances that gives loot, money etc. At night "banes" will come out of the instances and will hunt every city and player on the map.The cards gives you a overview of what you can do. Either you pick Item, Spell or Trickery. You need to be aware of what cards you have to win the fights and every card you pick might have a negative effect. If you spend your inventory on cards, you will lose cubes to throw, since they stand for the same. Be aware that some cards need gold before it can be used. The cards can also be throwed at your enemies or on your self or over citys to make traps, effect, health, damage etc. Making traps will show a icon on the area you placed. Besides all this, there is 3 types of gamemodes while playing to win the game. Each player can have it's own tactic and do the same. Either you:  1. Be a king slayer, 2. Spirit s tone victory, or 3. Prestige victory. The king has 7 health and is loseing 1 each day, when he dies some one need to take his place, but the kingdom is guarded by kings guard. If you kill or attack kings guard, the king will set a bounty on your head where every kings guard will follow you. Each game can last up to 60 mins, so you have much to look forward too!Besides what i've written so far, you can already see that the game has much to offer. If you have a hard time under the game, you can always press ESC and re-read the information you got in the first place to get a re-cap. I can gladly recommend this of it's huge amount of quality of content and playtime.Here is a demo:

												Armello is addictive and fun, but a bit complex and slow-paced. One map could last for 1-3 hrs depending on the pace of the players. The videos of the game here on Steam are a bit misleading, cause when I bought the game it was because it seemed like a story-rich game. This is false. Hope to see the developers add a story-mode in the future. I REALLY like the gameplay and strategy options of the game, so I have to give it a thumbs up even though I feel like I bought the game based on expectations that weren't met.Recommended

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								I grabbed this game last minute in early access, and I'm glad I did.  Quick rundown:The world of Armello itself looks great and feels very alive already, even though I've been playing for only a few days.  I'd love to see something like a single player story mode for each character in the full release or down the road, because I feel like the characters have strong potential for development.  That would also expand the gameplay possibilities in single player. As for the gameplay specifically, it seems complicated at first, but it doesn't take long to pick up.  There are tool tips everywhere, so you can figure out everything on your own at your own pace.  I also believe tutorials will be added for the full game.  That should help.I see just a couple drawbacks in the game right now.  First, it seems the A.I. is a bit overwhelmed by it all.  Once you have the basics down, it's clear that if you come in with a specific victory in mind, it's not too difficult to win a single player game.  With just one difficulty level, there's no scalability to the challenge; once you've figured out how to win, you routinely beat the computer. Second, it's hard to find a multiplayer game at the moment, but that's an easy fix as long as the userbase expands on full release. Those concerns aside, I'm quite impressed with this game, and it should only improve as it leaves early access.

 [FR/ENG] Un résumé est disponible pour ceux que ce pavé rebute :D / A resume is available under this big aera of text :D Je donne ici un avis subjectif, mais si cela peut vont vous convaincre d'acheter cette petite perle je serais comblé :) Armello est un jeu fonctionnant avec un système de jeu de cartes un peu rpg avec une vue de dessus et des personnages furry, présenté comme un jeu de plateau ou -MALHEUREUSEMENT- la majorité des actions fonctionnent aux dés ou à d'autres mesures totalement hasardeuses (en plus la malchance me colle à la peau...) c'est un jeu qui peux se jouer entre amis (mais toujours pas de local) pour des parties amusantes de 30 à 45 min, ou contre des bots, ou/et principalement en multiplayer, player pool pas énorme mais suffisante pour trouvé des games assez vite. Et, WOUAH un jeu vraiment beau avec de la musique superbe qui accompagne le tout, ça me fout une claque à chaque fois oO !En outre [FR / EN]LES PLUS + : Le gameplay est rafraichissant / refreshing gameplay Des graphismes magnifiques / beautiful graphismUn univers fantasy avec des dessins incroyables / fantasy universe with amazing drawingPlusieurs possibilités de victoires / 4 winning possibilities Pas mal de cartes aux actions variés / many cards with various actions8 champions jouables avec des capacités différentes (2 perso par clan) / 8 playable characters with different skills (2 char per tribe)Un objectif unique et simple, une histoire sobre et un peu originale / a unique and simple objective, a short story with some originalityDes perso furry *-* / Furry char *-*Tu peux être un lâche un héro un idiot un explorateur un sorcier (ce que tu veux) ! / You can be a coward a hero an idiot an explorator a sorcerer (what you want) !Une super OST ! / incredible OST !Un champ de bataille généré quasi-aléatoirement / an almost randomly generated battlefieldUn tuto sympathique qui nous présente les 4 personnages principaux / a nice tuto who show us the 4 principal charactersLES MOINS - :  Trop aléatoire, je n'ai pas de chance :( / Too random, i don't have luck :(On aimerais pouvoir regardé la partie de plus haut mais un effet de nuage nous en empêche / We would like to watch the game from the sky but an odd cloud effect blind usLes paramètres ne se sauvegarde pas quand on quitte le jeu / Settings don't save when we leave the gameLe tuto n'est pas ultra complet, vous mettrez du temps avant d'avoir le jeu en main / empty-like tutorial, you'll need time to handle the game properlyCertaines des possibilités de victoires sont trop dures / some victory possibilities are too hardLes Joueurs sont sans pitié mouahaha / Players have no mercy mouahaha Je pense que c'est à peu près tout, je mettrait à jour quand il y aura de nouvelles MaJ / I think that's almost all, i will change when updates will come out  J'espère que je vous aurais aidé à faire votre choix, n'hésité pas à laisser un commentaire et à indiquer si oui ou non mon commentaire vous a aidé, j'en serait ravi :) et merci d'avoir tout lu ^^Hope that helped you to make your choice, pls leave a message and say if it was useful or not, i'll be happy :) and thx for taking time to read ^^

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												EDIT2: I finally got to playing some mp games and I must say wasn't very impressed so far. Firstly, I barely managed to play them because every time I found other 3 players and we started up the game it would disconnect. I verified several times that the problem is not on my end. - After finally connecting to a game it turned out to last veeery long because players don't have immediate actions like AI (and even AI seems slow after several games).- players can leave the game when they like without any consequence and then AI replaces them- there is a huuuuge amount of luck involved in the game (a bit too much for my liking)- I still recommend this game because it needs more players to get better and it has quite a bit of room to be better, especially because these are some very nice foundations, but I wouldn't call it a final product because it kinda lacks content.I kinda bought this game on a whim not knowing what it's all about. I just like board games.This will be a limited review based on just my first few hours and I didn't even play the multiplayer yet.I was only disappointed in one aspect -  there is no real campaign mode or something similar, but I should've expected that since this is, primarily, a multiplayer game.Tutorial was really nice and I think single player serves only the purpose of teaching you the game so you can get into multiplayer. That purpose is served well.The setting, art, gampleay are all very nicely made and as I said, this will be a limited review since I didn't yet play the biggest aspect of the game.EDIT1: I thought cards had to be collected for mp, but I was corrected by Goon for Hire (thanks). This makes it even better since you are immediately ready for mp.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												VERY well done game.The combat, graphics, story... Basically EVERYTHING works with this game.That being said, its lacking a certain kind of polish.In my brief time of playing, I have been constantly plagued by audio bugs, such as crackling audio, delayed audio, doubled and sometimes tripled audio, certain sounds not muting when the sound sliders are set to 0 (mainly the life-stones and the banes noises).Another grievance I have with this game, is the lack of a proper graphical options menu, instead you have the choice of, "Very Low" to "Very High" settings. I am aware that this is a duel launch game also made for the Sony PlayStation, but this does not excuse this. ALLLL of that being said tho, do I hate this game? No, far from it, I adore this game, to the point that in my brief time playing, it has managed to work its way into my heart,  topping off my favorite games, at least for the time being. On a side note, they really nailed the, "board game" aspect with the Dice roles. 90% of them resulting in your face being melted by the pure hatred of the dice, but the other 10% turn out to be as if some divine figure reaching down and giving each of them a soft kiss. TL;DR: If you like board games and can deal with a bad options menu, get this game, you will NOT regret it.(Also, no I did not just buy this because it has anthro characters...)

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												I backed it on Kickstarter and it was the right thing to do. Armello is a great mixture between card, strategy and board game. The graphics and animations are amazing and so is the soundtrack. I haven't played the MP yet, but the Singleplayer gives you a good choice between different heros and especially during the first few hours you will always find new cards which can change the game. Replaying will always give you a slightly different map, different AI players and quests. So it's definitely worth the money. You can take your time to find the best strategy but you will also get a game for in-between, because one playthrough takes roughly an hour. 10/10 would kill the King again with honor, prestige and Soul Stones.

content:
Posted: April 26
												I'm a big fan of board and card games, so of course when I found this game, I bought it to see how it worked. It's a Virtual board game, so it couldn't be played in the real world, but is it fun as itself, ignring this aspect?Yes, yes it is. While I wish I could play with freinds locally with my copy (as some virtual board games allow.) Just playing it a few times wins me over. The lovable, visual charms of the game combined with the complex, yet easy-to-learn rules and mechanics made it a total blast. At currently 4 hours of play I'm certainly no expert on the entire experince, but the gameplay was fun enough that make me want to set aside more time for more games.Speaking of my little play, however, when looking at other reviews with FAR more play than I do, there's a common complaint about bugs that freeze up the game or make it unplayable. I've not encountered these, but then, I've only played about three full games.Final Thoughts: I own, and like, this game. I've not encountered any bugs, but they may appear more rarely, so who can know for sure? It's a reccomendation from me.

Early Access Review
								Armello is a board game and  the premier game from League of Geeks featuring fuzzy characters, some RPG-like elements, and cards to help get a leg up on your opponents. This to me this is a great example of how early access should be used. The amount of love, attention, and focus to detail is shown. I can say if you are looking for a change of pace in gaming or if you are into in depth board games this one is for you.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Hello!Armello really is a great game; people have likened it to Settlers of Catan, Magic the Gathering, Endless Legend, etc. It definitely has the feel of a board game, but in a semi-fast paced, strategy, top-down rpg added in. The art style is beautiful, and most of the mechanics are thoroughly ironed out for an Early Access Game. I admit, some things need balancing and it is lacking just a tiny bit more stuff. (i.e. Stealth really doesn’t work well, and AI needs to be buffed/has to have an easy-medium-hard slider.) But the game is already very complex and complete, with 4 characters to work with (4 more coming when it is fully released), several rings/amulets to choose from, and 4 ways to win. That’s not including the dozens of items, spells, and treasure you collect from wandering the smallish map and battling opponents.The price I feel could drop 5 dollars where the game is at currently, but it is still early access, and with the implementation of 4 more characters + the Ranked Mode, I would say it is a fair, balanced price at 25 dollars.A great recommendation from me!~Wolfy

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								I fully recommend this game to anyone that is a huge fan of board games and card games or table top games in general. This game is simply beautiful, the music is phenomenal and sets a wonderful mood while you are playing the game. The art style adds a wonderful look and feel to the game with out taxing your system to the limits but also at the same time the game looks amazing and has a beautiful high definition look. The game mechanics are easy to learn and easy to play but with a deep level of strategy in the game. As far as early access games go this game is fully playable and feels like a complete game. The length of a match is perfect for board game fans and  players who want a quick satisfying game with out dedicating hours of play. During a match you never feel like you don’t have something to do which is nice in keeping players intrigued. Playing this game single player is a bit on the easy side but it is a good way to master the various victory conditions and try out new things before you take them online. The rpg element add a nice feel to the game and allow for each character to feel unique and diverse with a different play style. Simply a rare gem on the early access market that you don’t see very often.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												It's a fun game to play, and I very much recommend it. It's definitely a unique experience for me and definitely for those who like to mess with other players and get ahead for the win. There are a bunch of different characters and it's been fun experimenting with each and every one to find out your preferred playstyle and your favourite character. Plus with unlocking rings and amulets, you unlock ways to either alter your playstyle or buff it up which I quite like.The board's randomised from what I can tell so to me, it never feels "same-y". It feels like a new, fresh experience each time and it all plays out differently, which I'm very fond of. So, Armello definitely gets the thumbs up from me!

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14
												First off, let me say that the game is fun. At times.The gameplay of Armello is that of a normal board game, with one objective, to become king (or queen). In order to do this, you have to remove the current leige. The twist is that there is four ways to win, which balances out characters quite nicely.  One of the pleasant things about Armello is its art style and soundtrack. Thats probably the only thing that keeps me from leaving a match that I am inevitably unable to have a chance at victory. But the game has a few, and utterly annoying, flaws.One of these flaws is the Constant disconnection that a lot of the reviews talk about. Keep in mind I have played the game for 110 hours, and let me just say, at least 1~2 games disconnect out of 3. I know it isn't my internet or my computer because I just got a new one that surpasses the recommended requirements. That aside, lets talk about the DLC, microtransactions, and rewards.Ah, Microtransactions. Sadly, with the 1.6 update, League of Geeks decided to add skins to the characters that are about $7 bucks a piece. It would be understandable if they bundled skins into a pack of four for each category of hero (Like the wolf clan, rabbit clan, bear clan, and rat clan), but they went the way most games are going now days. Essentailly, the skins only change the characters looks, nothing more, nothing less. Now to move onto the DLC rant.When the DLC for the Ursurpers was released, I bought it without a second thought. The characters are still pretty strong, but base game characters can still beat them. But, I am not complaining about that. Its the addition of the extra rings that are annoying. There is one such ring that allows the wolf clan 3 extra dice when they fall below 3 hearts. Sounds nice, but base game players do not recieve this ring because it is a DLC item.One last concern is the lack of variety in player character species. If you supported this game on kickstarter, then you recieved a character pack that added a few more characters (The Bandit Clan) than when you buy the game after its release. These characters cannot be used in multiplayer as of now because of unbalanced issues. Now, before all the early supporters get mad, I want to propose that the characters should be added as a DLC, so everyone could use them. I understand it was an incentive to support LoG, but they are just laying dormant in the games files. The Bandit clan added a little variety to the game.The species issue continues, however, in the actual game. The enemies you fight are the kings guard, who never change, the king, banes (Vulture like abominations summoned from the underworm) and the characters the four players chose. What gets me is that there are quest givers that are not apart of these defined factions. Like the spymaster, the blacksmith, the miner, ect. There should be a playable hero that is not apart of these defined factions.If you like board games with variety, then you may or may not like this game because it does get repetetive with the disconnections and long wait times, and there isn't really a variety with species. Also, before I forget, there is a nasty bug that just started to happen. When you find a match finally, the screen that allows you to join the lobby sometimes takes forever to pop up, and may not even show up at times.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								I don't think there's much I can add that already has been said, but here goes...Yes, it's a digital boardgame. There's a heavy focus on cards for items, spells, allies and playing nasty tricks on your opponents. One thing that differs from most turn-based games is that you can play many of these cards on your opponents' turn, so vigilance and timing is important. Both the AI and human players will play cards(if they can afford them) to stop your turn earlier or delay you in any other way. Not all players will like this, but it's definitely part of the game's strategy and I think hard core strategy players will appreciate this(after all I am one; takes one to know one, right?).Yes, several of the elements of the games are randomized. You roll dice to avoid traps and during battles. Your success in quests depends on how high your tested attribute is. Some players will not like this. However, it's not completely randomized. During battles and when evading traps, you can "burn" cards to directly add successes to your rolls. In quests, you can choose between three quests that test different attributes and even if you fail a quest, you are guaranteed a small prestige award and your tested attribute is boosted by one.One of the best things about Armello is balance. The game doesn't guarantee any one action during a turn will be successful. This means it's hard to exploit certain strategies and the Armello tends to reward the player who varies his strategies, at least most of the time. It also rewards players who adapt to ever changing situations. Players who unsuccessfully try to reach the same objective again and again tend to get punished heavily. That way, even a player who seems overpowered can be hindered significantly to the point that he is denied victory. On the other hand, a player who has started as the underdog can get the upper hand quickly depending on the situation. Armello teaches the player when to practice prudence and when to take risks. It also encourages experimentation. Not a lot of strategy games do this.No, it's not Disney. Don't be fooled by the cute-looking animal characters. Each has a deep and meaningful background story and the world they live in is pretty dark by cartoon standards. You can read all about it on League of Geek's website(just google Armello). More on this can be found in the art on the beautifully rendered(and animated) cards. A few of them are comic in nature, but most display sinister forces, wondrous treasures, powerful spells and sometimes, a cruel world. The object of the game is to dethrone the king(by any means necessary more often than not) and every part of the game demonstrates that. The music is almost melancholic in nature, it reminds me of winter for some reason, but it fits the atmosphere of the game nicely and is very pleasant to listen to.Yes, the game is not finished. There are still a few problems with the public multiplayer systems, but the developers are working furiously on it. You can still enjoy a private game with friends or go head to head with the computer in single player. The AI is not the smartest, but it can still surprise you from time to time. Either way, it's constantly being improved. There's plenty to unlock and discover in the game while you wait for the full release. Every game is 30-45 minutes, rarely going above an hour and very replayable. It's the kind of game you can play in between bouts of another Steam title to change things up, prevent boredom or avoid carpal tunnel syndrome from excessive button-mashing.All in all, a great game, with the potential to be greater at its official release.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Armello is one of those games where your decisions matter. Each turn is short and sweet and has consequences and rewards. No tedious turns or units to manage.Positives:- Each playable character is nuanced enough to allow varied play styles without losing the overlap that makes characters feel balanced with each other.- The art style. This level of polish for a game still yet to release in full is impressive.- Each play through takes around 40 minutes to complete.Negatives: - The Spirit Stone and Rot win conditions are difficult to pull off and happen mostly from exceptional RNG luck. (although when you win via these methods you feel awesome)- The difficulty of Perils is sometimes too high, with no guaranteed way of avoiding them. This leads to more failures than successes, but victories can be achieved regardless.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								One of the best early access games out there. The game is wholly playable, including multiplayer. It takes a moderate amount of time to finish, but it never feels too long or too short. Like Hearthstone turned real cards into a fun, digital game, Armello does the same with a turn-based board game.I do have some gripes about it, which is kinda expected from a game in early access. The AI difficulty is laughable and more often than not they manage to get themselves killed. I have yet to see an AI actually win a game. Having to play lots of games to unlock some of the content is frustrating, but thankfully the system isn't DLC and you don't have to actually win to unlock stuff.In its current state, I would say it has a 7/10 rating. Just needs polish around the corners to make it a must-buy.

								Armello I think is a fun early access game. That being said, a few things hold it back:- The map, although randomized, never changes its basic structure, and therefore feels very similar in each game.- Limited environment tiles. You're on a mountain, forest, or swamp every turn. (other than structures, which there are only 4 of if you include the king's castle.)- Only four playable heroes. (Many more on the way i hear though.)- No custom game rules/Not any options really.THAT being said, it's an early access game, and a bunch of those will probably change! What I really did enjoy was:- The Art.- Playing with friends.- Card and dice system.- Current victory choices.- The game takes awhile, but not too long.Would I recommend this game for an EA buy as a fan of board games and strategy games? Yes.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
Early Access Review
Mercurio weighted the Spirit Stone, smiling to himself. This was the last one. He had everything he needed to break the curse that had nearly devoured his king. And it was just in time - the king's mind faded with each day, and before long he would be beyond saving.On his way to the castle, Amber, the infamous gold-digger crossed his path - the ignorant fool! Couldn't she see that his task was infinitely more important than quarreling over riches? Mercurio felt little regret as he pierced her heart.To make things worse, Thane, the lord steward, fell to the curse, too, and driven mad with the rot, he was battling his way through the king's guardsmen.Unfavorable circumstances forced his hand; Mercurio had quite the way with words, and a fat purse to emphasize his arguments. He claimed the title of lord steward just in time to sign a decree that rallied additional warriors into the castle.The king was safe - for the time being. All that remained was to overcome another valley, another forest; and the ever-present Banes. It was a rough journey, but Mercurio did not come so far to fail now; battered and bleeding, he stood before the palace gates at long last... imagine his surprise when the very guards he rallied to ensure the king's safety approached him, weapons at ready!While he was busy battling the Banes, Thane, the corrupted madman, had put a bounty on his head!This was the moment of truth. Mercurio played all his cards, pulled all the strings; accompanied by a group of mercenaries, he cut his way through the royal guard and into the throne room, hastily applying the Spirit Stones -despite the circumstances, HE DID SAVE THE KING AND ENSURE PEACE AND ORDER THROUGHOUT THE REALM!---The point: this game is absolutely charming and magical, and the people behind it clearly love what they're doing and care for Armello.Worth every penny <3

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Hello!Armello really is a great game; people have likened it to Settlers of Catan, Magic the Gathering, Endless Legend, etc. It definitely has the feel of a board game, but in a semi-fast paced, strategy, top-down rpg added in. The art style is beautiful, and most of the mechanics are thoroughly ironed out for an Early Access Game. I admit, some things need balancing and it is lacking just a tiny bit more stuff. (i.e. Stealth really doesn’t work well, and AI needs to be buffed/has to have an easy-medium-hard slider.) But the game is already very complex and complete, with 4 characters to work with (4 more coming when it is fully released), several rings/amulets to choose from, and 4 ways to win. That’s not including the dozens of items, spells, and treasure you collect from wandering the smallish map and battling opponents.The price I feel could drop 5 dollars where the game is at currently, but it is still early access, and with the implementation of 4 more characters + the Ranked Mode, I would say it is a fair, balanced price at 25 dollars.A great recommendation from me!~Wolfy

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Kickstarted this game a bit ago and while the art style is gorgeous I'm left hoping that they'll fix some major issues I have with the game when it hits full-release.CONS:1. The tutorial is lacking and always feels a step behind the gameplay. You get plopped into the game and it just sits there. I didn't know what to do with my cards, how I moved, how to fight...everything was confusing.  I've played these types of games before so I DID figure it out after a bit but it was still worrying that a tutorial didn't kick in and say "Oh by the way here's how you do this thing!"2. Win/lose conditions aren't entirely clear. This goes back a bit to the confusing turotial, but quite a few times I was left wondering how or why something happened. I defeated the king but also lost? I killed this player, I survived...but also died? There is probably something I missed in some dialog box somewhere explaining this, but as it sits now it just left me disgruntled, confused, and annoyed. 3. The music/audio clues need work (This may seem a bit nit-picky, but I believe it's worth noting). I realize that this is a pre-release version, but as it currently stands the audio of the game needs work. I found myself getting bored from the game's repetition that it was honestly putting me to sleep at 4pm. When things happen in the game that is a big deal (dying, battles, monsters appearing) there needs to be a bigger impact on the game audio. 4. The game is, quite frankly, boring. This is harsh, but it needs to be said.  Everything about this game LOOKS like it should be a fast-paced adventure game based on mostly skill and a bit of luck, but it mostly ends up feeling slow and repetitive. The enemies don't feel scary, your deaths don't feel like they mean anything, and most of the time I end up saying to myself, "I have no idea why that happened...what's going on?" Yes, with time I'm sure everyone can learn what is going on and why things happen, but currently it doesn't feel rewarding enough to want to continue on. PROS:1. The game is gorgeous.  No really, this game is beautiful. It's very obvious that the art team spend a ton of time working on the art for not only the game board but also the game cards. The GUI is beautiful and streamlines and everything just makes sense as to where it is on the screen.  2. The gameplay is smart. While certain things I've mentioned before need work, once you actually get to the meat of the game it's pretty good. Draw cards to gain followers, items, spells, etc...but make the wrong decision and you may be missing a necessary item when you go to fight an opponent. You need to plan a few turns ahead of time to figure out if you want to hide, stockpile gold, or attack. It's not a new concept in games by any means, but it IS an interesting one. ConclusionWhile still in pre-release stage, I'm fairly happy with the way it is progressing. No major game-destroying bugs to be found yet, the gameplay is smooth, and for something technically not finished it played extremely well. For all of the CONS I gave it I'm still very optimistic that the development team will work out all the kinks in the future and this will turn out to be a terrific game.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												This is my first review on steam, so I'm going to be somewhat soft.First off, I think the game looks very well done and playing is enjoyable. The graphics looks great, the map textures are awesome, and I like the 3D models for the characters on the board. I like the animated battle scenes. they look great to me and change the pace a bit.  If there is one or two things I would change, it's the battle system and a story mode for the single player. Sure some strategy is used to place yourself in a favorable position, but it comes down to luck when it comes to getting cards and the die rolls. Can't tell you how frustrating it is to lose to someone who has lower health but get an awful roll. I've played a few time, losses on my part, and I still go back to play more. Adding in a story mode will give more depth into the lore of the Armello world and maybe even discover a thing or two about the characters.Overall, the game is enjoyable, this is a game where you'll learn from your mistakes and try to get that win that you always want through prep before game start. Yeah the battle system can be tweeked a bit, and maybe add in some sort of story play for the single player.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is what Dragon Commander tried to be and failed miserably at. Few games do the 'living board game' genre justice, where you take the core of what makes a fun board game, and a fun video game, and then mash them together. Armello has harnessed that magic masterfully and I can but recommend them and bow to their prowess.If you like video games, will you like this? I dunno. I guess it depends on what sorts of video games you like, but if you're anything like me (or Ron Gilbert, who's apparently also like me) then you have the capacity to enjoy a slower paced game. It wouldn't be fair to compare it to strategy games, though, that's not its jam. It is very much the living board game that everyone has been trying forever to make. If you like board games, will you like this? Definitely. This is a form of dark magic that brings a board game to life to be played in a way no other has.Not only that, but this game has a remarkable amount of lore behind it. How far did they go? There are audio books (!!) for it, which are beautifully done and excellently voice acted. I'd genuinely recommend grabbing those, too, as they make Armello such a complete experience. Armello is a place, a world, on a desk for you to interact with.Give it a try. It's like nothing else you've ever played.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												I want to love this game, I really do. It's just that it's held back by absurdly clunky UI, lack of graphical options, and the fact that stat-boosting items are progression locked for some inexplicable reason. While the game's atmosphere and its core mechanics are interesting, it's just bogged down by its appalling execution. There is a strange lack of borderless windowed in the video options and there is no way to turn off the clouds above the game board if you try to zoom out. There isn't even a way to look at the whole board, nor does the in-game UI give any at-a-glance information. Instead, you are stuck clicking in and out of menus just trying to keep track of each player's information. The gameplay itself is incredibly boring, even by board gaming standards. Eighty percent of the time is spent waiting for things to happen, only interspersed with several seconds of dice rolling, reformulating strategy, or watching the AI take its turn. Even the amount of RNG in the game is exceptionally high. While granted, there are several ways to reduce the RNG required, the sheer number of times it comes up-- spawning enemies, loot tables, King's choices, perils, dungeons-- puts it way over the top. The card decks are heavily watered down with seemingly no copies of cards, meaning that the chance of drawing specific cards in order to avoid RNG or simply be useful are slim. The only way to remove useless cards from your hand is to blindly charge into perils or combat in order to 'burn' them. If you want a strategy game, look elsewhere. If you're into dice-rolling and short trips to your local Taco Bell but can't afford to play Warhammer 40k, then this is the game for you.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
tl;dr -> After losing friends while playing physical Catan at someone's house, you can boot up Armello and ruin friendships even more from the comfort of your own homes. 11/10 would load Tabletop Simulator to flip digital tables again.I received a review copy of this game and was very excited to try it because I have a deep love for tabletop games, and this one seemed to blend many different archetypes of the genre like dice-rolling, card mechanics, and map tiles. After playing both the singleplayer and multiplayer game modes, I was extremely pleased with my gameplay experience. Be advised, however, that the game truly shines when played together with friends; singleplayer may get dull after a few playthroughs.If you enjoy playing tabletop games – especially ones with dice-rolling, cards, and map tiles; managing only one character, and playing against other people, then you will really enjoy this game.The aesthetics are good – the amount of detail in the character models, terrain tiles, and everything else is high and very well-done. The dice-rolling looks and sounds like actual dice, and the cartoon-style battle animations are fluid. The map can eventually become repetitive because the only change between each playthrough is the randomization of the tile placements. The sounds and music are great and create a nice fantasy atmosphere.Controls are simple and easy to familiarize yourself with. There are a number of tutorial missions that help you learn the gameplay mechanics and how each clan works. The learning curve is mostly minimal to moderate depending on your experience with tabletop games. Although the AI can be fairly challenging, the game is meant to be enjoyed with friends, so do not base the difficulty solely on the singleplayer experience.Gameplay revolves around beating your opponents in a variety of ways, with a rapidly dying Lion King as your turn timer. After every player has completed their turns, the King will take one damage (starting the game with 10 health points) and issue a royal decree. The royal decree will change an element of gameplay until the next round – for example, one type of decree will force all players to pay 5 gold, and any unable to do so must give a piece of equipment. The player with the most valour points chooses which decree will pass. Valour points are obtained in numerous ways, such as completing quests, defeating monsters/players, et cetera.During your turn, you are given a number of action cards (categorized as magic, equipment, and guile) based on your character’s wit, which also determines your maximum hand capacity (high wit = more cards). Equipment cards may give you bonuses like extra health or dice. Magic and guile cards can benefit you (similar to equipment) or harm opponents (ex: damage someone within range). To play cards, you need gold or mana (if you are using a magic card). Cards played on opponents usually require you to be within a certain range of tiles.You are allowed 2-3 moves, however, moving onto a mountain tile will cost 2 moves (but also provide a bonus to defence). Swamp tiles will damage you for one hp, ruins will give you a random event (yielding cards, damage, quests, etc), and town tiles will be captured and generate gold per turn.Quests can be selected when you begin, and completing them will grant you an item, bonuses, and valour points. To finish a quest, you will usually have to travel to a specific tile and can either risk a full (there is always a % of success/failure shown) or standard completion (higher chance of success).The King sends out castle guards, and monsters spawn during the night- these can be fought for valour, however, attacking a guard will put a bounty on you (that other players an claim).During combat, your attack rating determines how many dice you get to roll; endurance determines how many dice you get when on the defensive. Cards/equipment can boost your dice count, and “selling” cards allows you to lock in a particular dice roll (for example, selling an axe card guarantees an attack roll, removing one die from your total pool). Your attack rolls are subtracted from the opponent’s defence rolls, and any excess do direct damage. It is possible for you and an opponent to kill each other. In the event of a death, you respawn on your next turn in your specific corner of the map, losing a number of valour points.To win, you may do a number of things. If the King dies from his ailment (he is inflicted with chaos), the player with the highest valour wins. Killing the King, collecting all the spirit eggs from ruins and entering the castle, or attacking the King when you have more chaos points than him (you get chaos points from killing monsters/players) will also allow you to secure victory.Overall, the gameplay is fleshed out very well, allowing for smooth, fun experiences. The singleplayer can be a bit lacking due to repetitiveness (without the human element). There is a lot of replayability because you can unlock different starting items and abilities for your characters (usually by winning with them). Anyone interested in digital tabletop games should definitely give this title a try.Recommend!Cheers,DJSF @DJSF's Rogue ReviewsMy Website[theroguereviews.com]

content:
Posted: January 19
												I have not only bought this game for myself but also convinced 3 more of my friends to buy it so we can all play together. And instead of getting rewarded after each game, we do not get loot so if we need to get any dice loot (without having to buy it from another player) we have to play against strangers. That may seem ok BUT you are not allowed to work with your friend to achieve victory since everyone seems to threaten you that you will get banned because you are cooperating. A crappy loot system and developers who are banning you because you have a different opinion about the most ridiculous loot system in any game. The reason they have stopped loots from 4man premade games is to prevent people from farming dice...when they have ALREADY added a limit to how many dice you can get daily which makes the whole thing contradicting to itself. All in all a nice game but only if you don't have enough friends to play it with (and i wonder if i am the only one that thinks it should be the other way around in the worst case scenario)For the record this is my ban message:"Actually i am wrong about the COOP tag...but nontheless there is nowhere a statement when you buy the game that that is the case...so still my point is valid"Ban Reason:"Intentionally provocative and disrespectful language, directed at both the developers and peers. Breathe, relax and treat people with respect."
