content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												Having reached over 100 hours in-game, and with a new update recently released, I've updated what I had originally written to reflect both the current state of the game and my thoughts on the matter.TL;DR  -   Armello has a wonderful visual aesthetic and lore but has about as much "deep and emergent strategy" as yahtzee or mario party.  Gameplay has an overwhelming reliance on RNG, resulting in skill and tactics offering no significant impact on the game's outcome and making the gameplay generally frustrating.  Armello is additionally hampered by numerous graphical and UI bugs, a finicky matchmaking system, and one of the worst online multiplayer netcodes I've ever seen.  Well over half of the multiplayer matches I've attempted have never been finished or even started due to one of the issues listed above.Avoid if you have any love for strategy board games and videogames, Armello is nothing of the sort. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I originally wrote a review for the game last year, shortly after the game's release, with around four or five hours of gameplay on my belt.  Although the game had beautiful visuals and a stellar artistic design, I was more than a little bit disappointed in the actual gameplay;  over-reliance on RNG for most of the game's challenges left little control to the player and made most actions unnecessarily frustrating.  I could look past the frequent crashing, bugs, and the sheer difficulty of finding a full game, but the gameplay was a real dealbreaker.As of May 2016, the game's currently on version 1.3, and I have spent roughly 100 hours in-game.  There have been a number of changes made to the game's balance, additional content added, and some new mechanics implemented.  However, the real fundamental issues with the game were not fixed...  If anything, they've been increased with each update.  In it's current state the gameplay is so unbelievably FRUSTRATING that it overpowers whatever good the art, sound, and design give, and the developers really don't give any indication that it's ever going to change.  The real kicker here, though, is that most of the time you aren't even going to experience ANY of this.  The game's multiplayer functionality is completely broken and sporiatically functional, frequently crashing, freezing, or ending multiplayer matchmaking at a moment's notice.  The issues plaguing multiplayer matchmaking have been around since launch, but despite reassurances by the devs that they're working on fixes very little has actually been addressed.   Let me explain my gripes with the gameplay in more detail.  Although the store page proudly claims that Armello has 'deep, tactical card play, rich tabletop strategy, and rpg element', spend a few hours in game and you'll quickly find that this is false advertising;  The gameplay is almost entirely dictated by randomness (in the form of card draw, success chance, or dice rolling), leaving virtually no room for any actual strategic planning.  When just going for a ride and messing around, the game's fine fun.  But, the moment you TRY to do something, be it as simple as moving to a specific tile or killing a near-dead creature, you'll more often than not be met with stupid amounts of frustration.Wanted to move a couple of tiles to reach a quest?  Oh, sorry, you spawned an enemy bane that knocks you back, wasting a precious action and forcing you into a combat.  Have six dice for a peril challenge and need to meet only one symbol to beat it?  Sorry, you never rolled what you needed and you succumb to the trap.  Need some defensive equipment to ward off hyperaggressive players?  Wouldn't it be fun if all you drew for three turns straight were scouting, rot-related, or sword cards?    Forced into combat with an enemy, and have to push it out of the way to progress?  Hah, wouldn't it be a shame if you dont roll a single ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ shield[images.akamai.steamusercontent.com], resulting in your spontaneous death and sending you back to start?  This level of crap doesnt happen to you EVERY game, but its not a rare occurance by a longshot, and in each game hands down at least one or two players are going to get the short end of the stick while the others move unhindered.  A little RNG is good for games, as it keeps them fresh, but EVERY ACTION you can do in this game is a gamble with very little reward and a whole lot of risk.  And, unlike other games heavily reliant on RNG, there's NO limitations imposed on it.  You're equally likely to get ♥♥♥♥ed over when you're down as you are when you've spent the game trying your best to stay in the top.  When the latter happens, it's pretty annoying, but when the former happens you flat out want to uninstall the game.      Even when I win, it never feels earned, and from personal experience none of the players ever leave these games feeling particularly happy or satisfied.  I WANT to like Armello.  I keep diving back in now and then and try to find some kind of enjoyment for this game, but every time I end up closing the game for the same reasons.  I do feel like Armello is a huge waste of potential and could be a much deeper, skill and strategy-based game... but right now its just 'pray to the RNG gods for good luck'.If you're art-focused and don't mind bad gameplay, can look past the astounding amount of ui, graphical, and gameplay bugs, matches randomly freezing, online randomly booting you out of parties, and horrible AI, you might enjoy the game more than I have.  But there's no way anyone in their right mind could ever call this mess a good strategy game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												An amazing production all around. The art direction is beautiful, filled with animations and visually pleasing graphics.The soundtrack is very atmospheric and blends seamlessly with the games' many soundeffects.And the story, though tragic is equally powerful and immersive as both the visuals and the music.The gameplay itself is rewarding in every sense of the word, with things like microrewards just for participating in games, and a myriad of other ways to keep hope lit during a particularly unlucky streak. There's incredible potential for variety in every match, and no game is the other alike. In this game the pen and the sword are equally matched, and with the 4 alternate ways of achieving victory they ensure that every turn can twist the game in a new direction.At first it may feel a bit slow, because each turn takes a fair bit of time. But since there's little restrictions with what cards can be played on other people's turns, you quickly learn how to not only speed that wait up, but keep yourself busy during it.As with any game boasting this much variety between every match, luck can of course also become an obstacle. But in those scenarios you learn how to deal around it. Either by seeking an alternate path or just bide your time until another presents itself. Many games have been turned around completely by attentive underdogs who knew how to play their cards right.The multiplayer has also lived up to expectations. Swift game lobbies and amusing phrases exhanged between players doing their best to add more surprises to the game helps renewing gameplay even further. Once you feel confident enough to try it out I can wholeheartedly recommend it, with random players or friends.I can tell that a lot of effort was put into this game, and it took me completely by surprise just how well thought through it is in just about every single aspect.I sincerely recommend this game to pretty much anyone, either as a fun way to pass some time or a challenge for those who enjoy competition with other players. I'd give this game a 9/10.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												I'd heard it described as a "Game of Thrones board game with animal people"... That's not far off.At its core, this is a board game. Or at least it's styled as a board game. Besides the tutorial, there's not really a campaign. Each play offers you a small array of quests to choose for your character that form into something like a story. And that's fine: You're not playing against the program. In true board game fashion, you're playing explicitly against other people.The game is designed with enough complexity and win conditions close enough together, so that it never feels as though there's simply no hope. If you're not doing so well with one strategy, try switching to another. Play is well-balanced and fun. The art and animation is absolutely gorgeous. It all blends together to build a very well-crafted board game-like experience.If you enjoy the turn-based spendor and strategy of board games, Armello is perfect for you. Grab a copy for yourself and convince a couple friends to buy, and have a great time. If you find board games in general kind of slow and not really to your taste, it's simply not for you.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
Once again Steam didn't log all of my playtime and didn't record some of my achievements, I am working to fix this problem. Now Onto the ReviewTabletop games and video games feel mutually exclusive to one another at times. Tabletop players often think that video games are too easy, and video game players think that tabletop games are too needlessly complex. What if there was a game that managed to keep the challenge of tabletop games, but presented it in a more straight-forward way for the main stream video game audience to understand? Well, you'd get Armello, a game funded by Kickstarter, put into early access and now fully available on Steam by the developer and publisher League of Geeks. It's as if the world famous Redwall books made a pact with Game of Thrones and decided to make a game, and its results are fascinating.When it comes to gameplay, that's where Armello shines because it tries to make each and every experience unique so you'll never be playing the same game twice. You start out from the clan that you picked and you choose a quest. You can do this quest by moving across the game board to the appointed area, and there you can either choose to do a dangerous action or take the easy way out. If you take the easy way out then you'll complete the quest and gain prestige, but if you do the harder path, you'll be forced to play a game of chance, which might give you new items and more prestige. This game of chance isn't completely random since your success rates are based around your stats inventory and such, so you can turn the odds to your favor. At the beginning of each turn you're given the option to draw items, spells or tricks. Each can benefit your character in different ways, like giving them armor or chasing guards away from your point of interest. They're also a way of gaining more prestige for your overall goal. Prestige is the amount of points you gain to sway the king to your side, and if you lead in prestige you can advise the king to do actions you want him to do, potentially destroying the other players in the process. Gaining prestige one of the main ways you can win the game, along with gathering Spirit Stones, gaining more Rot than the king himself from various sources and becoming corrupted to kill the king, or just normal old killing the king. Each of these can be gained more efficiently by some characters than others, and it's up to you to figure out which characters are best at each strategy through trial and error or a guide online. Though you can figure it out through deduction from their skills, stats and abilities. Any character can do any role, but some excell slightly better at some roles than others. Full Review[www.noobfeed.com]

content:
Posted: March 27, 2016
SummaryA gorgeous game that seems simple at first but has a surprising amount of well-balanced depth.ReviewArmello is essentially a board game.  Actually, it’s a very complex board game that could only exist in any practical sense on a computer.  When developer League of Geeks created a physical prototype during development to hash out the gameplay, the result required two dungeon masters to keep track of all the rules and calculations, which I imagine made it a chore to play.  The computer, on the other hand, is an extremely capable dungeon master and is able to make the numerous calculations in a split second, so Armello matches are always fast-paced and fun.The King has come down with a sickness called “rot”.  Every morning he loses one point of health, and every evening he gains one point of rot.  This serves as a ticking clock because the King’s days are explicitly numbered - eight, to be precise - so games can’t drag on forever.  A menagerie of armored and weaponed bears, rabbits, wolves, and rats make up the four heroes vying for the throne, and whoever has the most prestige points when the King expires wins the game.  Of course you can be more proactive and seek to claim the throne by killing the King yourself before he succumbs, or you can collect four soul stones and cleanse him of his affliction.  There is a fourth victory type which requires you to become corrupted with rot and then kill the King, but this is generally the most difficult victory to attain and therefore the rarest.  You know, now that I describe the premise, it strikes me as rather brutal, but this isn’t immediately obvious when the main players are adorable woodland creatures.Players take turns moving their characters across a small hexagonal landscape and playing whatever cards they happen to be holding.  You acquire prestige by completing quests, killing banes (bird-like monsters from the underworld), and killing other heroes who then lose one point of prestige and are resurrected at their starting point.  Whoever has the most prestige at any given point in a match has the King’s ear and can choose which of the King's edicts to enforce each morning. This gives the prestige leader a small advantage, but it's mitigated by the fact that the edicts apply equally to all players, including the prestige leader.  During a player's turn, they can explore dungeon tiles which use a coin toss to decide if players are rewarded with treasure or if they awaken a deadly bane, claim towns which give gold, encounter a variety of perils that use dice rolls to determine if you succeed or fail, set traps for other players with trickery cards, hunt down soul stones which periodically appear in the mysterious stone circles, and pursue player-specific quests to improve your character stats. While you might be tempted to sit back and simply watch other players make their moves, it's important to realize that you can still play cards to the board even when it's not your turn. In fact, off-turn play is an important strategy.When you first play Armello, you may think that a prestige victory is the surest and least risky, and this might seem unbalanced.  After all, you just have to keep your prestige total higher than your opponents’ and wait until the King expires.  But by its nature, this is the victory that also takes the longest to achieve which leaves a big opening for more aggressive players to storm the castle at the center of the board and go mano a mano with the king or cure him with soul stones.  The prestige leader also has a big target on his back and will be under constant threat of direct attacks and treachery.  It’s not unusual to see the “Prestige Leader” title change hands several times during a game, so a prestige victory is never a sure thing.  It's often best to pursue one of the other victory types while keeping a prestige win as Plan B.One of the more curious aspects of Armello’s design is how the developers have gone out of their way to conceal information.  It’s impossible to zoom out far enough to see the entire board, and once you get a small distance away, your view becomes obscured by clouds and haze.  Basically, the developers allow you to get an overview of your immediate surroundings, but they actively discourage you from playing that way.  If you want to get information about your opponents, you can open a panel that covers most of the screen and then page through each hero’s status sheet one at a time which can be a little tedious.  League of Geeks has said they do this deliberately to discourage “metagaming” because they want Armello to feel more like an adventure than a board game.  Basically, you’re either doing recon on your opponents, or you’re watching events unfold on the game board, but you can’t do both at the same time.  I will simply say that I don’t entirely understand or agree with the developers’ reasoning here, but it’s not a deal-breaker.One thing I can say without reservation is that Amerllo’s presentation is outstanding.  This is a low-priced “indie” title, but it looks like it came from a AAA studio.  The heroes are well animated and full of detail and personality, and the game board is a lush palette of gorgeous terrain and a lovely day/night cycle.  Then there's the various cards which feature beautifully hand drawn and subtly animated illustrations which put even Blizzard's Hearthstone decks to shame.  In short, this is one fantastic looking game.One of the more unique aspects of Armello is the dice system.  Dice rolls are used to determine whether you succeed or fail a peril, or how you fare in battle.  And when I say “dice rolls”, I don’t mean an under-the-hood random number generator but physically simulated three-dimensional dice that bounce around your screen.  Depending on the situation, there could be as many as a dozen dice in play which can be quite entertaining to watch.Most importantly, Armello is fun.  Matches against the capable AI can be as short as 20-minutes if you enable fast AI turns, so there's always time for a game, or you can dive into multiplayer if you want a real challenge. I've seen people complain that victory or defeat depends on random luck, from coin tosses to dice rolls to which cards you draw from the deck, but isn't that the case with every board game, real or digital?  This is, of course, where player skill comes in, and there are various strategies for dealing with runs of bad luck.  It’s the skillful player and not the lucky player who will win. I think this is a good start for League of Geeks, and I could easily see Armello’s rich tapestry expanded into adventure games, RPGs, and even the 4X strategy genre.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Armello, where do I begin. The moment I saw the trailer of the game I was hooked, in 1:30 it managed to get me excited for the game. I'm not going to talk graphics and such as each game that's being released nowadays looks great, and so does this one. As for sound, after playing a couple of rounds I grew bored with it, turned it off and putt on some Youtube. Not to say it was bad, but you know, you can only listen to the same song and jingles that many times.Controls! Oh boy, I have a couple of gripes here. One being the cards being to close to your dice in combat and perils. Sometimes you roll dice when you meant to grab the last card to burn it, it's annoying. This is pretty much the biggest one, but there are numerous others. Camera resetting to a zoomed in position while you zoomed out, your camera being jerked everywhere when something happens, I think you get the idea, I'd say it's annoying, not game breaking. Bugs! This game is great when you play it casually. When you're trying to get the achievements, not so much. I had it happen numerous times that I was going for an achievement and the game just froze, in the menu, between turns, rolling dice, for no reason at all. This gets really frustrating at times and makes me want to punch the screen. Multiplayer. There is one, but I'm not going to try it because of the above reason. And also because there are exclusive characters you could only get when the game was being kickstarterted. I'm not playing against characters I know nothing about, it's an unfair advantage and these characters should be DLC at some point, be it with in a different skin, or some other model, I'm sure there is some solution.Should you buy it? Well, the game is worth the money, I'm at 44 hours now and have yet to get all the achievements, and some of the other unlockables. If the devs first work out the bugs, tighten the UI, and level the playing field multiplayer wise it's a solid title worthy of your collection.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												Guess I should have reviewed long ago but I am quite new to steam apparently.Overall, it's a boardgame made digital. It's intrigue. I've always wanted to get the feel of a board game, with dungeon master and so on. And this game sort of digitalized the real paper table game, and creamed with beautiful graphics, highly detailed environment and cute looking fluffy characters. For what it is, looking at the real board game now is less appealing anymore because they are all flat papers, decolorized statues, packed cards, tokens and have to calculate the maths yourself. And there's no special effects (unless the dungeon master got creative) like clouds, snow, day and night cycle. And since its automated, everything is running based on strategic skill and luck (rolling the dice). And I imagined having this feature sort of reduced the chance of players going against the dungeon master for "fairness".In the game players can either choose to go against each other or form an alliance (sometimes temporary). The main goal is to win the game in the end. And there's only one victor. Though most of the time I would just go in, and enjoy the pretty graphic, killing the monster spawned, or simply annoyed the hell out of other players by setting traps all over the map (to loose some steam). XD The cards of items and spells are fully animated, and I would dazzle by each new cards drawn. There is a downside to this however, the entire game Armello is still running on a board game system. It IS a board game in the end. While we normally won't have any feeling towards the little miniatures that we used to symbolize our place in the board, after looking at the cute, beautifully animated animals we control in Armello, it's hard not to develop any feeling towards it.  While the tutorial prolouge did give off some insight to the characters, I would really looking forward for more. Like how the characters would really interact with each other in some kind of RPG way. But that brings me back to my early statement. When all boils down to it, it is a board game after all (digital version).For those who are looking to enjoy a board game experience with friends, ranged from 1hour 15 min to 2 hours give or take. I would recommend trying it out. It has pretty graphics and very cute looking animals in it.

Posted: February 18, 2016
												Armello is a fun, light hearted fantasy game which features a rich experience in terms of playstyle and visuals by incorporating animations and detailed artwork to its card selections. There are a number of heroes each suited to a different playstyle, and every game leads to a new way to approach victory. With the random cards offered and different perils one can encounter, it offers a great amount of replayability and is fun with single player or friends in the multiplayer skirmishes. Makes a great gift or a purchase for yourself, either way someone's guaranteed a fun experience that dutifully recreates the feel of a classic board game, updated with interactive visuals and intuitive play. Definitely worth a try, you wont' be disappointed.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												This game is chocolate-covered bacon. A flashy video game with the heart of a solid board game. A sweet coating of eye candy with dark undertones. The gravity of Game of Thrones blended with the charm of Redwall.Given a casual glance, this may appear to be a strategy game or RPG, but make no mistake... this is truly a multiplayer board game experience in digital form. Expect much card-drawing and dice-rolling. All players take turns in succession. Complete games are fairly short, about an hour or less. It's very tightly designed, trading unnecesary complexity for satisfying depth. Each playable character has its own unique strength. While waiting for your turn, you are able to choose quests and play cards, so the thumb-twiddling common in many board games is minimized. Breaking from strict physical game tropes, there is a modest amount of progression in the form of unlockable amulets and rings that grant bonuses.On top of all this, it's very pretty, the character designs are delightful, and the animated artwork on the cards is just wonderful.It is not without its faults, though. Randomness plays a very large role, especially since conflicts are resolved with dice rolls. However, you can "stack the deck" in your favor with equipment and followers, and by burning cards. Also, the AI tends to make some pretty silly decisions at times, particularly when it comes to attacking the king. I have not played public games, so I cannot comment on the general experience there.Overall, Armello is easy to recommend if you love board games with dice and cards, especially if you can play with friends. If you are not a board game fan, this is still worth a look for its uniqueness and fun multiplayer.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												Armello is an engaging game that I really liked. It has it's basis in board and dice games, and I found the learning curve pretty easy. The graphics and music are beautiful. It has single player as well as online multiplayer. Each game takes roughly half an hour. There are 4 different ways to win suiting different play styles, fight (fight and kill the king, and live), Spirit stone (Gather 4 spirit stones. You don't have to fight anyone if you don't want to), Prestigue (have the most renown from completing tasks/killing banes or other heroes when the king dies) and Rot (one of the hardest victories for me.)I would definately recommend this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												Armello is a visually beautiful, tightly designed, quick-to-play adventure. I tend to play by myself, but multiplayer is functional and offers a bit of a different experience. I love this game.It's rare to find a game that packs so much, narratively and in terms of interesting mechanics, into a 90-minute session. All of Armello's characters are quite different from each other, and there's a lot of variety in how you set up your character to start. Once the game begins, though, it's time to be flexible, because with dice fights and card draws, you've got to enjoy rolling with the punches. I disagree with the reviewer who said that everything is determined in the first few turns -- things can, and do, change suddenly. If you want to set things up perfectly and then have them go exactly according to plan, you'll be thwarted.Armello is well worth the money, and so is the expansion. It's fun, thrilling, sometimes heartbreaking, and just technically really well done. The studio crossed their t's and it shows, and I hope they continue expanding it in the future. I would definitely throw down cash for an RPG set in the same world.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												Let me start by saying this: Armello is a fantastic game, one that I could spend hours upon hours playing for my own enjoyment. It rarely ever gets old for me personally.Armello is an anthropomorphic digital card/board game developed by the awesome people at LoG, featuring beautifully and lovingly crafted animations/artwork created by several artists, lovely background music/sounds that help to immerse you in the world, and some pretty sweet gameplay that provides unique chance and strategy based challenges. Not to mention the fully animated 3D heroes, dazzling winter/summer maps + tiles, and a cool story that's sure to have you hooked. Some may criticize the amount of RNG that occurs in this game, but really, I feel like it isn't any more than it should be. Sure, the chances may be annoying at times, but not once has it pushed me over my limits. (Basically, it didn't cause me to ragequit.)Here's a quick little bit of lore, to anyone who might be interested in this game: Basically, the King of Armello has become infected with a horrendous disease known as the Rot. It is slowly killing him a driving him mad, causing him to do outrageous and destructive things. The four clans (Wolf, Bear, Rabbit, and Rat) have put forth their heroes to take the throne and become the King/Queen of Armello by any means: Killing the King in a fight and winning, letting him die of natural causes and becoming the ruler through popularity (prestige), banishing the King with four powerful chunks of ore called Spirit Stones, or becoming an even darker lord than the Corrupt ruler, using his own rot against him in a war of sickness. You must spend the game finding resources, becoming powerful, and rising up in Armello's world of politics so you can face the King yourself; but remember, you aren't the only one with eyes on the throne. You have competition, who wish to steal the crown for themselves. The perils of the treacherous landscapes have doomed heroes for all eternity... but they have also made Kings and Queens of the unlikeliest of characters.Not only is this game top-quality in almost every aspect, but the fact that LoG is constantly putting out Updates just continues to improve the game. I could go on a whole rant about how our community is probably one of the best game communities I've ever been a part of, but I'm going to attempt to stay on track with this review.So far, I've mentioned several positives about Armello. But trust me, it isn't all sunshine and rainbows. There are a few things to be desired, and the main ones are the Multiplayer issues that appear often enough to be frustrating. Lately, I've found that I get kicked from the network at random, though that hasn't happened very recently. The game would crash for pretty much all of the players involved if it happened to one. Also, there have been complaints about not being able to return to a multiplayer session after disconnecting, but there isn't much that can be done about that. LoG themselves have stated that those particular aspects of the game have more to do with Steam than anything, so if you've disconnected, you're disconnected. Not much else to say.One last little nitpick I have: Singleplayer can become somewhat boring after a while. If played enough, the patterns (though mostly RNG based) can become familiar, and I've found that I can predict many of the AI's moves. However, AI is exactly that- Artificial Intelligence. Besides the very advanced specimens of their kind, AI will rarely ever maneuver a hero with the unpredictability and calculation of a real human player. So that, I can let go.To summarize, here's an organized list of Pros and Cons for ya:PROSIncredible game quality/experience. Top-notch graphics, orientation, and design.A lovely track; pleasing to the ears, but sinister when it wants to be. A true conveyor of the mood.An immersive plot - interesting lore and fun tidbits of story scattered throughout.Over 100 animated cards that directly credit the artists, in-game, a great sign of respect for these awesome people!Multiplayer games help you meet new people, observe new and interesting play styles, and this can really help you improve your own actions while in Armello. I noticed that, after playing nonstop multiplayer games these few weeks, I've gotten much better. AND gained a couple of awesome new friends!A fairly constant stream of updates from the Geeks themselves. I speak for the whole community when I say that their dedication to us has been beyond incredible.Awesome custom dice skins to boast!CONSMultiplayer related issues involving game crashes and lost network connection.The occasional bugs (which, mind you, LoG works VERY hard to eliminate)!Two or more players ganging up on one in particular. Sometimes people will make "Teams of Torture" where they play just to torment the odd player out. I have not come across such people before, but I know of some who have. Be reasonable, please!Leeches... people who sit at their clan grounds and continue to end their turns, simply to farm Chests and Keys without having to do any work. The very REASON LoG put these items in the game was to get people to play some Armello with each other! Avoiding doing any work while playing with people just isn't fair.I don't have much else to say in terms of Cons, because I have very little against this game at this point. 9/10, LoG, highly recommended to anyone and everyone. <3

content:
Posted: February 5
												In Armello, you play as a hero representing of one of four clans (Rat, Rabbit, Wolf and Bear) vying for the throne of Armello. At the start of the game, the King of Armello is infected by the Rot and starts dying slowly. You and three other players must gain prestige, fight battles and cast spells while the king descends into madness and finally dies in order to ensure your place as his successor on the throne of Armello. I've fallen in love with Armello for several reasons:  It is a deep strategic tabletop-like experience with multiple paths to victory and interesting decisions throughout.  It has an epic scope with games lasting around one hour and half with each turn being more exciting than the last and never leaving you bored.  The game design is top-notch, its greatest success is that no matter how behind I am, I've never felt out of the game.   It has beautiful 2D and 3D artwork and animations.If any of this sounds interesting to you then I hope to see you in Armello.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												I don't often write that many Steam reviews, however I felt like I had to for this one.To put it simply, Armello is a fantastic game. There is so much about this that makes me squel with joy when I play. It's just oozing with love and you can clearly see that the developers, League of Geeks, put a great deal of effort into this title. There is a ton of character and charm behing this. The art direction is fantastic. The whole game idea is just so good. This is one of the best "tabletop to video-game" takes that I've had the joy to play.There are a few things that I would like to see get added to the game though.First, I would love it if there was another game mode. This is obviously something that would take a ton of effort to produce. However, I'd be more than happy to pay some if this was part of a DLC pack or something. The base game offers a ton of variety. This is due to the fact that you can aim for a variety of different victory conditions. It would still be cool if there was a secondary game mode that was some other task than trying to deal with the king and his rot. This could also be an avenue for creating a game that lasted shorter. As it stands, the games take quite a while (not too different from a board game). Some people might not always like that, or have the time to sit down and play for that long. If there was a secondary one that went quicker, that would be awesome.Second, just give me more Armello! More heroes, cards, quests, and all the like! I just love the game so much, having more content to it, even though it really does have a ton right now, would be so sweet!Sorry for the long review. If you can't tell, I really, really, love Armello. So yeah, if you like strategy and/or tabletop games, get this. Seriously. It's fantastic.Alright. Gushing over.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												Short version: A delightful, quick, fun game. A dice & cards based combat system. Easy to play, fast game matches, custom modes. Worth the price but a must buy if discounted. Good as a single player but more fun in multi-player. Worth it.Long version: This is a fun digital boardgame that allows you to take as much or little interest in your opponents as you wish. Choose a character from the different clans that best suits your style whether that be sword & adventure, subtle & stealthy, magic & trickery or a mix.Graphics: The cut scenes are very nice, the cards have small animations that a subtle and humourous whether this is a stranger twitching his eye or seeing a bear get struck by lightning and seeing the skeleton & ribcage light up, it's a nice touch, The movements are smooth and the rigging on the characters have been done well. The interface is easy to use and clean.Sound design: Decent mix of music and sound effects. The ambient environment sounds can be repetitive and annoying at times but zooming out removes those but they are be overwhelming if you are zoomed in at maximum. The music is good but there isn't any theme or music cue that really stands out but it's enough to give you a decent feel of the mood but it isn't the most amazing soundtrack which I think is probably the low point of the game which means the rest if pure gold.Game-play: Tough to describe as it's a mix of drawing cards, dice rolls, substituting dice rolls if you have the right cards and using passive abilities at the right times as well as gaging when to use active abilities based on the day/night cycle.It's fun. It's easy to pick up. Each character has a very distinctive play style but you don't have to beholden to that and can easily play your own way. I like that it can be a very coop game until the last few rounds as it becomes a race to the crown but it can just the same be played as PVP all the way through.Overall I'm impressed with the game's theme, style, structured tutorial which is heavily story-line focused making you gain an affinity for the characters then suddenly have them turn villain on you as soon as you are invested in them emotionally.Looking forward to seeing what else the devs bring out. Excellent.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												I love this game already. I've played many great graphical games but few have given me the kinda of thrill I had tonight on this virtual board game. As Thane (the wolf) I was locked into this epic duel with the king as we both constantly kept endlessly drawing each other other in attack versus defense with him down to one HP and me down to 2 WHILE fighting off rivals THREE times all in two turns! It was amazingly epic.This game is really addicting but every game has its cons sadly. But there's really only 3 i can mention, so I will just name 3 of each of my biggest cons and pros.Cons:-Short gameplay. Even "Epic" setting isn't long. I don't like that the king auto dies after a period of time. At least let him retain one HP or have an option to turn rot off on King or something.-Map can feel small. It has some random generation but 4 heroes + 2 - 5 kings guards and banes (or even more) all at once can make it feel congested. That means lots of battles, which can be hard on people trying to be more stealthy. It might be just my lack of experience so far, but it seems flat out battling with decent equipment is the way to go. Did a round as the Wolf and never died once with a defensive build while managing to kill off most people by sacrificing saved up cards for +damage rolls when I felt needed to.-Lack of customization. I don't think there really needs to be one but it would be nice if we could, say, create a custom with our own name of choosing, cycle models and pick the one we like most then pick a playstyle or something. Either way, implemented or not I enjoy the current characters a lot. Pros:-Creativity. Man does creativity come into play or you could find yourself surrounded by enemies. It's not a bad idea to draw some spell cards or trickery cards to lower someones HP or find a way to make a quick getaway.-Battles can get intensive and the world change instantly. You can go from peaceful to people surrounded by banes and guards going after player bounties. I love the complete randomness of it! Even quests are never a promised reward.-Freedom and Politics. Politics can change the flow of the game. And I love going from being the prestigious kings right hand man to stabbing him in the throat the next turn for fun.In the end, this game is amazing. It's random, can change in a flash, and when you get into it you can FEEL the struggle sometimes. Seriously, worth the pay.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												Great artistic design, cute and charming characters, and a good, if quick board game to boot.  Recommended with friends!  We all know the positives, so I'll take the time to list out some moderate to mild issues.  NOTE: I have only played singleplayer so far.Number one!  OPTIONS MENU.  PLEASE LET ME ADJUST DETAIL MORE SPECIFICALLY.  Medium, High, and Very High run at around the same framerates but low bumps me up to a flat 60 no problem.  I want to enjoy the aesthetic but dropping below 30 is unacceptable to me.  Unfortunately, Low has the most drastic change and blurs out a lot of the detail.  Two: AI could use a bit of tweaking.  Sometimes they'll walk into swamps and...die.  Oh.  Othertimes they'll be great.  Varying AI difficulty would be nice, if difficult to integrate, but it would go a long way into extending the longevity of the game.3: Game balance?  Prestiging seems like the easiest way to win right now, at least against AI.  More often then not, I inexplicably end up with 5-6 prestige a few rounds in (without trying) while the AI generally has much less than me.  There need to be more prestige debuffs, I think.  Also, it seems the more cards you hold, the more likely you'll be able to win, so that might need to be rebalanced as well.

												Armello basicly is a digital boardgame in which strategy is important. You play against 3 other characters, which could be AI, or online players/friends. I must say that when you play against AI, you are almost sure of a prestige victory or a kingslayer victory when you choose the right character and have the right items equipped. Although, luck must be yours, since it seems that the game also depends on the luck you have.It has amazing animations and artstyle in both the board and the playing cards. The fighting scene surprised me, since this is not like the rest of the animations, but is still amazing.I normally play games that support controller with a controller, but I must say this game is also perfect for keyboard.I've played AI games of around 50 minutes, when not playing on double speed, and online games of around 1h30m, since turntaking takes some more time. If you've played with all 8 characters available at the moment I write this, it's best to move to online, because of the earlier mentioned reasons. When playing online, everything can happen, even going from prestige leader to last in the final round.To summarize:Beautiful boardgame with amazing artwork, though it can get a bit boring if you don't play online.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												It is amazing to me that I have yet to write one of these for this game but this is what I have to say about Armello. Armello is an amazing game, with astonishing visuals, awesome battle animations and amazingly crafted characters and variety that just screams "MUST REPLAY". Even with rather light-hearted customization abilities, the character personalities and the separation via clans has you clutched in a constant internal battle of which character best fits you and what clan do you truly belong to. (Personally I prefer Rat clan, Mercurio is love, Mercurio is life).The game really is simple to learn and easy to pick up, with hundreds of card combinations that allow for a different experience within each play through. I always find myself delegating each character to different victory types only to realize that I may have misjudged one, and having to play even more Armello to truly discover the potential each character has. Having 4 Victory conditions, that being in Spirit Stone, Rot, King Slayer and Prestige also adds to the pace and variety of the game, as you may find yourself geared towards a King Slayer Victory only to realize that you have 4 Spirit Stones or a ton of prestige and thus having to change your method of plan in order to better suite the type of victory that you are geared towards. This also allows you to find different ways to play the same character and really discover their potential even further. The game is loads of fun, every game is different, every play style is different, and having so many characters to choose from (with more coming soon) really allows for a fresh feel every time you play.  The board design is beautiful, with the chance of winter occurring and snow being sprinkled all over the land, as well as a really awesome transition in animation whenever you enter a battle sequence. The swift strikes of Mercurio's blade, the bulky bludgeoning blows of Brun's Mace and even the Cute and Adorable expressions that Barnaby makes when he swings his hammer really adds personality to the battles. But don't let that adorableness fool you because Barnaby can really kick♥♥♥♥♥ I wlil admit the damage animation really surprised me as well I definitely wasn't expecting blood and the sound effects that accompany really instill the feeling of pain in you, you almost do feel annihilated when you are super over-killed by any character. This definitely livens up the battle and makes it a much more invigorating aspect of the game to engage in.I will say this however. Armello is hard to master, but not because of real complexities of the game and characters. Yes you can customize the stats of your character in so many different ways offering so many different ways for you to play, but at the end of the day Armello is all luck. Yes there are ways in which you can modify your stats and skills in order to better yourself for victory but everything down to the bone of this game is luck. The cards you draw, the dice you roll, the gains from dungeons, the spoils form quests, everything is luck and in the end you are basically finding ways to manipulate RNG to work in your favor. Which brings me to defense. Armello loves seeing the attack dice stack up to ungodly amounts, (I myself have had 20 attack dice in a battle before) with 3 sides of the dice awarding you with a hit on either time of day corrupted or not, you can literally get infinite attack if the RNG works in your favor. Unfortunately there is only 1 of the six sides that awards you defense, making it extremely difficult to survive in some cases. Yes there are items and cards that can remedy this but again it is up to the luck of the draw and luck of the roll to gain shields. Even with that, you can enter a battle with 20 dice against someone with maybe 5 and still end up dead due to favored rolls for attack and getting no shield dice. You only need so many hits to kill and so many hits to survive and more times than not you will find yourself overkilling by massive amounts only to get hit just enough to die, making the overkill, very enjoyable to receive but meaningless in the end due to dying anywayIf you are looking for a game to play "competitively" Armello is honestly not your game, sure there is that wonderful rush of "you are never truly out of the game" but more times than not it is the game just rewarding you with lucky rolls and draws than it is you being rewarded for playing skillfully. Which is unfortunate because while it feels great to win games in Armello (believe me I take so many screenshots and share them happily, they make great desktop backgrounds) some of that glory is taken away by the shear fact that as strategic and skilled as you can be in the game, 90% of that was still RNG potentially playing in your favor or it playing your favor when it mattered most. With that being said, I have played well over 300 hours and as frustrating as this game can be (believe me, it really can) it has that charm and style that makes you want to play more. Part of it is the competitive player in me not accepting a loss and having to prove the might of the rat clan (RNG please Mercurio loves you) but another part really just is the connection you establish with the game. The characters in my opinion are more than board pieces manipulated across a board. They are characters with personalities and styles that give life to the game you are playing. For the longest my twitter handle Read *Rat Clan* because I truly enjoyed the witty gameplay that came with Mercurio and the rat clan. This game is tons of fun to play with friends, and still an experience to behold online with other players. But I can completely understand people growing weary of it after a few hours of play and there are definitely ways for this game to be even better than it is.I end this by saying one of the biggest reasons I still play and have played over 300 hours is the community. The developers are really invested in the community, listening to forums, chats, hell every week they have a Dev v Community game stream where you can face the devs (I won one, not many people can say that ;)) and that really breathes a deeper life into this because you become even more invested in a game that you know is not only bringing you a satisfying experience but one that is listening to you as well. Mercurio knows that he can be OP sometimes but he is doing his best to understand your pain and tone down his desire to Hoodwink you. Buy the game, it is worth it, even if you only play a few times!

content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												This is my first review on steam. I have played about 80 hours on the game and have probably unlocked all the rings, each game taking about an hour or so. I bought this game out of curiosity since the graphics were just amazing to look at. The sound impressed me as well. What I like about it is that it is a friendly game that doesn't have in game chat. It kind of hinders the social experience of the game but keeps it civil, instead having the built in text to choose from. This game has an interesting concept of having four ways to win which is rot victory, highest prestige, 4 spirit stones, and defeating the king. It's really fun how there are lots of ways to win and kill your opponents. There is a lot of strategy going on, such as skill cards, magic cards, and trap cards. You must go on with your quest while defeating your enemies and winning by one of the four victories. There is a lot going on in this game. The dice is also an excellent touch, since it allows you to click on it randomly which allows it to be fair aND challenging. Beware that although I do recommend this game, there are still more developments that should be made. Such as when the Internet connection is loss, you are automatically kicked out and cannot join the same game. Penalties for leaving games should be longer since it destroys the overall game play of having to play with AL players. Ranked matches are also not availible yet. Overall I recommend this game despite its ongoing developments because it is visually satisfying and fun.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												An addicting and amazing boardgame with a relatively steep learning curve.The game has an amazing vibe, good compelling dynamics and is beautifully, masterfully crafted in order to make RNG not only competitive but not that frustrating!!So to explain how they did that (or why I believe they did) I must first say that, I bought this game as a boardgame designer, to understand some really interesting peculiarities.It is imbedded in RNG and as far as transparency goes, this game is not an example. So is it bad? No...As a strong believer in pre-production and heavy design in order to combat rng and give space to balance and skill, this game showed me new possibilities for luck and uses it in a way that hasnt really been seen in Boardgames before.Most decisions in the game, involve luck ( % ), however, it is post luck, as in, first macro decisions (where you go, what you do and so on) then micro decisions that will have luck mechanic. To illustrate: you gear your character, move him on the map and decide whether you want to engage in luck events or not. IF you do, then your gear, character info (relative to race, buffs, etc) shall weigh the outcome of the event, may it be a battle or some other encounter.So luck serves as a weight to your moves in order to make the game more competitive and dense Strategically wise.Furthermore, the game uses really amazing Aesthetics to brush off unecessary intensity and soothe your experience, as a hot soup blow. So when rng does get on your nerves, you will barely notice it over the amazing music, illustrations and whole experience.The only con to the game, is the amount of info you must attend to simultaneously. Meaning that, while it does have a good UI, it uses the fact it is a digital boardgame, to incert more information than anyone could possibly process. PLus, the learning curve is indeed steep and although tutorial process is connected storywise, it is still a dull process....All in all, this game is really really good and worth cutting through the tough leathery learning membrane. Online games are really intense but still manage to maintain the shoothing game's vibe. 8/10

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								EARLY ACCESS REVIEWAs an avid play of board games, tabletop RPGs, and computer games, Armello was an obvious choice to try. A very beautiful game with a lot of care and craft put into it so far, but not without its problems. PROS:- The artwork is amazing, making even the humdrum activities like running into perils (traps set by other players or npcs) or picking out items sublime. This alone is worth the purchase IMO.- The blend between board game and computer game is carried out well. While on the surface Armello may appear to be an adaptation of a board game for computers, what with the map, the dice, the cards, etc., the automation of the game format allows complex rules and events to be streamlined in a way no board game could reproduce smoothly. It manages to be both casual and relaxed while still involving the players and suspending disbelief.- The graphics are not only serviceable but quite nice to look at. The aesthetic is strong visually, and there's very little clutter. The models for the characters and npcs are very faithful to the art.- The sound, while not spectacular, is pleasant and fits the thematic elements of the game nicely. After hearing the music over the dozen or so games I've played I can still say that it's not grating. CONS:- The price point of $25 is a bit steep if you ask me. Perhaps it's just because it's still early access that I feel this way, but for those of us on a tight budget it's a shame to have to hold off on purchasing such a beautiful game for want of funds. - Understanding that this is still early access, I can't help but feel that, after 18 hours of playing this game, it's starting to wear a tad thin. They do release updates fairly regularly, adding new cards and quests, but it is starting to feel repetitive. There's only one game mode and right now only four characters. This means that every game of Armello will run pretty much the same way, with some variations. Apparently four more characters are coming with the full release (in fall maybe), but I'm not sure that even that will be enough to get me to invest another 18 hours. Generally the game follows one of three possible outcomes (prestige victory, spirit stone victory, or killing the king), with the same time limit every game based on the king's deteriorating health. Personal quests vary the game quite a bit, but often you can only get one or two done before the game's conclusion.I would like to see the introduction of optional modifiers. Perhaps options to extend the game, or perhaps team-based play could help the repetition. Or maybe different ending objectives, such as we see in Talisman, could improve replay value. Something like a bane-rush mode, where Banes spawn more rapidly, or where players work cooperatively to repel them. CONCLUSION:This game has its problems, but I don't hesitate to recommend it. Quite possibly the most beautiful game I've ever played. It plays to the strength of the board-game style while keeping things smooth and exciting with the speed of a computer game. However, don't expect to get it on sale before full release; the devs have specifically stated that they do not intend to put the game on sale any time soon.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												Beautiful design, art, and score. What can I say more? ;)The goal is simple: Become King/Queen of Armello. The actual accomplishment of the goal is far less simple. ;) If you've ever joked that Monopoly ruins friendships... Armello is just like that, haha! Backstabbing and strategizing all over the place-- but on a gorgeous backdrop with adorable, lovable characters.Every game is different enough to keep things interesting and keep me, at least, always coming back for more. (After a year of playing, I've finally won ONCE! But, then, I suck at strategy and thinking ahead and keeping track of my fellow players. :P) The map is variable, and you have oodles of playable character choices to cut your teeth on. :)I recommend everyone give Armello a serious consideration. You won't regret it!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												This is my first review on steam. I have played about 80 hours on the game and have probably unlocked all the rings, each game taking about an hour or so. I bought this game out of curiosity since the graphics were just amazing to look at. The sound impressed me as well. What I like about it is that it is a friendly game that doesn't have in game chat. It kind of hinders the social experience of the game but keeps it civil, instead having the built in text to choose from. This game has an interesting concept of having four ways to win which is rot victory, highest prestige, 4 spirit stones, and defeating the king. It's really fun how there are lots of ways to win and kill your opponents. There is a lot of strategy going on, such as skill cards, magic cards, and trap cards. You must go on with your quest while defeating your enemies and winning by one of the four victories. There is a lot going on in this game. The dice is also an excellent touch, since it allows you to click on it randomly which allows it to be fair aND challenging. Beware that although I do recommend this game, there are still more developments that should be made. Such as when the Internet connection is loss, you are automatically kicked out and cannot join the same game. Penalties for leaving games should be longer since it destroys the overall game play of having to play with AL players. Ranked matches are also not availible yet. Overall I recommend this game despite its ongoing developments because it is visually satisfying and fun.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												I have enjoyed this game, the art style, gameplay and over all idea if pretty fun. I would give it a 7/10 though, few reason which I'll give below.Pros:-Lovely Art Style-Interesting play style of the old hexagon rpg table tops-Animations are well done and fluid-Concept of the game is imagnitive-Multiplayer works well and tests your friendships (Who will help you or end you)-Interesting Game mechanics, from complete dice modification, to in game affect through choices.-Loveable and cute characters: I mean look a Barneby, He's so damn eager to bonk them. Cons:-No game customization (You can't alter your map experience, each map is rerolled at a set size. Ways to fix this would be allow an option of multiple map sizes, with other game alterations)-Winning is single minded: You win by having the highest prestige, whether or not you have slayed the king or not. (Ways to fix this, Make prestige victory a draw breaker [both player and king die or king dies without a killing blow being dealt] I beleive the game could have alternative ways to win as well, fix the king, remove the rot from him, corrupt him fully, etc)-Restricted Character: The block on the additional bandit clan almost made me not buy this, and some of my friends refunded because of this. This is a good way to hurt player base when you have a purchasable game with locked characters, if the game was FTP then it would be understandable, or if they were purchasable from a DLC (Which would be a good idea for future clans as well, or adding them in as free updates)-Short: This game is short, if you don't love it, you'll get bored quickly.The map is as big as a small continent from Sid meiser's Civ games. Quests only go to about 5 or 6 (haven't counted persoanlly) before you get end game quest.

Early Access Review
								What do you get when you mash up a board game, an RPG, and animals into a PC game?  Apparently you get Armello!  In the grand tradition of games like Dokapon Kingdom you play as one of four characters who are trying to set themselves up while the king dies.  The games are fairly quick (maximum of 18 turns until the King's demise) but with 4 ways to win (and more ways to screw over your friends) why not pick this up!

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												An addicting and amazing boardgame with a relatively steep learning curve.The game has an amazing vibe, good compelling dynamics and is beautifully, masterfully crafted in order to make RNG not only competitive but not that frustrating!!So to explain how they did that (or why I believe they did) I must first say that, I bought this game as a boardgame designer, to understand some really interesting peculiarities.It is imbedded in RNG and as far as transparency goes, this game is not an example. So is it bad? No...As a strong believer in pre-production and heavy design in order to combat rng and give space to balance and skill, this game showed me new possibilities for luck and uses it in a way that hasnt really been seen in Boardgames before.Most decisions in the game, involve luck ( % ), however, it is post luck, as in, first macro decisions (where you go, what you do and so on) then micro decisions that will have luck mechanic. To illustrate: you gear your character, move him on the map and decide whether you want to engage in luck events or not. IF you do, then your gear, character info (relative to race, buffs, etc) shall weigh the outcome of the event, may it be a battle or some other encounter.So luck serves as a weight to your moves in order to make the game more competitive and dense Strategically wise.Furthermore, the game uses really amazing Aesthetics to brush off unecessary intensity and soothe your experience, as a hot soup blow. So when rng does get on your nerves, you will barely notice it over the amazing music, illustrations and whole experience.The only con to the game, is the amount of info you must attend to simultaneously. Meaning that, while it does have a good UI, it uses the fact it is a digital boardgame, to incert more information than anyone could possibly process. PLus, the learning curve is indeed steep and although tutorial process is connected storywise, it is still a dull process....All in all, this game is really really good and worth cutting through the tough leathery learning membrane. Online games are really intense but still manage to maintain the shoothing game's vibe. 8/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												5/5 StarsI'm one of the original backers for the game, and I'm very satisfied with having backed this project. It is exactly what I thought it would be in all of the early material, and it is just as much fun as I had hoped. This is very much a board game that I don't think could reasonably exist in physical form due to its stealth, ambush, and quest mechanics, and thus is a unique experience for board gamers and something that should be added to any collection.The characters and plot quests are reminiscent of Arkham Horror, as is the concept of multiple types of victory. I love Arkham Horror for its story and chacters, so of course I consider these to be good characteristics to emulate.I love that the prestige leader gets to choose between two potentially very bad options. It provides a reason to stay competitive about prestige even if you're trying for a different kind of victory.The AI is challenging and aggressive, so getting a victory is not a cakewalk and feels more like competing with other real players.As for the graphics and music, I think the music is perfect for the game, and the animate card graphics are lovely. If I want to be picky, I think the 3D animations could have been better. They're a bit too sharp and block defined around the edges, though the movements are smooth. They're a bit reminiscent of early 3D animations in games rather than being on par with where we are right now. But in terms of turning out a great game on a budget and on schedule, I think the simpler animations were a good choice.It's also worth mentioning that if you like achievement hunting in games, this is definitely a game for you, as even if you feel you're going to lose the quest to rule Armello, you can focus on completing some of the Steam achievements, which means even a game where luck is not on your side can make you feel that you accomplished something.If you are a board gamer or know someone who is, I highly recommend picking up Armello.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												You don't just need Armello now, this game was needed ten years ago. Armello brings me back to a simpler time when gaming felt like an excursion in to another realm. And here, with the help of the other Armellians and even some multiplayer companions, I can escape into that realm. The music is so intensely beautiful that I sought out the soundtrack via Armello.com.The visuals harken to Redwall with a color pallette that looks like a fairy tale of paint and bloom.The gameplay is so quick to grab onto and satisfying that you'll lose hours to it as you perfect strategies.I could say so many things and I've reviewed this game once already online but I will say that this game deserves the meager price in which it's offered and don't let the Early Access scare you away -- this game is as polished as you could expect from a full release and is being updated regularly.Not enough love can be expressed for Armello. It deserves evangelizing.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												I have trouble finding the words to do Armello justice. It is a wonderfully thought up board game, but developed to be played in a digital format, as a result it can do things that tabletop boardgames just can't. Players using stealth vanish from the board, there are neutral 'characters' who have their own agendas in game, the game itself is very carefully crafted and cleverly put together to be interesting and gets very challenging if you go online.But all of this is secondary to the one thing that League of Gamers utterly nailed, and that is the theme. The aesthetic of Armello is a joy to behold, from the serene looking map and hauntingly simple but evocative background tunes to the cheery character designs and battle animations and card art that will make you want to stop and take the time to appreciate it from time to time.Okay, sure, the AI players are a little easy and finding a game online can be a little difficult depending on your time zone and when you're looking, but there is still development going on and content being added, with the Bandit clan DLC on it's way and recent 'the stranger' update shaking up the ruleset a little, it seems hopeful that we'll see some more expansions and further improvements to an already wonderful game.Highly recommended to any lovers of board games.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												I'm over 100 hours into Armello now, mostly in multi-player.  The game is a real hidden gem; it's fun, it's cheap to buy, and it's still getting cool new stuff added to it.I enjoy the competition and wild unpredictability of multi player mode the most, but be warned: it's a turn-based game, and sometimes you get a player or two that is reeeeeeally slooooow at taking their turns, which really ruins the game flow.I think as time goes on, you'll be seeing mostly players who are pretty quick at taking their turns though. It's the noobs who tend to agonize and overthink their turns, somehow not noticing that the biggest factor is simply your dice rolls.  And once the current sale is over, I think we'll be seeing a lot less noobs.For sheer fun, and cartoon animal silliness, Armello is a definite 10/10. And if slow turns get you down, there's always single player, which plays VERY fast. Almost too fast, because AI opponents love to try to kill the king and end the game ASAP. Make sure you're always #1 in Prestige ranking when you do single-player, cuz often the AI opponents aren't even close to being geared enough to kill the king and survive, so the winner ends up being the player with the highest Prestige.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												Usually i'm skeptical of games that try to fuse too many genres, but Armello does it really well. The strategy, CCG, and RPG elements and each simple enough that the game is easy to learn, but they blend in organically so the game achieves and depth through width. Plus, the individual charactes have a good amount of balanced variety so you can either rely heavily on the game mechanics you like the most or do a bit of everything and still have a chance at winning. The game does rely heavily on RNG, but there are countless ways to control it and effectively doing so is what makes you a good player. Bonus points for having a great art style. Well worth 20 bucks.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												This game is simply wonderful.It has a story, and a very good one at that. Its not even a story that you can act upon, since its, you know, a board game. It works as the setting to the world the game happens on, explains why youre doing what youre doing, and it even expands farther from whats needed to provide depth. There is even lore to explain what exactly is the Rot, which is a game changing mechanic, even though you dont really have to know what it is to appreciate and play the game.It has quests. No, it doesnt have level ups or anything, the quests are simply there to take you to your objective (and equip you on the way) to take the throne. If you pay attention to the questgiver's dialogue, it expands upon the aforementioned lore, so you know what your chosen hero is going through even though you arent in 1st or 3rd person controlling mode.Speaking of characters, those are charismatic, and each has its own lore and gameplay. While you can finish the game by completing any of the objectives, its clear that some characters are better suited to some victory approaches than others. This makes for a varied strategical touch, and adds a lot to the games replayability and, given that its a multiplayer game, its not as if you will only want to play this once anyways.Lastly, graphics and animations are amazing, music is impressively good (you dont mind at all that its being looped), and the spell effects are beautiful. As for bugs, so far I have encountered only one kind, which stops game flow when someone drops from the game; seems to be a bit random, although it may be caused solely when the player disconnects during a load screen. And for those of you worried about raging players, fret not, there isnt an open chat during matches; all players are limited to a quite big selection of interactions, roleplayed by the chosen characters.Overall, great game, fully recommended, way worth the full price, and it still has unreleased content, so keep an eye out for updates.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												I bought Armello upon release, something I don't usually do (wait for patches/sales/etc), but I don't regret it.Basically, it feels like a great board game ported to videogame world.Pros:- Overall great game mechanics: balanced enough so skill/experience matters, random enough to make it interesting and not pre-defined- Dice-based combat- You have a lot of options and strategies to pursue during your turn- Good art (especially cards) and lore- Flawless Linux version (single player)Cons:- Problems in multiplayer (see below)- Minor flaws in the interface OK, not for the hard part. So multiplayer clearly has some issues, and while some of them (network problems and game-stalling bugs) can be expected to be fixed in the near future, others are more tricky.The average multiplayer game lasts 1 to 1.5 hours, and you don't have much to do during your opponents turns and game events (King's Guards and Banes) - that is, 70 to 80% of the time.It would be perfectly ok for a BOARD game, where you can chat with your friends/fool around/do some diplomacy, but it i NOT a board game (although feels a lot like one).You even don't have an in-game chat, only pre-defined emotes.Some options to overcome this:- play with friends and chat in Skype/whatever- read Twitter/what you prefer during other players' turns- have a beer in hand (always helps)That being said, I still enjoyed multiplayer to a certain point, and single player is completely OK (although can get boring after 10-15 hrs).

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Board game + Card abilities + RPG and Strategy elementsThis may sound like a weird combination, and perhaps this game is the first of its kind... but it actually works well!It is based on a board game of the same name. However, it seems the developers are so passionate about their project that they added some abilities and mechanics that were not present in the original board game.Even though the game is perfectly playable and enjoyable in the current early access, they are still releasing regular updates nearly every 2 weeks. Some of these updates introduce new mechanics and remake old ones, but the overall effect is an ongoing IMPROVEMENT.Graphics: Simple 3D graphics on the main map + animated cartoon characters. The animal characters remind me of the Disney version of Robin Hood... but even MORE charming. Don't be fooled by the cartoonish characters >> this game is suitable for all ages and has enough depth and variety that older gamers will definitely find it worth playing.Sound: Once again, simple and elegant. The music complements the graphics and atmosphere perfectly. If you play this game, you will wish that they make a movie from it. I'm not kidding. The immersion is that solid. The main downsides here are a lack of narration and voice-acting. Some music tracks can get a little repetitive. Adding 2 or 3 more tracks would be great.Gameplay: The game has a perfect balance of complexity and accessibility. It is easy to learn but also requires your constant attention if you want to win. You currently play against 3 other players in both single and multiplayer (4 players only). There are 4 victory conditions, all of which are related to the King's inevitable death. (as you may have heard, it's like a Disney version of Game of Thrones... except it is way better than the current Disney stuff)In Early Access you start with 4 playable characters. Another 8 will be available in full release (according to the forums). They all feel unique and each is more suited to certain victory conditions than the others. And you can still choose your starting bonuses with amulets and rings, so there are plenty of combinations for you to experiment with. Replayability is very high and rewards you with unlocking a variety of starting bonuses.In terms of strategy, the game is mostly about making the best out of what you have and holding on to your advantages. It is currently difficult to aim for a specific victory condition without getting lucky (especially Rot and Spirit victory). So ultimately, the Prestige victory is the most likely end-scenario, especially versus AI (who is not the smartest). Nevertheless, they recently made new additions to the Spirit victory (and added cards that will help you achieve it). So the end-game scenario is gradually being improved. I anticipate a well-balanced game at full release.Overall, this casual yet engaging experience is recommended for anyone who enjoys Strategy/RPG and wants something more relaxing than Civ 5 every now and then. This is also a great game for families. If you want to introduce your kids to Strategy gaming and play with them, Armello is perfect for the job even in Early Access.Early Access rating: 7/10 - worth the priceFor more details, check out my Let's Play below! (NOTE: my Let's Play is from BEFORE the "At Wyld's Will" update. The Spirit Victory has been changed after that update. Keep that in mind.)


YouTube™ Video: Let's play Armello #1: That wascawi wabbit! (Intro with Amber) 

			Views: 91		

			Greetings! This time we will be playing through an early access Turn-based strategy game with minor RPG elements. It's called Armello and it is based on a board game of the same name.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												I bought Armello upon release, something I don't usually do (wait for patches/sales/etc), but I don't regret it.Basically, it feels like a great board game ported to videogame world.Pros:- Overall great game mechanics: balanced enough so skill/experience matters, random enough to make it interesting and not pre-defined- Dice-based combat- You have a lot of options and strategies to pursue during your turn- Good art (especially cards) and lore- Flawless Linux version (single player)Cons:- Problems in multiplayer (see below)- Minor flaws in the interface OK, not for the hard part. So multiplayer clearly has some issues, and while some of them (network problems and game-stalling bugs) can be expected to be fixed in the near future, others are more tricky.The average multiplayer game lasts 1 to 1.5 hours, and you don't have much to do during your opponents turns and game events (King's Guards and Banes) - that is, 70 to 80% of the time.It would be perfectly ok for a BOARD game, where you can chat with your friends/fool around/do some diplomacy, but it i NOT a board game (although feels a lot like one).You even don't have an in-game chat, only pre-defined emotes.Some options to overcome this:- play with friends and chat in Skype/whatever- read Twitter/what you prefer during other players' turns- have a beer in hand (always helps)That being said, I still enjoyed multiplayer to a certain point, and single player is completely OK (although can get boring after 10-15 hrs).
