												4 ways to win, 8 characters(I hear more are coming, like Squirrels) with their own bonuses and only takes around 30 minutes for a full game.  I love how you can customize to set yourself up, but then the little bit of randomness in each of the three decks of cards (you choose which you draw from) can totally change your strategy."I just need one more Spirit for this Teleport" "This ally makes my spells cheaper" "A staff that gives me prestige for holding towns?" "Shoot 2 points of rot right off the bat I guess I should try for the Rot Victory" "Oh a spirit stone appeared right beside me, maybe I should collect them"  "I can box him in with Perils..." These are the kind of things you'll be saying.  There is a large element of luck, but a lot of it is playing(or finding ways to get rid of) your cards well and the game can quickly change right up to the end.A wonderful race of guts and glory, my new GOTO game when I don't have a ton of time to sink.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												Wonderful multiplayer experience for fans of tabletop gaming of all varieties. Hexagon style board and movement with resource management simialr to catan with the developemnt and progression focused on character characfer instead of a settlement. Nice reward system that seems to give you an additional different bonus to select pregame each time you utilize a different playstyle/character , which continually opens up more options for you. Gorgeous artwork that was clearly held in high importance during development. Matches move at a decent pace, giving you limited, but not entirely absent, actions to perform during other players turns. Length of each match is nice, most taking under an hour, giving you enough time to figure out a playstyle or character and moving on to another. The music is pleasant and fits mood nicely, but does not stand out in any particular way. Combat is simple, using a unique D6 system that is supplemented by combat and spell items and based off various symbols as opposed to numbers. Could benefit from an initiative system, as of now both characters engaged in combat simply get their full attack turn with no real importance to order unless they are outright slaughtered, going nearly negative their full health pool.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												Surprisingly rich and complex boardgame brought to the PC in a really beautiful way. There is a surprisingly depth to Armello, for each of the characters, that would make this game terrible to play on a tabletop, but as a digital boardgame it excels -- impressive!There is a fair bit of cartoon violence and intercharacter conflict... which is to say, murdering your fellow players is an effective and often necessary strategy -- friendships beware. Death is only a minor setback, and may be beneficial in many cases, though.The art style is beautiful and accentuates the background story and keeps every turn engaging. Attack animations, unique touches for the characters, and wonderful card art (and animation!) are all top notch. If you're curious, investigate how they incentivized art contributions!There are a few bugs: things like chunks of the interface that can go missing, but for the most part, resetting resolution or alt-tabbing can fix that. Full-screen functionality (Command+F) on Mac seems to be wonky, but works most of the time. There are some sound issues.Game balance is pretty well done. Rot seems hard to collect, but that's about the extent of it. Some folks complain about River sniping the king, but to them I say, kill the Wolf! Would love to see better error-handling in the netcode, as there is no way to get a player that disconnected back into the game; they're replaced by a hot.Note that the game is MUCH improved by playing with real players. The AI is a little on the simple side and tends to go all out to fixate on a specific character each game -- often the player. You can't argue with AI, and the minor metagame of diplomacy does improve the experience.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												Ups and downs, but fun regardless, especially so when playing with friends. It's good in that the gameplay is solid and straightforward, with a simple set of rules but a lot of room for skill and creative maneuvering. It's particularly interesting in that it's not always clear whether it's good or bad to accumulate or lose points in a certain statistic. Some games you will want to be poor, some games rich, some games you'll be forced to make unconventional plays, and some games you'll find it better to suicide in certain situations, even though suicide is a bad thing in this game. Or is it? Only thing that bothered me about the game was that it just took too long for the AI-controlled units and entities to take their turns.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												Having watched this game through Early Access iterations and release, I can say that the game is fun and also that the devs care that it is in a good state.HARDWAREGTX 970, Phenom II X6 @ 3.2ghz, 16gb RAM, SSDMouse and Keyboard Steam Controller - Works great, see below.Performance - The game never drops below 60FPS and looks great 98% of the time.  Minor texture flickering may occur and occasional audio performance issues from using the newly released Steam Controlled and Big Picture mode it seems.  The game is being constantly updated.  I have experienced NMA (no more action) bugs only twice or so in my 74 hours of gameplay, some other minor bugs after its release from early access as well but the release is solid and you should not experience any real issues either.  Netplay seems to work very reliably and has Steam integration for playing with friends.Gameplay - Armello is more or less a tabletop board game where you control one of several semi-customizable heroes in your quest to be the new king.  This is achieved by acruing the most prestige when the king dies of a magical corruption (or failed regicide), killing the king and surviving, or by collecting four artefacts required to cure him.   You have several decks of cards with themes of equipment, magic, and subterfuge, which you can draw and play towards your goal.  There's choices on how to progress your character, risks to weigh against rewards, and plenty of tussles to be had with the other players as you fight each other along the way.  The thematics in this game are all wonderful, and the art, music, and visuals all contribute to the great presentation.  The duration of a full-length online game is about 45-90 minutes depending on how long people take on their turns, and it can be less if a player achieves one of the other victory conditions,But is it fun?  I think so.  The game has a strong element of RNG.  Random board terrain, cards drawn, AI character movement, fickle dice rolls, and other players strangely unpredictable behavior all contribute towards making the game seem a crapshoot.  One of the more prevalent complaints I have seen is how RNG heavy the game can be.   But strategy does exist and a large part of it is being adaptive to the state of the game and trying to sway the odds in your favor.   Knowing what decks to draw out of to try get the right cards you need, knowing what your objective should be for that phase of the game, and knowing what victory condition you should be working towards (and not just wandering the board aimlessly), these are all important and more.  True, this isn't always going to work, but the game would probably be a lot more boring if every player was able to run consistent strategies, or only a few consistent strategies existed.  The randomness of the game gives you more unpredictable 'oh-my-god that just happened' moments.   It wont require any sort of grand strategy game knowledge to enjoy yourself either, so if you like to just play by the seat of your pants you can do that too.  I think most importantly, if you can be a bit laid pack and not get upset over the outcome of a dice roll going completely wrong and maybe even losing you the game every now and then, you will have a good time. All in all, its a great game.  I've played 75 hours and loved them all, and I hope to play many more.  There's been a lot of balance changes from Early Access up til now a few months after release and the devs do have an ear to the community for the most part.  There's some more content on the way in the form of new characters as well, and maybe even some more content DLC down the line (I hope!).  Its a good one.  I'd recommend it.-STEAM CONTROLLER-Game works great with the Steam Controller!  I would recommend my custom setup I have uploaded to the community profiles section, or you can read my suggested binding here.  This arrangement lets you easily and quickly view player positions and keep an eye on the action.  I put left click on the left side (unlike the default for steam controller) because it felt more intuitive to grab cards located on the left side of the screen that way.I'm Not Sue's Armello KB BindingsLEFT BUMPER assigned to Right ClickLEFT TRIGGER assigned to Left ClickRIGHT BUMPER assigned to Hero Shelf (H)RIGHT TRIGGER assigned to Inventory (I)STICK assigned to w,a,s,d respectively.RIGHT PAD is set as mouse.  Customize sensitivity to your preference.  No click action.LEFT PAD is set as Directional Pad. Assign buttons to Focus Player (1-4), keyboard 1, 2, 3, 4, and click action to Focus Quest (Q) Q.  Require Click is off.Assign mode switch for the LEFT PAD to LEFT GRIP.  Scroll clockwise and counterclockwise to Camera Zoom In and Camera Zoom Out (mousewheel up / mousewheel down).RIGHT GRIP is assigned to Focus Active Player (Spacebar)LEFT GRIP is unassigned.Y BUTTON is Roll Dice (R)A BUTTON is Left ClickB, X BUTTONS are unassigned.< BUTTON is Show Scoreboard (Tab)> BUTTON is Menu (Esc)

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												" I can't become king if someone else already sits on the throne."- Nickolai Luzhin. ( Kingslayer Barnaby)If you are a fan of Dungeons and Dragons mixed in with Game of Thrones, with a Dash of An American Tale. This Game is for you, the art is just a feast for the eyes. Each character is unique in both appearance and design. For a board game that encourages adventure, it is truly a unique experience. As I played hours as Barnaby, the Screwloose genius who’s pretty much a medieval MacGyver in brass armor and is a tan Rabbit. Using certain item combinations, I used my bag of tricks I outsmarted the guards and killed the evil king. The land is once again cleansed of evil. The age of oppression is gone, finally we took back our home! We must fight the evil, and this land is once again ours and we’ll see it wiped clean of the scourge of Rot Banes that has ruined Armello. Free from tyranny! Armello will see freedom. Let the other houses squabble while someone takes the initiative. I see Barnaby sitting on the throne after killing the evil king, bruised and battered, He remembers all those whom have given their lives to see him succeed; as he now contemplates on bring back the Armello to its former glory.  ( And This is my story when I played the game. This happenes everytime when I play this game online. It is just..I am a loss for words. It is unique in everyway and I hope to see more from this series) This game is centered on killing the Evil King who’s ruled the land for far too long. He is plagued with the disease known as the Rot, a sickness that turns the characters into crazed killers, as it corrupts the mind and makes them into shadows of their former selves. Combined with political treachery and betrayal from the other houses, you cannot trust anyone in this game, not even your own house! It is a mad dash to the throne, whatever way possible. Cure the king, but in doing so he dies. Or challenge him to a duel. become a kingslayer that killed the mad king. You can even go the political game and gain prestige, by gaining the peoples approval. However you can go to the darkside and kill other players and become corrupted with the rot, sending Armello into eternal darkness. You have the power to do anything, just make sure it is the right one. This game is not perfect but it is a good start. I want to see this series grow into something wonderful.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												Armello, where League of Geeks truly brought tabletop adventures to life. This is a game that I've been waiting for so long as a Kickstarter backer, and now that I got to experience it I can say with all the confidence in the world that it was definitely worth the wait.Beautiful aesthetics and a very very simple playstyle that even the youngest of the family can sit down and enjoy with ease.While RNG plays a huge role in this game it never feels like it's out of control. (Excluding some wyld die explosions)The game is quite versatile, it has 4 different victory conditions, a robust cast of characters and each also has further customization options with rings and amulets that makes each one of the very vast number of possible combinations feel unique and it changes the playstyle quite a lot, making each game feel (and play) differently.There are a few parts to touch on however, even if the game has a huge amount of character customization it lacks settings for the game itself, unable of setting a longer or shorter duration of the game (by modifying the initial health of the King) or even changing the size of the map.The single player game while it's (very) fun you won't find any difficulty modifiers, so if you're looking for a challenge I'd suggest you to play with friends who have experience with the game instead. The AI controlled units are decent, after a few games you can start predicting their patterns if you pay attention to their moves, also sometimes they make some very questionable (or well... just plain dumb) decisions so there's that.With all this said, right now it's early on the game's life and so far I'm amazed by every aspect of it. Can't wait to see what else LoG will do with this gem.I hope this review is helpful to you. I give this game 8/10 in its current state, seriously consider buying and playing it with some friends.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
												This has become my go-to game for a good time. It looks beautiful, the world is rich, and the gameplay is that quintesential "simple to learn yet difficult to master" style I love. Best of all, every game can be drastically different from the last, and they all end within 45-90 minutes, even if they are multiplayer. I find this a refreshing session time for a strategy game, as opposed to the endless and sometimes arduous hours I've found myself devoting to other titles. This is especially important when it comes to multiplayer, because unlike other turn based strategy games whose time commitment to multiplayer seems to span far into the next century, this game can be won or lost in the time frame of an hour or two. This amazing quality removes the drudgery that has bogged down other strategey game experiences I've had with friends, and allows me to enjoy the thrill of cursing them incessantly as they stab me in the back with wanton disregard for the future of our relationship. This is fantastically juxtaposed by the aesthetic style presented, letting the players watch these almost Disney-esqe animal archetypes vying for the throne in the most machiavellian of ways. I highly recommend Armello for anyone who enjoys boardgames, but hates when they take forever and therefore stop being fun. Armello's comparatively short and sweet nature guarantees a freshness that will keep you and your friends playing for a long time, but only because one more game couldn't possibly hurt.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
First: Game is exceptional and worth every dollary, so I have to recommend.Howver: There are some frustrations. Perhaps I'm not understanding everything yet, but success or lack of failure rather, seems to boil down to minimizing attrition, because unless you have substantial gear/followers,  you are very suseptable to to being killed in one encounter.  This is due to the variability of dice/cards and the numerous modifiers within the game.  Even at full health, with some good cards, your not safe. This makes early game survival critical as heroes are going be getting sent home frequently.  Making matters worse is the variability of the cards and drawing a hand full of cards you cant use.  Sure, you can burn uneeded cards and lock rolls, but I seem to need to do that far more frequently than I'd expect.  Its easy to get discouraged when, no matter what you do, no matter what options you choose, there is little chance of success, and no real option other than restarting.  This makes the prospect of online match-made games pretty grim, as players will quit in the first few turns as soon as someone has a clear advantage.  Perhaps I just suck and don't get it yet, but before they dumped money into the beautifull, triple-A assets,  they should have playtested the crap out of the game in a physical version to expose what feel like game ballance issues.  On the otherhand, I'm going to continue playing, becuase it's presentation is so slick, I'm optimisitic the frustrations I have so far are just because I'm no good.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												On the surface, Armello is what the boardgaming community classify as an ameritrash. There's nothing wrong with that. Some of my absolute favourite game is an ameritrash, it just means that the game favour theme and the experience resulted in said theme and a good amount of randomness over a thinky robust mechanic commonly found in a eurogame.Not that Armello is lacking in the gameplay departement. I personally think it's quite fun. There are several characters you can choose from with unique abilities and stats that play very differently to each other. During the course of the game you explore the land to finish a quest, improve yourself with various power and weapon, harass your opponent, or work toward a victory.The rounds are finite and it's a race against the others. Every single move counts and a mistake can set you back significantly. There are multiple path to victory that's a little bit confusing at first but once you fully understood it you'll soon realize that being the strongest in the land may help, but it's not necessary to win.As you can see in the screenshot and video, the visual are amazing. it may not have the best fidelity, but the work the art department did was quality. You might miss it in the screenshot or video, but some of the cards are animated. A little touch that makes the already beautiful game more pleasing in to play. That is if you're into art.A downside of the game, much like any other game in ameritrash category is the randomness. Sometime you love the dice, sometime you wish nobody invented one. The game can overstay our welcome sometime, dragging for quite a while if nobody plays well.All in all, despite the downside, I'm still in the opinion that the game is worth your money and your time. A thumbs up!

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												" I can't become king if someone else already sits on the throne."- Nickolai Luzhin. ( Kingslayer Barnaby)If you are a fan of Dungeons and Dragons mixed in with Game of Thrones, with a Dash of An American Tale. This Game is for you, the art is just a feast for the eyes. Each character is unique in both appearance and design. For a board game that encourages adventure, it is truly a unique experience. As I played hours as Barnaby, the Screwloose genius who’s pretty much a medieval MacGyver in brass armor and is a tan Rabbit. Using certain item combinations, I used my bag of tricks I outsmarted the guards and killed the evil king. The land is once again cleansed of evil. The age of oppression is gone, finally we took back our home! We must fight the evil, and this land is once again ours and we’ll see it wiped clean of the scourge of Rot Banes that has ruined Armello. Free from tyranny! Armello will see freedom. Let the other houses squabble while someone takes the initiative. I see Barnaby sitting on the throne after killing the evil king, bruised and battered, He remembers all those whom have given their lives to see him succeed; as he now contemplates on bring back the Armello to its former glory.  ( And This is my story when I played the game. This happenes everytime when I play this game online. It is just..I am a loss for words. It is unique in everyway and I hope to see more from this series) This game is centered on killing the Evil King who’s ruled the land for far too long. He is plagued with the disease known as the Rot, a sickness that turns the characters into crazed killers, as it corrupts the mind and makes them into shadows of their former selves. Combined with political treachery and betrayal from the other houses, you cannot trust anyone in this game, not even your own house! It is a mad dash to the throne, whatever way possible. Cure the king, but in doing so he dies. Or challenge him to a duel. become a kingslayer that killed the mad king. You can even go the political game and gain prestige, by gaining the peoples approval. However you can go to the darkside and kill other players and become corrupted with the rot, sending Armello into eternal darkness. You have the power to do anything, just make sure it is the right one. This game is not perfect but it is a good start. I want to see this series grow into something wonderful.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												Armello, where League of Geeks truly brought tabletop adventures to life. This is a game that I've been waiting for so long as a Kickstarter backer, and now that I got to experience it I can say with all the confidence in the world that it was definitely worth the wait.Beautiful aesthetics and a very very simple playstyle that even the youngest of the family can sit down and enjoy with ease.While RNG plays a huge role in this game it never feels like it's out of control. (Excluding some wyld die explosions)The game is quite versatile, it has 4 different victory conditions, a robust cast of characters and each also has further customization options with rings and amulets that makes each one of the very vast number of possible combinations feel unique and it changes the playstyle quite a lot, making each game feel (and play) differently.There are a few parts to touch on however, even if the game has a huge amount of character customization it lacks settings for the game itself, unable of setting a longer or shorter duration of the game (by modifying the initial health of the King) or even changing the size of the map.The single player game while it's (very) fun you won't find any difficulty modifiers, so if you're looking for a challenge I'd suggest you to play with friends who have experience with the game instead. The AI controlled units are decent, after a few games you can start predicting their patterns if you pay attention to their moves, also sometimes they make some very questionable (or well... just plain dumb) decisions so there's that.With all this said, right now it's early on the game's life and so far I'm amazed by every aspect of it. Can't wait to see what else LoG will do with this gem.I hope this review is helpful to you. I give this game 8/10 in its current state, seriously consider buying and playing it with some friends.

												Let me start by saying that this game is beatiful. Great art, great music, good gameplay. Despite the fact that the devs kindda milk their players with DLC (heroes) and microtransactions (dices, board and hero skins), I would say this game is 10/10. No pay per win or anything like that, for the record.So why I am not recommending this? At this state the ammount of bugs make the game unplayable. 6 out of 10 games ended for me in freezing, hanging or connection issues. Having 60 minutes of progress lost all of a sudden is unnerving, specially if you're ahead or really close to claim a crushing victory.Nope! No progression, no experience, no drops, nothing! Just a sour taste in your mouth and another AI hero for your fellow players.This game gave me a good time, epic moments and great joy, but also broke my heart many times and made me angry many more, not by gameplay design or anything else but by the sheer ammount of bugs present.I would 100% recommend this game if it werent for the game breaking bugs that just won't go away.I will keep playing it and I do hope to be able to change this review in the future.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												TL;DR- This game is awesome for the first couple of playthroughs. If you don't have friends to play with, playing the same game gets old very, very quickly. The lack of game types or customization destroys the replayability of this game, and therefore it's only a great game for the first few hours, and I would recommend spending your money elsewhere. I would definitely change my opinion if they opened up more options on customization to allow epic style games.Looking at the graphics and the concept of this game, I was really pumped to get it. With that being said, I probably had higher expectations than what I should have going in. This game is a board game, plain and simple, and the first few playthroughs of the game that I had with each hero were awesome, since I learned the strengths and weaknesses of each hero, the randomness of cards and dice rolling, and the strategies of how to navigate the board as well as developing an overall strategy to win the game, on top of all of the "randomness". (Quests are random, with random bonus rewards, with a % chance to GET that bonus reward). All in all I really liked the luck aspect of the game balanced with the strategy aspect of the game, and the music and the artstyle really help making play the overall game fun, even if I feel that the AI turns take a bit longer than I would want to. Overall, the gameplay experience for the first couple of playthroughs was amazing.With that being said, I tend to enjoy games where I can change the parameters around to make the game more interesting once I understand the and have a decent grasp of the games basic concepts. I've sadly grown fond of being able to change gameplay aspects due to modding. In custom games you can switch it up, but at the same time I would really enjoy being able to change more aspects of the game to get a different experience each time. For instance..-I would love to be able to change the size of the map, or the amount of movement my hero can make on a turn. I'd really like there to be more than 2 maps to play on, since this gets very old, very fast.-I would really like to be able to choose if I could equip more items on a hero. Having 3 helps with strategy, but I would love to get into crazy battles where I can have 8 or 9 dice with a few spells I could cast and extra cards to throw away. -I would love to be able to purchase specific items or followers for a significant amount of gold to reduce the luck factor of a game. I've played a game where certain AI can get incredibly lucky early on with items and followers, and completely dominate the game. Purchasing a key item or follower for 10 gold or 10 magic would make the game feel less luck dependent, where at least I could have a chance at being able to augment my heroes strategy. -I'd like to be able to choose in a custom game where only certain victory-types are allowed. Creating an epic long game without rot on the king just makes the AI go for a stones victory every time, versus a long drawn out game. I would also like there to be an option to be able to choose the amount of quests you can get before you are directed towards the king, so playing a longer game becomes viable.Basically, without customization factors and with only 2 maps to play on, if you are not playing with friends, this game becomes pretty old, pretty fast. I guess I have a higher bar, since I'm used to playing games that allow modding, and that may not be fair, but there are many games out there with much longer staying power.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								**Edit since the new update** ** Edit** I really love the new updates that they've given to the game -- the quests now lead you right up to the castle to defeat the king -- giving you at least a chance to be able to confront him or not. New cards have been added. And after a few playthroughs, the cards have become quite strategic in countering your rivals or enhancing yourself. A subtle thing that I love is the day descending into night and vice versa. As your turn begins, it is the very break of day and as each player takes their turn, it gets darker and darker until actual evening. I really like that. My love of the actual game is starting to lean towards actual fun and recommendation. :) If they keep enhancing it more, I can see Armello being something truly special. ** Edit ** I don't think I can mask my disappointment with Armello. I seen the previews, I love anything with animals and love RPG's and card games. I guess, in my excitement for something new, that I glossed over the "board game" aspect of it. That's what Armello is -- a digital board game. The story is very intrigueing and I love it. I love anything new and different. But, with just a digital board game aspect, I don't see how the story can unfold -- the way it could with a card game or RPG. ... You start the game with the king already consumed by the rot. You and three others journey across the board. You have a few ways to win: gain prestige until the king dies, gain more rot than the king and battle him, confront him without the rot and battle him ... Questing takes the form of dungeons on the mountain hexes on the board -- it's random what you get: either coin and objects, or a clash with a dark specter. You can also quest across the board on various tiles, performing either acts of good deeds or not. You are given three choices to make and each choice will get you a different result. Perhaps this was the rpg aspect they were advertising. Or maybe it's the table top aspect that was completely lost on me.The card game aspect feels like an add on. Again, I guess I was expecting an actual collectable card game type of thing. ... But the cards, themselves, are beautiful and a new and interesting aspect about it as each one has something animated happening in it. I've played a few games and for what it is, it's a fun way to pass the time but ... I guess with this particular game, I was hoping for something more.I'm torn about this. I really want to love Armello ... but an hour and a half of a play through as opposed to taking my time and exploring or going on a side quest to do something else, the count down of the king's life is an ever present thing.Maybe when the game devolps beyond what it is right now, I may look at it differently. I *am* in love with the story and the animal world that they've created. It has amazing potential to go in so many different directions -- books, tv/movie -- maybe an actual, traditional rpg game in future, I don't know. But I will definitely keep watch on new and upcoming updates with this game and this world.In the end, it depends on what a player likes and wants. Some people are into the traditional table-top paper/pencil experience. I suppose, in this regard, Armello seeks to deliver. If it's something more like Final Fantasy or Magic the Gathering, it's not like that all. I recommend it for a new and different experience -- and for the story. It might be what other people are looking for and others might be wanting something different. It's difficult to really say where a recommendation is concerned. If you want to take the chance, put some money down to check it out.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												After my sixth game, I think I have a basic understanding for how the game works. It is definitely worth the full asking price, and I can see myself playing this game for another 20+ hours despite the repetition.I'm by no means an expert, but I think I have a grasp on what are the game's sources of improvement (as well as misunderstood expectations from negative reviews). Hopefully these insights will be of use if you're undecided.It's Like Civ But Not Like CivEveryone I've seen describing this game has used at least one of the three comparisons:Redwall Series (anthropmorphic grim fairytale with some realism) + Game of Thrones + Civilization 5 = Armello While I would probably use the same base description, some aspects might mislead fans of Civiliation 5 by accident. Here is the simple answer to the question, "How is it like Civ?"LIKE CIV:It has a hex-based grid system that generates maps for every game.  You get that "Just One More Turn/Game..." feeling in a good game.There are political and warfaring tactics, along with other means (in this game magic), to improve your odds. You make a small amount of moves per turn, each cultivating in the always potential victory or defeat through your own choices. Grinding certain units for rewards, i.e. the Barbarians. (In this game, the Banes and Knights.)Each character caters to a specific playstyle and has some personality.You can start the game with small bonuses to stats. (Unlockable things here.)UNLIKE CIV:It's not a 4X game. Each game (for singleplayer with AI bots) lasts 45 mins to an hour and a half.You control only a hero, not a settlement and armies. Instead of hundreds of turns, the game works with nine days (a round for day and night; 18 turns total).Character animations cannot be disabled (and there's a gameplay reason).The goal of the game is to take the throne in one of four victories. (GoT comparison).Although some characters might be better for one playstyle over another, you can win with any victory condition.RNG elements are in plenty.That last aspect is the most important one. Although Civ has probabilities, you still had a lot of control over your actions; in this game it's pretty much the opposite. But you can always better your odds.For example, ALL of the win conditions (whether for avoiding traps, fighting, or even achieving a victory) is based on some luck. You can influence your chances by improving your Wits abilities at the start for traps. You can accomplish  quests (goals to get improved stats, cards or loot) to improve your character. Or you can use cards you get every turn to better your luck or help you in the game.Like old RPGs/tabletops, the challenge is working probabilities in your favor for success.The Balacing ActThe game has an interesting gameplay element: The King. Everyone is out to kill/banish him and retake the throne from his madness, which is essentially the basic storyline. Each day the King loses one-heart, which he can only regain from killing a corrupted player. You spend one turn to breach the walls, trying to break the trap; the next one to finish the King. Regardless of your choices, the King will die at the end, and the victor is the one who suceeds him.There are one of four victory conditions: Prestige Victory (the normal victory) is when the player who has earned the most fame/goodwill with the King takes his place when the King dies. Kingslayer Victory is when the player kills the King in battle AND lives to earn the throne. Rot Victory is where a corrupted player, higher Rot level than the King, kills the King AND lives to earn the throne.Banish Victory is where a player collects four banish stones and gets to use them on the King, ridding Armello of the Rot.Out of the four, the Prestige Victory is going to be the main outcome. (4 out of 6 games I won with that outcome; the other two I lost due to the same reason.)Two of the victory conditions require you to live from the battle, which both players can kill each other in combat. So if you kill the King and die, the Prestige Leader wins. (And if you attack the King, you lose your Prestige). The "good" option takes some time to gather the stones and you also have to get lucky to banish the King.My take on this system is that there is a reasonable risk/reward system for going for the King. Because the odds are against the player living from the battle, it keeps players from bumrushing  on his last heart, while at the same time rewarding the player who does live to take the throne. (Many times I play the Hyena route; get on the King's goodside before becoming a cutthroat).There are plenty of means to take away Prestige from the highest player--bounties, special cards, King decrees, constant deaths, etc.--all of which are due to chance. But they are plentiful to never seem like a game is hopeless. The King Decrees are an option for the Prestige Leader to choose that may benefit him or hurt everyone--you only get two bad options that display the King's madness of power.The Rot system, while benefiting the most corrupt in battle with extra dice, takes away one heart every dawn. The magic system recharges at every dawn too to some minimum stat. Burning cards only gives you one assured stat for Perils (traps) and battles.The rest of the game is centered on luck, but measurable luck, as you can put on equipment or followers for extra bonuses and play other cards for temporary buffs or set traps. (For better or worse, you can play these cards when it's not your turn, which is helpful when an enemy gets too close or you set a pre-ambush. This is why the game won't skip animations when it's not your turn.)Honestly, the luck system doesn't bother me because I still feel like I have lots of input in my outcomes. And every decision I make feels all the more impactful when it cultimates in a victory of my own doing... But not always of my own efforts.Needs Some TweaksFor starters, having the King's health-bar be customizable might extend gameplay without ruining the balancing act. As well as having more variety in maps other than locations of settlements, dungeons, terrian, etc., randomized and given a different seasonal change.I think nine hearts system is fine since I like the compact Civ feel. The maps, however, are way too compact. I hate having to quickly backtrack to recapture a settlement because some player recaptured it after respawning at home. Again, player customizable options would be nice.Although the characters do not determine your playstyle, some characters feel pressured into one or two routes without a lot of bonuses in the game. More character classes too would be great. (Currently there are 8; two from each clan.)For example, Zorro the Rat cannot take damage, at all, and he's good for sneaking up on players (disabiling their card-burns) and getting bounties.The only way I can see him killing the king is for going for a Rot Victory to get more dice. But he'll need a lot more health to not die in three turns.I think these limitations will give seasoned players some edge in spoting tactics with the characters tropes.The typical, "Foxes are doing something cunning; pigs are being piggish; weasels are weaselly"kind of cliche for anthropomorphic characters. (Am I the only one who hates that?) I do like that tropes are a potential mechanic.Also, being stuck with a crap set of cards is annoying if you can't burn them often. A discard option outside of perils or battles would be nice for those nothing turns.Try Your LuckI really wanted to talk about the gameplay storytelling, but I think the balancing and misguided expectations were more important to address. This is a pleasant, little surprise for 2015.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								I was extremely attracted to this game because it immediately reminded me of the Redwall book series I loved as a kid. Bought it on sale for a rather steep $20... still not sure if it was worth it (only time will tell), but I can say that the game is fun and well-designed. Pros: Despite having very little in the way of a tutorial, I found the rules and mechanics pretty easy to grasp after a couple quick test runs. The interface and controls are quite intuitive. Playing as most characters (see more on this below...), the game's difficulty seems well balanced, not too hard and not too easy. This is due in part to the fact that luck does play a role in whether you win or lose any given battle/situation, but I see this as a positive rather than a negative. Your skill is still what wins you the game in the end. Nice art design, graphics, music, and overall theme. The game rewards you for playing and achieving different paths to victory, with unlockable perks for each character. Cons: Could use more content, more maps, maybe a campaign of some sort... The story is superficial and leaves a bit to be desired. This is also something that a campaign mode with cutscenes would help fix. One of the playable characters, the bear, seems to always lose really badly when played by the AI. I haven't tried playing her yet but there's obviously a bit of an imbalance there.

Out of 10 times playing multiplayer, 5 of those times the game just stops, music continues, everything moves, but no actions can be done causing the players to start leaving the game. After a player leaves, an AI is supposed to take their place, but guess what: nothing happens. You are just stuck there. This ONLY happens in multiplayer, and apart from that you get penalized for leaving.I like your game really, but a great deal about the game is multiplayer. How about we try to figure out whats up with that first?6.5 outta 10 because of that, otherwise 8/10

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												A non-biased quick look @ the game:


YouTube™ Video: ➜ A Quick Look @ 'Armello' + 1 Steam key to Giveaway! ENDED! 

			Views: 204		

			This game is available here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/290340 MASSIVE THANKS TO THE DEV'S FOR THE REVIEW COPY + BONUS Steam Key to Giveaway!		

If Walt Disney was in charge of making a Game of Thrones style Might and Magic game, this would be it. Armello is a grand swashbuckling adventure that combines three styles of play; The deep tactics of card games with the rich strategy of table top board games, combined with a character role-playing system. As a hero from one of the clans of Armello, you'll quest, scheme, hire agents, explore, vanquish monsters, cast spells and face off against other players, with one ultimate end goal in mind — storming the palace and becoming King or Queen of Armello. The Kingdom of Armello is as dangerous as it is beautiful, perils, banes and bandits hide around every corner and a spreading corruption known as the rot is leaving no creature untouched. Armello is League of Geeks’ attempt to revolutionise digital board and card games, whilst providing players a rich world within which they can craft their own stories of epic adventure. The aim was to create a rich game full of backstabbing, close shaves, shattered alliances, ruses and empty promises - a perfect game to play with your friends. - Highly Recommended!

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
												Premise:Armello is a game where players take on the role of heros from various animal clans (Wolf, Bear, Rat, Rabbit) as they vy for control of the kingdom come the King's eventual demise to The Rot. The Rot corrupts those that it infects, granting them power at some cost. Heros can acheive victory by either gaining the most influence by the time of the King's death, using Spirit Stones to banish the corrupt King, or outright killing the King as he becomes weaker and weaker.Gameplay:The game is played much like a tabletop game with various points of interest. Cards are drawn each turn which can assist the player and harm or hinder their opponents. Quests are given to players to strengthen their character during gameplay to assist them in dice based combat where equipment Cards can influence a combatant's attack or defense.Pros:+ Great graphics, sound, and music score+ Relatively easy system to understand and play+ Games can take from between 20-40 minutes depending on how versed players are+ Different characters and different ways to play and win leading to each playthrough being different from the lastCons:- The Rot system doesn't give much benefit to players that desire corruption- Some characters have only one way to play or win given their base stats and passives (IE: Sana)- Sometimes the Card RNG/Dice can be very cruel to where a player can litterally not win at all.- No game editor: You can't make the game last longer, you can't change the map size or gamplay difficultyVerdict:While Armello is probably one of the better tabletop-to-screen games on Steam, it does feel a bit lacking in the options department of gameplay. That said, it's a fun game to play when you're looking for a thoughtful and strategic game while keeping the gameplay casual. The price is fair and well worth a four-pack if you want to enjoy a strategic game that doesn't involve tanks, starships or explosions (Unless you consider some of the trechery and magic cards). While it's not a game you can't necessarily binge on, it's a good way to break up the monotony between other games.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												This is somewhat of a hard review for me to write. Do I recommend this game? In some ways, yes! I love the game. I love it too much. I've been involved with it from Day 1 back on Kickstarter. I love the art and the premise and I feel like playing it every day. However, here are the reasons that I have uninstalled this game with a heavy heart:I've played several games of Armello, some multiplayer and some single player (Note: more than what Steam quotes, as I have a different version from Kickstarter). The major flaws at this point are evident. One, in every single game I have been able to finish, the game has been won by the Prestige Leader. Every other victory condition is unbelievably hard to attain and I have never seen it done. As noted in a previous review, getting stuck in an endless cycle of dying and restarting is rampant and extremely difficult to break out of, which leads to the game timing out before anyone can achieve anything. In literally every game I have played, I have set out with the intention of winning with Spirit Stones, and while I have no problem getting enough of them, getting to the king is impossible with this endless cycle of dying. Now, onto more clerical problems. In each game I have played (literally every one), something or a lot of things have gone wrong with the running of the game. In two or three, my Gold counter has gotten stuck at a certain number and I have no idea how much I have to work with. I don't know if it is logging my newly acquired Gold, but when I try to use a card, it will always tell me I cannot afford it, despite sometimes saying I have 12 Gold even. I have run into a couple of games where it will freeze so to speak and the characters are just in a constant loop of "fighting," but the game does not progress. This has been documented by two of my Steam friends as well. Two or three times, I have had friends kicked off the server and the game has been restarted automatically. The gameplay and music/sound effects often lag (like, almost always) and are choppy (even with turning down the resolution, shutting down all other processes on my computer, and changing to a more powerful computer). I have had a couple instances when playing multiplayer that a countdown clock will never appear on the player screen, or we will be stuck in an "all-ready" screen with nothing happening. While attempting to play with my friends, they are asking: "Is this game in early access!?" Unfortunately, it kind of feels that way. The minute a patch is released to fix these gameplay issues, I will be re-installing this game, because it is honestly my love right now. My recommendation is that you will want this game. Hard. But right now, maybe it needs a pass for a little while.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												I wanted to like Armello, this is the best implementation of a Digital Board game I've played, with elements that aren't possible in a tabletop game.Unfortunately, there is little skill  since your overall strategy can quickly be destroyed by the RNG. Randomness is tricky to do right, the best games give you tools to work with what you have, the RNG creating a new puzzle to solve. Armello has randomness at nearly every level, random card draws, dice rolls, dungeons, and quests, with very little you can do to adapt.

Posted: February 5
												Unfortunately, this game is overpriced and suffers from some crappy dev's - though it's a fun game.There are STILL MAJOR ISSUES with disconnecting and games freezing! Some updates have broken the game for days.And, as it's really a minigame that is comprised of roughly 1 hour matches, it shouldn't cost the same price as a triple-AAA studio game that has 50+ hours of novel gameplay for 2 copies and a set of DLC characters.The worst part of the pricing and dev' management is the DLC: each sweaty cosmetic DLC balloons the last in cost, so that 3 character skins cost more than the base game, which includes 8 characters... Gives perspective, right?Armello is a fun game. BUT, it has too many totally unresolved gameplay bugs for it to be really fun, and their DLC scheme is greedy and ugly. If you can catch Armello for less than $10 on sale, then you might find it to be agreeable for the price.

Posted: April 11, 2016
												Armello is a pretty fun game if you were ever into Mario Party and had enough money to buy yourself a new laptop every game or 2.Because almost everything is out of your control unless you play the safest way imaginable.Now this isn't to say that it's a bad game, I highly recommend this, but I do warn you that ANYTHING can happen.You can be a legendary wolf knight finished with all of your quests, ready to fight the king who is 1 hit away from death and you are completely decked out with the best equips and greatest party members in the game, but still get burned to death by a bunny holding an umbrella.This doesn't even factor in that almost nothing goes according to plan unless through the infinite power of Jesus Christ, you manage to have everything manage to go your way from the start.Regardless, there are many different ways to win in this game with many unique characters and equips for them for you to try and win with.It is an incredibly slow start for beginners to not only learn, but earn said equips, but once you get into things, you'll find yourself enjoying this strategy boardgame.Things get even worse when you talk about dices which you'll most likely grind for to show off your status.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												I read a lot of Red Wall when I was a kid because I wasn't really too interested in Harry Potter or all that nonsense. Uh. Not sure how that's -exactly- relevant? But it is. Armello's been an amazing experience that I'm trying to currently push on my friends. To note: This -is- basically an videogame boardgame, but it's super fun, and the animation is smooth. The tactics are varied and interesting, and there's a lot of room for risky play. Anyways, I'm probably more coherent when I hate a game. It's hard to praise a game as much as I have, so I'll get to the cons:-There's only one game board.-There's a pretty small character selection.That's uh, about it. That and turns can take a little long, but that's okay when you're doing singleplayer anyways, because you can just turn on quickturns. I'd really love it if the developer considered DLC addons for maps and characters. I would definitely buy both. I'd be happy to support a developer that's made a wonderful game like this, anyways.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
Early Access Review
Before I start this review, I want to point out that my playtime is NOT accurate. Due to connectivity problems, my playtime has not been registering correctly for many games. That being said, I played this for about two hours.Ever read that book series called "Redwall?"The imagery in this reminds me so much of when I read some of the books in that series years ago. Your choices for characters are anthromorphic animals, with different strengths and drawbacks. I will confess that I expected more of an RPG than a board game with this, but that was my mistake. The imagery is definitely rich here, and if you're into fantasy novels, there's a good chance that you'll enjoy looking at the game for awhile. The visuals were probably my single favorite part of this game, but I can't say that's not due to my weak understanding of the genre. Grid-Based Board GameReally, I should have prepared myself better for this. I'm not very good at this type of game, and I don't know if that's because I haven't played very many of them, or if it's because I'm simply impatient. The gameplay is easy to get the hang of, the tutorials are supremely helpful, and for a gamer like me it probably presents more of a challenge than it would for someone accustomed to this sort of thing. The inclusion of multiplayer is a big plus, I can see that being a determining factor when other people I know obtain the game and want to play something. The board game aspect is very strong with this - dice rolling, cards, etc. I'm a sucker for this sort of thing, but it works so much better within a multiplayer setting, where my playing was focused on a single player campaign. That's not to say it wasn't fun, that's just to say that I'm confused easily by this sort of game. Gotta Love That SoundtrackThe soundtrack for this is awesome. I've played a lot of games recently with great soundtracks, and it's starting to spoil me. My biggest complaint about most games prior to recent plays is that the soundtracks just aren't that great - for whatever reason this ignores that rule and creates a great atmosphere. As I said about the feeling of the book Redwall, earlier, I imagine that this would be a soundtrack to a movie or game made from the series, and combined with the imagery, it creates a pleasant atmosphere that doesn't become stale quickly. Overall Opinion Graphically, musically, this game ranks very high on the list. Without being able to comment on the gameplay with any authority, because I don't normally play this sort of game, I have to say that it's rather difficult to get started with...It's not a "get-up-and-go" sort of game, but if you're a stronger fan of the genre than I am, I'm sure you'll find it pleasant. The screen is packed full of things that you can use, actions to take, and the way the tutorial system is set up is fantastic. I will probably have to play this game more when some of my friends get it, because I am recommending it! Based on my limited knowledge of the genre, but enjoying the overall atmosphere and pleasantries of the game, I'm not hesitant to give it a solid 7.5/10. So, final: 7.5/10I will probably revisit this review after I play more of it, and definitely after I play a multiplayer campaign. As it is, I failed at nearly everything I tried to do - so the game is a challenge if you're not familiar with the genre! Great job, guys.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												Let me start with some simple pros and cons before giving a more comprehensive review:Pros:  1)  Easy to pick up and learn with a comprehensive tutorial.  2)  Multiplayer that lets you play with a dedicated group of frieds or random strangers.  (Plus a solid singleplayer experience for when you're antisocial or your friends are away.)  3)  Procedurally generated maps mean every board is different.  4)  With eight different characters and a variety of customization items to select before the game starts you'll quickly find a style of play you love.  5)  Rewards extra customization itmes based on who you play and how.  (Let's face it, we all love customizing things.)  6)  It's pretty to look at, which never hurts.Cons:  1)  When playing single-player the AI sometimes makes some quirky decisions...  Like walking through a swamp before attacking someone and consequently losing a fight it might have survived.  2)  The Prestige Leader vicotry condition is a little odd in cases of a tie.  Several hours and a dozen games later and I'm still no entirely sure how it picks a leader in the case of a tie...  That being said in this game ties don't last long at all.The Overview:     Armello is a beautifully rendered boardgame that is easy to pick up and learn but deliciously difficult to master.  You may gear yourself up with a particualr victory in mind (there are four different ways to win afterall) but quickly find that your plan isn't falling into place they way you had hoped.  This is the kind of game that rewards opportunists, flexible thinkers, and clever tacticians.     The entire game is played on a hexagonal board and you spend your turn moving, collecting cards that give you powerful items, spells, or tricks you can use to hamper or kill your enemies, and possibly fighing off the king's guards, banes, or other players through dice rolling.  Fulfilling quests boosts your stats and grant generous rewards so you'll constantly be trying to plot the best route from A to B.  Your final objective is to overcome the corruption in the land represented by the king by either killing him, cleansing him, becoming the new king of corruption (and also killing him) or by becoming the most famous hero in the land and succeeding the king upon his death.  The king draws closer to his demise every sunrise so you'll constantly be racing the clock to amass your power and wrestle victory away from the other players.     Also all the characters are represented by animals, which is kind of neat and gives the whole thing a Redwall meets Game of Thrones kind of feel.  This game is wildly fun, deceptively challenging, and has immense replay value.  All in all this is a fantastic game I would recommend to anyone who loves boardgames or games that reward you for being quick on your feet and flexible in your planning.  Best played with one or two friends once you've mastered the game concepts but as I said, the solo play is strong with this one.  Enjoy!

												When you consider that a good strategy tabletop board game can easily cost upwards of $50, a rich game like Armello feels like a steal. Fantastic design and production values, varied strategies, well-balanced characters, and strong environmental storytelling, for what is ultimately a 4 player board game. Some bugs, and I wish this had local couch co-op, but for the price, it's an excellent game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												Armello is a beautifully picturesque board game. From the thrilling battle exchanges, to the delightfully animated cards and intro sequence, to its storytale-like writing that paints a small saga for your character through your quests, this game is a treat for the eyes and a fun dice-rolling way to occupy about an hour. However, as Armello is primarily a board game, you may turned off by its randomness and its slower pace.For me, Armello's chief strength is the quality of its visuals. You can see this yourself, as a number of a YouTube gaming channels have recorded their playthroughs of it during Early Access, including: Northernlion; Stumpt; and Jesse Cox. There have been a number of changes to the game since it exited beta status, but what you can see from those channels is largely how Armello looks in its final state. You should also notice the "talking woodland creatures with swords and magic" theme, which can prove to be quite the nostalgic bonus for those of you read Redwall novels and Mouse Guard comics. Armello also features a "dynamic sandbox", which essentially means every game will have most of the terrain tiles on the board randomly generated, ensuring a different experience and requiring different tactics for every game.It must also be noted that Armello is quite friendly to new players. While the game starts off simply as your chosen avatar explores the land, a player can be swamped by the variety of cards and events he'll face. Fortunately, the game is very informative through its in-game guide (easily accessed from the main menu and during play) and is sufficiently detailed in its hover tips. This is especially the case with the cards, the major method you'll be using to interact with Armello's world. Each card comes with a short but clear description of their uses, so the player should never be left in doubt. Furthermore, the game has already seen two patches since its full release, and both patches have added new free content to the game including new items and cards. Details on these past updates can be found here at Armello's website[armello.com]. As is apparent, Armello has a dedicated development team behind it, one that fully intends to keep the game alive by bringing even more to it through future updates.Mind you, if you find yourself frustrated with the randomness and waiting of board-games, then Armello may similarly irritate you. While some strategy is possible, victory in Armello is greatly dependent on the luck of the draw and the luck of the roll (though this can also be an appealing spice for the adventurous). Also, every game of Armello requires 4 players, whether they be human or AI controlled. This means you'll find yourself sitting through quite a bit of downtime, watching other players go through their turns. In the game's options, you can opt to skip AI vs AI battles to lessen your waiting time, but you can't fast-forward all of it. You could leave the computer while AI turns play out, but watching other players' moves is also part of the game (i.e. planning your own moves based on where your opponents appear to be going or what they may be planning to do).All in all, Armello is a wonder for the eyes, and one round is a delightful way to spend half an hour to an hour. While PvP games online are completed in one go, offline player vs AI games can be saved and continued at a later date, making this game a fine option for a short spot of casual fun as well. If all this tickles your fancy for fantasy, delve deep into Armello and try for the Lion's throne.

												I've enjoyed this game thoroughly.Having followed it since it's infancy on Kickstarter, I can't help but revel at how much it's progressed from the beta stages to the current gaming incarnation. The storyline is rich and full of character (and characters). And while it seems simple; there is masterful amount of strategy to be had in something that feels so fluid. This truly is more than a simple turn based strategy. It's a game that has depth. And while every 20 round game feels as it will be too short to truly experience anything; I find myself drawn not only into the game world but to the storylines behind each avatar's play style. To this effect I woud recommend this game and I forsee expansion packs in the future.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
												# 53      ArmelloA board game set in a fantastical world  where animals are the dominant species, and a sickness called the rot ravages your King.  Adding cards, perils and board stylings of Catan, this board style game is actually a pretty slick joy.  Its a bit faster paced than Talisman, and way more polished.  One game ran me about an hour to play on single player, which is pretty fair for this type pf game.  The visuals are beautiful, smooth and well drawn, easy on the eyes.  And the sounds and music are very easy on the ears.  At first glance the mechanics seem daunting, with a steep learning curve.  Not that way at all.  The tutorial is set up into 4 chapters, highlighting 4 of the 8 or so clans.  Each one adding a few new mechanics, until finally you learn about how to win the game.  Like i said, smooth.  Developers seem pretty active, having a twitch stream after each new update, highlighting the new features.I was a little peeved at the price, but after sitting down with it for a few hours, 20 bucks is actually pretty fair.8/10 might buy a copy for the spouse

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												Armello is , for me the hardest game to categorize. in my entire life. of 500+ steam games not counting the others i have in other consoles, i'm a game poacher, i've played♥♥♥♥♥♥that's so bad it gives you scrotal cancer, and i've played amazing jewels of mastery and perfection so stupid delicious they just take your mind, and kick it out of the damn stadium. this game is of the latter, and if i had to categorize it , it would be something like this Armello is a Turn based strategic Rpg experience with a lemon slice of trading card game. yes, you heard me, this game is a mixture of many many amazing and counter effective things, but instead of forming one ugly disgusting paste, or a monster of frankenstein, they for this beautiful chimera with a menagerie of colors and a complexity that makes it  just impossible to say What is that makes it tick.I'm an artist, I draw for a living and I've groomed  my skills as much as i possibly could , focusing on character design and interesting "looks" and "feel" of the concept. i've read dozens of books about how to make characters work, books that tell you a bunch of unbreakable rules, rules of thumb, impossible to miss details and basics. this game somehow breaks them one by one in a beautiful majestic way, "make your characters stand out of the crowd" at best armello characters are the most basic representation of themselves, an animal, from an animal clan, but following a fallout feel, somehow you manage to put yourself in the shoes of your chosen character every game, how differently they play, mechanically speaking they are more deep than any tridimensional character i've ever wrote, and they don't even say a word in your whole gameplay. they feel empty of story at first, the tutorial gives you a good slice of some of the background of these fellas , but that's it, how their story evolves every match depends on you.the game is easy to understand, a quick brush at the tutorial will get you started, it also is easy to master, you will learn how to strategically place yourself, how to support, or doom the other 3 players of the round without much effort, but the ever changing nature of the game , maps and other stuff will always force you to improvise on the go, explore, do missions , find weapons equipment and magic to aid you in your journey.and now i realize , i haven't talked at all about the journey, if i can summarize it correctly, it stands like this. The king. the honourable , kind, benevolent king that managed to unite the clans, has fallen into corruption, the "rot" how they call it in the story, takes him over  a couple turns at a time, turning him more and more into a corrupted monster, and damaging his life every 2 turns.  his days are counted, and dark days come for the land you live in if he is not stopped in time, Banes will appear and desolate the place, other corrupted individuals will want his head on a pike just for power, brave warriors will see the end of the horror by the sword, aristocrats will seek his side, stay on top of the popular food chain so , when he dies, the noble of higher name takes his place. and spiritual  leaders from all around will seek to purify the rot, no matter the cost. this is how you win the game, none of them easy to get, since you will always be playing against other 3 champions, who of course, have their own agenda.Anthropomorphic characters, lovely music, Fantastic artwork and animations, visuals are more than enough to immerse yourself into the world. this game is a rough diamond that's constantly being polished and promises hours of fun.so... do i recommend this game? the short answer is yes, the long answer is ♥♥♥♥ the hell yes.10/10 would cleanse myself by accident with the stones again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
												Armello is a beautifully picturesque board game. From the thrilling battle exchanges, to the delightfully animated cards and intro sequence, to its storytale-like writing that paints a small saga for your character through your quests, this game is a treat for the eyes and a fun dice-rolling way to occupy about an hour. However, as Armello is primarily a board game, you may turned off by its randomness and its slower pace.For me, Armello's chief strength is the quality of its visuals. You can see this yourself, as a number of a YouTube gaming channels have recorded their playthroughs of it during Early Access, including: Northernlion; Stumpt; and Jesse Cox. There have been a number of changes to the game since it exited beta status, but what you can see from those channels is largely how Armello looks in its final state. You should also notice the "talking woodland creatures with swords and magic" theme, which can prove to be quite the nostalgic bonus for those of you read Redwall novels and Mouse Guard comics. Armello also features a "dynamic sandbox", which essentially means every game will have most of the terrain tiles on the board randomly generated, ensuring a different experience and requiring different tactics for every game.It must also be noted that Armello is quite friendly to new players. While the game starts off simply as your chosen avatar explores the land, a player can be swamped by the variety of cards and events he'll face. Fortunately, the game is very informative through its in-game guide (easily accessed from the main menu and during play) and is sufficiently detailed in its hover tips. This is especially the case with the cards, the major method you'll be using to interact with Armello's world. Each card comes with a short but clear description of their uses, so the player should never be left in doubt. Furthermore, the game has already seen two patches since its full release, and both patches have added new free content to the game including new items and cards. Details on these past updates can be found here at Armello's website[armello.com]. As is apparent, Armello has a dedicated development team behind it, one that fully intends to keep the game alive by bringing even more to it through future updates.Mind you, if you find yourself frustrated with the randomness and waiting of board-games, then Armello may similarly irritate you. While some strategy is possible, victory in Armello is greatly dependent on the luck of the draw and the luck of the roll (though this can also be an appealing spice for the adventurous). Also, every game of Armello requires 4 players, whether they be human or AI controlled. This means you'll find yourself sitting through quite a bit of downtime, watching other players go through their turns. In the game's options, you can opt to skip AI vs AI battles to lessen your waiting time, but you can't fast-forward all of it. You could leave the computer while AI turns play out, but watching other players' moves is also part of the game (i.e. planning your own moves based on where your opponents appear to be going or what they may be planning to do).All in all, Armello is a wonder for the eyes, and one round is a delightful way to spend half an hour to an hour. While PvP games online are completed in one go, offline player vs AI games can be saved and continued at a later date, making this game a fine option for a short spot of casual fun as well. If all this tickles your fancy for fantasy, delve deep into Armello and try for the Lion's throne.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Let me preface this by saying that I have thoroughly enjoyed playing this game.Pros:  It's beautiful.  The graphics are stylized in a really interesting way, but it isn't so cartoony that it feels "cheap."   The gameplay is fairly choice-driven, so no two games are the same. Flavor text & characters are on point. You actually find yourself rooting for the Rabbit Clan, or the Bear Clan, or (my favorite) the Mouse Clan. The flavor text has just enough silliness that it keeps things amusing while still immersing you in the role-playing.Cons: The multiplayer.  I know, I know.  This has been said a few times over, but it really does need a failsafe for when queues aren't hoppin' and people still want the multiplayer experience.  I've seen other reviews recommend a "fill-with-AI" option that still allows you to get chests & keys, assuming you aren't the only PC in the game.  I stand behind that.  There have been a few times that people have quit during character choosing, and that's really frustrating when you've been waiting 10+ minutes for a game. It often feels like you're playing alone.  The canned chat is actually pretty comprehensive, but it would be nice to have an option to chat freely if both players have it enabled.  I know it could encourage cheating for achievements, but it could also encourage dialogue about the game and make it feel less... lonely.All in all, enjoyable game + good graphics + good writing on the part of the devs leaves this game at a 7.5/10.  If the multiplayer issues were corrected, it could easily be a 9/10.  It's got huge replay value, and I quite enjoy the characters and their weaknesses/strengths.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												Armello is a great looking digital adventure boardgame.  There's a lot to do and there are multiple paths to victory and opportunities to adjust your strategy during the game.  It feels a little random at first, but once you start learning the cards and strategies, you feel like you have more control.The continued support and last few updates have done a a lot to streamline the game (particularly the quick AI turns). Some of the design descions feel like they should have stayed in a board game ,ex. rolling actual dice, non-syncronous turns.  Multiplayer has a lot of down time between turns.  This isn't a game for impatient people.Overall, if you are patient and take the time to dig in, this is an interesting strategy gaming experience.  I initially disliked this game due to clunky UI and too much downtime in multiplayer. I feel the developers have sufficiently addressed this (although more can be done) and find myself willing to dig deeper.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Armello is a digital board game that mixes strategy and luck, where you play as a hero and go for one of several victory options in order to become the new king of Armello. It is a fun and cunning game, where anything can happen at any time and where no one is ever counted out. Up until the last turn, you can easily pull off a victory despite having virtually nothing going for you -- but only if you can deal with your opponents accordingly! The game feels a bit like a mixture between a lot of Mario Party, a good dose of Civilization, and a touch of Skyrim. My only gripe is that turns aren't simultaneous, making it so that you watch your opponents play more than you play yourself.
