content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Armello is a mostly turn-based strategy game played with up to 4 players. Your ultimate goal is to overthrow the Mad King and restore peace to the land. Or rule over it with an iron paw; this game isn't about what comes after, but the hard-fought journey to it. It is a fresh take in the turn-based genre, where you don't simply go from point A to point B and finish first. You must use this strange land as a tool to build up and achieve victory through combat, magicks, or trickery (usually a combo of all three!). Each player chooses a hero each with their own passive ability and allocation of stat points. Afterwards, you choose a ring, granting an ability based on what clan they hail from. Then an amulet from a shared set that can boost a stat by 1 or make a particular victory condition slightly easier to obtain.Dice appear in combat and perils (traps that require the dice to match symbols), where you either hit, miss, or defend. Each shield blocks one hit, where misses are 33% likely, hits are 50% likely, and shields are merely 1/6 likely. Attacks are resolved at the same time, so mutual kills can often happen unless you were geared up defensively. I don't feel this is a flaw exactly, just a design that requires player understanding and adjusting accordingly. However, you can guarantee certain dice rolls by burning your cards, matching its symbol on the top-right.Card decks are used whenever you start your turn and draw new cards up to your Wits stat. You may choose from Items (healing, equipment, movement), Magic (stat buffs, teleportation, peril spells), and Trickery (traps, resource stealing, sabotage). While you are free to pick, your ideal choice lies with your character, position on the board, and time of day. Almost nightfall and you still have some magic? Draw a spell and use it up before you receive more for free. Have a lot of settlements under control? Draw trickery and take advantage of your discount per owned town.I say it is mostly a turn-based game, in that you can play cards during other player turns. You can equip items to prepare for a potential battle, use buffing magic cards, play perils on the board, even teleport off-turn. While you cannot use a spell directly onto a player currently moving, you can still place traps in their way. Overall, this is the best time to modify or cement the strategy to be used on your next turn, rather than always being bored waiting for the three other players.The "rule of four numbers" is a reoccurring theme in this game. There are four hero clans: Wolf, Rat, Bear, Rabbit; and you must always play with 4 players, even if the remainder is AI-controlled. There are four main stat points: Fight, Wit, Body, Spirit. There are four "resources": Gold, Magic, Prestige, Rot. There are four ways to win the game, and you must keep all of them in mind to hinder the other players' progress while slowly reaching your own under the radar.Each player starts in their Clan Grounds and have 3 movement points to use on the board, which itself is divided into different hexes. Each hex is a particular terrain type which may help or hurt you or your enemy from their current goal. This is an important distinction from other board games: CURRENT goal. Maybe you need to finish a quest to get another stat point, maybe you need a couple towns under your control for gold next dawn, maybe you're hunting a monster (Banes) or another player for more Prestige. None of these actions is a direct victory action; you are building tools and resources to aid you in reaching victory.The map is not very big, but the land of Armello is a dynamic, living entity that is randomly generated each match. During the match, perils, hazards, and enemies will move around or be added/removed by player actions and influence. As the King is slowly dying each day, there is a time-limit for the players to work. You may win by Prestige where you inherit the crown after the King passes. You may collect 4 Spirit Stones to banish him after you breach the palace grounds. Or you may throw down the gauntlet and use brute force to combat him directly. OR take to the dark side and show just how corrupt one can get before facing him.Your stats help you combat the hazards in the game. Body is the simplest stat; it is your max health. Fight almost always determines how many dice rolled in combat. Your Wit determines your maximum cards drawn at the start of your turn, your dice if Evading in defensive combat, and rolled dice in some perils. Your Spirit is how many magic points you are balanced to each nightfall and how far you may cast a spell from your character, and your dice against magical perils.The presentation of the game is fantastic. Every character model is sharp and inspired, with a colorful fairytale-esque aesthetic. Shadows cast across the land based on the time of day/night. Beautiful animated art is on every card in the game, even viewable in the gallery. The idle animations are done well for each hero and fit their personality. They play a "boast" animation on certain conditions, such as on killing their combat target or finishing a quest. Even Guards, Banes, and the King himself have subtle animations that follow these same rules!Armello is visually designed to feel alive during a match, and when everything comes together, I really get that feeling. Instead of a static board, it is a living world that we adventure in. The developers have invested a lot into polishing this game, and it shows. The music is excellent and further immerses one into its world, covering the right moments of atmosphere, tension, and drama. Hearing more about our heroes in the future would be great. However the lore is provided indirectly through guides and stories that won't immediately be visible during matches. Quest logs do explain what your character is going through to get the throne though.There is a good amount of randomness to the game, which may turn some players off, as they are expected to be strategic in a game where fate keeps dealing you the wrong cards or combat dice rolls came out poorly despite beating all your opponent's items and stats. Nonetheless, each player can manipulate the situation to best be on top. Try not to end your turn near a dungeon if night is coming and you cannot handle combat if a Bane were to randomly spawn from it. See if you can afford to go around a peril if you aren't prepared to (literally) roll with it. Don't always choose Risk on quest rewards. Don't make enemies too early just because you can. Ultimately, you are your own ally and alliances are temporary - Finding balance between risk and reward, and having a Plan B are key in this game.The developers are still looking towards future updates and game balance, and are occasionally tweaking different cards, items, and elements. It's a very polished, visually-pleasing game to play that takes 60-90 minutes once you know how to play. Deeper down, there is a lot of replayability to be had if given a chance. Even now, there are elements of counter-play involved when choosing a character. Playing against Thane, the sword-crazy wolf who can passively cause armor-piercing attacks? Play a spell-caster or Zosha who can Ambush at night. In a match with multiple spellcasters try a Witty character and focus on a non-combat victory while countering with Trickery. With four players, there is never a true counter-class to everything, meaning your best skill is improvisation and never surrendering even if you were killed and sent back on the final day.I have really enjoyed my experiences with the game and encourage others to give it a try. It mixes a board game formula with a very lively aesthetic and dynamic gameplay, pushing you to think ahead about What Ifs, threat priority, and resource management. Don't let the random elements be a turnoff, enjoy the potential the game has to offer, and ultimately play in your way that lets you have fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Let me preface this by saying that I have thoroughly enjoyed playing this game.Pros:  It's beautiful.  The graphics are stylized in a really interesting way, but it isn't so cartoony that it feels "cheap."   The gameplay is fairly choice-driven, so no two games are the same. Flavor text & characters are on point. You actually find yourself rooting for the Rabbit Clan, or the Bear Clan, or (my favorite) the Mouse Clan. The flavor text has just enough silliness that it keeps things amusing while still immersing you in the role-playing.Cons: The multiplayer.  I know, I know.  This has been said a few times over, but it really does need a failsafe for when queues aren't hoppin' and people still want the multiplayer experience.  I've seen other reviews recommend a "fill-with-AI" option that still allows you to get chests & keys, assuming you aren't the only PC in the game.  I stand behind that.  There have been a few times that people have quit during character choosing, and that's really frustrating when you've been waiting 10+ minutes for a game. It often feels like you're playing alone.  The canned chat is actually pretty comprehensive, but it would be nice to have an option to chat freely if both players have it enabled.  I know it could encourage cheating for achievements, but it could also encourage dialogue about the game and make it feel less... lonely.All in all, enjoyable game + good graphics + good writing on the part of the devs leaves this game at a 7.5/10.  If the multiplayer issues were corrected, it could easily be a 9/10.  It's got huge replay value, and I quite enjoy the characters and their weaknesses/strengths.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
  "Dovie'andi se tovya sagain."  It's time to toss the dice. Being a lover of fantasy, roleplaying, anthropomorphism  No, I am not a Furry, trickery, and dumb luck, I decided to buy this game. I have not regretted it. I was a little lost starting off, but after a few matches I started to pick up all the intricacies of the game better, and now I only improve the more I play. In this game, you select a Hero or Heroine of one of the Five Clans: Wolf, Bear, Rabbit, Rat, and Bandit.  The four Bandit Clan characters are currently only available to startup backers, and will become accessible to the purchasers of a DLC that reportedly comes out in early 2017.  Your quest? Save the kingdom of Armello from the careless rule of a once-good King overcome by the Rot, an all-consuming corruption that has tragically driven him into spiraling madness. You must become the new King or Queen of Armello by  whatever means necessary,  be it alliance, betrayal, fame, daring acts of heroism, or, if you so choose, by becoming even more powerful in the Rot than the Mad King himself. Like I said, this game relies heavily on RNG, which is (as far as I know) essentially a technical term among RPGers for blind, dumb luck. Most of your strategy comes from leveling up certain stats, thereby increasing your "luckiness", and by playing cards to other players and to different tiles. You can win three different ways. The first is a Prestige Victory, where the Hero or Heroine with the most "Prestige" becomes the new ruler of Armello after the King perishes (he is slowly dying) by right of succession. The other two methods are much more direct: Kingslayer and Spirit Stone Victories. Kingslayer is exactly what it sounds like: you confront the Mad King and defeat him in combat. A Spirit Stone Victory is the trickiest, but I believe it is the most satisfying. You collect four of these objects called "Spirit Stones", holy objects of great power, that crystallize randomly at Stone Circle tiles across the board. You then confront the King and use their power to banish him. There is also a Rot Victory, though I consider it to be one and the same with a Kingslayer Victory, but of course with the added detail of your Rot exceeing that of the King.Getting into the Palace is usually the hardest part. Everyone has their eyes on it, so everyone wants to keep you from reaching it. I have yet to try Multiplayer in Armello, but from what I've heard, it is much more fun with friends than with strangers.So, if you like politcal intrigue, fantasy, animals, and tabletop RPGs, get this game. You may want to wait until a sale to purchase it, though. That's what I did.As for the DLCs, I have not yet purchased them, but I do plan on doing so. The added characters look fun to play as, and the aesthetic pack looks good, as well. But once again, you should probably wait for a sale.I give this game a 10/10.EDIT:I just bought Usurpers, and the characters seem pretty balanced. I recommend getting it, but, again, wait until a sale. Now I just have to hold my breath for the Bandit Clan DLC...EDIT 2:Multiplayer and the community are great! I've played with both cutthroat and nice gamers, and the matches can get very intense and competitve.  A forewarning: some players have a highly developed sense of vengeance. Messing with them once may make you their nemesis for the remainder of the match. EDIT 3:Okay, I admit the games can run a little slow in multiplayer, but I still enjoy them. Just make sure you have an hour or two cleared--no one ever said tabletop gaming was quick.Like my review? Check out my  Curator  page!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												Armello is essentially a digital board game and a very good one at that. From turn one of this game, the player must make important, often risky, and game altering decisions that will shape the way they and other players progress to the end of the game. There are as many avenues for victory as there as there are players in a game which always leaves you with an opportunity for victory despite your circumstances. The small victories and defeats you experience will keep you engaged in the game up until the very end where the game's stakes rise as each player makes the final preparations for their win condition (though I concede that sometimes turns can take a little longer than I'd like). As with any multiplayer game, it is best played with friends as you will often find yourself deliberating and even deceiving them as you play. That said, I think this game would benefit from having a text chat to be able to better communicate with players in-game as the only option to do so right now is through pre-determined phrases (which have an element of humor in their own right I'll admit). The reason I bring this up is because the game claims to offer opportunity for alliance between players but in truth this can only be achieved from a few select cards and potentionally King's Declarations (this issue is, of course, circumvented through voice chat with friends but leaves solo players at a disadvantage). Ultimately, this game is a very fun and charming experience and anyone interested in this style of game will likely find themselves addicted.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												Having recently found an interest in digital board and card games, I thought I would give Armello a try given the high ratings, and was not disappointed.  Though I am personally not a big fan of the whole "whimsical animals" theme, the game itself looks very nice and gameplay is quite engaging.  Though I'd recommend picking it up on sale if possible, it really is a unique blend of different game types (part rpg, part strategy, part card game).Offhand, it reminds me of a combination of Chaos Reborn and The Witcher Adventure Game, though there is much more to it.  If you enjoy such hybrid games, I highly recommend this title!  It is not overly difficult to learn, though it clearly takes some time to master.  Unlike some card-based game, one is not put in a situation where they find themselves having to purchase cards in-game, a very strong selling point for me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												I love the flavor and the themes present in this game - the impending doom of a power vacuum and the trickery you can pull off with temporary alliances. It's all very lovely until you get into the center of the game: The dice.RNG is an important part of games because it keeps things interesting. It helps people in the back pull forwards and the leaders fall into more manageable positions. But it often times feels like you as a player are fighting RNG and not the players. It's less your strategy versus theirs and more like your fighting a coin flip.Nonetheless I recommend this game for how fun it is with friends and family. But as a warning: Do not expect to play this game like a multiplayer with progression. It's a board game where dice and random numbers decide what happens not you; so play it as such.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
												I don't play a lot of board games, card games, or tabletop dice games, so considering that Armello is a mix of all three, that should frighten me. However, I do love the premise of fantistical, swashbuckling, swords-and-magic adventure, and when you add animal characters to the pot it happily brings me back to the days I read Brian Jacques' Redwall novels.A complete Armello game normally takes about 60-75 minutes, and there are four main ways to win: doing the most "good" before the turns are up is the easiest, while the other three can be much more challenging to accomplish. Over time it may be discouraging to see time-out endings happen the most, but I think a player needs plenty of experience, a plan from the get-go, and modest luck to reliably go for the quicker, decisive wins. I'm not there yet...The artwork is lovely and so are the landscapes. All of the design resonates charm and liveliness and presents a convincing world with a broad range of characters - but only on the surface. It was a little disappointing to see a lot of this detail come only through the art. There aren't deep backstories of the playable heroes, or lore that permeates throughout the world. Events don't really happen on a timeline or connect to each other very deeply. It's like there's either "good people or bad people", "named character approaches you, you do one of two choices on a quest and that's the last you'll hear of him until you replay". The players write most of the action while fighting, betraying and sabotaging each other, but that story always resets when the game ends and another starts. Basically, don't look for a compelling narrative to be there in stone.But this takes nothing away from the core mechanics, which are pretty balanced. Each hero specializes at doing something with the three card types, whether it's suiting up in the best equipment, weapons and armor, casting spells and boosting themselves (or crippling others) for a while, or setting up traps and causing havoc to tip the scales in a different direction. Managing gold and magic to do all these things is a tricky task. Anything drastic needs the right cards in your hand and every decision to spend or save them is nerve-wracking and exciting. They're good defense most of the time, but for me they're the reason I keep getting wiped off the face of the earth by lightning when I walk out of tree cover.I think the biggest issue I have with this game is how easy it is to attack and how hard it is to defend. In most circumstances there's 3 sides of the die that grant strikes but only 1 side that provides a shield, nullifying a single attack; kind of unhelpful if strikes just outnumber everything anyway. So there's a lot of times where two battlers will just pointlessly tear each other to shreds, die, and get sent back to their homes in frustration. The game's tips do point out that combat is costly, which I guess kind of contradicts the thought that things should be settled on the battlefield. However, this ends up justifying the use of cards to do some of the fighting and keep the dice on hold.Overall, I think I'll get my money's worth out of Armello. It's not an exaggeration that this game sways in the balance of luck all the way up to the final turn and keeps things interesting and unpredictable. Armello is a worthy starting point in a genre I'm no longer unfamiliar with.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												Armello has been aptly described as a "virtual boardgame". You play against other folks online or against computer opponents, on a rather small but artfully rendered map, with the goal of becoming leader of the kingdom in one of four ways. You increase your stats by completing quests, defeating other players (or evil critters known as banes) in battle, or by luck of the draw from a deck of cards. Cards can grant you bonuses, temporary or otherwise, or you can play disadventageous cards on your enemies. Cards can also be "burned" (exchanged for a sure roll on your dice) in battle.While strategy has a decided effect on the outcome of a game, sometimes there is nothing you can do against a bad run of luck, and that is my only real complaint - too much luck is involved in gameplay, what with the cards, the dice rolls, and the arbitrary appearance of the quests and perils. I won my very first game almost purely by luck, because I really had no idea what I was doing.Despite this, I find Armello enjoyable and well worth the cost. It will appeal mostly to people who enjoy board games, but others may find it engaging as well.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												I have a love/hate relationship with this game. But I can't in good conscience recommend it.The Good: The game mechanics are well thought out, the characters and their abilities are also very balanced. Playing a game, you feel like you always have a chance to win it, even if there are setbacks. There is enough strategy to keep your brain in it, and enough luck that it doesn't get repetitive. Basically, the game itself is awesome.The Bad: It crashes. A lot. There have been days where I've had four games crash in a single day, due to reasons like someone quitting the game - more often than not, that locks up the game for all of the other players. This wouldn't be that bad, if it didn't happen afte you'd already invested 45 minutes into a multiplayer match. Don't take my word for it - go to the discusson forums and the Bug section. It's the same problem, hundreds of times. Every time, they ask for bug reports, but there's no solution. When I have reached out to the developers for assistance myself, they've said the same thing, asked for bug reports and game logs, which I've provided, on numerous occasions. Then nothing happens. The issues are never fixed.Even this wouldn't be that bad, except that they keep releasing DLC. It's like they're building additions onto a house with no foundation. Also, they're parting out cosmetics like they're trying to turn this $20 game into a $60 release. I get that no one has to buy extra dice or seasons, but it's infuriating that they seem to have the development time to push this stuff out, but not fix the very serious game breaking bugs that have been in here since the very beginning.I have about 250 hours in this game, so obviously there is a lot to enjoy. But I don't recommend you buy it until you start seeing posts here about these issues being resolved. It's absolutely infuriating, because this could be a truly great game, and instead it's something I come back to every few weeks, hoping will be better, and it never is.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												This is a fantastic game and you're missing out. I started with the excellent, in-depth tutorial, and mastered nothing. Don't get me wrong. The game is well explained and is easy to pick up, but the tutorial teches you how it is played, not how to play it. Then I started with some matches aginst the ai.It went well. I tried to get a win with each charcter. Nine games later, all but Barnaby, Twenty games later, all but Barnaby. 72 games later, all with Barnaby.I decided at this point I was versed enough for multiplayer. The first game I won on a random hero (Mercurio); presitge victory 24-6-3-2. I said, "Damn I don't know what happened but I must be a god."Then I suffered a prestige loss 10-9.After, I lost to a player sacrificing their 11 prestige to attack the king. The winning player won with 2 prestige.Then I lost, cornered in my own clan grounds as Amber by 2 banes, River, and Thane while I had 4 prestige versus a high of 8. I don't even remember who won. Nevermind, I did. With prestige. I'm still not sure how.Would buy again, 9/10.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												Armello tries to simulate a tabletop experience and does so pretty good.Think of it as Game of Thrones with animal characters.PRO:Different ways to obtain victoryDifferent Characters offer different play stylesPlaystyle can (and will need to) be adjusted in gameFeels like playing a tabletop gameCON:Some victory conditions are harder to meet (hello, rot victory)If the character you want to play gets picked by someone else you might have to change your playstyleFeels like playing a tabletop game (dice hate me ;) )Armello is a game about tactics and getting screwed over by dice and cards. Very often the player who is best at adapting to unplanned circumstances will win. Twists at the end are very common. The game is more deep on tactics than it looks and the random factor of dice and car draws help in getting that board game feel the game tries to achieve.All in all I'd say grab it while on sale, except you have a group of friends who will also get it.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												If you like board games, not boring old monopoly or life or whatever, but games with real choices and depth, get this game. It's everything a board game should be with all the things only a video game can add. The rules are simple, but provide many different strategies to win and claim the throne of Armello for yourself. The King of Armello has succumbed to the rot, a plague of darkness sweeping over the land. It weakens his body, and addles his mind. Each morning, he gets one step closer to death, and each night, he falls further into darkness. The throne is up for grabs, through one of four methods, Killing the king yourself, and surviving the fight. Gaining enough prestige throughout the land, and being crowned once the king dies of his rot (Or is killed and kills his attacker.) Finding four spirit stones, and using the magic of the Wyld to banish the king, or becoming even more corrupted than the king, and becoming the new dark lord of Armello. You and 3 other adventurers have stepped up to try and claim the throne.So explore Armello, finding treasure, ammasing wealth, growing stronger, anything to give you an edge. And once you think the time is right, storm the castle walls and take the throne. It's one of the better looking games I've seen, and yet isn't very hardware intensive (It runs perfectly fine on my crappy laptop that can't even run TF2 anymore). Goes to show how well stylized graphics can make a game shine.Currently has 8 characters, (But more are coming soon). falling into a few different archetypes, and various amulets and rings to fine-tune your character, and a crate/key systen similar to tf2 with dice skins instead of hats. No need to buy keys though, they drop as well as the crates.Overall, a very fun game that's great to play with friends, or just when you want to play a round or two.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												As a big fan of board games, I have never really enjoyed any video game version of a board game. Too many board games that make their transition to PC seem to stay too faithful to their source material, and don't realy take full advantage of what they can do with the medium. Armello is able to avoid this issue by being built from the ground up as a video game in the style of a tabletop board game. It utilizes mechanics like stealth which would be unfeasible as an actual board game, and wraps everything in beautiful visuals that really bring the game to life. Yet as a video game, Armello hits all the right notes as a board game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												I love the flavor and the themes present in this game - the impending doom of a power vacuum and the trickery you can pull off with temporary alliances. It's all very lovely until you get into the center of the game: The dice.RNG is an important part of games because it keeps things interesting. It helps people in the back pull forwards and the leaders fall into more manageable positions. But it often times feels like you as a player are fighting RNG and not the players. It's less your strategy versus theirs and more like your fighting a coin flip.Nonetheless I recommend this game for how fun it is with friends and family. But as a warning: Do not expect to play this game like a multiplayer with progression. It's a board game where dice and random numbers decide what happens not you; so play it as such.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
												I don't play a lot of board games, card games, or tabletop dice games, so considering that Armello is a mix of all three, that should frighten me. However, I do love the premise of fantistical, swashbuckling, swords-and-magic adventure, and when you add animal characters to the pot it happily brings me back to the days I read Brian Jacques' Redwall novels.A complete Armello game normally takes about 60-75 minutes, and there are four main ways to win: doing the most "good" before the turns are up is the easiest, while the other three can be much more challenging to accomplish. Over time it may be discouraging to see time-out endings happen the most, but I think a player needs plenty of experience, a plan from the get-go, and modest luck to reliably go for the quicker, decisive wins. I'm not there yet...The artwork is lovely and so are the landscapes. All of the design resonates charm and liveliness and presents a convincing world with a broad range of characters - but only on the surface. It was a little disappointing to see a lot of this detail come only through the art. There aren't deep backstories of the playable heroes, or lore that permeates throughout the world. Events don't really happen on a timeline or connect to each other very deeply. It's like there's either "good people or bad people", "named character approaches you, you do one of two choices on a quest and that's the last you'll hear of him until you replay". The players write most of the action while fighting, betraying and sabotaging each other, but that story always resets when the game ends and another starts. Basically, don't look for a compelling narrative to be there in stone.But this takes nothing away from the core mechanics, which are pretty balanced. Each hero specializes at doing something with the three card types, whether it's suiting up in the best equipment, weapons and armor, casting spells and boosting themselves (or crippling others) for a while, or setting up traps and causing havoc to tip the scales in a different direction. Managing gold and magic to do all these things is a tricky task. Anything drastic needs the right cards in your hand and every decision to spend or save them is nerve-wracking and exciting. They're good defense most of the time, but for me they're the reason I keep getting wiped off the face of the earth by lightning when I walk out of tree cover.I think the biggest issue I have with this game is how easy it is to attack and how hard it is to defend. In most circumstances there's 3 sides of the die that grant strikes but only 1 side that provides a shield, nullifying a single attack; kind of unhelpful if strikes just outnumber everything anyway. So there's a lot of times where two battlers will just pointlessly tear each other to shreds, die, and get sent back to their homes in frustration. The game's tips do point out that combat is costly, which I guess kind of contradicts the thought that things should be settled on the battlefield. However, this ends up justifying the use of cards to do some of the fighting and keep the dice on hold.Overall, I think I'll get my money's worth out of Armello. It's not an exaggeration that this game sways in the balance of luck all the way up to the final turn and keeps things interesting and unpredictable. Armello is a worthy starting point in a genre I'm no longer unfamiliar with.

Posted: September 29, 2016
												It's a fun little jaunt and experiment into how a virtual board game would work. It has some clever mechanics and is overall quite fun. Be warned, though, that playing with other people (as opposed to just playing the AI) will make the game substantially longer. If you can get together and play with some friends online, you'll probably all have a lot of fun. If you're just playing with randoms, you'll probably have a bad time as you wait what feels like an eternity for your turn to come back around.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												I first got this game expecting it to be a weird, annoying, and complicated game but of course I was proven wrong. I love the game for its gameplay, creativity, and art style and I love how it allows us to build our own little story out of these characters. Me and my friends are hooked and I think we recently met a developer online! But there is still room for improvement! Some ideas me and my friends had is that when a game is finished we could save our quest journals so we can read them whenever we want! I also do think that the map tends to get a little cluttered and could use expansion (DLC possibly?). Speaking of DLC I looked at the prices for the new characters and such I do think that it is WAAAY overpriced... TEN WHOLE DOLLARS!?! SERIOUSLY!?! But yeah I hope maybe the devs take these ideas into consideration because I have a feeling this game may start to get a little dull soon... ;-)

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												Armello is a great looking digital adventure boardgame.  There's a lot to do and there are multiple paths to victory and opportunities to adjust your strategy during the game.  It feels a little random at first, but once you start learning the cards and strategies, you feel like you have more control.The continued support and last few updates have done a a lot to streamline the game (particularly the quick AI turns). Some of the design descions feel like they should have stayed in a board game ,ex. rolling actual dice, non-syncronous turns.  Multiplayer has a lot of down time between turns.  This isn't a game for impatient people.Overall, if you are patient and take the time to dig in, this is an interesting strategy gaming experience.  I initially disliked this game due to clunky UI and too much downtime in multiplayer. I feel the developers have sufficiently addressed this (although more can be done) and find myself willing to dig deeper.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												The art style and presentation is excellent; this is very much a digital board game, and has the look and feel to match. The gameplay is simple to grasp: move around the play area completing quests and the like to reach one of 4 win conditions. Variety, depth, and replayability comes from the 8 characters; unlockable buffs; and a large number of cards to reveal. I played through the tutorial just to get an idea of how the game plays, and I was instantly hooked. I have only played through 1 full game but will definitely replay as it is very fun and compelling to play. I've two main gripes with Armello.The first is that there can be a lot of down-time between turns while the AI/other players decide what to do, which would be fine in a table top game, here it leads to boredom. You can speed up AI turns, but I imagine that when playing with 3 other people will lead to very long games.My second gripe is that there is not a lot of interraction between players. You can lay traps (You've activated my trap card!) and cast spells on them, but a lot of the time the only way to sabotage someone's plan is to out-and-out attack them (if you can get to them, movement is slow enough) or to pip them to the post and win faster than them/complete an objective faster than them.I would recommend this if you like board games, but maybe put on a show to watch when it's not your turn, or have voice chat to allow witty reparte and the lively back and forths that you get with IRL board games.

												Armello is not only the best boardgame I've ever played, it's also run by the best community!!! I highly recommend you join the discord which is on the armello reddit, the players there will teach you so much and help you learn about the complexities and nuances of the decisions you make. They will celebrate your successes and comfort you on your failures, all whilst teaching you. Moreover, this is a boardgame at heart. Playing it with stranger to whom you can't talk is not the way it was designed to be played. I beseech you to try this game, put the time in to learn its strategies and allow yourself to be swept away in the wonderful and blissful land of Armello.NOTE: I'm aware this game is not for everyone. It requires a lot of patience at first, and does involve a large amount of RNG.

												One of the best indie title on steam! a must have in anyone steam library. also a really fun game to turn into a drinking game. the whole idea of the game is to either save the king from rot, or you can consume a bunch of rot and take the kingdom over as an evil empire, or you can kill the king in a king slayer victory removing the rot but killing the king, or you can gather the spirt stones and clense the king of rot. you draw from three diffrent card decks. iteam, magic, and trickey. choose from the 3 and compete agasint 3 other players attemping which ever victory they desire.p.s. watch out for this cat he a real stranger in the game.the king really doesn't like him.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Backed this game on Kickstarter, it's really come a long way. Armello is an absolute gem of a game. A digital board game featuring lovable animal characters trying to dethrone a corrupted king and claim the throne for their clan. Mechanics are well thought out, and the game is regularly updated with new and improved systems to add additional depth while not making the game overly complex or confusing. There are multiple ways to win, which helps keep a single person from dominating the match, though the game is quite RNG-based, relying on dice rolling for battles, card drawing, procedurally generated board, semi-randomized quests, and a few other mechanics. Sometimes even with excellent strategy, the luck of the draw can't be overcome.Still, an excellent game I never get bored of. Game length: 1-2 hoursPros:+ Beautiful and unique style and graphics featuring anthropomorphic animals+ Great soundtrack+ Procedurally generated board means every game will be different+ Multiple ways to claim victory, to stop a single player from dominating and blocking others from winning+ Interesting and unique systems for combat, bounties, and 'traps'+ Each character has a unique hero power that makes them different from other heroes+ Each hero can be further customized to your playstyle with a selection of rings (exclusive to clans) and amulets (available to all heros)+ 'Microtransactions' handled very well and very positively for everyone. Dice skins can be found in chests and traded or sold on the Steam market, which the Devs get a cut of when an item sells on the market.+ Updated fairly regularly with new and enhanced systems+ Devs are very attentive to bugs and glitches and do their best to solve them as soon as they can+ Promotes public play with a chest and key system, in which both chests AND keys drop+ Custom rule settings for private games+ Can play a single-player match while waiting for a game (though queues are rarely very long), tab on taskbar will flash when you find a game while queued is you don't want to play singleplayerCons:- RNG-based, sometimes too much- Some hero's powers are almost useless, while others are very powerful- Private play doesn't give you keys or chests, making those who prefer to play only with friends unrewarded and left out (though the keys and chests only contain cosmetic dice skins, so it's not a mechanical disadvantage)- Currently a set of 4 exclusive Kickstarter heroes, though anyone playing in a private game with someone who owns them can use them, they can only be used in private games, and the Devs have stated they will be released as DLC for anyone to purchase eventually- Only way to communicate is through a set of 'commands', such as Hello, Good-bye, etc. No voice or text chat.- DLC is a little pricey, especially in comparison to the full game (the set of 4 DLC heroes is $10, 2 board skins are $5).

I can say for sure, that it is my underdog of the year.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
 BASICALLY ITS REDWALL IN VIRTUAL TABLETOP RPG FORM. Both the 8 year old and the 18 year old in me are giddy with joy! So to start I'll sum up what is generally not well liked by pretty much everyone and get that out of the way. Firstly, nearly everything in this game is in some way randomly generated. I could explain the systems and what I think were the design choices that led to the extreme amount of RNG in this game but it really isn't worth the time. Suffice to say that the one consistent element in the game is the number of tile you can move on a given turn. There have also been what I see as contradictory complaints about the game being too long to be fun and too short to be playable. I fundamentally disagree with both of these assessments on the grounds that A) I have only had difficulty achieving one play style after less that a days worth of play and B) a game will last you less than an hour to complete when something like irl Dungeons and Dragons will take like three just to get from town to town and a grand strategy game like any of the Civ games can take multiple days to finish on lengthier settings. And to be clear, I mean the game will take less that an hour because the game has what is effectively countdown clock built into the game with the way that the king (the victory condition in this game) works. Basically, the game ends when he dies and he is already on the way out the door by the time the game starts. Secondly, There is, at this time, not exactly a wealth of content available. THIS DOES NOT MEAN THAT YOU WILL PLAY THE GAME ONCE AND BE DONE WITH IT. What it means is that there is effectively one game mood and one map. What keeps the game fresh, in my opinion, is the very randomness that some people seem to distain. From what I have seen on the forums accessed from within the game, they are still actively working on bring more playable characters into the game and genuinely seem interested in improving the game with time. As for maps and game modes, I haven't seen any developments of note. In my personal opinion, the game is well worth its price as is but that is a very personal evaluation I leave up to you. If these are concerns for you, you may wish to avoid this game, at least for the time being.Otherwise, EVERYTHING ABOUT THIS GAME IS AN ABSOLUTE JOY.The art is lovely in a way that I won't even attempt to describe. It manages to be both whimsical (prob mispelled) and sufficiently, well not exactly bleak but fitting for the sort of dark fantasy game that they were going for. The RPG elements, which I admit are a tad simplistic, are very rewarding if you take the time to read the in game text, consider you actions through the lens of you character, and put in the smallest effort to care about what your doing. In short, use your imagination for 5 seconds. Its good for you. There is some RPG style progression and a wealth of collectables of extremely high quality (such as animated cards that you unlock for viewing after being played) and trinkets to change the way each kingdoms champions play after you have used them multiple times. I personally love the gameplay. Note that I say this as someone that plays Dungeons and Dragons semi-regularly and has absolutely no problem waiting for 15 minutes while Sir Mixalot (actual name of friend's character) makes a decision as to what song he is going to play and then roles like thirty dice just to see if it all amounts to anything meaningful. Yes, it is undoubtably slow as a result of there being no way to skip the AI's turns and it is most certainly very random. However, it is not the total cluster that some of the negative reviews might lead you to think. Each character has certains stats at which he or she is better equiped to use. If you pay attention, you might even pick up on the fact that each of the 4 kingdoms is designed to be better at a certain type of victory condition, of which there are 4. And when I say might have noticed, I mean play throught he tutorial up until the point where the game literally tells you which victory each of the AI players are going for and which you should aim for. If that wasn't a big enough clue, maybe just put on your thinking cap an realize that trying to win a game by killing a lion as a rabbit is probably not the best course of action. It's a lot like rock, paper, scissors except this time with "fatal" consequences.Also, not that this is the biggest thing to note, but the music is very pleasent. I'm not talking like Bastion levels of amazing or even Skyrim levels of IS THIS EPIC ENOUGH FOR YOU. It's more subtle and relaxed in a sort of "what if Game of Thrones didn't make you have an minor heart attack everytime you watch" sort of way (note that I do realize that a great deal of GoT is just people talking at each other and not all that eventful). ONE LAST WORD OF CAUTION: I do think that a large part of my personal enjoyment of this particular game comes from the theme and setting. When I was a younger, I read a great deal of the "Redwall" series by Brian Jacques that I mentioned at the beginning of this review. It is in no way an understatement to say that these book made me love to read. I can really explain what it was about them as a whole that I responded to but I know that, by shear virtue of the easy parallels between the books and this game, that Armello stirred within me many of the emotions and affections that struck me as a child while reading the collective works of Mr. Jacques. If you, like me have any fondness for those book I highly recommend giving this game at least a cursory glance before passing it up. If you don't then go read any book from the Redwall series right now, or at the very least keep them in mind if your looking for something to gift to an 8 to 12 year old. I say all of this as an admission of bias. Please do take it into consideration.So to sum this whole thing up, if the idea of midieval furry simulator 2015 sounds the least bit interesting to you, give this a chance.Forgive any spelling or grammar error you might find in this thing. I wrote it at 1 in the morning.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												Here's my two cents on this game: - Really beautiful graphics, great gameplay. - 8 characters to play from, all with unique abilities and differing stats but even the weakest can be the strongest.- Win in 4 different ways or be like me: Kill king's guards cause they're standing on my quest (._.)- Sabotage your opponents and laugh like a maniacal mastermind. (Even better when they're so close to winning) - Then get sabotaged in return (Sucks when you're so close to winning) - Dice rolls, mhmmm, don't even let me start on that. Unique but still partially dependent on your luck xD (RNG !@!%@!)Additional stuff:- I do get this weird rough-ish sort of sound in game and sometimes it gets a little annoying (not that it affects the entire gameplay anyway). - Game might be still a little buggish (or maybe it's just my PC's issue x.x) but developers are quick to respond xD.TLDR; Great game, should try getting it if it's on discount if you feel the price is a bit eheh. Not that type of game which you can play for 5 hours straight, a game or two a day with friends makes it all the better xD. If you're not the board game type of person, might not be entirely worth it to get it at full price but it's a great way to spend time with friends, so do give it a try :D9/10-ish. Hopefully the developers add a little more content (maybe expand the map and add more winning conditions or allow more players?), but it's still a job well done xD.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												Love this game to death with a nice community and a lovely game. There are some quirks to it but that's quickly overshadowed by all the fun you have playing the game. For starters:This is a turned based game that has a lot of cool mechanics which are and are not limited to:Mana usage - Cast spells on opponents during your turn and on someone elses turn (can't target players that is taking their turn)Money usage - Funds the perils and trickery cards which turn the battle for Armello in your favorPerils which are traps Different character types and abilities for each of the clans united by the KingA generator map that is different everytime you play it.This game is really fun but the core of the game is how you're suppose to win. There are 4 ways of winning the game. 1. Win by Prestige. Most common winning method by my experience. You pretty much do good deeds and kill enemy heroes and banes. You can also complete the quests.2. Win by King Kill. Go into the Palace and kill the king to win the game!3. Win by Spirit Stone. After stepping into the Palace, you can win instantly by exiling the king.4. Win by Rot. Compete against the King to whoever is the most corrupted. You gain additonal die for having a higher rot score.There are different ways of playing the game, but why don't you buy it and try it yourself? It's 20 bucks and well worth the amount of money being put into the game.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												Great strategy board game. Sometimes feels a tad slow because theres so much content in the game. Mixes card playing aspects nicely for battle mechanics. Haven't been able to play online (keep getting bumped) but not sure if mac and pc matchmaking exists, as I've been playing on the go on a macbook, not on my main PC. Props on the art style, as it's super well done. Character animations for battle scenes can get somewhat repetitive, but it's more about the journey towards being the king and killing everyone/thing in your path. The AI is fairly good, so don't assume you'll always win. It's a slow burn to win, but enjoyable none the less. Multiplayer against friends is probably even more fun. Worth checking out if you're into strategy/board/card playing games.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												Armello is an incredibly original and refreshing experience.Combining boardgame strategy with roleplay mechanics in a fairy tale ambiance, the game has this unique aura that won't leave you indifferent.There are a few different characters, each having its own features and specificities, and four different ways to win the game that will require you to adapt to the unpredictable events happening on the board. Even after hours spent playing, I still haven't unlocked everything and I just can't stop launching new games because this is just too much fun.You should definitely make a stop by this enchanted kingdom. Not sure you'll manage to leave though.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												Armello is better than most boardgames brought to pc.  It is a unique hybrid that has elements of board games and strictly PC RPGs.   It is not a couch party game (at least not yet) -- not sure if it would work or not since it has a stealth element.  Controller support in-game is nice for SteamOS (though you can't  navigate menu yet).  I think it is a better version of Wizwar or Talisman (more stratedy and ways to win) though there is still some luck/badluck that can frustrate or make you jump for joy.Overall, I have tried many Early Access games and many seem to progress very slow.  I would put Armello at the top of the list for customer support, updates, dev team, ect.  (alongside Brawlhalla); I am thoroughly impressed.UPDATE: 7/15 -- Developers have continually patched multiplayer performance and added new cards and events to the game as free content and work on balancing the cost/values/stats of cards.  The game continues to get better and they are planning to add more heroes to play (free or not, I'd pay for more champs and diversity).

												I have a library of about 45 games and have only reviewed one other game.  I am simply not compelled to do so very often but I must say how much I love this game.  The art is fantastic.  The devs are very active and it is just fun.  Sure, it has little issues here and there (would love multiplayer matches to form a bit faster for example) but this is a rare game indeed.  Victory is never guaranteed, you can help other players or stab them in the back.  Become an epic hero in battle or out-wit everyone without swinging your blade.  Take your pick; there are so many ways to win...and lose.  If you are on the fence...dont be.  I will see you in battle.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												I always feel a bit of secret relief when the results of a Kickstarter project finally makes it into my hands. Kickstarter is both a great tool for people to gain funding for, and put forward ideas for, projects they are passionate about. It’s also a recipe for disaster. Projects often over-promise and under-deliver, much like the last decade for Peter Molyneux. And there’s no guarantee that the people behind the projects have any concept of how to manage a small business, which is essentially what kickstarter is enabling.Fortunately, the Kickstarter that is Armello did not over-promise and ended up resulting in a great game. League of Geeks, backed by Screen Australia and Film Victoria, have developed a digital board game, and one of the first that I know of that isn’t an adaptation of an actual board game. What makes Armello a great game is its use of the digital medium. It does things that most other board games couldn’t. There are several different game systems which make this a complex game, but complexity is fine in this medium. When you move into forests at night, you become invisible, something you couldn’t do with a hardcopy game. It also allows the NPCs to be a force of nature in themselves. The king and his guards have their own agenda, the banes that spawn out of the rot also act individually. But the best thing about having a digital board game is that there’s added character and personality in the game. The guard dogs sniff the air as they stand to attention. Some of the cards have animations. Day and night is actually day and night. You have a little advisor which pops up when you need to choose a new quest.I’m yet to play with other humans, which will definitely provide a stronger challenge than playing with AI (one difficulty setting), and I’m looking forward to it.For full review, visit: http://icarusreviews.net/2015/10/12/armello/

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												I primarily game as a single player, so it made reviewing Armello difficult because a lot of the magic of Armello is found in Multiplayer with the community. Luckily, the community is healthy, supported, and talented. Here's a couple reasons why:1. Developer Dedication - The LoG crew streams 3 times a week, providing answers to questions, insight to new developments, and generally being a stand-up crew. It's well past launch, and the developers continue to be a positive presence in the community. 2. Player Community - On both the forums and in the streams, you'll find dedicated players willing to answer questions, consider strategies, and talk about the future of the game. Games online maintain a friendly but competitive atmosphere. Because at its core, Armello is a digital boardgame, with all the pros and cons of one.A number of reviews have brought up the pace, the danger of battles, and the tendency for Prestige victories to be more common. These are all true, but they're part of what make Armello great. For pacing, you wouldn't rush through a board game, you want to take the time to consider your actions. Plus, you can also play a lot of cards while it isn't your turn. This is where the strategy of Armello really shines.The battles, I've found the battles are very dangerous because the rewards are significant. Especially when there is a bounty on the player's head, or you're fighting the Prestige leader, or you're clearing a bane from a settlement. All of these can generate +2 relative prestige, which is an enormous boost. With careful maneuvering, you can easily go from underdog to leader, if you roll well.Finally, yes. I've won a ton more as Prestige Leader than any other. That's what develops the tension. From the very beginning of the game, every player is working toward Prestige victory. That's the long term goal, but sometimes when you are coming up short. That's when you can invoke some of the others such as Spirit or Kingslayer to steal a victory from the Prestige leader. Being flexible and adjusting to changing game conditions is part of the fun of Armello.There are numerous other critiques players have brought up, which I've considered, and I've now come to terms with. A lot of them are part of what makes Armello great and provides the challenge in the game. I don't think this game is for everyone, it isn't an RPG where you grow stronger and unstoppable. Nor it is a strategy game where consistent good decisions will insulate you from doom. Instead, Armello is a dynamic game full of life and capable of catching you by surprise. And that's why I recommend Armello.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												I picked this game up in the early access stages and was very impressed from the get go. I don't play it as often as I would like as it's one of those games I prefer to play with friends rather than with random strangers, but when we do manage to get a few games in we always have a lot of fun. Armello is a board game brought to life in virtual form and it is done beautifully which is a credit to the developers as board games rarely convert well to a video game format. The game is set in a mythical fantasy kingdom of medieval animal characters, initially of which four were selectable but another four have been added since. There are four factions that represent different species, rats, rabbits, wolves and bears. The rat faction is home to charismatic sneaky types who suit the player that values cleverness and cunning (I always play as Mercurio for this reason) the rabbit faction is home to nobility who fare best at exploring and unearthing valuable artifacts, the wolf faction consists of brave warriors, suitable for players who value honour and battle and the bear faction consists of druids who suit players that prefer to use magic. All four factions and the characters who represent them are well balanced and give the game a good amount of variety in it's functionality. The object of the game is to dethrone the corrupted King (who naturally is a Lion) and usurp the throne for your own faction. The land has been swept by an arcane sickness that has brought about large ravens that leave death and destruction in their wake, the corruption they spread is a blight that darkens the souls of creatures it touches, which is why the King must be dethroned. The game takes place across a day and night cycle which alternate every turn, each night the King takes a point of corruption which weakens his health but makes his ability to fight more devestating. There are four ways to win in Armello, you can kill the King yourself thus dethroning him in person, you can opt to be a little more guileful and gather prestige so that you are selected to be heir should the King die due to corruption rather than player intervention, you can collect four spirit stones that can be used to cure the King of corruption so he can be banished or you can gain as much corruption as possible through evil deeds which will give you a better chance at killing the King. As the game plays out you move freely around the board as many spaces each turn as your character abilities allow for, you collect cards that come in various forms that affect yourself, other players and the board in various ways. You can also opt to go on quests that come with their own rewards and add a good deal of role playing and flavour to the game. Should you come across an opposing player you can opt to battle them and if you do you get given the opportunity to burn any cards you don't want and each card will be converted into a dice that represents whatever burn ability the card had alongside it's own ability, this can come in the form of combat and various other things that will affect how the battles play out. There are honestly so many unique functions and things to do in this game that to go into all of them would take too much time, but for a game that lasts around an hour per session it really manages to suck you in and offer you a great deal of things to do without ever seeming too rules heavy or complex, which really gives it great appeal to both hardcore board game players and newcomers alike.I really, really like Armello, it's a beautiful game with fantastic artwork, design and enough tactical depth to keep you coming back for more. I play a number of board games with friends and Armello has outstayed many of them, which is quite the feat for a virtual board game. If you have any interest in board style games at all or were just looking for something to play with friends and family I highly recommend Armello, it's quickly become one of my favourites.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												I picked this game up in the early access stages and was very impressed from the get go. I don't play it as often as I would like as it's one of those games I prefer to play with friends rather than with random strangers, but when we do manage to get a few games in we always have a lot of fun. Armello is a board game brought to life in virtual form and it is done beautifully which is a credit to the developers as board games rarely convert well to a video game format. The game is set in a mythical fantasy kingdom of medieval animal characters, initially of which four were selectable but another four have been added since. There are four factions that represent different species, rats, rabbits, wolves and bears. The rat faction is home to charismatic sneaky types who suit the player that values cleverness and cunning (I always play as Mercurio for this reason) the rabbit faction is home to nobility who fare best at exploring and unearthing valuable artifacts, the wolf faction consists of brave warriors, suitable for players who value honour and battle and the bear faction consists of druids who suit players that prefer to use magic. All four factions and the characters who represent them are well balanced and give the game a good amount of variety in it's functionality. The object of the game is to dethrone the corrupted King (who naturally is a Lion) and usurp the throne for your own faction. The land has been swept by an arcane sickness that has brought about large ravens that leave death and destruction in their wake, the corruption they spread is a blight that darkens the souls of creatures it touches, which is why the King must be dethroned. The game takes place across a day and night cycle which alternate every turn, each night the King takes a point of corruption which weakens his health but makes his ability to fight more devestating. There are four ways to win in Armello, you can kill the King yourself thus dethroning him in person, you can opt to be a little more guileful and gather prestige so that you are selected to be heir should the King die due to corruption rather than player intervention, you can collect four spirit stones that can be used to cure the King of corruption so he can be banished or you can gain as much corruption as possible through evil deeds which will give you a better chance at killing the King. As the game plays out you move freely around the board as many spaces each turn as your character abilities allow for, you collect cards that come in various forms that affect yourself, other players and the board in various ways. You can also opt to go on quests that come with their own rewards and add a good deal of role playing and flavour to the game. Should you come across an opposing player you can opt to battle them and if you do you get given the opportunity to burn any cards you don't want and each card will be converted into a dice that represents whatever burn ability the card had alongside it's own ability, this can come in the form of combat and various other things that will affect how the battles play out. There are honestly so many unique functions and things to do in this game that to go into all of them would take too much time, but for a game that lasts around an hour per session it really manages to suck you in and offer you a great deal of things to do without ever seeming too rules heavy or complex, which really gives it great appeal to both hardcore board game players and newcomers alike.I really, really like Armello, it's a beautiful game with fantastic artwork, design and enough tactical depth to keep you coming back for more. I play a number of board games with friends and Armello has outstayed many of them, which is quite the feat for a virtual board game. If you have any interest in board style games at all or were just looking for something to play with friends and family I highly recommend Armello, it's quickly become one of my favourites.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2016
												Armello brings the charm of board games into the digital world, and does it better than a simple port might.A lot of digital board games simple replicate a board game with a screen and buttons. This can be fun, but one thing that sets Armello apart is that they actually take advantage of the medium and do things that would actually be impossible in a real-life board game, but yet they never take away from that dice-rolling, peice-moving wistfulness that comes from playing a good board game. The game looks and sounds fantastic, with battle animations and background music, all while rolling dice and drawing cards. It's a very nice balance of a board game and a video game, without sacrificing the charm of either one.As for the game itself, you pick a anthropomorphic animal hero, then move around the board to try and overthrow the kind before one of your three opponents do. There's combat, and spells, and stragedy, and many options for how to win. Not a whole lot to say here, except that if you like turn-based, board game combat with some stragety and thinking but also some luck, you'll like this game. To anyone who likes board games and video games, this is an excellent example of how to properly merge the two genres.

												I most definitely recommend this game. I don't have any other friends to play this with, so I'm basically just stuck playing singleplayer. The fact that I can just play as the Wolf Clan any game I want instead of being stuck having to be one character and one character specifically. The fact that I can just completely avoid having to fight the king is awesome, seeing as I can win the pristige victory whenever.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												Armello is a very good implementation of an electronic board game.  The game is colorful, and I feel the champions abilities definitely give each character a distinct play style.  Combine that with the items, and no game really plays quite the same.  However, due to the winning conditions, yes the end game will appear on the surface to be the same, but how you got there, and the actual board situation can differ significantly from game to game.How you build your character and what items you get into play are very important.  Taking items that provide additional dice, will typically give you a better attack, but they leave you vulnerable in defense.  If you take defensive items, you tend to get guaranteed die rolls (shields), but you give up some attack potential to do so.  However, you need to keep an eye on what your opponents are doing.  If they are building defensively, and they have higher base health than you, going defensive is not your best option.  If they are going for a high attack, it might be best for you to rely on subterfuge and obstacles to achieve your aims.  I highly recommend this game, but having a liking for boardgames definitely enhances the enjoyment.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												JUST ONE MORE GAME AND I'LL WRITE A REVIEW! JUST ONE MORE...!That's what I've been saying ever since I bought this game, and I can't stop playing. Armello is a gorgeous virtual board game with a surprising amount of depth to it, and like all dice-based board games, a surprising amount of frustration. However, trust me when I say that once you figure it all out, this game becomes incredibly fun to play. So, here's my pros and cons for the game:PROS:+Aesthetic, artwork, art style--everything about this game is gorgeous!+Simple to learn, decently difficult to master+It's a virtual board game that's actually goodCONS:-Frustrating amount of luck required at times (I just spent 4 hours trying to get ONE Rot victory, and currently, it's nearly impossible to do)-The AI's difficulty spikes in opposite directions, at times (I've had one become king of the world by turn 5, only to be destroyed by a weak Bane; other times, they've been so easy to get past that it took me less than 10 turns to secure my victory)I had to work hard to find those two gripes, and since the game's getting frequent patches, I'm certain that they're going to be fixed within the next few months. Seriously, though, if you're a giant nerd like I am and you have spent several hundred or thousand dollars on board games, Armello is probably right up your alley! I don't score games with numbers, because I don't think it's possible to quantify an opinion into a number, but instead I use a scale of: "Buy it now, wait for a sale, wait for a massive sale, or DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME OR MONEY!" This game gets a solid 'Buy it now' from me, ESPECIALLY if you're a board game fan like myself!It's $20, and while I've had some frustrating matches, I understand that that's going to happen in a game like this. The dice might decide, "Oh hey, you know how you need a shield? I'm going to slow on that side, look like I'm going to stop, AND THEN I'M A MOON SUCKA! AHAHAHA!" or you might draw 6 cards in a row that are completely useless to you, but that actually makes it more appealing to me. You have to learn to adapt to any situation that the game throws at you.Anyway, thanks for reading the review, and I'll see ya next time!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Great game for fans of turn based strategy games done in a single sitting.Here are my first thoughts after 50 hours.  About 5 hours single player and 45 multiplayer, so I'm definitely focusing on the PvP aspect, though I suppose some might even enjoy single player.Pros:+ Great graphics+ Original and fun gameplay mechanics+ Pretty good gameplay balance+ Healthy multiplayer community (rarely more than 30 seconds of queue time)+ Good loot drop system, especially if you enjoy the Steam marketplaceCons:- No replay system (probably the most obvious oversight), especially being a turn-based strategy game)- No option for a full overhead view, which would be extremely helpful.- No campaign besides the tutorial- Very little voice acting- Technical issues with sound (certain sounds consistently come in crackly, perhaps poor recording?)- Lots of waiting for your opponent(s) (=overly long matches)- Some bugs/unexpected behavior with card effects- RNG + long match time = anti-fun (see below)I didn't mention RNG itself as a pro or a con, because I think it can go either way depending on the player's taste.  There is too much RNG to bank on being able to pull off a particular strategy each game, but that can be viewed as a good thing since it forces a player to cosider all options at all times.  However, the problem here is that your match usually comes down to a single dice roll (attacking the king), which can be very frustrating at times.  You can outplay your opponents the entire match and go into that dice roll and fail miserably (lose the game), which would be fine with an RNG-type game like this if it weren't for the fact that you spent 45-90 min leading up to it.IMO, the game should have been made with a slightly smaller board with only 3 players (instead of 4).  This would take the average game down down to something more managable like 30 min.Despite all of the cons, the fact is that this game a lot of fun, even for an RNG-hater like me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11
												Despite mostly positive reviews, I have to admit I wasn't too sure about buying the game at first. Most people that reviewed the game negatively, seemed to dislike the apparent long waiting times in matches (and as such long matches) and the general randomness. It put me off a little. I did put the game on my wishlist and I noticed I kept checking it out every day. So what the heck, I took the plunge.After getting a few games under my belt I can safely say: I do not regret buying it.The game looks great and plays exactly like a tabletop game should play. Not entirely sure how to explain it, but it has that feel to it. The amount of time you spend waiting for other players is very manageable; I never felt like I wanted to do something else while waiting. Matches take about an hour or so, give or take, which to me is perfect. And the randomness, well.. it's a dice-game.. It seems silly to complain about it (you don't complain about a RL game of Risk, or similar, I'd imagine) and there are plenty of ways to build your character as well as influence the game and other players by your actions. There's luck, and there's bad luck, but I always felt "in control".The lack of a regular chat system seemed odd at first, and at times I do miss it still, but the preset phrases you can hurl at eachother seem to cover most bases, and I can see the point in that it keeps things friendly. No salt or toxic nerdrage to feast your eyes upon. Being thick-skinned, a mute button would have been enough for me, but we have what we have, and it's fine.There's the odd quitter here and there, and it's difficult to determine if they quit intentionally or by accident. I've had one game lock up on me after 3 people subsequently dropped. Not sure what happened there, but it seems to be something that's around for a while already. I really hope it's not a too common occurrence; I don't mind losing a game, but getting a big "nope! - you just wasted nearly an hour of your time" simply sucks.All in all, solid 8,5/10 for the game, well done! If you're on the fence for the same reasons as me, don't hesitate to give the game a try.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												I was looking for a new game and saw this on the day of its release, bought it as a curiosity.  I never write reviews, ever, but this game deserves it.Armello has done the impossible, digitalized the tabletop strategy board game while mantaining the feel of rolling dice with your friends.  What's more, the digital platform has allowed for beautiful gameplay, and new and creative stretches to the genre.  It looks great, feels authentic, and tantalizingly hints at a deep and rich mythology that the devs are slowly revealing via updates and dlc.Some people have complained about the gameplay mechanics, I haven't found them at all random, I mean,  no more than you would want with a game of its type.  The game is incredibly complex but easy to learn, and the devs are always releasing new tweaks, they really listen to feedback, and their patches and updates help, I particulary like the +1 body to all heroes, not to mention the slew of new content that is coming up.The game is ground breaking. If you ever wanted an easier, more streamlimned way to play Avalon Hill type games without sacrificing the deep strategy, this it it.  Cannot recommend it enough.
