number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												Armello: Haphazard RegicideEver wanted to kill a king? No? Oh… Well, ugh, this is significantly more awkward, isn’t’ it? I guess– er, you know, forget I said anything.So…Do you like anthropomorphic animals? Yes? Cool! Well… Remember that murder thing I mentioned…?Armello is a pretty rad indie game that simulates a stellar board game experience. One that mixes elements from Table-Top, Pen and Paper RPGs, and a bit of MtG to make for a very unique experience. Armello is pretty simple to play once you get the hang of the game’s systems. But it’s fairly complex to explain… Despite a bit of a learning curve, this game is definitely worth the initial hump of “What the hell am I doing?”.Before we get into the nitty gritty, the main goal of Armello is to become the new Monarch. The current King has been stricken with an evil disease called ‘The Rot’. And as you would expect, he’s not doing so hot. Every night his condition worsens, and every day he inches closer to death. The Rot also affects his mind, sending him into madness. I feel bad for the guy.Now, how does this relate to the player? Well, every win condition involves usurping him, either by waiting for him to die and taking his place. Or taking the throne through force. Heck, even the condition that involves purifying the King of his Rot kills him. So you need to get comfortable with the idea of regicide. Despite it’s appearance, Armello is a pretty dark and rough game.The death of the King is the impetus, and the final goal, of your actions. Almost everything you do will revolve around this end goal. But the King is more of a passive piece on the board. He looms over the game, and carries out evil machinations, but never poses an immediate threat. What you have to look out for is the three other people all actively scheming, and advancing their own plots. You’ll be put in situations very regularly that involve you prolonging the King’s life in order to ensure you’re the one to end it. The enemy of my enemy and all that.There are a lot of moving pieces in Armello. Four players all working towards a similar goal. With alliances and rivalries beginning and ending on a turn by turn bases. What might appear like help from another player is really just them protecting themselves. I’ll help you this turn to back stab you next turn.Everything might be going exceptionally well on turn three, but by turn four the entire board state has changed and you must re-assess. It pays to think ahead, and have a plan, but it is invaluable to be able to adapt. There were many occasions where I was one turn away from winning, only to have it slip away from me when the AI pulled a total dark horse victory out of thin air.How is this possible? Well, every player has a wide array of abilities that can, when used creatively, be applied to completely ruin another player’s day. There are pieces of equipment that increase your prowess in battle– making it easier to kill the King… or anything else. There are magic spells that give nasty status effects, such as: ending your turn prematurely, move you across the board, or possibly even killing you. And my personal favorite, traps. These can be anything from poison, killing companions, stealing their cards or gold, negating their equipment.. the list goes on. If you think through your actions, and use everything at your disposal, you can send someone in the lead into last place with one turn.The order you do things in, and how long you wait to do it are incredibly important. On your turn you, usually, have three action points that allow you to do the various things at your disposal. Some take more than others… Simply moving three spaces can wreck havoc on another player. Scattered around the game’s map are little villages. If you move your character through them they will pay tribute to you in the form of gold. Without gold you can’t perform certain actions. Having three turns worth of set up be ruined because you’re short one gold is incredibly disheartening.The swings in Armello are fast and hard. I’ve gone from first to last and back more than once over the course of a game. It’s never dull, and never boring. The pressure is almost always on. And the games are fast enough that you can play one over a lunch break.Aside from killing the other players, there are also quests you can embark on that give various rewards. Sometimes the rewards can be game winning. Other times they can be a massive disappointment. But you’ll always walk away with some kind of a bonus, like an increase in your stats and Prestige. If the King dies of his Rot, the player with the highest prestige is the winner by default.Armello really requires you to think, and demands a good bit a strategy. The games go by quick so your plans need to come to fruition sooner, rather than later. I find myself planning for the end game on turn one. “I want to win via killing the king”. And adapting my play towards whatever will actively further that goal.It’s a good mix of long term and short term planning at the exact same moment. If you realize that things aren’t going your way, you need to adjust your strategy or risk losing. By the time you realize “things are bad” it’s almost too late. It’s as much about furthering your own ends, as it is interfering with everyone else’s. Because everyone’s position is so precarious, just a small bit of interference is enough to make someone target you the rest of the game… “If I can kill the bear this turn, I’ll lower their prestige enough that when the king dies two turns from now I can win.”  Or even better “Well… If I can’t win, you’re definitely not winning either.”Armello is a very mentally stimulating experience… And I’ve only played with the AI. So I can’t speak for playing with humans. I have to imagine it’s a hundred times better. But, that’s one of the best parts of Armello. The AI is actually very good! Now, once I got really acquainted with the game I was able to out play the AI fairly easily. But they’re still definitely capable of einschrauben mich über, hardcore.And on top of everything else I’ve mentioned here. The game has some seriously great artwork. It has a great storybook style to it that is simultaneously both lighthearted, and very dark.Watching a cute little rat solemnly hand over money to the king’s guards as they terrorize the townsfolk hits way harder than you’d expect. He’s not happy about it… but it has to be done.Armello is awesome. It’s worth every penny. Seriously, support the Devs. If you like strategy, check it out. If you have friends, and want something to play together that doesn’t require a large time investment– Armello’s your game.Buy it. I highly doubt you’ll regret it.If you liked this review, check out 100HourSave.com for more.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												I read some reviews before buying this game that were a bit misleading, so mostly I'm writing this to clear up some misconceptions you may have about this game. (I haven't touched multiplayer yet, so I'll be leaving that out)First off, this game is awesome. Fairly simple, easy to get into, and from what I've seen of the dev's website, continually updated. A single game on the default settings usually take 30-45 minutes to complete. You have the choice of eight different characters to play as and two different maps. You also have the option to equip one ring and one accessory that up different stats from the beginning of a game. You never know what's going to happen in a game, and you may even set out to win in one way, but end up on a different path later on. The card system adds a very deep layer to the gameplay, especially since you can play cards during other players' turns. Maps do seem small, but the way the map is used with quests and different terrains makes it feel a whole lot bigger.If you like turn-based games, get this. If you like card games, get this. If you like RPGs, get this. This game has all that and more for the very reasonable price of $20. Just buy it man, it's awesome.

content:
Posted: February 6
												The base game is a really cool board game, with enough video games and win conditions to feel like it took some inspiration form the Civalization series of games. Although your outcomes will feel incredibly dependant on random chance, there's a ton of fun little stories each time you play. Combat against other players makes you sometimes care less about winning and more about making the guy that killed you twice lose, and that's a really cool experience in this game.Over all, the game feels like its designed to be played with your friends, being able to hang out and talk crap over some VOIP for an hour while using the game as a facilitator to do something. But I also have a huge blast playing against 4 random strangers online and just enjoying the game. The run time can get a little up there, as certain turns may end up taking forever with repeated bad rolls of events, but when those turns are yours they are these wonderful nail-biting heartaches.The only real concern I would have is that there is a little too much focus on cosmetics, having a DLC just being reskins of the board, and recently skins for the characters. However, the game itself doesn't need any of them. Heck, you can get by and enjoy the game without touching the DLC character pack. Its just an opprotunity to send the devs a little more love, which they have easily earned from me!

Overall, I would say this is a fantastic little game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11
												This game is pretty well built for a board game and has a ton of interesting features for gameplay! I love the animations and everything seems pretty streamline. I think there are still a few kinks to work out of course, but overall this is a pretty polisdhed product. Sometimes the game will hiccup, and I noticed multiple sound files would glitch and the right channel would go dead. Other than that, everything ran smooth. This may be due to hardware, but I have a relatively good setup and it should have no issues.The only cons I can say about this game is that it isn't really friendly to new players. The AI can get sort of ruthless, and you can definitely tell the computer has a plan, and will stick to it till you fail. There was a time where I took over a city, and the bear character attacked me three times in a row. It's possible, except for the fact that I destroyed him the first two times, (thanks to the lucky dice rolls, which is another problem I would like to get into) and on the last, the computer had enough and just killed me. As mentioned, this game is mostly chance. The only skill that is required of you is map movement, everything else is chance. Whether it be random♥♥♥♥♥spawning of enemies, or the cursed dice doing their thing. I sort of whish it was something more skill based than chance base. Sure, you can enforce strategies into the game, but they are so built on the chance factor (which often seems to be a 75% lodr 25% win ratio most times) that the strategies often fall apart. TL;DRGreat game, with some minor polishing that needs to be done, and gameplay relies too much on chance.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26
												If you are a board game junky, and like P v P/ P v E, and games like "Risk"; then you're probably an Armello fan and just don't know it. Armello is a turn based, table-top video game. The objective: Become the king of Armello. Armello is currently ruled by a tyrannical king simply known as "The King." He is consumed by "Rot," and no longer acts on the behalf of his fellow country men (animals?). Take control of members of the Bear, Wolf, Rabbit, and Rat clan and seek to overturn his rule. You can win via four paths: Collecting 4 spirit stones and breaching the castle walls to banish the King, gathering so much rot of your own that you can kill the King at his own game (players roll several die to attack and defend, and if you have more rot than an opponent you get their rot number in additional dice), simply retain the King's favour via "prestiege" (Prestiege is earned by completing your own personal quests, claiming burning settlements as your own, and of course killing enemy players. This is where the P v P comes into play full-force), and lastly you can win by simply breaching the kingdom walls and just killing the King the old fashioned way in head-to-head combat.I typed this out and it still doesn't explain the game well enough. The strategy nerd in me can't even convey this properly. Just buy it, man. If you are even thinking about it; do it. Quests, items, badass animal characters, a whole Kingdom to explore, and a fun way to mess with your buddies. You won't know the sensation of breaking an alliance in the very last minute of a game by killing your friend with a spell card and taking their place in the throne room as the new king of Armello. Not if you don't buy it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												This is a digital conversion of a charming board-game. All the busywork has been taken out, allowing casual players to pick up a game for an hour. I normally don't do a lot of multiplayer due to min/max metagamers of nerdy rage; but this game was meant to be played with humans. Just like any game worth its salt, you can learn through loosing and win through experimentation and luck.Once you have the mechanics of the game down, it's time to learn the cards and characters. Then you can formulate your strategy. Some players give a negative review of the game due to "too many attack dice" being used- they just didn't pray hard enough to the RNGod is all. Dice are random, and you have to be able to take your losses if you want to play this game.If your friends never have time to get together in person, this is an activity you can easily fit schedules together with. Plug into Teamspeak, and it's like it's the 1990's again- you know, before the internet when we used to socialize over the tabletop.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												I love the game. It's a table top game with graphic animation. it has a good mix of Strategy, luck and role playing game.Each character is unique and have different play style. the Sana is more magic base and defense. River is balance character with a bit of stealth and magic. etc.Pros- the game is dynamic. every play through is different even if you play the same character. - the game is unpredictable. you might be winning the game in turn 8 but things can go horribly wrong in turn 12.- different ways to win but achieve the different win condition is hard. 90% of the time i usually end up winning prestige. - Beautiful art . the cards are beautiful , the graphics in general is beautifulcons- maticilious , you cannot pass forward the animations . - Need more cards!!! - there are a lot of permutation combination... that's the fun part of the game for me. seeing the different equipment/followers/magic combinations.  - bigger map. if i play Sana sometimes i end up adjacent to all fighter characer.. which pretty much ruin my strategy. I endup working around it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												It is an interesting game and concept. Much much more could be done with the platform and I hope that LoG takes advantage of this more and more, with more quests, more cards, different game modes (maybe with alternate map for coop campaign roleplayey thing?), more house rules, more characters, some sort of faction system to do 2v2, LAN multiplayer (The GoG version has or used to have a 4 digit number for each private room that you had to give to your friends to join and it works on LAN, while the multiplayer of this version is solely through Steam (you need Steam Overlay activated or it is a complete no go). --Here are some things that dont click too well with me or suggestions:-I noticed that the quests are generally the same, you can expect the same three for your first quest and so on. Combat is fine, with some ok armor and weapon any character can be an ok fighter. -But I do have a little bit of an issue with questing being the sole way so far to increase your stats permanently, there is no real benefit to killing banes or heroes other than the rot, prestige or healing bonuses, and there is no real benefit in defeating perils unless you have a bard follower. Also some perils could make use of different stats, facing a band of mercenaries should be "fight" instead of "wits" and dealing with a magical peril should be "spirit" and not "wits". -As a suggestion I think you should have some bonus to fighting infected or corrupted heroes (and banes) if you have collected the necessary spirit stones, you are even glowing magestically, yet corrupted heroes (and banes) are unphased by this (and you can still take rot points like usual).-Also, I would like to be able to start my games with a completely empty hand so I can draw what we would like to start with, seems pretty sensible, but that's just me (get OK gear, then worry about other things).-And finally characters characters characters, the more the better!---As for the praise:-Visuals are amazing, you will not be dissappointed. And the Steam version seems to be well polished, I havent experienced a single crash with it, and there are some minor bugs but they will not impede gameplay (that I have seen so far). -It provides a pretty satisfactory multiplayer experience.-It also appears well optimized, which is a surprise to me nowdays since I run on an outdated system (aka, a pentium 4 with an old 6200GS and DDR1 ram, WinXP SP3 32bit) and it runs surprisingly well. I just hope that this doesnt change with upcomming updates like other games I played *cough* Starbound *cough* sorry.  -Soundtrack is absolutely excellent, you should get it, I should get it, everyone should get it.And that's all. If the game changes enough, I may update this.

content:
Posted: January 14
												Edit: This game breaking glitch has now occured for me 3 times in a row tonight. It's no longer occasional for me, it's damn near every match. TL;DR Unfortunately, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME UNTIL THIS BUG IS FIXED. $20 wasted.It's a great online board game, however, there is one critical game-breaking glitch at this time: If a player leaves the game early, the AI that takes them over can at times fail to do or end their turn. This requires all players quit the current lobby and suffer a loss and a timer pentalty on their next matchmaking game. If it happens several games in a row the queue can be locked.  Additionally, the mechanic when rolling in Perils should get reworked. The roll dice should be a button and not a drag and drop mechanic. Several times I've gone to burn a card, and have had to drag the card over 3-4 times. The timers are short so it's critical it needs to work the first time. Occassionally, when you do this, it will glitch and toss the dice instead. They need to make one or the other (Peril or cards burning) a click button and not a drag/drop mechanic. It doesn't work when they're both so close if you have like 7 cards to play.   Aside from buggy Peril and AI mechanics, the game itself is fun and worth the $20. If the AI glitch happens to you, hit escape and in the top right click the bug icon. You can submit a bug report there. Maybe it will help them patch it faster.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Let be known the review is still for the Early Access release of Armello (who knows what 6 months will change!) - but so far I'm really enjoying it. From the music at character selection to the card animations, there's a lot of aesthetic pleasers in this game. Each game has ran about 40-60 minutes for me so far (single player) and it was a bit of a curve to get familiar with everything (like most board games, though). I really do enjoy almost everything about the game so far. I feel like so far it's been fairly difficult to win, unless by means of prestige. If I find myself behind in prestige about half-way through the game, I almost know that there's no way to catch up and kind of already consider myself having failed which kind of burns my gameplay morale - but besides that! This is an amazing game so far and I can't wait to see what comes out in the full release in 6 months. So excited!

												Let me start by saying i really love the game itself, and have lots of fun playing it. i see why some people would criticize it for iots gameplay but i personally dont mind the random chance(thats board games) and long matches. And i honestly dont even mind putting in paid cosmetic dlc......what i DO mind is the developers pushing paid cosmetic dlc and focusing on in-game charges INSTEAD of putting out more interesting characters. or delivering the ones they ALREADY finished to people to buy yet(the backers on kickstarter got them for free, i get that,ill gladly pay...but why has been MONTHS since they were said to be coming out?).as much fun as it is unless you get it for a CRAZY sale, i wouldnt recommend it until the devs start caring again and focus on improving the game and not on trying to cash in quick with overpriced cosmetics . i understand devs need money too but majorly overpriced cosmetic skins that arent much different than base are NOT the way too do it. Focus on getting GAMEPLAY dlc and gameplay fixes out first, but with each "delay" on the bandit clan and focusing on cosmetics before the game itself make me weary of this games future. ill Leave it "recommended" for now but ill adjust accordingly

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												It is an interesting game and concept. Much much more could be done with the platform and I hope that LoG takes advantage of this more and more, with more quests, more cards, different game modes (maybe with alternate map for coop campaign roleplayey thing?), more house rules, more characters, some sort of faction system to do 2v2, LAN multiplayer (The GoG version has or used to have a 4 digit number for each private room that you had to give to your friends to join and it works on LAN, while the multiplayer of this version is solely through Steam (you need Steam Overlay activated or it is a complete no go). --Here are some things that dont click too well with me or suggestions:-I noticed that the quests are generally the same, you can expect the same three for your first quest and so on. Combat is fine, with some ok armor and weapon any character can be an ok fighter. -But I do have a little bit of an issue with questing being the sole way so far to increase your stats permanently, there is no real benefit to killing banes or heroes other than the rot, prestige or healing bonuses, and there is no real benefit in defeating perils unless you have a bard follower. Also some perils could make use of different stats, facing a band of mercenaries should be "fight" instead of "wits" and dealing with a magical peril should be "spirit" and not "wits". -As a suggestion I think you should have some bonus to fighting infected or corrupted heroes (and banes) if you have collected the necessary spirit stones, you are even glowing magestically, yet corrupted heroes (and banes) are unphased by this (and you can still take rot points like usual).-Also, I would like to be able to start my games with a completely empty hand so I can draw what we would like to start with, seems pretty sensible, but that's just me (get OK gear, then worry about other things).-And finally characters characters characters, the more the better!---As for the praise:-Visuals are amazing, you will not be dissappointed. And the Steam version seems to be well polished, I havent experienced a single crash with it, and there are some minor bugs but they will not impede gameplay (that I have seen so far). -It provides a pretty satisfactory multiplayer experience.-It also appears well optimized, which is a surprise to me nowdays since I run on an outdated system (aka, a pentium 4 with an old 6200GS and DDR1 ram, WinXP SP3 32bit) and it runs surprisingly well. I just hope that this doesnt change with upcomming updates like other games I played *cough* Starbound *cough* sorry.  -Soundtrack is absolutely excellent, you should get it, I should get it, everyone should get it.And that's all. If the game changes enough, I may update this.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												I purchased this game along with the newly released DLC the day it came out together. It totalled around £18.99 (ish)So no, I have not owned the game for long. Despite this, my love for the game has made me create a group for it (http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ArmelloArmada) and I have spent money on the market buying keys / chests. Pros- Multiple win conditions leading to various people taking various routes to win the game- Quest system which creates a story for your character as you progress through the game you are in- Varied clans with diversity in its classes- The game itself looks very good - Possibly my favourite factor is the cards. I am a huge fan of Hearthstone and every card in Armello has an animation which looks gorgeous. They are so good I had to make them as a seperate point from the game looking good- The game itself has good AI compared to other games - Games are just long enough- Easy to play, hard to master- Each tile has a name and the maps are not the same each game- After game loot which allow for more dice in gameCons- No in chat feature outside premade emotes making telling people what you plan on doing eg. in an alliance- Really nitpicking here but no form of campaign other than the prologueOverall 9.5/10Pretty much a must buy

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Short yet fun Board Game for the computer.  That's currently the best way to describe this game right now.  I've played a few times, won a few games, lost a few (even against the a.i. which was a fun suprise, usually the a.i. in games arnt challenging enough).  However the game lacks the long term strategy aspect that most games like it thrive off of and prestige victory seems to be the most viable option for a game lasting only about 20 turns/10 days. the upside to this is it gives you a game where you can sit down and play a game in 40 minutes without worrying about saving.The game is ideal for playing with your friends and for those days where you need something to do for the next 30-45min.Is it worth the price?  So far for me...  $25/6.3hrs of play=$3.96/hr  for me that is worth it as I know that price will drop as I play more.Overall rating- 7.1/10  -  The game has alot to offer at an early stage.  But a game speed option should be added to fit the needs and wants of the average strategy gamer because lets face it, failing all of my quests at 40-60% is just pure bad luck and there's no way to bounce back from wasting 15 turns on failed quests in a 20 turn game.  But thats just how the dice roll sometimes.Yes for anything 7.0 and up thats what i always say.  What's the point if i only enjoyed %50 of the game

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												OKAY.WHEW, where did the time go?So I've got 22 hours of gameplay under my belt at the time of this review and here's what I can say....WOW. This game is wonderful.People talk about luck when it comes to this game. Well, isn't real life a game of luck? We all have to deal with what cards we're dealt in life. And that's what it all comes down to, how smart, how strategic can you be with the cards you are dealt?And can you accept how the die roll? That's LIFE PEOPLE, LIFEEEEE.Anyways, enough life talk, let's talk about the game.This game is not entirely down to luck, you can be smart about what you're given. Sometimes, you really will be cornered. But the thing is, everyone starts each game at square one. No one is OP, (at first) and the game can change in your favor or anyone elses. You can sabotage others and they can sabotage you. To me, that's very fair.The die in this game are not pre animated, they physically roll as they should in real life, and they are completely random because of this. To me that's as fair as it gets.If you're the type of person who cannot accept the fact that sometimes things don't go your way, then this game may not be for you. If you like the thrill of the risk, the fun that can be had by the fact anything could happen at anytime and you just might have the resources to counter anything against you, then this is for you.The graphics are great, the music is great, it's easy to pick up and learn if you just play through the tutorial and try one single player game, you'll have a grasp of the whole thing.This is highly recommended by me, it's incredibly fun, quite tactical and just plain good.As an Early Access game, there are bugs. They don't happen often at all. But there were only 2 instances where 2 of my friends couldn't finish their games. All other times have been good. There's also a terrific built in bug reporting system for these instances as well. So yeah!GET THIS GAME. Sale or not.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												    First of all, I'm just gonna spoil my review of this game RIGHT OFF THE BAT.  This game gets an honest 10/10 from me, it is one of the best games of this year; and it will not be forgotten in my grand book at all.   Secondly, I want the Official board game to this game right now!  Who cares if it's $40.99, I'll buy it.   Thirdly, I think this game is highly under priced; it's worthy of a $30.00 price range on the steam market.   Alright, now that I got that all out of the way, it's time to get on with the actual review.  This is an actual board game on the pc, that's all it is but that's also part of the charm.  This game feels like a more gritty darker sequel to the story of RedWall.  If you are a fan of Redwall, you understand what I'm getting at.  This game has a fantastic card system that adds personal items, spells, tricks and/or treats and companions that can either be implimented to your inventory or played on the map to either other players or locations.  This game's combat is also fantastic, it has a dice rolling sim that you can either roll with on just chance alone, or influence by burning some of your cards you keep on hand.  Despite this game being E+10 rated, it feels more like a mature game that doesn't throw kiddy humor in your face at all; it respects you and it's honest with you, and in return you admire it (kind of builds a relationship between the player and the game itself).  You have a selection of 8 unique characters to choose from that you can play with right off the bat.  There are four different ways to win the game, and all but one of them are valid; I won't spoil the fourth way to win the game.  This game has a beautiful art direction and set of animations in both the 3D world you play in, and the cards you pick up; it heightens the mood and setting you play in.    That's all I really have to say for this game, it's all absolutely solid and I can't seem to find any problems with this game.  I haven't run into any bugs yet, and it seems the devs are constantly updating it to make sure it looks even better than its' original launch state.  I fully support this game, and once again I'm just gonna say, it gets a 10/10 from me.  There is one thing I want to say to the devs right now, just from me personally; I don't speak for the other fans of this game.  PLEASE, make an expansion!  I'll buy it, the other fans might buy it; I'm spreading the word about this game as much as I can.  Thank you

content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												I've never felt compelled to write a postitive review about a game before, however Armello exceeded my expectations for a turn-based strategy game. In essence, Armello appears to be a unique blend between Monopoly and the Heroes of Might and Magic Series. However, Armello trumps both through its multiple win conditions that lead to relatively short, 17 to 20 turn games (from my experience).Armello's focus on both random and non-random events to determine the winner of a game reminds me heavily of how Hearthstone can be played. In certain cases with Hearthstone, an individual card draw may win the game. However, there is always the aspect of deck building and card play order which can provide the stronger influence. Armello's strength by contrast, lies in the building of your hero's stats, equipment and buff usage throughout the game. As a result, Armello avoids the pay to win mentality of Hearthstone.An argument I disagree with is that Armello can be criticised over its choice of unlockable perks for playing the game, which can potentially disadvantage newer players in the multiplayer environment. Firstly, a new player in multiplayer is far more at a disadvantage for lack of knowledge about the game mechanics than anything else. If a person plays a game without a strategy as to how they are going to win, they are very unlikely to do so. Secondly, the unlockable perks can be so minor in their impact, that they will not affect gameplay anywhere near as much as strategy or a good random draw.TLDR: Armello is an excellent cross between Monopoly and Heroes of Might and Magic. The games are relatively short. It's not pay to win like Hearthstone. A good strategy is the most likely way you will win a game.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												Armello is a beutifull, well thought out game. It's a little like dungeons and dragon's, where the randomness factor comes into play during combat and cave exploration. Anyway, the world itself is gorgeous. at the start of the game you can go through a tutorial (which  highly recommend you do) and it will run you through the main characters, and their passive's and perks, e,g, river, from wolf clan, she carries a bow and arrow with her, if YOU attack anything, she will fire her bow and deal 1 damage before attacking, making her an excellent asassin. The end goal of the game depends on how you play, and play as/with. You can win either by, killing the king, and not duying during the combat, waiting for the king to die and (if you were well renound throughout the kingdom) take his place automatically, or you can bring 4 spirit stones to him, cleansing him of his corrupt ways. Thats just the main point's of the game.As soon as i understood how the game mechanics worked, i  was immedietly captured by it.Now this game is good, and kept me busy for a couple of rounds in a row, but after a while, you have to walk away, now thats not a bad thing, EVERY TIME, its a new quest,journey,story and experience, you can and probably will come back to it over and over again, the fact that you can come so close to winning and to lose it all in  an instant, is just great, for once it feels good to NEARLY win, still getting xp for that clan and for your self, it's just great.anyway,ill leave it here, yes without a doubt, recommend this game, no faults with it, it's in good committed hands ( i think) and i hope more branches of this game. love it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												I purchased this game along with the newly released DLC the day it came out together. It totalled around £18.99 (ish)So no, I have not owned the game for long. Despite this, my love for the game has made me create a group for it (http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ArmelloArmada) and I have spent money on the market buying keys / chests. Pros- Multiple win conditions leading to various people taking various routes to win the game- Quest system which creates a story for your character as you progress through the game you are in- Varied clans with diversity in its classes- The game itself looks very good - Possibly my favourite factor is the cards. I am a huge fan of Hearthstone and every card in Armello has an animation which looks gorgeous. They are so good I had to make them as a seperate point from the game looking good- The game itself has good AI compared to other games - Games are just long enough- Easy to play, hard to master- Each tile has a name and the maps are not the same each game- After game loot which allow for more dice in gameCons- No in chat feature outside premade emotes making telling people what you plan on doing eg. in an alliance- Really nitpicking here but no form of campaign other than the prologueOverall 9.5/10Pretty much a must buy

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Short yet fun Board Game for the computer.  That's currently the best way to describe this game right now.  I've played a few times, won a few games, lost a few (even against the a.i. which was a fun suprise, usually the a.i. in games arnt challenging enough).  However the game lacks the long term strategy aspect that most games like it thrive off of and prestige victory seems to be the most viable option for a game lasting only about 20 turns/10 days. the upside to this is it gives you a game where you can sit down and play a game in 40 minutes without worrying about saving.The game is ideal for playing with your friends and for those days where you need something to do for the next 30-45min.Is it worth the price?  So far for me...  $25/6.3hrs of play=$3.96/hr  for me that is worth it as I know that price will drop as I play more.Overall rating- 7.1/10  -  The game has alot to offer at an early stage.  But a game speed option should be added to fit the needs and wants of the average strategy gamer because lets face it, failing all of my quests at 40-60% is just pure bad luck and there's no way to bounce back from wasting 15 turns on failed quests in a 20 turn game.  But thats just how the dice roll sometimes.Yes for anything 7.0 and up thats what i always say.  What's the point if i only enjoyed %50 of the game

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												The artwork is beautiful, the gameplay is easy to learn (but not easy to master by any stretch of the imagination) and the dice mechanic is more fun than just rolling regular numbers.4 different ways to win: Collect 4 Spirit Stones, kill the King, kill the king while your Rot is higher than his, or have the highest prestige.8 characters: Two rats (a manipulator and an assassin), two rabbits (a tinker and explorer), two bears (a warrior and a druid) and two wolves (one melee, one ranged) with multiple playstyles depending on which amulets you pick at the start of the game.The only downside is no chat function other than the preprogrammed phrases. Not going to be either, according to the devs (they don't want to have to moderate, etc). It's also a -little- slow paced, but that's good if you like a relaxing strategy game for a couple of hours a game.

												This is a very polished indie game that has a lot of potential to go further. It plays very much like a board game. The game, to me, draws much inspiriation from the board game Small World with different victory conditions almost like a Civ game. There is a lot of charming character to the presentation of the game, the music and art direction are fantastic and the game mechanics are fun and polished. The balancing is pretty solid too, the only real criticism is that the game can tend to favour a Prestiege victory over many other types and defending is much harder than attacking.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Excellent board/strategy game set on a deeply involving fantasy setting. This ain't your grandma's fairyland. While not as dark as an original Grimm, it's also definitely not olden Disney fare. If anything, the universe is a western take on the Miyasaki universe... But i digress; what truly matters here is that every detail was clearly painstakingly crafted to be as fresh and fun on your 50th game as it was on your first. The learning curve isn't too bad, and the tutorial competent. And every charscter that you play as, or every new card you discover offer a new flavor to the formula... Beautiful animation, 2D and 3D alike are complemented by a top notch score. Superbly realized, and lots of hours of fun.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												I've played 5 or 6 games and have won against the AI twice, each in a different way.  To me, a casual gamer, that's a decent but not imposing learning curve and yields a nice reward.  Also, I like the variety of the 8 (at this time) characters, so I can test my skills with different strategies.  A game on a reasonably swift computer takes about an hour, which is awesome for someone who can't spend all night gaming.  My first game or two were on my laptop, which had either not enough RAM or a poor video card (likely both) and a game took me 3 hours and I couldn't burn cards in battles, since the computer lagged.  So, play on a decent PC! Really enjoying the game and if I want something more challenging, I know multiplayer is lurking, waiting with practiced players and longer game time.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												What a gem!With a fantastic art style and gorgeous visuals, Armello is a simple to learn, tricky to master and consistently challenging.With a number of different routes to victory, this is a game that rewards agile tactics that can respond to ever changing conditions. Indeed, succesful players are going to be those who are able to think on their feet rather than those attempting to execute a long term strategy.The map is small, yet difficult to cross, with numerous obstacles and choke points barring the way. Players can win this game "on the board" by holding strategic positions, through playing cards that provide various spells, buff/debuffs, by setting traps to disrupt other players, or by defeating the corrupt King of Armello. Players can achieve political victory by accumulating prestige, military victory by defeating the king, magical victory by destroying the rot infesting the land and inflicting the king, or by becoming rotten themselves. A number of resources and skills are available to the player including gold, wit, magic, prestige and rot, and all provide advantages or can be spent in battle or in general play.Combat is conducted via die roll where players attempt to gain an advantage by equiping various items, and by becoming more experienced and applying various spell to themselves and their enemies. Terrain and the use thereof can also provide significant in combat, be it through stealth or defensive bonuses for fortifying oneself in mountains or settlements.Games take about an hour to complete, and each will provide a new challenge. This is a genuinely innovative game that all lovers of board games should support. Definitely worth a purchase at full price, and a no brainer while on sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												Armello's is a digital board game whose theme is a cocktail of DarkSouls and Game of Thrones, all of it presented with a gorgeous artstyle. Although not especially deep at the moment, it's fun and hasgreat potential for future patches.---Pros: * Art - The art style in this game is absolutely beautiful. The cardsare lovely with their subtle animations and the 2D character art lendsthe heroes a lot of personality. Sound effects and music areappropriate and lovely. I'm looking forward to the DLC at least asmuch for new art and cinematics as I am for new mechanical content. * Fun and Balance - Hard to quantify rigorously, but the game feelsfun - it rewards being thoughtful without demanding that every actionis supremely calculated. Characters feel pretty well balanced giventhe recent release, although not perfectly so. Mechanics likecorruption and the special abilities of followers mean that a singlecard can be applied in different, interesting ways.Cons: * Arbitrary - Serious board game fans should realize that Armello hasa fair amount of luck involved: Drawing the right cards is importantand the outcome of almost all conflicts is dice based (although youmay burn cards to reduce the factor of luck here). However the realelement of luck is in the placement of random events, quests, andperils around the map. You may lose a game due to an unluckypositioning of an early quest or win one because of a timely spiritstone spawn. To win, the rewards from the 'risky' option of quests arevery important, but you'll often have about a 40%-60% chance to failthese, taking an expensive penalty instead. This is particularlynoticeable when two players are both close to victory and thedetermination may hinge on one being a single turn ahead or having alucky/unlucky teleport. It's all fine for a video game, but playersexpecting a more rigorous experience like mageknight or agricola maybe frustrated. * UX Issues - The game permits you to play effects during anopponent's turn, but doesn't offer a good way to pause or an interruptsystem like Magic's. The result is an imperfect blend of real-time andturn-based feels that is jarring at times.  I also experienced are someminor issues in the game such as UI elements disappearing or the soundfailing during certain effects. None of it threatened stability, however.---As for a sense of how the game plays, you spend your turns travelling around the map, preparing yourself through items and quest rewards to face the King, while trying to prevent the other players from doing the same. Usually there are several objectives you could pursue at once (is it worth taking an extra turn to reach my quest if I explore a dungeon first? What about one less turn if I take damage by going through a swamp?) to keep the mind sufficiently tickled. The game has a stronger emphasis on inter-player conflict than board games like Dominion so many of these decisions may involve whether to spend resources pulling yourself up or pushing someone else down.Time factors into all of this. There are a very limited number of turns before the King dies. This introduces conflict between the players pursuing different victory conditions: As the King grows physically weaker over time, a player planning the regicide victory may wish to wait till late to face an easier battle. But if they wait too long and the King dies 'naturally' from his advancing corruption, the current prestige leader will win a diplomatic victory as heir.Overall if you want a beautiful, clever game and don't mind a bit of bad luck, you'll probably like Armello. If nothing else, your eyes will thank you.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												Beautiful and engaging pc boardgame experience. Best played with friends (since the AI lacks that edge and ability to cooperate which makes the game that much more entertaining). Armello was originally prototyped as a physical game, and that feel carries through into the digital version, from the dice physics to the card decks, without requiring the mental chore to keep track of all the math / board counters / other variables that would bog things down in real life.Each space on the board has different terrain and variables -- towns give gold when claimed, forests give stealth in the cover of night, druid circles heal anyone who enters, and dungeons have the option of offering treasures or waking monsters. Players are given quests to travel across the kingdom and commit deeds of heroism that strengthen them for their eventual confrontation with the mad king at the center of the board. Equipment cards affect the number and types of dice you have to roll when facing tests and combats, and there are various spells, items, and traps that can be played to  terrain and/or players that can help or hinder them. Combat and perils are challenged with dice rolls -- you gain dice by equipping items and using spells to tip the odds in your favor.There are currently 8 different characters (with more planned), each with different skills to complement different playstyles, from magic-using tank to sneaky hit-and-run thief, to item-hoarding situational card-swapper. The flow of each game requires players to be able to adjust their strategies for victory or be left at the mercy of more ambitious opponents. Either challenge the king directly or work to sabotage the plans of others and grab a win through trickery and amassing personal prestige. Literally stack your dice with clever use of your cards and abilities, and make a grab for Armello's throne before someone else does.If you are a fan of tabletop and card games, then Armello is definitely worth a try. :)Cons: No auto-reconnect if a player acidentally disconnects, no ingame chat (voicechat improves the boardgame experience feel, imo)

content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												Having followed Armello from the Kickstarter campaign, I can say wholeheartedly that the final product is something that the crew at League of Geeks should be incredibly proud of. Armello is a unique and fantastically executed blend of RPG, tabletop game, card game, and turn-based-strategy. The world and characters are brought to life by the sublime art and sound team, and Armello is brimming with character. Gameplay is easy to pick up, but has enough nuances and options to keep players hooked and learning more and more each match. Matches tend to take an hour to complete roughly, but in Single Player the autosave function guarantees you can drop out and back into the action at any time. If you're even remotely curious or interested in this game, I'd certainly recommend you purchase it!

content:
Posted: April 3
Armello is like that place you've always wanted to visit, because you somehow know that once you're finally there it will feel like home - it will fill a medieval bear sized void in your heart.Before I bought this game I was sceptical for various reasons. I've read most of the reviews on Steam and elsewhere, but  even though it's praised for the incredible visuals (obviously), little is said about the actual gameplay - specifically after the early access release. Also, some of the reviews make it seem like the gameplay is only enjoyable when playing multiplayer.Having now spent the best part of a Sunday playing single player mode I really feel happy about the game. The single player experience is great.The only real story time in the game is a brief tutorial (acting as a prologue) that introduces you to the 4 main characters and the surprisingly easy gameplay mechanics. You *will* find yourself wishing for more, and that's okay, but this is where Armello stays true to being a digital boardgame - you have to make your own story. Brutal deathThe first time a little critter died I was pretty shocked, but then it respawned and all was well with the world. Needless to say you get used to dying... a lot.Again, this game is bloody gorgeousApart from the awesome cut scenes (that's no doubt the thing that caught your attention in the first place), there are over 100 collectable item | spell | trickery cards that are beautifully animated. As you play the game over and over again you discover more and more cards and it becomes quite a challenge to find new ones.LoreThis is a world akin to Brian Jacques' Redwall. It has also been compared to Game of Thrones for some reason... it's probably all the dying and the creepy king. But really this is something quite unique. The collectible cards mentioned before really help to flesh out the world of Armello.According to the developer forum they are planning and actively working on content for the game, like a Bandit Clan DLC that will introduce a new clan of 4 heroes and more story missions - Scheduled to release Q2 2017.http://leagueofgeeks.com/forums/index.php?topic=3037.msg20613#msg20613ConclusionBuy the game. Be patient. Enjoy the small things.This is the beginning of an epic story, one that would be better left to unravel at it's own pace.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Updated Aug. 7th, 2015 Review Additions:Over the past few months, I can honestly say this game has made leaps and bounds from where I hopped on. The community continues to grow, the game continues to get better, and I can only imagine what amazing things are in store from its actual release and onward.LoG and the rest of the Armello community are some of the best people I've gotten to know, and every dime spent on this project was well used. I can say with a surety that this game is well worth your money, and that this game is ten-times as good as it was in its Early EA.If you're still unsure about whether or not this game will interest you, I suggest keeping an eye on LoG's twitch channel, and watching the weekly community vs devs games (they're a hoot!).~~~Edited Original Review:So, even after my first match with AI, I can wholeheartedly recommend this game. The TLC that LoG constantly states they've given this game is quite evident, even from the main menu and first few turns. Literally everything in this game works together to create quite a triumphant and easily enjoyed experience that does not disappoint. The art work, fabulous. The music, fantastic. The gameplay, classic, yet new.Performance:I have helped LoG (and continue to help them) squash as many bugs as possible, and I can honestly say that they are rather fast and efficient at getting rid of game bugs. Thankfully this game runs rather well on my lower-mid level laptop. Not to mention that it has a rather low space footprint for a game of this kind.Aesthetics:This game is very pleasing to look at and to listen to. If you don't believe me, you obviously haven't watched the trailers. The trailers alone send shivers down the spine, and leave a considerable amount of chilling goosebumps upon one's person. I sincerely hope that the OST will at some point be available, because it would be an easy buy, even if you don't play the game, for the music, too, plays an integral part in sweeping you away to the magical land that is Armello.Gameplay:Armello is designed to play a lot like a table-top RPG/Card/Board game. Each of the 4 base characters have initial stats and a unique ability, and receive bonuses based on a ring and amulet of the player's choosing. The characters play a large part in how the outcome of the game can be achieved by catering to different playstyles, making the character choice a rather important one - though, not necessarily game-defining. While one can achieve different types of victories with the same character, some conditions are easier met by certain characters.Each turn can easily be a game changer, as players are constantly in a close struggle to gain prestige, gold, magic, or treasure all necessary things to taking the throne, the ultimate objective of the match. There is seldom a point in the game where one can relax, because someone else is almost always on your heels in terms of strength, or physical/magical gains.Experience:This game is rather easy to jump into and enjoy, however, it is highly recommended to look into the game guide here on Steam. Even with its current, early mechanics, this game is easily replayable. Each match and turn is able to bring quite a different experience, and only gets better in a game against other humans. The characters and other pre-match choices can make a large difference based on who's playing who, so the strategizing happens from the get-go.I chose to buy in because this game interested me, and I know that being an Indie Dev is far from easy, and every dollar counts. However, I do again, sincerely hope that this first project doesn't leave a bad taste in the gaming community's mouth because of a mistake made in their infancy (the KickStarter incident, which as since been cleared up!).Pseudo TL;DR -This game is a rather specific purchase...If this is a game you're looking for, I can personally recommend it.For those of you sitting on the fence: Trust me, this game is well worth it, and the community is truthfully one of a kind.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												Edit: If you want to see the game in action, I strongly suggest you check out the League of Geeks Twitch channel[www.twitch.tv] Sundays at 6:00pm Pacific time for their weekly Devs vs. Community game. It's a good time and a great place to ask any questions you might have and actually get them answered.Since I bought it back in November, Armello has become one of my all-time favorite multiplayer games (still narrowly beat out by Timesplitters, but what can you do?).Each match is a 4-player free-for-all power grab to rule the land. There are multiple ways to accomplish this: Combat: Break into the Palace and kill the King in single combat.Prestige: Having the most renown when the King dies naturally (he loses 1 health every other turn) or if another players kills him, but dies themselves in the attampt.Spirit Stones Collecting 4 spirit stones that may be found in dungeons, rewarded from quests, or randomly spawned on the map then breaking into the Palace and use them to banish the corruption from the king (which, conveniently, also kills him).Rot: The corrupting force in the game that has infected the king and spurred the heroes into action against him. Though it very difficult to pull off, a player can achieve a higher Rot value than the King and then Break into the Palace and kill the King in combat. This is very similar to a Combat Victory, but when 2 opponents both have Rot, the one with the higher count gains the lower's count as bonus dice. Against the King (who is for the most part a stronger combatant than any of the heroes), this is both a great advantage and hinderance (You roll more dice but for every die you roll that doesn't get matched to attack or defence goes to the King to roll against you). Basically, pulling off a Rot Victory is mostly for bragging rights.My favorite part of this game has to be that, even if the whole game is going against you, the other players attack you, banes attack you, your card draw is terrible, etc. etc. etc, it is still possible to sometimes go for the last-ditch-effort break into the palace and attack the king. At worst, you'll die killing him and give the game to the Prestige leader (or just die, granting the king 1 more health and extending the game for 2 more turns), but there's always the chance that you can kill him and win, turning around a game that had been going against you the whole time, and snatching victory for yourself. These are the wins that are always the most memorable because steamrolling your opponents is only fun so many times. The best victories are a struggle.After every (online/non-private) match, you are given a chance at either a key or chest that, once you have one of both, you can use to unlock new dice skins. Winning has no apparent effect on the drop rates, though keys do seems to be somewhat less common than chests (despite which one you get being represented by a coin flip). The keys, chests, and skins can all be traded/sold on the Steam marketplace.The biggest (non bug related) complaint I have is that, since the map is randomized for every match, sometimes you just get completely screwed on the placements of settlements, dungeons, mountains and swamps (either for too much or not enough of any of them near your spawn grounds).The biggest bug related problem is that sometimes, when a player disconnects, the whole match will feeze and everyone will be forced to quit out, negating the end-of-the-match reward. This seems to be more likely if it happens while someone is in combat, and is definitely the biggest bug/glitch problem the game has.One other point of irritation is, since you can sell the rewards from the end of a match, I occassionally run into bots/scummers that pass every turn (some contend that it is almost literally every match, but I think they're just especially bitter people in general). The especially awful ones spam the emotes constantly. Having one less player usually makes the game significantly less interesting and fun. Furtunately, you can report these wastes of air through the in-game bug report feature.At first it might seem like everything's random so you're success or failure is based solely on RNG, but as a long time player of XCOM (new and original), your success or failure is based more on how you operate with the options you're given, rather than the options themselves.TL;DR: If you think games that rely on RNG don't take any skill, go ahead and skip this one. You'll only wind up bitter.

Thankfully this game runs rather well on my lower-mid level laptop. Not to mention that it has a rather low space footprint for a game of this kind.Aesthetics:This game is very pleasing to look at and to listen to. If you don't believe me, you obviously haven't watched the trailers. The trailers alone send shivers down the spine, and leave a considerable amount of chilling goosebumps upon one's person. I sincerely hope that the OST will at some point be available, because it would be an easy buy, even if you don't play the game, for the music, too, plays an integral part in sweeping you away to the magical land that is Armello.Gameplay:Armello is designed to play a lot like a table-top RPG/Card/Board game. Each of the 4 base characters have initial stats and a unique ability, and receive bonuses based on a ring and amulet of the player's choosing. The characters play a large part in how the outcome of the game can be achieved by catering to different playstyles, making the character choice a rather important one - though, not necessarily game-defining. While one can achieve different types of victories with the same character, some conditions are easier met by certain characters.Each turn can easily be a game changer, as players are constantly in a close struggle to gain prestige, gold, magic, or treasure all necessary things to taking the throne, the ultimate objective of the match. There is seldom a point in the game where one can relax, because someone else is almost always on your heels in terms of strength, or physical/magical gains.Experience:This game is rather easy to jump into and enjoy, however, it is highly recommended to look into the game guide here on Steam. Even with its current, early mechanics, this game is easily replayable. Each match and turn is able to bring quite a different experience, and only gets better in a game against other humans. The characters and other pre-match choices can make a large difference based on who's playing who, so the strategizing happens from the get-go.I chose to buy in because this game interested me, and I know that being an Indie Dev is far from easy, and every dollar counts. However, I do again, sincerely hope that this first project doesn't leave a bad taste in the gaming community's mouth because of a mistake made in their infancy (the KickStarter incident, which as since been cleared up!).Pseudo TL;DR -This game is a rather specific purchase...If this is a game you're looking for, I can personally recommend it.For those of you sitting on the fence: Trust me, this game is well worth it, and the community is truthfully one of a kind.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												Edit: If you want to see the game in action, I strongly suggest you check out the League of Geeks Twitch channel[www.twitch.tv] Sundays at 6:00pm Pacific time for their weekly Devs vs. Community game. It's a good time and a great place to ask any questions you might have and actually get them answered.Since I bought it back in November, Armello has become one of my all-time favorite multiplayer games (still narrowly beat out by Timesplitters, but what can you do?).Each match is a 4-player free-for-all power grab to rule the land. There are multiple ways to accomplish this: Combat: Break into the Palace and kill the King in single combat.Prestige: Having the most renown when the King dies naturally (he loses 1 health every other turn) or if another players kills him, but dies themselves in the attampt.Spirit Stones Collecting 4 spirit stones that may be found in dungeons, rewarded from quests, or randomly spawned on the map then breaking into the Palace and use them to banish the corruption from the king (which, conveniently, also kills him).Rot: The corrupting force in the game that has infected the king and spurred the heroes into action against him. Though it very difficult to pull off, a player can achieve a higher Rot value than the King and then Break into the Palace and kill the King in combat. This is very similar to a Combat Victory, but when 2 opponents both have Rot, the one with the higher count gains the lower's count as bonus dice. Against the King (who is for the most part a stronger combatant than any of the heroes), this is both a great advantage and hinderance (You roll more dice but for every die you roll that doesn't get matched to attack or defence goes to the King to roll against you). Basically, pulling off a Rot Victory is mostly for bragging rights.My favorite part of this game has to be that, even if the whole game is going against you, the other players attack you, banes attack you, your card draw is terrible, etc. etc. etc, it is still possible to sometimes go for the last-ditch-effort break into the palace and attack the king. At worst, you'll die killing him and give the game to the Prestige leader (or just die, granting the king 1 more health and extending the game for 2 more turns), but there's always the chance that you can kill him and win, turning around a game that had been going against you the whole time, and snatching victory for yourself. These are the wins that are always the most memorable because steamrolling your opponents is only fun so many times. The best victories are a struggle.After every (online/non-private) match, you are given a chance at either a key or chest that, once you have one of both, you can use to unlock new dice skins. Winning has no apparent effect on the drop rates, though keys do seems to be somewhat less common than chests (despite which one you get being represented by a coin flip). The keys, chests, and skins can all be traded/sold on the Steam marketplace.The biggest (non bug related) complaint I have is that, since the map is randomized for every match, sometimes you just get completely screwed on the placements of settlements, dungeons, mountains and swamps (either for too much or not enough of any of them near your spawn grounds).The biggest bug related problem is that sometimes, when a player disconnects, the whole match will feeze and everyone will be forced to quit out, negating the end-of-the-match reward. This seems to be more likely if it happens while someone is in combat, and is definitely the biggest bug/glitch problem the game has.One other point of irritation is, since you can sell the rewards from the end of a match, I occassionally run into bots/scummers that pass every turn (some contend that it is almost literally every match, but I think they're just especially bitter people in general). The especially awful ones spam the emotes constantly. Having one less player usually makes the game significantly less interesting and fun. Furtunately, you can report these wastes of air through the in-game bug report feature.At first it might seem like everything's random so you're success or failure is based solely on RNG, but as a long time player of XCOM (new and original), your success or failure is based more on how you operate with the options you're given, rather than the options themselves.TL;DR: If you think games that rely on RNG don't take any skill, go ahead and skip this one. You'll only wind up bitter.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18
												I love Armello, I really do love it, both the gameplay and mechanics it has to offer and the characters's designs with their unique abilities. The skins are a good implementation (though I haven't gotten any of the character things, and I'll explain why later) and the random events that form part of your adventure's development are one of the things I love the most from this game.I like that you can wear different types of rings and amulets at the start to have a bit of your own customization, and that you can act with 3 types of decks, get followers that aid you, etc.The music is nothing too original or anything like that, but it's not annoying and it fits well regardless.I like that you can have multiple ways of winning a match, some more risky than others, but all of them are interesting to try if you like finding your own way to victory through different paths.I can say that this game is worth buying and playing, if a friend is recommending this to you so you can play with him/her, do it. Hell, if you have more than 3 or 4 friends who have this game and who would like to play it with you, then buy it. This game is great when it comes to multiplayers.Now, since this is a game meant for multiplayer, here are some flaws that you HAVE to consider if you really want this game:-First, sometimes people will ragequit and MAY make you or another player be stuck where they are, forcing all of you to leave the game, this can anger some people but it's not something that will happen 100% of the times, since when someone disconects, they are replaced by an AI. (I personally haven't found this too bad of a flaw and it just happens like 5% of all the matches I've had)-The game rewards you for playing online, giving you keys or chests at the end of a match, this is a great concept that unfortunately is affected by the first flaw, so I wanted to mention that this bug will mean that the match will be stuck and that no one will earn the rewards that you use to get skins, this can be bad but as I said before, don't think it's something that is going to happen that often.Now... this is my biggesst complain, I was really thinking on relunctanctly not recommending this game, that's how bad it is but it's not really the game's fault:-This game has a growing community, meaning that most of the time there's going to be around 190 people playing and you will most likely not find anyone joining, like I do. I really want to play this game, but during this month all the times I've tried playing online have resulted in me not finding absolutely anybody. Maybe this game has region blocking or something and that's why it's harder for me to find people (that's my guess at least), but I really CAN'T FIND ANYBODY ONLINE, meaning that I can't play the most enjoyable thing about this game anymore cuz I can't find people online that easily.I used to just click to play online and I wouldn't wait too much before entering a match, now it looks 97% impossible to find someone, in fact, after looking for people for the 9th time I've opened this game, NOW I just found someone online, JUST ONE person... they left 10 seconds later... ♥♥♥♥ you if you are that person, by the way.I do recommend this game cuz it's fun to play with friends, wich is why I said before that if you got people who play it or who would like to play it with you, thn it's worth buying, the more people you got that play armello the better the possibilities you'll enjoy this game, but if you have no friends who play this game then MAYBE you'll have a harder time getting to find people online.However, if you get this game, you do help the community to keep growing and in time it'll be easier to find people online to play with, THAT was the only reason I changed my mind from not recommending to recommending this game.So yeah, with nothing else to say, buy it so this game keeps growing and specially if you got friends who have this, it's a great game but the lack of people keeps it from being one of my favourite games.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												A turn-based digital board game set in a disney's Robin Hood like world where anphropomorphic animals rule the land. Whether playing single player or multiplayer; the game consists of 4 heroes vying for the future of the throne. The game is easy to learn but difficult to master. The board is randomly generated (except starting points and the palace) with each terrain having a different effect on the game and your hero. Settlements generate gold, mountains require double the movement, swamps cost health to traverse, forests provide stealth at night, stone circles heal the uncorrupted and dungeons can help or hinder you. Time is limited by the king's decaying health and turns alternate between dawn and dusk each providing different benefits.Not finished, work in progress.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
												This is a pretty fun game. The problems that have stopped me from playing are the lobby times to play with other people, and the way to rot victory is painfully difficult. In order to get corrupted you more or less have to hope you die to banes to increase your rot because getting cards that give you rot are few and very far between. I think they need to add more rot cards into the decks. 9 times out of 10 the win condition is either kingslayer or prestige and it takes away from the game when there is so little chance for other paths to be taken. This includes spirit stone victories as well, but I can understand how that condition is a little more random.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												For all of it's flaws, Armello is a game that overflows with character. The animations of the various cards make every card feel unique and adds to the flair of playing the cards. The designs of the characters all look great, and the colorful atmosphere and antropomorphic chracters initally make this seem like a high fantasy setting. However, the cards, quest descriptions, and general point of the game all hammer home that for all the color and style, this is basiclly Game of Thrones meets Redwall, minus the sex and with lots more evil. You can even give into the dark side, known as the Rot, and win by killing the King while being even more evil then said insane king.9/10, would become a dark lord bear again

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								EARLY ACCESS REVIEW: In an attempt to summarize, I will try to keep this short. I've put about 4 hours into the game thus far into this early access title and overall, I've enjoyed it. The game has a great card game/board game hybrid feel to it and there are some distinct "Game of Thrones" vibes to the game that I really enjoy. That being said, I do feel after a few hours that the game is slightly repetitive at this early access stage and sometimes I find the AI to just generally not be the brightest. Do not misundertstand, this game feels very polished- particularly for a title in "Early Access", but it does not yet feel complete at this stage. I think there is a really great game buried here, but I don't believe it's reached that point yet. I hope League of Geeks will continue to flesh out the game and push this game farther along. They could have a really great game on their hands with some additional content and mechanic tweaking. IN SUMMARY: Despite some flaws and repetition, I would still recommend this game as a "Buy" as I'm confident the final product will be very solid and you can definitely have some fun with the game "as-is". I will follow-up on this review as the game continues to develop.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												Just played a few games and I love it to bits. Yes there's a few niggles graphically (The -massive- DoF effect when zooming out is somewhat irksome, and sometimes clouds literally block my vision when zoomed in) but besides that, the presentation is great, the art style inspiring, and to be frank it reminds me a lot of Redwall. Which is a good thing.It's basically Talisman, except your movement isn't restricted by dice and the world is drop dead beautiful, and there's more than one way to win. The overall 'rules' are relatively simple and easy to grasp, but there's enough tactical depth to keep things interesting.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												Being an avid board game and video game player I was excited to try out Armello. The first thing you will discover when playing the game is that the designers put a lot of work into creating the game. The artwork is fantastic and the game does a great job building an interesting environment. While Armello does take some time to adjust to, the gameplay is quite interesting and provides for plenty of opportunities for strategy. With four different paths to victory no two games will ever be the same. Armello does a great job combining elements of RPGs, card games, and other tabletop mechanics. While my playtime is currently kind of low, Armello is not the type of game where I would play multiple games in a row but it is the type of game that I plan on playing every so often. If the concept behind the game interests you and you like board games in addition to video games, I think you will really enjoy Armello.Note: I received a free review copy of Armello. Other than the review copy I received no other compensation for this review and receiving the review copy had no impact on the content of this review. Read My Full Review [www.geekyhobbies.com]

content:
Posted: May 27, 2016
“There is a savage beast in every man, and when you hand that man a sword or spear and send him forth to war, the beast stirs.” ― George R.R. Martin, A Storm of Swords This beautifully created world of beasts and other furry creatures has stollen my heart. It’s a well thought out casual, yet challenging game of strategy, luck and gentle humor. That is, when you enter the game with an understanding of what you’re about to embark on in this quest of art and mind. When stresses of life and the insanity of other games I enjoy tend to wear me thin, this is the game I always run back to with my arms wide open. The visuals are soothing. The gameplay is perfect for someone that just wants to relax after a long stressful day of getting scolded from their bosses or hearing the screaming of impatient children. Grab a glass of your beverage of choice, make those nachos you have been craving all week and sit down and enjoy the bliss and relaxation as you laugh along with others when you are riddled with bad luck or good fortune. The series of set phrases that you will have in this game, used to communicate with others in multiplayer, bring a special roleplaying aspect that makes it very hard to get angry. (That is, unless you’re just angry by trait) Having a sense of humor will take you a long way; here in this game and in life. I encourage everyone to pick this game up for themselves, friends or their kids (Great for all ages because the chat between everyone is talentedly limited) and have a great adventure of mind and visuals. Armello is one of the best relaxed yet, challenging turn-based strategy board like games I’ve come across. And, oh! I am so glad I did.
