number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												My first complaint would be the lack of communication that the game lets you have with your fellow players. You have a small set of pre-written messages that you can say, but that's it. For a strategy game, that makes it very limited.My next complaint would be the lack of replayability the game offers. There is only one map size and shape, and the only thing that changes are the different biomes/tiles, which there aren't very many of the start with. Once you play 10-15 games in it, it'll get old, and you will see every move your opponents make coming. It gets rather boring after awhile.Another thing that gets a bit old is the unbalanced nature of many items and clans/characters. There are a few very powerful characters that everybody rushes to at the start of the game, and the player(s) that get it(them) have a large advantage. In addition, if you get unlucky and roll a bunch of♥♥♥♥♥♥items/spells, you can kiss that victory goodbye. Or the other way around, if you get some top-grade gear, the game is pretty much over, unless someone else can manage to get it aswell. Which is very unlikely to begin with.Last but surely not least, the small size of the map and pure chance of most events happening can lead to players getting ahold of very powerful equipment that makes them unbeatable to the other players. This in itself is not bad, but since the players in this game seem keen on holding grudges for the smallest of things, "Capture The Throne" can turn into "Free For All Deathmatch" very quickly, the objective of the game lost. And as mentioned before, since the map is quite small, a stronger player could simply spawnkill another player they happen to not like. Refer back to the previous point about unbalanced items and characters.The game was fun for a little bit. I really tried to like it, I did, but I can't.EDIT: Upon the continued playing of the game, I've found that this experience wasn't just a fluke. Quite a few times now, especially at the beginning of battles in multiplayer, the game just stops working. You have no choice but to sit there for hours and wait for the game to do nothing, or to leave, which you are punished for. I have high speed internet and this never happens with any of my other games, so it is not on my side.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Originally posted at: http://caffeinecrew.com/2015/06/10/loading-not-yet-ready-armello/The King of the land lets out a mighty roar and decrees that this morning all of the land’s Heroes must pay taxes worth of 2 gold. I cringe and hand over my money—I braved the depths of the local dungeon and potential face-off with a Bane to obtain it. There are but a few days left of the King’s life, and I’m incredibly close to obtaining the means to cure him and save the land from devastation. I am now forced to decide between trying to cure him (which may be impossible in the allotted remaining time), or attempt another approach.This is but one playthrough of League Of Geeks’s first title, Armello—a high fantasy digital board game. Currently in Early Access, Armello sports a unique design centered around 4 players (Human or AI controlled) attempting to either overturn the beleaguered King, or to save him against a mysterious plague known as The Rot. Armello also maintains a somewhat procedural design, in which map tiles are randomly placed each game in order to create unique playthroughs each time. It’s with this design in mind that it makes sense the Armello game board is so small, but at the same time it often feels a bit too cramped.Armello’s 54 tiled design makes for fast paced sessions, coupled with the ability to move up to 3 spaces per turn (or 2 if you intend to cross a mountain), accessing a lot of the board’s missions and special objectives seems quite easy. Or so I initially thought. Attempting any of Armello’s 3 possible game endings means staying heavily focused on a series of gameplay elements at all times and more often than not (unless you get insanely lucky), you will find yourself abandoning your current ending goal for the most common: Prestige (more on that later). But at the same time you will likely be bumping into one of the other 3 Heroes, the King’s Guard, or the terrifying Banes. Sometimes this can get in the way of gameplay and feels somewhat oppressive, albeit understandable.Personally I would love to see larger board sizes incorporated into later builds of Armello so I can further customize the experience for longer and more in-depth sessions. This, however, leads into Armello’s fairly short session time thanks to each playthrough lasting a maximum of 18 rounds (9 Day/9Night turns). Not having an option for more turns really puts the squeeze on the game’s potential win outcomes. Rounds are managed by the King’s health, which drops by 1 after every Night turn passes (1 day/1 night). Day turns are the safer of the two as Banes deal far less damage and appear less frequently, while night-time makes them stronger, and occasionally spawn from dungeons. Some Heroes, such as Thane, gain benefits at night like an extra attack die.Armello uses Gold and Magic Points as currency for using their myriad card selection ranging from equippable combat effects, to direct player sabotage. You can also take your cards and burn them during dice rolls to guarantee specific dice outcomes; this removes a number of dice equal to the number of cards burned, but can potentially guarantee winning or overcoming a trap.Armello’s other form of “currency” is Prestige, a form of positive notoriety that is earned from killing Banes, other Heroes, finishing Quests, or from cards. The player with the most Prestige gets to pick the King’s daily decree each Day Turn, and will win should the King die (end of turn 18) via a Prestige Win. This type of win is the most common from the games I played, and is the easiest to obtain. After 3 times of getting a Prestige win I found the mechanic a bit unbalanced and boring. The other possible ways to win are: Killing the King and surviving, and curing the King via Spirit Stones. Both options require intense player building with the latter needing a focus on good timing and Quest management.All of this in mind, Armello sports some of the most amazing art and music I’ve seen in an Early Access product. The character models, the animations, and even the cards themselves are all beautifully crafted to bring the game to life. It has this undeniable charm that pervades every aspect of the game, from the Heroes both majestic and shifty, to the Banes—unearthly Rot creatures—who maintain an air of danger and threat. There are a few minor hitches such as the King’s Declaration graphic staying on-screen for far too long and obstructing any action taking place during that event. The music as well is moody and ethereal, creating a mystical atmosphere throughout each playthrough. However, when browsing cards on the Main Menu there are no sound effects when clicking on cards.It’s still very soon in Early Access, but Armello is definitely one of the more tightly designed digital board games I’ve played as of late, and its future developments could prove quite interesting. I suggest keeping your eye on it if you’re on the fence. If you really enjoy digital board games, though, grab this and run with it along the development process.

												I'd like to point out that I've only had this game for two days. I've given this game many chances to captivate me, however it hasn't. Which wouldn't be bad if I could have fun in some way while losing but personally I did not enjoy this. But hey I tried something new.

												First, let me say that I like the game. It's a great game, with good potential, but I don't recommend it for 2 reasons:1) The AI is very bad. content:
Posted: August 23, 2016
Product received for free
Review A board game with tactical card play, RPG and strategy elements.The (Lion) king is dying and you need to defeat him and take his place before the other players do.On your way to take his place you can (and should) complete quests, earn prestige and become stronger.You'll fight or avoid, as much as you can depending on your hero, fighting other players, watch out for threats, summon powerful spells, get weapons, followers and make traps for your opponents.Choose your hero/clan, each one with different stats and skills.Currently the game has 8 heroes but there is a DLC with another 4 heroes coming.It looks like online gameplay is the focus of this game.The AI turn takes too much of your time. First thing you must do is to turn the "Quick AI Encounters" options on.You'll die, but that doesn't mean the end of the game. You'll restart on your clan base again and the only thing you'll lose is prestige, which is a very important stat to win the game.This an easy to play and hard to master game. There are so many gameplay details that it's impossible to talk about all of them on the review. But you'll learn about them on the Prologue/Tutorial and also on the guides you'll find on the community guides.Pros:  Beautiful art. Not only the map, the heroes and the other characters, but also the cards. There are a lot of them with really beautiful animations.Tutorial/Prologue is well done. Not only it teaches you how to play the game, but also introduces you to the (short) story.Different ways to win the game/defeat the king.Different characters and skills.Random generated maps.Dozens of different cards. Cons:  Lack of content. There's only one map. On my second run I beat the game as Thane. The only incentive to play the singleplayer game again is to get the remaining achievements.Instead of releasing new maps/story, the devs are focusing on releasing new heroes.There is an annoying bug that has been already related to the devs but they haven't fix yet and that prevents you to end your turn. The workaround that worked for me was to change the screen resolution in-game so I could see the "End turn" button.The animanted scenes that you see on the trailers you won't see in the game.You can't collect items on singleplayer, just on multiplayer. Rating:7/10For similar reviews and great giveaways please visit Steamified[www.steamified.com]

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Tl;dr: Gorgeous graphics, garbage gameplayOK, I have played this game 4 times through now (5 if you include the tutorial). I enjoyed the tutorial. The graphics are lovely. There is a potentially deep, intelligent, strategic game under here. So here's why I feel like I wasted my money:1.) The AI is terrible. I "won" my first game vs. the AI because they killed the king while I was prestige leader. There is absolutely no reason for them to do this - it was a move which ensured a victory for me which I could not have secured for myself for many turns.2.) A game will last somewhere between 25-40 turns as a guess, but is generally decided within the first 3-4. It is very, very easy to get into a position where either A.) one player is so far ahead their victory is certain, but won't happen for another 3/4 of the game B.) you can't win because you lost a few early battles to the RNG and now can't hope to get back on your feet.3.) The battles are a snooze-fest and you are forced to watch *every single one*. I don't mean every one you are involved in - I mean battles between two characters who aren't even opponents of yours (essentially NPCs) on the other side of the map which have 0 bearing on your strategy etc. Battles you do not care about. Battles that last around a minute and consist of randomly thrown dice.4.) There is some small element of strategy involved in dice throwing -you can trade your cards to lock dice into position - but god knows why you'd want to when a dice roll can and will randomly reroll itself giving you extra victory points/defence/etc if it lands on the "right" side. Why would you trade the possibility of this potentially infinite loop for anything else?5.) I think the game is supposed to be primarily multiplayer - but the same problems of it being essentially a dice rolling sim persist. What's more the "chat" system is restricted to a handful of clickable speech buttons which don't actually even say the thing that's on them ("oops" becomes "well, that could have gone better" etc.). Also see the game being won/lost in a few turns yet lasting so much longer than that it's literally painful.I played for less than 5 hours I know, and I would say at least 2 of those were me giving it extra play time so i could be sure I was being fair. I do not understand the overwhelmingly positive reviews of this game. If it was £3-£5 or still in early access I would give it a break but as it stands this is a real waste of your time and money. Finally: everyone who disagrees with this review, please, please, please explain why I am wrong. Like many of the other negative reviews say I desperately *want* to love this game but I could get the same gameplay value rolling a dice and trying to get the same number 5 times in a row. If there is something I am missing that makes this game amazing despite my reservations, please point it out!

content:
Posted: February 4
												This game had potential, but unfortunately, while the general concept is good - it just doesn't live up to what it COULD be.Went into this game thinking "Oh hey, it's based on tabletop RPGs - I've played those before and they can be entertaining, going through dungeons in a group, questing, etc. Sure, I'll give it a shot!" but alas, it wasn't meant to be...There is absolutely nothing in this game that "sucks you in" in terms of gameplay. The ENTIRE time you're playing, you're staring at a tiny little map broken up into hexes, with giant figures featuring you, the three opponent "player" AI, and various other AI representing the King's guards, Rot enemies, etc. all moving around....but that's it in terms of gameplay. Want to quest in a dungeon - just step on a dungeon hex! But that's all you end up doing - after that your reward is randomly generated or you could trigger one of the Rot NPCs....you don't get to go through an actual dungeon, quest, deal with monsters, find treasure, etc. like you would in a tabletop RPG. Nope, you just step on a tile and the system randomly rewards (or penalizes) you.Want to explore a town, maybe do a quest? Yeaaah....no. Not gonna happen. Once again, step on a tile, a quest pops up - you gotta roll dice or burn cards with symbols on them (seriously?) to somehow "win" the quest. Fail - penalized, win - oh boy, you get a few coins or maybe a card...Want to buy equipment or upgrade your pre-existing? Nope - you gotta somehow hope that you pick an item card (when that finally happens in the game) that fits what your need, if not, you're stuck with a card for a piece of equipment you don't want.No, the entire time you're playing this game, you're staring at a hex map. Want to start a party - maybe quest some? Nope, not here. A "party" are basically npcs you win through questing - and we've already talked about questing. They're basically cards that hardly ever interact (if at all) with you and just provide a modicum of points/benefits (if any) for you.This entire game is nothing more than numbers chasing - you're trying to become the Prestige leader for every turn, trying to acquire 4 soul stones to MAYBE heal the Lion King, trying to gain enough corruption/hit points to take ON the King in combat, etc. Meantime, the other npc players are trying to handicap you at every turn, laying traps, stealing your money, attacking you, etc.Needless to say, this got boring FAST.Listen, this game is basically eye-candy and even then - not much else. Plotwise - it's got about as much depth as a kiddie pool with a half-inch of water in it. The storyline is the barest boned I've seen in a LONG time. You never really explore this world - you just wander through it, trying to get your character high enough before the game times out or is won by someone else. Game mechanics are pretty much luck based, and if there's something along the lines of actual strategy involved - I've yet to see that.This game had the potential to be SO much more. Given the types of similar "anthropomorphized animals in a medieval/magic-based setting" content out there - such as the Autumnlands and Mouse Guard comics, plus pre-existing RPG games that follow D&D mechanics, such as Might & Magic, this game could've been more immersive, more plot driven, so much more INTERESTING than it currently is! Where are the quests to try and find out more about "The Rot"? Where are the quests to explore the history of this land? Where are the quests to explore the land, PERIOD!?!? I'd have loved to be able to put together a party of npc characters or even multiplayer friends, and just QUEST in a dungeon or explore the wilds of this kingdom, fighting monsters, doing quests, etc. instead of running around like crazy people, from one end of the map to the other, trying to perform what comes down to as MEANINGLESS quests, all in an effort to numberchase against AI opponents...This isn't entertainment, it's very pretty annoyance and monotony. And yes, much like everybody else, I find it appalling that there's FURTHER in-game purchases for what is nothing more than variations of the same eyecandy skins that already comes with the game, and very little of anything else. The fact that they charge almost (if not more) for the "upgrades" than the game itself make me scratch my head in wonder as WHY someone would continue to fork out money for a game to look remotely prettier if the game mechanics are (at the end of the day) still pretty damn boring.My recommendation - Avoid Like the PLAGUE!

Early Access Review
								At this point in the development i already feel that Armello has set a standard for digital boardgames. The 4 characters introduced with the initial early access build each play up different strengths and weaknesses exposing distinct strategies, while still allowing for a variety of general strategies. With the different game winning conditions, as long as players are active a couple setbacks do not feel game ending. The prime example of what feels like an out of the box come back is the rot win, allowing death to be the means forwards. I've had a great time playing the game and look forward to the new cards, additional heroes and an expanded community of players.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												Want more players in multiplayer? Multiplayer is regional block by Steam. To change region, go to Steam -> Settings -> Download -> Download RegionEurope has a big fan base, my favourite region is UK London. I notice that multiplayer's strategy changes base on region.This is a tabletop games, takes 10-20 hours to unlock all rings and amulets. Then the only thing left to do is multiplayer. You don't have to put much time into this game to be powerful, don't have to worry that you can't catch up with others after leaving the game once a while. Just play with people whenever you want. You need skills and luck to win, neither devotion nor pay to win.Move three cells each turn, draw a number of cards base on wit. Cards can be equipments, useable items, spells, traps, etc. Finish quests to gain more stats and rewards. Three ways to kill king, or win with prestige. Every character has their own special ability. Each clan has their unique rings. As a result, strategy is diverse. You can speed up AI in option, and push . button, to speed up AI further, too. In multiplayer, people uses strategies that you never see with AI. I learned a lot in multiplayer.For those who complains about randomness. I have played so many turn-based strategy games, a few notable are heroes series, Xcom series, talisman, Elder Sign, Hard West, King’s Bounty, etc. I tend to play on highest difficulty and get boring because it is too easy. In Armello, I win 70-80% against AI because of randomness and I enjoy it. I won’t play this game if I know how to win 100% every time.Multiplayer is where the real challenge begins. Where you feel anxious and tense, the intense pleasure, a kind of addiction. The stimulation is too good...You don’t want to go back to single player anymore.Conclusion: A Hidden gem. Must play.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												Want more players in multiplayer? Multiplayer is regional block by Steam. To change region, go to Steam -> Settings -> Download -> Download RegionEurope has a big fan base, my favourite region is UK London. I notice that multiplayer's strategy changes base on region.This is a tabletop games, takes 10-20 hours to unlock all rings and amulets. Then the only thing left to do is multiplayer. You don't have to put much time into this game to be powerful, don't have to worry that you can't catch up with others after leaving the game once a while. Just play with people whenever you want. You need skills and luck to win, neither devotion nor pay to win.Move three cells each turn, draw a number of cards base on wit. Cards can be equipments, useable items, spells, traps, etc. Finish quests to gain more stats and rewards. Three ways to kill king, or win with prestige. Every character has their own special ability. Each clan has their unique rings. As a result, strategy is diverse. You can speed up AI in option, and push . button, to speed up AI further, too. In multiplayer, people uses strategies that you never see with AI. I learned a lot in multiplayer.For those who complains about randomness. I have played so many turn-based strategy games, a few notable are heroes series, Xcom series, talisman, Elder Sign, Hard West, King’s Bounty, etc. I tend to play on highest difficulty and get boring because it is too easy. content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you're a fan of board games and RPGs, this is a must try, especially mage knight the board game, if you ever played that one, then this game has a lot of elements from it, but obviously simplified for everyone to get into.Everything from looks to art is great, except a minor thing which is the animations in battle seem a bit wonky/awkward, but that's just a preference.Now I understand they decided to limit a lot of deep elements of the genre to attract more people, but I do believe a few things need to be considered for the final release:1) A leveling system: Be it in game for the characters, they gain exp for killing enemies/heroes and when they level up they get to pick some character specific skills which they can use once per round etc.  Account level up to show progress of some sort and rewards such as skins or whatever, rather than just earning rings and whatnot.2) A better variety of enemies more than just a crow/ the option to be able to attack kings guards without the need for the kings orders to allow it.3) Introduce elements such as Fire shield or Ice attack which count as 2 swords and needs 2 blocks to block 1 ice attack and such, this might be a little too complex for the general public though.4) More maps, hopefully this is already being thought of/implemented.5) Like someone has suggested, even though the game has 4 routes to take to win the game, everyone ends up going for the prestige route because its the easiest and more beneficial way, they need to somehow balance to improve variety.6) Different game modes, cooperation between 4 players to fight against the map and conquer castles or such and the trickery spells etc could be used by the enemy minions, another one would be a two on two sort of match with the same elements.7) Allow us to buy recruits at cities or settlements with coins or magic depending on their type, seeing as leaving it to RNG doesn't really have a fun feeling to it.Overall this game is great and I'm quite excited to see it in its final form, but for now I think I'll give it a  rest until it's finished. Great job guys, unique experience.

content:
Posted: April 4
												TL;DR A pretty fun game with some preformance and balance issues, but worth picking up if on sale.Pros:+ Beautiful environment+ good soundtrack+ fun strategy Cons:+ Unabalnced; certain characters are substantially easier to win with+ unnecessarily graphics heavy+ various bugs/errorsArmello is a lovely, strategy table top game where there are several ways to win. The game is fun and definitely has some interesting strategies you can use to win, however, it suffers from unabalanced gameplay and bugs. As a Mac user (I know, screw mac - you're a fanboy - buy a pc - blah blah blah) the game unfortunately is so graphic/animation heavy that it causes a little bit of lag on my Macbook Pro 2016. My primary gripe with this game is the unbalance. While there is always something to be said for champions, hero's, classes (whatever you want to call it) that are easy to play, the "easy to play" hero in this game is also unfortunately much easier to win with as well. This makes the game a bit less tactical and a bit more hero specific. All-in-all, I definitely reccomend this game as a fun, engaging, and well packaged table top game that's just priced a bit too high for the quality. I'd recommend picking this up at around $10 or less.Happy gaming!

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												"RED-WALL!!!" "EULALIA!!!" "BLOOD 'N' VINEGAR!!!""WINTER IS COMING!"Ahem... anyway...The introduction video is pretty self explanatory. Four players with unique heroes navigate a perilous hexagon tiled board in their quest to succeed the Rotten Lion King.There are three ways to win as of Aug 30 2016; have the most Prestige when the King dies, slay the King and survive the battle, or collect four Spirit Stones and engage the King to use them. A "fourth" option is to have collected a higher Rot count than the King and slay him in battle.Every day in the game is two turns, Day and Night. Each turrn you draw cards, your Wit stat determines your total cards in hand. The game is played by spending Gold, Magic etc on these cards to affect yourself, other players and the tiles of the board. Battle uses dice to determine hits and misses. They are six sided but use symbols unique to Armello. The effects upon your characters determine the number of die you cast and buffs and penalties to your rolls.All in all a fun and addictting board game.I like it because you can be helped or destroyed by chance at almost anytime. I've been in last place and won the game in one turn more than once... and vice versa.Perfect game to play when you want to eat too.... Now playing it makes me hungry...

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												**Slightly outdated review, will update eventually**The game is just too short. I don't really mean that each game session is too short but the overall experience is too short. After a few times of playing you feel like you have experienced all that Armello has to offer. I really think that there needs to be more content in this game to make it worth 20 dollars. Here is my reasoning:Heroes:There needs to be more heroes to play to make each session more interesting. There are only 8 heroes so you see a lot of the same things over and over again. Also, you get all the heroes right off the bat with no effort needed. Instead they should have made more heroes and required the player to unlock the heroes through gameplay. This would have extended gaming time for the players.Cards:All the cards are offered right from the beginning. Similar to the hero section, there should be more cards in the game to add customization and also offer more content to the game. Similar to hearthstone, Armello could have required the player to earn new cards through gameplay. Then the player could have set up decks for each of the heroes that they had unlocked. Map:The map is okay. The tiles do change from game to game which leads to more replayability. However, the map has the same shape every single game. It would be more interesting if the map took on different shapes, which would require different strategies for the player to deploy to win. Also, a wider variety of tiles would increase replayability and alter player strategies on the fly. Conclusion:Really the game just needs more content and variety to make it worthy of 20 dollars. Maybe I value higher levels of game time and content more than the next gamer, but I still feel Armello is on the lean side of those categories. When I buy a game I expect to sink a decent amount of my time in it. Armello just didn't do that for me.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												I never really liked or even cared for tabletop strategy games, but a handful of my friends had Armello and insisted that it was super fun, so I decided to get it anyway. And I'm honestly glad that I did! Once I got used to all the game mechanics and learned all the rules and characters and such, I was hooked. Even after all these hours played, I still have a blast both online and offline, trying to get powerful items and followers while either avoiding or killing enemies, perils and other players in a race to defeat the corrupted king and become the new ruler of Armello. And the graphics, artstyle and effects are nothing short of gorgeous.As fun as I consider this game though, it's not without its faults. For example, at times it feels like it's just far too luck based. You're constantly at the mercy of an unforgiving RNG, whether it be something like fighting another enemy or player, or just trying to complete a quest. Should the RNG decide that it hates you, you're in for a rough time, whether it be failing a quest and not getting items that you want, or dying constantly and having to start from your clan grounds over and over. There's also this really annoying bug that happens every now and then. Sometimes when a player ragequits, the game will pause and lock up, making the game unable to continue and forcing you to start a new game (hopefully that will be fixed though).But still, despite these flaws I still think that Armello is a really nice and well-made game. Definately a great game to play solo, or with friends to either encounter shenanigans together or to annoy the heck out of them. 4.0/5.0

content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
												A game full of strategies, tricks, cards and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ trolling dices that will decide if your hero will take the throne!In Armello, you play as hero in a rush for the throne against three other heroes. Each hero have their own traits, pick one that fits your playstyle. You can also pick up rings and amulets to further enhance your hero as you desire.All heroes have the same total stats points, they are just distributed differently.Armello's art are gorgeous! (specially these card arts!)This game resembles Game of Thrones with baddass animal characters instead of humans.If you are looking for a fun strategy game with dices and varied victory methods, then Armello probably won't disappoint you.Pros: It's fun, you can achieve victory in different ways, smooth animations.Cons: It needs map layouts, after some matches the same map will look boring and the DLC Bear's Clan Character have a ability that feels unfair. (Don't judge me, its my opinion)9/10, would took 5 damage in my face from a single wyld dice all again!

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												Edit: Originally not recommended, it was borderline. After many plays, the game is in fact a lot of fun to play and the characters add a lot of variety. My gripes with the game still stand though, some crazy RNG, user interface issues, lack of options, easy AI, slow pace with no current way to disable animations.Here are the selling points from the store page and my breakdown of said features.◘ Easy to Play but Hard to Master - Armello is an intuitive game, easy to pick up and experience but with deep and emergent strategy. Full release will include a tutorial mode.Emergent strategy basically means that there is no long term strategy, things change from turn to turn, a new card draw with less than stellar cards means you may have to try and burn them off rather than continuing to your quest marker so maybe you'll get a better draw next time. The card draw is one of my biggest gripes in the game. There are a lot of different cards in the deck, so you can never really plan on what you want to do with your character based on equipment and spell cards, you just have to develop a new plan based on each draw. I wish the game gave you a little more control over the card draw.◘ Fast & Thoughtful - Adventuring in Armello is fast-paced fun but filled with deadly tactical and politically complex decisions requiring careful forethought and planning. The pace is simply not fast, you have to wait for your opponents to finish their turn and it takes forever. You can occasionally play some cards off turn, but it's rare. Planning is thrashed by card RNG, if it works against you, your opponents will quickly outpace you in stats and equipment. Poltical descisions are not complex at all and you basically choose between a or b, prestige in the game is relatively easy to get.◘ Multiple Playable Heroes - Full release will include 8 playable Heroes. Each unique Hero possess a special power, stat line and Ai personality. Also heroes can be customised with Amulet and Signet Ring load-outs to match your play style or counter an opponents strategy.Fair enough.  Edit: I didn't elaborate, but characters are all very different and require different tactics. My favorite to play at the moment is Amber (dungeon RNG reducer) . Upcoming Bandit Clan DLC will also add to the variety with new characters and different buffs.◘ Dynamic Sandbox - Armello features a gorgeous dynamic world which procedurally generates a new map each and every game, complete with a dynamic quest system ensuring no two games of Armello are ever the same. I don't feel like the quest system was very well fleshed out. Pick the stat you want, travel to get it, a random dice roll risk if you want a little extra. Random map generation does not really help replayability because of the small map size and a small handful of different tiles, I feel a larger map with increased action points and more tile variety would have been more immersive. I feel like I travel the same tiles, and take the same route over and over.◘ Turn-Based Day & Night Cycle - Armello features a fuzzy turn-based system, cycling between Day and Night phases. The fuzzy turns allow you to still play cards and do certain actions when its not your turn, and when it is you use Action Points to move around the hex board. I wish there was more to do when it's not your turn, this is less of a problem late game though as players begin to rush the palace.◘ World Class Music & Audio - By Michael Allen, internationally acclaimed artist Lisa Gerrard, Stephan Schutze and Jacek Tuschewski. The audio is outstanding.◘ Animated Cards - Armello will feature over a 120+ beautifully animated in-game Cards, from artists all over the world. They do look nice. No complaints.Edit: The game is truly gorgeous to look at, I mentioned it in my ea review, but didn't mention it here,  the all around atmosphere of Armello is near perfection for a game, I don't think there are many games in my library that come close.◘True Tabletop Feel - We spent months making sure we cherry-picked the best parts of the tabletop experience, like our custom physics-based dice!There are some things that are not consistent with a tabletop feel.  During a King's decree, the camera locks and I can't even scroll the board. I want to look at my card descriptions while trying to figure out a quest, nope, not happening. The devs have reduced the fog in the game for better visibility, but I just want to zoom out more and see the whole board at once, but the devs are obsessed with the artistic atmosphere and zoom is nerfed. Multiplayer makes the game a little more fun, as the AI is not great and makes some puzzling decisions, but the pace slows even more and it's agony if you've fallen behind.For me, Armello could have had some more strategic choices (especially card draw mechanics) and less battling with the RNG.  I do play quite a bit because RNG games have a place in my library. I will also continue to play in the hope of seeing some improvements, but I'm afraid this is the devs final vision (except for some tweaking) and it's not gonna change much.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												You play one charakter with unique abilites like a first strike or getting more money from villages etc. From then on you try to win the game by either killing the king, curing him or let him die by himself and be choosen as the next king by reputation.Which way you choose depends on your playstyle but also on your cards which you draw at the start of your round. By completing personal quests you get items, gold and other usefull stuff to beat all other players. But beware of them trying to interrupt you.It is pretty much RNG at many times - too much for many guys. But it is a board game with dices - so there have to be RNG. However it's much more about how you take adventage of your luck and make your way to victory not too obvious. I really enjoy this game.It's pure fun and beautiful.

Early Access Review
								As someone who rarely purchases games, I am very pleased that I decided to invest in Armello.The whole game oozes charm and elegance with lovely graphics and a flowing soundtrack that fits perfectly with the mood of the moment. It features some old ideas but executes them so that they feel new and original.The game can be played straight from the box but, as the player gets more involved, the various strategies and mechanics become clearer. Do you strive for strength in close combat or opt for tiptoeing around the world, searching for spirit stones, and using long-range tactics to shatter your opponents?I love the way this game has been designed. It has the power to immerse and captivate you with plenty of variation and scope for future expansion. Each of the heroes provide a different approach to winning the game and can be further defined by completing quests and obtaining a wide range of useful objects like armour, spells and follower companions. The element of luck and random outcomes makes every game different and entertaining.If you enjoy employing your brain, I think you'll really like Armello!

												I didn't want to like this game. It looked a little too cutsie, almost like a dolled up girl's version settlers of Cataan. Well, my board game buddy bought a copy for me and I played the introduction. I was hooked. I love Civilization, I love Endless Legend. I loved this game. It was easy to learn. It has a lot of variety. The graphics are really nice. Actually, I want to have an actual board game version of this. The dice are quite fun. They way your character levels up is great. When I lose, I have fun. When I win, I have fun. I'm having a lot of fun playing this game and I didn't think I would. But I did, and I do and I will.If you have room in your library for a relaxing 30-45 minute strategy turned based multiplayer boardgame style game. GET THIS ONE.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Let me give you the TL;DR first for those of you wanting a quick review.Excellent game, beautiful graphics, challenging and fun. The price tag is acceptable for the gameplay presented (and I'm incredibly picky about price vs. quality). Oh, and I ran this on a painfully bad laptop and it still looked and ran flawlessly.Cons: for those who button mash, jump blindly into things or have no patience, you're going to have a steep learning curve ahead of you because the game requires strategy. No compendium of spells/items/trickeries for review and future planning (though this does give the game an element of think-on-your-feet strategy).Final ruling: Worth buying, especially for the multiplayer.Now, let me go into a bit of a lengthier review, I'm reviewing this game while it is in-dev, and while I usually don't leave a review, I feel that I should definitely give this game some credit and accolades. First off, beautiful game, as I said before. I ran this game on a computer that failed to meet two of the specs in the initial screen and it still ran without a single hitch and lag so minor that it  maybe  added on 10 seconds to my overall game. What I'm getting at here is that the game is incredibly user friendly.In playing the game through with each of the characters once, their traits are balanced so that you have a fair chance to win with each character, though you still have to win with strategy, as blindly rushing the king will more than likely help your opponent achieve victory. Took me a second to realize that to activate cards I had to drag and hold, but after I realized this I also came to the conclusion that whoever made this mechanic is a lovely person who didn't want us to have to click yes in an 'Are you sure you want to do this?' popup box hundreds of times.I'll give further review as the game develops and adds in new features, but for an in-dev and early access game, it already has me quite happy and eagerly awaiting further releases.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've always been a board game fan, and had both high expectations and trepidation walking into Armello. Would the RPG element be complete enough? Would the game be deep enough in a one hour play through? Would it be exciting enough to get me to play it over and over?  More importantly, would I ever choose to play Armello when I could otherwise play Settlers of Catan or Dominion on my kitchen table? The answer is YES, to all of these questions. The RPG element is too downplayed to really be called "RPG". It is more "inspired by" RPG. The closest thing I can think of to it is Munchkin—the RPG parody. Yes, you go around and get treasures and equip weapons, but the real reason for doing this is to get a strategic advantage, not just to make yourself more badass. The advantages are sufficient that you are encouraged to quest not because the quest is interesting (it's not) but because if you can complete it, you'll be one step farther than your opponents to achieving late game dominance.In terms of game mechanics and win conditions, the latest update, Engines of Fate, has greatly improved the chances that trying for another victory condition other than a prestige (points) victory could nab you the win. Better, even if they don't, trying for another victory condition could give you the advantage you need in the late game to lock down a prestige victory as a fall back. It is this full-game strategy that makes Armello worth playing. Once the full version is released, I expect that this to be an extremely replayable game, and a refreshing change from most turn-based video games like Civilization that take most of a day or longer to play.

content:
Posted: March 31
												Ok, I had my doubts about this game from the start but it is crazy addictive. The claim that it is an adorable version of Game of Thrones is accurate, and I like the general mechanics of the game. I would reccomend a few things:- Maps with special twists not just reskins, I know that this can be hard as it may inately slant the balance toward more heroes.- A rebalance of a few heroes inparticular. I know I am not exactly a veteran of this game but I have played enough to see that there are a few heroes that are simply above the point of balance. First: I have never won a game against a River and I have never lost with her, and no, RNGesus was not always on her side. Her passive plus a defensive gear build absouloutly ANNIHILATES. Also it can kill the king AND give her the kingslayer victory, I mean what is with that!?Second: Magna, while I like her playstyle, seems too potent to be considered a "tank", provided the RNG is the same, she is basically a better version of Brun.There are numerous tweaks i would like to see made, but the game, for all intents and purposes is young. I have seen games with far worse balance issues.Overall, great game, most addictive one I have played since ARK: Survival Evolved.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												A very well executed board game, made to be a beautiful video game. The visual presentation draws you in and the mechanics compels you to stay and explorer more of it.The only weakness I feel is worth mentioning, is that if you try and stringently pursue a certain victory condition, the game will slap your hand and throw a myriad of random events at you, which might screw up your plan. The trick then is to be able to revise your plans immediately and go for a new victory condition, if that one seems more plausible than your old one. Also, sadly, a lot of online games I've playe so far are marred by people disconnecting. But that's a problem with the player base. The game is very enjoyable in single player as well, which is a rare quality in a virtual board game.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								There are already plenty of reviews stating what this game is, so I'll skip that part. The real question is, is it enjoyable, and the answer is a resounding yes. Is it worth 25 USD? Well...Being early access there are still a few kinks I feel the game needs to work out, but the developers are constantly tweaking the game to make it as fair for all players and strategies as possible. New characters can currently be previewed in game and on the forums, so the current four are certainly not the end all, and more content and game modes are still being worked on. Multiplayer is operating, though it's currently easier to schedule a time with friends than wait for a public match. Single player is still a hoot though, and will keep you busy for hours as you try and achieve the different win conditions for in-game rewards that can be used in multiplayer matches. Artwork and design is also stunningly beautiful. For what's there, 25 may seem a little steep, but for what's promised, 25 is well worth it.

												Wonderful strategy game.  The love and care put into the "digital board game feel" is absoutley outstanding.  I love the design of the game and the heartpounding finales to each round. content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												Nice game.I like it.  A very good product of a designed based on hybridizing board/dice/card games with RPG / 4x-esque games.  It might be a bit too oversimplified, but deeper strategies do exist.My favorite part about the game (and the part in which I think it does the best) is its job of developing and presenting the theme.  The artwork, the lore, the presentation of the entire story (which is unforutnatly a bit short) was very well done.  The win conditions are all very fitting, from slaying the king in direct combat to submitt oneself to the corrupting Rot, it all goes with the lore very nicely.  At the end of each game you can pretty much imagine a tale written about what happened in the past 1 or 2 hour of gameplay, as the mechanic of the game trasnlates into a story smoothly.  Now the gameplay in itself is not bad at all.  People say it is too luck dependent, but really it's just a factor you stratgize around.  The actual range of risk analysis isn't so big.  Sure, rollin 4 dice might sometime beat someone who is rolling 6, but that should be in your consideration of margin of risk and possiblity.  Engagment with dice differentiation of 4 or more is rarely unexpected.  Furthermore, the overall health of all the character is relatively low in comparsion too all the things that can kill you.  It's more often than not that both combatants just die from fighting than one guy winning purely due to chance.  The only thing that is bit too chancy is quests and spirit stones.  Although they normally don't change the outcome too much, it's a weird mechanic of odds with a payoff that doens't really makes much sense.In other words, the game has set a very good premise on this hybrid genre.  It has a good base, a great art form, phenomonial theme and lore.  All it needs is to expand on the mechanics, extend compaign story, rework the chance mechanics a little.  I hope they can pack a lot of more good content in a DLC or something, because otheriwse there would be little incentive to keep working on the same game.8/10 for novelty.  10/10 if you are big on thematic and artistic elements.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												Armello is a great game for anyone who enjoys elements of the RPG and Strategy genres. It's essentially a turn based board game which supports up to four players at once, with players attempting to win the game in one of the four ways to win. Each player selects a character and each character has different starting stats and a unique ability. Each player will begin the game and select a quest out of a few different alternatives. The quest will boost a stat and give a chance to win gear. Gear is great in this game and I've seen most games come down to gear loadouts and, of course, dice rolls. Oh yes, a public service announcement: anyone who doesn't like dice mechanics should probably bypass this title as it is ALL dice!There is also the rot game mechanic. Rot is a stat that is basically like evil corruption. I mention this separately, just in case there are any players, like me, that like to take the left hand path and play evil. Armello indeed has the low road and it takes the form of rot. Get to a higher level of rot than the King (the villain) and you will get a huge bonus. Plus, I have rarely seen other players use that route, increasing its novelty with multiplayer.Now here are some things I dislike about Armello. I think that there are some balancing issues, especially for Corrupt characters (ie. very rare corruption cards) and a complete lack of aesthetic customization to characters. I'd love to take my evil bear priest and trick her out.Again, if you like strategy, board games or RPG's, pick up this title. Armello is one of my new favorites and with multiplayer matches only lasting just above an hour or so, I'm not sinking a whole afternoon into it.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												Its sad I cant share my actual Armello stories. Some of them have been pretty good.Pick one of 8 heroes, each from one of four clans. Wolf, Bear, Rat, or Rabbit. Chose the ring and amulet that will give them special, clan specific, bonuses. On top of the heroes unique ability. Then begin the quest to become King or Queen of Armello. The king will succumb to the Rot a little after a week. Depending on certain choices made before day 9. Or the king defeats a few would be heroes.Chose cards based on three types. Trickery, that may require gold, or prestiege. Magic, wich requires the magic resource to use. Or Items, requiring gold. Each type may also cause corruption. Corrupted weapons, magic, and trickery will cause the user to contract Rot. Becoming corrupted has its own benefits and drawbacks. And is one of the four ways to claim the throne. You could also win by being prestige leader. By combat. Or by spirit stone, and banish the king. Its never clear how you will win each game. Or who will ultimately become the next ruler of Armello.Positives:+ Nice artstyle+ Neat game and dice mechanics+ 4 different ways to win+ No two games play exactly alike+ Immersive music+ Procedurally generated maps, no two maps are exactly the same+ Interesting and animated cards+ Addicting, reminds me of hearthstone in a way+ Can still use cards, even if it isnt your turn+/- Luck plays a big part in some games, epic underdog wins happen.Negatives- Only 8 characters currently, the amount of heroes feels small- Maps only have one size & cannot be changed, currently- Games are short, only four-ish quests can be done before the king dies- No animation skips, you have to watch the AI's turns.- No team game modes. A Clan Vs. Clan would be fun, like the Rabbit Clan versus the Rat Clan.After playing for a few hours, I dont mind losing, the adventure, challenges, choices, chances, and rewards in each playthrough keep me hooked. Each game tells a story it feels like. And the music and art can get pretty immersive. And Im used to playing bloody metal shooters like Killing Floor2. Another good game, if you are wondering.Armello is great,Buy It/10

												Armello is the best virtual board game I have played to date. It does a great job of feeling like a board game while taking advantage of a lot of things that are only possible in virtual space (ie hidden things that only certain players can see). This is one of the few games that has lived up to its initial hype (and it's not even done yet as I write this!). A must-have game for any board-game enthusiast and an excellent game regardless.Watch gameplay here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLL5JEFvVpx9pi5wJBFo_WUegKuWro60Q2

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												In short: This is a charming game. It's fun, it's replayable, and it's nice to look at. But if you like reading longer reviews -Armello is a turn-based strategy roleplay game, built much like one would build a board game. In fact, I would go as far as to call this a, 'Virtual Boardgame'. The gameplay is exactly what you'd expect from that: Rolling dice, moving tiles, drawing cards, and collecting stuff, until you can claim victory, or the timer runs out. Gameplay is a bit repetitive, but you certainly don't play Monopoly because of the ways you can innovate. There are several ways to aquire victory; some of which are somewhat hard, and there are playstyles that show through that. It's very hard to secure a 'Rot' victory, but fairly easy to accumulate prestige, and simply wait the timer out. I really like the art style, and I am a big fan of the 'furry' theme. Don't worry, non-furs, there's no Yiffing here. It's visually appealing, and the music matches what's going on on the board very well, as well as helping to really immerse you in the game. Though, I wouldn't exactly say that the soundtrack alone is worth half the game's pricetag, (at a whopping $9.99 at the time of this review) it definitely helps my score. It's very moving, and flowing, and keeps a light-hearted tone until the grim of battle finds you for the first time.Overall, I have to give the game a 8/10, marred only by the steep pricetag, and a lack of a campaign.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												A very well executed board game, made to be a beautiful video game. The visual presentation draws you in and the mechanics compels you to stay and explorer more of it.The only weakness I feel is worth mentioning, is that if you try and stringently pursue a certain victory condition, the game will slap your hand and throw a myriad of random events at you, which might screw up your plan. The trick then is to be able to revise your plans immediately and go for a new victory condition, if that one seems more plausible than your old one. Also, sadly, a lot of online games I've playe so far are marred by people disconnecting. But that's a problem with the player base. The game is very enjoyable in single player as well, which is a rare quality in a virtual board game.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								There are already plenty of reviews stating what this game is, so I'll skip that part. The real question is, is it enjoyable, and the answer is a resounding yes. Is it worth 25 USD? Well...Being early access there are still a few kinks I feel the game needs to work out, but the developers are constantly tweaking the game to make it as fair for all players and strategies as possible. New characters can currently be previewed in game and on the forums, so the current four are certainly not the end all, and more content and game modes are still being worked on. Multiplayer is operating, though it's currently easier to schedule a time with friends than wait for a public match. Single player is still a hoot though, and will keep you busy for hours as you try and achieve the different win conditions for in-game rewards that can be used in multiplayer matches. Artwork and design is also stunningly beautiful. For what's there, 25 may seem a little steep, but for what's promised, 25 is well worth it.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												Wonderful strategy game.  The love and care put into the "digital board game feel" is absoutley outstanding.  I love the design of the game and the heartpounding finales to each round.  Music is wonderful, and the animated cards bring the game to life.  It's the perfect game to play at the end of the day and kick back to, but once you begin to scheme new ways to play and win it's incredibly addicting.  Rounds are perfect lengths too, only about 30-40 minutes a piece.  I've been playing many rounds on my PS4, and then rounds on campus whenever I have a spare half-hour.  A few visual hiccups and audio balancing issues aside, this is my new strategy game addiction!

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												Nice game.I like it.  A very good product of a designed based on hybridizing board/dice/card games with RPG / 4x-esque games.  It might be a bit too oversimplified, but deeper strategies do exist.My favorite part about the game (and the part in which I think it does the best) is its job of developing and presenting the theme.  The artwork, the lore, the presentation of the entire story (which is unforutnatly a bit short) was very well done.  The win conditions are all very fitting, from slaying the king in direct combat to submitt oneself to the corrupting Rot, it all goes with the lore very nicely.  At the end of each game you can pretty much imagine a tale written about what happened in the past 1 or 2 hour of gameplay, as the mechanic of the game trasnlates into a story smoothly.  Now the gameplay in itself is not bad at all.  People say it is too luck dependent, but really it's just a factor you stratgize around.  The actual range of risk analysis isn't so big.  Sure, rollin 4 dice might sometime beat someone who is rolling 6, but that should be in your consideration of margin of risk and possiblity.  Engagment with dice differentiation of 4 or more is rarely unexpected.  Furthermore, the overall health of all the character is relatively low in comparsion too all the things that can kill you.  It's more often than not that both combatants just die from fighting than one guy winning purely due to chance.  The only thing that is bit too chancy is quests and spirit stones.  Although they normally don't change the outcome too much, it's a weird mechanic of odds with a payoff that doens't really makes much sense.In other words, the game has set a very good premise on this hybrid genre.  It has a good base, a great art form, phenomonial theme and lore.  All it needs is to expand on the mechanics, extend compaign story, rework the chance mechanics a little.  I hope they can pack a lot of more good content in a DLC or something, because otheriwse there would be little incentive to keep working on the same game.8/10 for novelty.  10/10 if you are big on thematic and artistic elements.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												At first glance, the game is all I want. Fantasy, boardgame, nice graphic, etc. However, the truth is the game can't really go far after I try it out.1. Lack of game content. Only one game mode except tutorial. With the mechanism and all the set-ups they should be able to come up with more.2. Poor multiplayer experience. No communication at all. That is killing a boardgame! 3. Not balanced. The winning conditions and the characters are not well balanced.4. Extremly random. Luck decides everything.5. Tends to snowball. A 50%-chance bad start may totally destroy you whole game, not leaving you any chance if others not stupid.If the game is like a $10 small product I would like it much better.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												For all the people who hate Early Access, Armello is a game that proves it can be used well.  The devs were remarkably on-point with updates for content, AI, and game play issues.  I am just floored by the experience of watching this game grow.As for the game itself? It has a small community right now, but even the single player creates amazing scenarios and so many moments of nail biting tension that you will love and hate and get to experience every time you play. It is probably one of the best uses of a digital platform for a board game design I've ever seen, up there and perhaps beating Civilization.  It feels like a board game that simplifies what would be an immense amount of complexity and a game box the size of a Cathode Ray Tube TV into background programming. The negatives are there, of course. The graphics can suffer at high res, the mouse sensitivity has cost me a few games (mostly from a card not burning in time, or being played to the wrong hero) and the Rot victory is incredibly difficult to get if you don't base your entire game around it, but it is so, so satisfying when it works that I cannot truly fault it for that.  The first two issues are likely because of the game being also developed for mobile, and the last feels a bit more like the game designers discouraging you from being totally evil the entire game.  All in all, I recommend this game very much so to all the folks looking for a game that's fun, gorgeous, and will leave you sweating until the king's crown has fallen down.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												In short: This is a charming game. It's fun, it's replayable, and it's nice to look at. But if you like reading longer reviews -Armello is a turn-based strategy roleplay game, built much like one would build a board game. In fact, I would go as far as to call this a, 'Virtual Boardgame'. The gameplay is exactly what you'd expect from that: Rolling dice, moving tiles, drawing cards, and collecting stuff, until you can claim victory, or the timer runs out. Gameplay is a bit repetitive, but you certainly don't play Monopoly because of the ways you can innovate. There are several ways to aquire victory; some of which are somewhat hard, and there are playstyles that show through that. It's very hard to secure a 'Rot' victory, but fairly easy to accumulate prestige, and simply wait the timer out. I really like the art style, and I am a big fan of the 'furry' theme. Don't worry, non-furs, there's no Yiffing here. It's visually appealing, and the music matches what's going on on the board very well, as well as helping to really immerse you in the game. Though, I wouldn't exactly say that the soundtrack alone is worth half the game's pricetag, (at a whopping $9.99 at the time of this review) it definitely helps my score. It's very moving, and flowing, and keeps a light-hearted tone until the grim of battle finds you for the first time.Overall, I have to give the game a 8/10, marred only by the steep pricetag, and a lack of a campaign.

I hope more folks get the game so that this wont' be an issue when it goes v.1 live. The AI is pretty good, but I do see it make some stupid mistakes sometimes.Great game. I can't wait to see what all they add as time goes on.

Posted: November 21, 2016
												If you enjoy board games (not Monopoly or Risk, but real board games), you'll enjoy Armello. It reminds me a bit of a simplified Mage Knight (board game) or Runebound. It's addictive good fun, so long as you don't mind random elements like card draws and dice rolls. If you go into the game appreciating it for what it is, and not expecting every element to be skill based, you'll have a blast. I don't think it's fare to give the game negative reviews simply because you didn't know what it was going into it.While there are random elements to the game you have no control over, there is still a large amount of strategy and skill. From hex movement and board control, to skillful usage of card playing and 'burning' cards in combat, to equipping your character before and during the game... there is a lot to it.The animated 2D art is absolutely fantastic - the cards and the (too few) cut scenes are beautiful, the 3D board itself is fairly meh. The character designs are great (I'm especially fond of River's design and Sana's design), and their implimentation in 3D is the best aspect of the 3D elements of the game.I would recommend the game to anyone that enjoys colourful art, doesn't mind spending an hour or an hour and a half playing a game based roughly 50/50 on skill and chance, and that likes board games.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												I like it+ A mix of Talisman and Catan+ Art style is great+ Simple rules+ Games will end in a set period of time+ Fun with friendsDownsides- Game is cpu heavy. Don't be decieved because it's a "board game". If you have an old computer that struggles to run Civilization 5 then you will run into the same problems- Turns feel really long.- Feels incomplete. I feel that it's missing some features that it should have like the options to fine tune graphics or gameplay features. I'm sure these features will come in time.- No hot seat gaming.Now some people complain about the RNG. I don't think it's a problem because it actually averages out. For example, if you have a character with 6 dice rolls. You have a 1/2 chance of getting 1 point of attack per roll. That means on average you should only get about 3 attack rolls. You might get more or less but point is you are very unlikely to score all 6 dice rolls as attacks. If you take this in mind rather than hoping to getting "double sixes" then it will be a much more pleasant experiance.It's a board game so expect to lose some games because you were not lucky enough.Overall I'd definitly buy it if you enjoy board games and can get 3-4 friend to play with.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
												For all the people who hate Early Access, Armello is a game that proves it can be used well.  The devs were remarkably on-point with updates for content, AI, and game play issues.  I am just floored by the experience of watching this game grow.As for the game itself? It has a small community right now, but even the single player creates amazing scenarios and so many moments of nail biting tension that you will love and hate and get to experience every time you play. It is probably one of the best uses of a digital platform for a board game design I've ever seen, up there and perhaps beating Civilization.  It feels like a board game that simplifies what would be an immense amount of complexity and a game box the size of a Cathode Ray Tube TV into background programming. The negatives are there, of course. The graphics can suffer at high res, the mouse sensitivity has cost me a few games (mostly from a card not burning in time, or being played to the wrong hero) and the Rot victory is incredibly difficult to get if you don't base your entire game around it, but it is so, so satisfying when it works that I cannot truly fault it for that.  The first two issues are likely because of the game being also developed for mobile, and the last feels a bit more like the game designers discouraging you from being totally evil the entire game.  All in all, I recommend this game very much so to all the folks looking for a game that's fun, gorgeous, and will leave you sweating until the king's crown has fallen down.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												Armello is the best virtual board game I have played to date. It does a great job of feeling like a board game while taking advantage of a lot of things that are only possible in virtual space (ie hidden things that only certain players can see). There are several very different play styles for different win conditions and with each patch, gameplay gets more and more dynamic. This is one of the few games that has lived up to its initial hype (and it's not even done yet as I write this!). A must-have game for any board-game enthusiast and an excellent game regardless.Watch gameplay here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLL5JEFvVpx9pi5wJBFo_WUegKuWro60Q2

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												A very well executed board game, made to be a beautiful video game. The visual presentation draws you in and the mechanics compels you to stay and explorer more of it.The only weakness I feel is worth mentioning, is that if you try and stringently pursue a certain victory condition, the game will slap your hand and throw a myriad of random events at you, which might screw up your plan. The trick then is to be able to revise your plans immediately and go for a new victory condition, if that one seems more plausible than your old one. Also, sadly, a lot of online games I've playe so far are marred by people disconnecting. But that's a problem with the player base. The game is very enjoyable in single player as well, which is a rare quality in a virtual board game.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												Its sad I cant share my actual Armello stories. Some of them have been pretty good.Pick one of 8 heroes, each from one of four clans. Wolf, Bear, Rat, or Rabbit. Chose the ring and amulet that will give them special, clan specific, bonuses. On top of the heroes unique ability. Then begin the quest to become King or Queen of Armello. The king will succumb to the Rot a little after a week. Depending on certain choices made before day 9. Or the king defeats a few would be heroes.Chose cards based on three types. Trickery, that may require gold, or prestiege. Magic, wich requires the magic resource to use. Or Items, requiring gold. Each type may also cause corruption. Corrupted weapons, magic, and trickery will cause the user to contract Rot. Becoming corrupted has its own benefits and drawbacks. And is one of the four ways to claim the throne. You could also win by being prestige leader. By combat. Or by spirit stone, and banish the king. Its never clear how you will win each game. Or who will ultimately become the next ruler of Armello.Positives:+ Nice artstyle+ Neat game and dice mechanics+ 4 different ways to win+ No two games play exactly alike+ Immersive music+ Procedurally generated maps, no two maps are exactly the same+ Interesting and animated cards+ Addicting, reminds me of hearthstone in a way+ Can still use cards, even if it isnt your turn+/- Luck plays a big part in some games, epic underdog wins happen.Negatives- Only 8 characters currently, the amount of heroes feels small- Maps only have one size & cannot be changed, currently- Games are short, only four-ish quests can be done before the king dies- No animation skips, you have to watch the AI's turns.- No team game modes. A Clan Vs. Clan would be fun, like the Rabbit Clan versus the Rat Clan.After playing for a few hours, I dont mind losing, the adventure, challenges, choices, chances, and rewards in each playthrough keep me hooked. Each game tells a story it feels like. And the music and art can get pretty immersive. And Im used to playing bloody metal shooters like Killing Floor2. Another good game, if you are wondering.Armello is great,Buy It/10

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												I really wanted to be able to write a positive review and recommend this game, but I just can't. It has fantastic artwork, and *some* fun game mechanics, but its flaws in sum are crippling, and in the end cause more frustration than enjoyment. The game suffers from a combination of excessive luck, snowball effect, and too long average game sessions accordingly. Far too often, within the first 2-3 turns, it's already obvious which one or two players will actually have a chance at winning, while the other two or three players got screwed by RNG. This would be OK, in a game that takes an average of 30 minutes. But to have zero chance of winning over half the time due to bad luck just ten minutes into a one-hour game is just not my idea of fun or enjoyable. For this game to be what it could be, they need to find a way to drastically cut down on the snowball effect, or give players more control over their fate. One idea I can think of is to add a deck-building component, where players can choose which cards will be available to them, so as to be more likely to draw cards that work together and help a specific build; think MTG.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												This is a furry game, yes I have to break it to you, this is totally a furry game, so much furry. But to sound the all-clear, this is not a furry-fandome game, be blessed by the gods not a furry-fandome game. Because that way everyone can enjoy it.I actually never thought it would be that furry but it just fits the tone nicely, the fairy tale tone. Okay it is still a furry fairytale. But anyway let's come to the actual review. This game is Amazing for board game lovers. This is rather a computer board game than a videogame. It seems much like civilization but instead of heaving a length lice settler of catan or monopoly it is not a to long one. a game against the AI only eats about an hour, for a match with other people it can eat up to 90 minutes. The length reminds me at Company of Heroes or the regular shooters but is a bit longer. Also the game is not to complicate to learn and there are many victory options, it is possible just to win as the underdog in the last few rounds. That is great!. And many board games I've plead lack this. Even computer games, only company of heroes seems to have a similar chance for a come back but games like civilization especially against the AI are so predictable that this annoys the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you, especially since they are long as all hell.But another big selling point is the theme and it also is reflected in the game mechanics, for example if you get slaughters by a roten beast or bane as it is called in this game you will suffer the rot and become more well rotten. But once you are more rotten than the beast you will only rot via a victory over the less rotten. I love that touch, also the stone circles that heal you a bit every time you enter them will kill you instantly after you are rotten to the core. There are many other little details which make the whole game so more enjoyable. Also there is a little theme with the visitor. While he seems very annoying at first he become pretty enjoyable when you get that there is a bit story hidden in the game. Another great aspect for me was that you eventually will kill the damn lion! Man I hate lions! They aren't royal they are just a disease, and luckily you can kill them. Whoever told the story of the pure Hearted lion was full of♥♥♥♥♥♥ look at them they look like dirty scam politicians! I say only a dead lion is a good lion!.So please, play this game and enjoy it, and always remember dead all lions, those damns tyrants!.

content:
Posted: April 14
												Is this game fun? Well yes.The reason I'm down voting this game is the slimy practices of the company after gathering a fanbase. DLC City, this is something I would expect from EA or Activision but not from a indie company. So I bought the game before the DLC swarm started, it was fun it was quick and the Devs seem to care about the customer.Since the last update, the Dev have slowed up on the release of new characters that were promised (The backer faction if I remember correctly.) and every new release is a poor reskin of a character or new dice. The dice are nice but effectively boring after first roll.This practice leaves a bad taste in my mouth and pretty much ruined my enjoyment of this game. The game still has a ton of bugs when it comes to multiplayer so thats a thing that is barely addressed in favor of more skins. I will never buy another game this company puts out after my experiences, fool me once I guess.TL;DR The company made it's money so ♥♥♥♥ the people who invested early and wanted more cards/features instead of pallet swapped skins that cost almost half as much as the original game. Save your money and get another game, it's only going down hill from here.

												Very fun game. Using the story with animals gives it a nice Mice & Mystics feel. I love the confined map forcing you to interact and battle. content:
Posted: April 27
												I really really believe the game needs to let everyone take their turn at once, then put up the timer, as opposed to one at a time, with timer after 2 minutes.One, less waiting. 3/4 of the game time is spent not touching your controler, and watching everyone else play their turn. 75% downtime. It would reduce idleness and be far more intense if you know either of you can make a move at eachother, actually race to an objective, or all end up having a big brawl at once.Most things are very straight forward in the sense of "action, counter" and as such can completely screw you over if you dont have a hard counter.The most advanced combo you'll really see is stacking of a few spells that dont directly work together but the buffs just add up. Some things like Rot can completely ruin the game, and some games are over for you in as little as 4 turns.Some people have the money to burn and thats fine, but 7 dollars per skin, not even for a pack is absurd, especially since they are small models and half the game is spent not looking at your person, again, 75% downtime. If you play with 4 friends, all the time, every time, maybe. But staring at paint drying is fun with good friends, so I don't let that be an excuse for any game.
