content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												I must say, I really do enjoy this game.The visual style is, of course, stunning, with the nice blend between the cartoon animated characters in the fight screens and the 3d models in the world emphasizing the uniqueness of each character, and the backgrounds being quite easy on the eyes as well. The battle system is very quite enjoyable as well, with a nice random element in the dice rolling that is curbed by the card burning mechanic, in which you can sacrifice a card from your hand in order to get a precise dice roll. For example, if you burn a card with a shield symbol, you will lose the card, and one of your dice will become a guaranteed block.The reason I'm giving it a negative review, however, is the fact that player interaction in this game is completly crippled. All conversation is limited to a range of preset emotes, just like in Hearthstone. While that may work in a card game like Hearthstone, where only limited messages need to be sent across to the other player, in a strategy game such as this, free chat is vital. There are basic emotes such as "Let's form a truce." and "Let's attack X character.", but these emotes completly simplify and dehuminize the message. You can't ask to form a truce personally, negotiating terms such as "I'll get rid of your bounty if you form a truce with me." And endeer yourself to the partner in the truce, therefor making them less likely to break it, you can't play any psychological power games with the other players, you can't even ask someone to move from your quest tile, as you'd rather not fight them. In strategy games free chat is a vital element, and removing it like this makes you draw no disctinction between the players and AI, and makes it impossible to form relationships. All and all this game is still very very enjoyable just because of it's mechanics and style, however I could not recomend it to anyone who's looking for an in depth tactical expirience, unless the developers decide to add free chat as a house rule, then I could recomend this game to everyone.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												The premise and art style are neat, I'll give it that.The actual game mechanics, though...I think the best word I can use to describe the game is "erratic". There are multiple win criteria and multiple characters who are better suited for different victory paths than others. There's a big problem with that when you combine it with typical tempo/flow issues in games of chance along with some characters being vastly superior or inferior to others.  Example: as of the time I write this, there is a character who can win instantly in the last turn of the game, with this requiring little more than being prepared to take it. Another example is being prepared to win one way, and getting cards that won't help in that direction at all. This results in a highly unsatisfactory experience.The erratic nature of the game can also be seen easily if you get poor cards at the start of the game, or if you get targeted by a player with decent cards. You will get dropped to the back of the pack faster than getting hit by a Blue Shell in Mario Kart, and just like Mario Kart, once you're at that end, there's really very little chance of getting ahead short of someone making a critical mistake or disconnecting and being replaced by the sketchy AI. Also regarding the winning criteria, of them, one is essentially not possible to achieve in multiplayer.On top of all of this, there's also another hurdle in the game's progression rewards. Seasoned players have rewards that can be used to give them more of an advantage over newer players. While the bridge can be crossed with relative ease as these unlocks thankfully aren't based on wins but just games played, it just makes for a more frustrating and imbalanced experience than it needs to be.I think this is a case of a game that can be fixed over time with patching and tweaks, but none of that matters when the game isn't fun right now.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												An addictive digital board game that will usurp the dwindling hours of the night that, foolishly, you thought you could spare. Play til 10pm, because of work the next morning? Why not, instead, zone out and play until it is 3am and lazily muffle a curse out of your lethargic lips when you realise you sacrificed a good nights sleep for a few hours of strategic maneuvers under the fate of a dice roll. Then, whilst you prepare to sleep, you can debate the role and function of free will and determinism, or just god damn luck based compatibilism. However your argument pans out, be sure as you're going to be grumpy in the morning, that at least Armello was saved from a King ridden with Rot. Until you play again. But of course, only until 10pm. The mechanics of the game work seamlessly, and the fluid deck building dynamic adds individuality into each game ensuring a reasonable element of uniqueness for each session of kingdom saving joy. The writers have clearly gone into great length into writing stories for the optional (and recommended) quests that you perform each game, but I fear that those poor scribes have worked in vain, for it is not a story dependent game (however, I for one found it extremely charming, and appreciate the effort - it's just that it is not integral to the actual joy of the game. If you are to take my opinion on this matter, you must take in stock that I have read most, if not all, of the in-game books from the Elder Scrolls series, Morrowind and up. What am I doing with my life? God knows, but ‘He basically read meta-fiction in games and enjoyed manly solitary one-handed pleasures’ wouldn't be the most untruthful epitaph I'd have scribed on the marble above me)I would say it is a short lived novelty game, and I don't think I'd be completely wrong. I have stacked up 50 hours on this sucker in a short amount of time though, and that is due to the relatively small time you need to invest into any single game. It is by this virtue that makes it a remarkable digital board game. Hell, if you were of the creatively productive type, you could fashion tiles out of cardboard, make painted clay figurines, print out cards, make some dice, and successfully play this with offline friends (there was a time in humanity where we socialised amongst fleshy alterations of ourselves, believe me or not. Back then, we just called those people 'friends'. But they became tiresome and didn't have numbers or pop cultural references in their monikers, and their avatars were what we called 'faces'). Basically, you choose between four different species (Bear, Wolf, Rabbit, Rat), who in turn, have two variations that centre on their particular strengths and abilities (Wizard, Warrior, Diplomat, Rogue). With that, you choose stat perks and bonuses. Then you're thrown into the game. You compete with three other souls to try focus on one of the game victory conditions. It's not too difficult to grasp, but would be redundant to type here as it is explained competently in the game description and the developers website (which is charming in itself, I implore you to explore it yourself). Either way, cracking game in its simplicity and its uniqueness. Go have at it.Or don't. I'd rather you did though. Needs more players active for multiplayer, and I don't have the time and energy to replicate a physical board game, nor acquire friends. Enjoy, you magnificent people. For Armello.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												I love table-top games, from pen and paper RPG's, to miniatures like WarHammer 40k, Star Wars: X-Wing, and even Armada. I also like board games. So Armello has got me hooked. The games don't take very long and the map almost alway looks the same, but majority of the time in most board games and table top games, the board, maps, or layouts do, as well.I haven't really encountered any bugs, except for one time I accidentally hit the speed up button and it sped up so fast that it literally got itself stuck and wouldn't progress any further. An opponent (A.I. at the time), just stood there, waiting for it's animation to end and it never did. Wasn't a loss, though. I literally quit the game and restarted it, chose "Continue" and it continued from where it left off as.Anyway, this is a much better game than No Man's Sky and anything Valve has released in the last 5 years.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												A freshly unique take on a digital boardgame that is centered around the kingdom of Armello and the war between the clans to take the throne from the corrupt and dying king.  It offers several ways to win and sports several unique and interesting characters that allow for different playstyle options.  Some characters favor cunning and wits, some spiritual magic, and others just favor brute force or fighting talent.  The card  and character artwork is fantastic and the character design is unique and creative.  I enjoy loading this up every so often to play a game or two.  If you enjoy boardgames, fantasy settings, and variable gameplay then you will surely like this as well.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
Product received for free
												At first glance, Armello appears to be a game about strategy, tactics, forethought, and planning, with the ultimate victory going to the most clever player who also has a bit of luck on their side. If you play this game thinking this, it will be the most frustrating experience you can have. The true fun of the game comes when you realize that it's all about winging it from turn one, going with the random things you do or don't get, and spending the game attempting to build up to victory with half your effort, and being an absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥to a player whose face you don't like with the other two-thirds of your effort. (Yes, that's a total of 116.6% of your effort, but you'll figure it out. Using the in-game character speech buttons helps.)In general, Armello is a more structured Mario Party without minigame and with furry characters, so if you can play a game and find your own way to enjoy it without necessarily completing the stated objectives, get some friends and play this game so that you can be absolutely gobsmacked when they get the Baneblade that you just failed to win as a quest reward by stepping on a random dungeon for the first time in the game. Just don't take it too seriously, and you'll find a great game you can tell stories to your friends about. Like the time I got the Bully Mammoth achievement and the person that was my target won the game by Prestige. Play Armello and determine your real-life Luck stat.

												A board game in which diverse animals fight to seize the throne held by a dying king affected by the rot. It's a little adventure where you get to go on a journey to either go agains bots or players to fight for survival sort of. It's a fun game even alone you can enjoy it, however it's a bit glitchy at times I had some weird audio issues while playing, online does suffer a bit too. The ways you can win are pretty unbalanced, it's much easier to win certain ways making the rest tedious for no reason. The characters are generally fun to play they have their own perks and play style, I would not recommend buying something else than the extra characters and that is if you really enjoy the game, the rest is cosmetic and not really worth the money in my opinion. So summary, fun game a bit glitchy, if you like board games like these and can look past the glitches go for it it's not that bad.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4
												I was introduced to this game by a friend and I fell in love with it from the moment I started playing it. It is a tale of a kingdom's tragic spiral into chaos and the fight to end a king slowly dying upon his throne, sick and twisted by a foul corruption, The story made me feel sorrow and pity towards the denizens of the kingdom because I felt like I could connect to that conflict. "No matter who wins the struggle for power, the strength of the kingdom is still lost as the bond of those who formed it disipates into the fires of war".As for the gameplay, it brought back the enthusiasm I had in tabletop RPGs long ago. Everything is easy to understand for beginners, but still provides a challenge to long time players. The choice of characters and their traits actually makes me feel like I could play as any of them with ease and no matter how south things go in a game, there's a way to turn it around thanks to there being multiple ways to win. The constant threat of royal guards, perils set by the king, and corruption kept things interesting every game. Get some friends together and the chaos will ensue as the game gets more intense as the days pass.I know this isn't much to say about the game considering that I love it, but Armello is my go to game when I need to get my mind off of things or when I just feel like playing a game. The story connects to my heart and the gameplay reminds me of the joys back when I played D&D when I was younger. I'm getting everything for this game because the devs definatly deserve the support.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												I love table-top games, from pen and paper RPG's, to miniatures like WarHammer 40k, Star Wars: X-Wing, and even Armada. I also like board games. So Armello has got me hooked. The games don't take very long and the map almost alway looks the same, but majority of the time in most board games and table top games, the board, maps, or layouts do, as well.I haven't really encountered any bugs, except for one time I accidentally hit the speed up button and it sped up so fast that it literally got itself stuck and wouldn't progress any further. An opponent (A.I. at the time), just stood there, waiting for it's animation to end and it never did. Wasn't a loss, though. I literally quit the game and restarted it, chose "Continue" and it continued from where it left off as.Anyway, this is a much better game than No Man's Sky and anything Valve has released in the last 5 years.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												Armello is a great game if you enjoy the mechanics of turn-based strategy without it being too lengthy per game such as Civ V or Endless Legends.  It's also great if you enjoy tabletop RPGs that utilize dice-rolling or card drawing.  In addition, if you fancy the idea of playing as adorable animals, this game is perfect for you!Pros:- Variety of heroes and clans (4 Clans, 8 Heroes- 2 Heroes per Clan)- Each hero has unique power - Four different victories to claim the throne- Dice and Card System allows for battle, dungeon, and peril events to be interesting (has mix of luck and strategy)- Quests allow for chance at rare items while also guaranteeing stat upgrades- Random events implemented- Interesting plot - Nice soundtrackCons:- Way too easy to get a prestige victory compared to other victories (I've played four consecutive games and won all of them with a prestige victory even while trying to get a different victory)- Standard games are the only way to gain achievements (which means if you're trying to aim for other victories instead of prestige, it's more difficult to do so in nine turns)- Each game is a little short (about an hour per game)I'd give this about an 8/10.  It's a great game in terms of cost with beautiful visuals and music.  Not to mention the gameplay is fun!  However, I'm personally not a fan of how you have a time limit to achieve a certain victory with limited resources (like action points per turn).  Whether you try to kill the king or not, he'll either kick off from rot or by being killed at low health by a hero.  This makes the game not only short but also limiting in which victories to pursue.  Overall, I enjoy it and would recommend playing custom games with friends if you want a greater challenge.

Early Access Review
								I used to adore this game and everything about it; Art style, story, music, etc. It was a masterpiece.Unfortunately, the devs' decisions over the years have been growing worse and worse, going down the greed road and completely disconnecting from their playerbase. They used to listen to their community, but now they just shut down any backlash by acting like our complaints are irrelevent to the ongoing success of the game. Arguments are always met with stubborn replies that only justify their choices by claiming they know better, with no data to back said claims.To make things worse, the game still has some of the same game-breaking issues it's had since early access. Their excuse to this (And almost everything else) is that they are a small team. But i've seen plenty of smaller teams fix bigger problems. It just doesn't feel acceptable anymore, not after so much time.

content:
Posted: February 6
1.7 Brings Bandits. At last.Disregarding most of the issues concerning the developers behaviour (such as disregarding data from their testing group, their asinine pricing of hero skins, and assorted other misdemeanours that would likely hit the word limit of the review if I went into them in depth) the release of the Bandits FINALLY means I can now thumbs up the game as everyone has "Hero parity".You can now, some year after the intended due date for delivery, get your hands on the Bandits, something League of Geeks assured us would happen back when the initial kerfuffle happened. This means you now have access to all the heroes that the KS backers have, and there is now less of a divide between backers and non backers.I did notice a slightly acerbic tone there Mr. Tiger, something I should know?I emphasise the "less" bit.Backers are treated by LoG as a class above the proletariat, and that will always remain the case (unless they pull what one specific backer did, in which case LoG throws them under the bus.)With full hero parity, I now fully recommend people buy the game.Not the ludicrously overpriced skins though. These developers don't deserve *that* much of your money. If you need to see what I'm getting at, take a look at WordSlices responses in the thread below, recommend you pick up a good cheese to go with the whine.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												Armello is a beautiful game. I love beauty, I love board games. I really wanted to love Armello.And I kind of did. I enjoyed playing it. At first, it's fun, it's pretty. But the game also made me feel somewhat... betrayed?I won't talk about the gameplay itself, as you can find a lot of info about it in other reviews. You may or may not like it, it's personal preference. I found it.. decent.Let's go over a few things I didn't like about the game. The Art and Story	The game is beautiful, yes. But the trailers oversell it. It shows animated scenes, stories. None of that is in the actual board game. You won't see any of it in a game. Look at the screenshots of a game being played, and this is what you get. No animated cut scenes, no story, nothing like that. The UI	It's just bad, and clunky. The game isn't Early Access, it should be polished. Navigating the map is annoying. The Price	I think that's my biggest issue with the game, and why I felt 'betrayed'.The game is fun, yes. However, I don't think it's worth that price. Yes, yes, a lot of work has been put into it, no doubt.But I feel like the devs are just milking us for money. Yeah, they're friendly, they host little games on twitch among themselves in which you can watch them play, and hear them discuss the game and future updates.But instead of releasing good content (that the game REALLY needs to justify this pricetag), or having awesome promotions to get a bigger player base (that this game also REALLY needs, by the way), I've seen lots of things like trying to get their fans to pay an extra $5 to subscribe to them on twitch, just to have a cool colored die.Or releasing extra content that you have to pay for, on top of the big price tag the base game already has. It feels like they're milking their small group of loyal fans' money instead of making the game grow and getting new fans After all, who wants to pay that price just to try a board game? There was one free weekend, which was a decent start, but that's it.But they should really be making the base game MUCH cheaper (free, even), and then creating more dice and character skins, even emotes or whatever, as DLC material. I think that would be a much better recipe for success than having an expensive base game AND releasing costly DLCs.The game needs WAY more content - right now, you get tired of it fast (at least I did). New maps, new cards, new characters - and I don't think we should be paying extra for that... we already don't get enough for the base price. Just release more base content that players don't have to pay extra for, and the game will be way more interesting.Then release skins and extra cosmetics, people will definitely pay for it if the game grows. Conclusion / TLDR	I feel like there's not enough content to justify the price tag.The game is beautiful while also being clunky.There aren't that many people playing it, it's sometimes hard to find a game, and I feel it will just die down. A lot of it, I believe, has to do with the business model of it.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												Armello is a nice looking game, though that's where the positive notes end. I've played about 5 or 6 games I think, and they've all been dreadfully slow paced and most times quite dull. The supposed intrigue between players doesn't really happen, and in my experience there really aren't any big incentives to interact with them at all, except maybe kill them if they venture too close to your settlements. The game is easiest won by grinding, amassing gear and waiting for the king to get to about 3 health, then move in for the kill. Gathering stones is not gonna win you the game unless you get extremely lucky with stone spawning, since moving around the board takes forever and will probably see you perish to the many dangers along the way. I've not tried for a rot victory, but it seems underwhelmning since you're probably going to be weak health wise due to attrition (fellow players have gone for Rot victory about 3 times and not succeded once). All in all a pretty game, but I would rather play another boardgame irl. This is a slow affair with little few tactical options that loses it's novelty very fast. After the first session of Armello, I found myself constantly alt-tabbing and reading the news instead.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Armello is okay.  The game play is pretty interesting, even pretty good at times, aesthetically the game looks and sounds good, and the prolouge chapters do a good job of explaining the rules.However, the pace of the game is tedious.  Even with the fast AI turns setting turned on, the time between turns can be grueling.  You could easily double the pace of play without feeling like things are going too fast, and the AI is often pretty poor. I have played multiple games with AIs starting fights they can't win and feeding other AIs.  If this is intentional, to make the game harder for the player, there have to be better ways to increase the challenge. If it is not intentional then the programming is poor. In either case it's frustating to sit through.Most of my gripes about Armello boil down to things that are really related to the game play itself.  As a board game Armello would be very fun, but as a video game it's clunky, slow, and tedious.  If you can get past all of that then give it a try, but otherwise I would avoid spending more than $5 on it.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												I'm sad to say this, but this game disapointed me. At first it looks and feel like digital gameboard game with great artwork and story in awesome fairy-tale climate, and it really is - it makes an impression of traditional boardgame, it has really great artwork (especially on cards, I really love it) and convenction of some animal clans fighting for throne of dying lion king is such a great idea.But there is the problem: the game has nothing more than this. It's even worst - game will not let you enjoy those elements unless you like totally random gameplay where your choices hardly mean something. I have played a few games of Armello - all of them ended with my win or lose only to some lucky or unlucky dice rolls. You can play a game where you will win all your quests, spawned at your base or a game where you won't even go to your first quest as it will be placed on other side of map, and thankfully to RNG some enemies will permanently block your way. There are mechanics that should help you with RNG but they just don't work, the game is still 90% of luck and I felt like I have no influence on my game, its just a hour of dice rolling and you can be lucky or not. Also bad interface and not clear enough tutorial will makes your first games a quite unpleasent experience.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												Here are my main two gripes with the game:1. Excessive reliance on RNG. RNG itself isn't bad, but when its an overwhelming factor that takes more importance than strategizing or good tactics, it just feels like you're playing a more complicated version of Monopoly in the end. There's thankfully some strategizing in how you choose to play certain characters and highlight their strengths, but it still feels somewhat limiting as their seems to be one dominant playstyle for a character. There's also a pretty strong snowballing effect, so when you're consistently dying / not hitting your quests due to random luck, you just feel sort of screwed.2. Lack of chat. The developers have chosen not to implement chat due to concern regarding 'safe spaces'. I don't particularly understand the concept of playing multiplayer without being able to chat with each others (and no, pre-set voice commands don't count as chat), let alone playing a board game / table top game without being able to communicate. The entire fun in a board game is communication. Furthermore, Armello games take roughly 1-2 hours to complete and you'll be waiting 5~ minutes for other players to finish their turns at sometimes. Not having chat to kill the time while waiting is a pretty awful decision. You can get around this by playing with others and there is an online community, but if you're looking for a quick game you might end up waiting for a while.Conceptually, the game is interesting, but I think the gameplay could use some tuning to be less luck-oriented and more skill-oriented, while the chat thing is just absolutely silly.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												I would like to start out by saying that the games advertising is pretty misleading about what this game is and is not.  I watched the trailer video which makes the game look like you choose a character and as you play the game you get to go on quest and possibly advance though multiple adventures.  Defeat different AI bosses and maps, possibly carry over card/equipment onto other adventure and so on.  Then I read that they are marketing this game as a "table top game"(printed on their own web page)  which I am a huge fan of and have been playing for many decades.  The only way I have ever played table top games... is with other players.. usually in the same room.. usually at the same table.. "sigh".  Now this is where the very misleading part comes into play...  This game has no table top functionality in regards to being able to play with other players as you would with a "table top game".Okay so maybe they shipped the game early and they are going to add the "table top" into the "game" with a patch or update.  Nope they said they did not design their "table top" game to be "table top" friendly.  "Sigh"So back to the trailer video...  In the video watching example play is actually the into series to the game.  So as you watch the trailer and expect to go on different adventures on different boards.. with different characters and win conditions.. different bosses.. randomized turn orders etc etc... what you get is...Set player turns, players vs AI player 1 will always go first.. the three other AI characters will go after you and they will always capture you cities on the night turn before dawn.  If you play the game you will soon realize how unbalanced that is.Computer AI will use cards against you as the player even if the same card played against an AI player is either (A) in the lead or (B) more dangerous to them geographically speaking on the map.*Example : computer AI plays a card that does -2 health spell, there are two possible targets.  (A) player that has 4 health 2 squares away on a tile of no importance, or (B) computer AI with 2 health 2 squares away, on their own quest location, and has killed the card player previous 3 times.*What happened:  {Comp playerX} plays spell on {playerY} does (-2) hps (4-2=2hps left), {Comp playerX} moves 2 squares and attacks {Comp playerZ} that is sitting on his quest tile, CompX has 4 hps, CompZ has 2 hps.  CompX has far superior cards and kills CompX by a land slide.  If CompX played his spell vs the other AI on his quest tile he would of been able to complete his quest and not die.  It is as if the AI was programmed to use all hostile cards VS the player first regardless of who best the card should be played in their personal interest.Okay so the AI is terrible... Who needs AI when you can play with friends so no problem.. wait.. oh I forgot you can not play with you're friends.Well you can play with some people.. over the Internet at least.. so lets hit that que button...  30 minutes later you are still in que.So that does not really work either.So what does work...  The into the game works.  You can load it up... get introduced to four of the characters one by one in their own mini adventures.. and well.. It is actually really good.  In fact its so refreshing you think, If they made the whole game this way,  The money spent would have actually been for what you were expecting.The upside to this game is the art.  If you want to play something for a couple hours.. get lost in its ambiance, get some steam achievements and then uninstall it once you realize that theres literally nothing left in the game you haven't seen or done then this games for you.I got it on sale and for the couple hours played it was similar to going to a summer movie... Not a lot story, shiny bits in between, and after its over you kinda wished you waited to see it on TV and kept the money in you're pocket.Maybe if they make the game into what it was marketed as It will be worth it in the future, but "as is" I regrettably have to say its an unistall waiting to happen.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Bought this game so I would have something to play with my autistic, furry friend. It's okay... it's like a furry board game or something. I won the first game I ever played with a backstabbing, rat thief. Purchased on sale for 30% off and it still feels a little expensive for what you get, given that you still have to pay for character DLC. As I undestand it, the furries that kickstarted the game voted to allow non-backers to get the backer-exculsive characters as DLC sometime in the future. Good on you, furries; I would never have bought this game if I felt like I would always be missing exclusive content.As far as gameplay goes, It definitely feels like the AI gangs up on you. There is a lot of randomness to the game (dice rolls) but I like RNG in these type of games. The maps are randomly generated (good) but feel really small (bad). Game could definitely use bigger maps and maybe online with more people? Eight players would be a good maximum on a bigger map, and you could even do teams of two or something to help the game feel more varied.Great game if you are a furry; okay game if you just want something to play with your mentally-ill friends.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												Game is dope as hell. Probably the best tutorial to what otherwise is a very confusing game. Sells the tone and characters of the world really well. The tutorial itself is a promising experience and I don't think I've thought that about any game ever.The game is really everything that's promised on the back of the box. The paths to victory are satisfyingly Machiavellian. The card mechanics run deep. I am over the moon for this game, very happily surprised.A few things do feel "missing". This game is far from incomplete, it's all there and it's good - but there are a few things I couldn't help noticing are just not there:1. A mini-map. While the board looks lovely and you can zoom out a fair distance, I found myself constantly scanning through the environment trying to find my own character. It's impossible to see at-a-glance where other players or where important map features are.2. Prestige should pass over or at least account for fugitive status. As I was attacking the king to kill him, he turned to me as the prestige leader to make the new decree. It was an odd moment between us. Thematically it just doesn't make sense. Might seem nitpicky but I need a mini-map for this game. The game itself alreaady plays on something like a cupcake compared to Civ or even Starcraft, but I need an even smaller version of that.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												Originally I backed this project as soon as I heard of it with much excitement well over a year ago,  and now that I've gotten to play it, I must say it simply feels unfinished, or entirely disappointing for what it was promised to be, in some ways.The art is.. alright, and the sound is less than what I expected it to be. The gameplay is fun and charming in a niche way the first, second, and third time around - and then it gets to be repetitive and extremely predictable. The games in my opinion feel rushed and offers a very low skillcap, with much of your progress based on luck. I hope sincerely that content patches bring this game forward by leaps and bounds because as it stands now, it is not worth what I paid for it I'm sorry to say. From the gamebreaking multiplayer bugs, lackluster texture work and general underwhelming game size, this feels more like a free to play title.I can't wholeheartedly recommend buying the game, because it's simply asking too much to pay $20 for what feels like a game that took two or three months to make (And I have the developer experience to know what work goes into these things.)

												I wanted to love this, because the concept is one I appreciate. I bought it for myself and family members so we could play something interactive online together while chatting on coms. The graphics are great and the gameplay is fun, if limited in the variety it offers. If you ever wanted an interactive 3D board game (think Jumanji, minus actual tropical diseases) this is what Armello aspires to be. Sadly there's a bug that resets all the items you unlock (vital to competitive gameplay and achievements) that happens to Mac users. Customer support seemed unmotivated to address this problem, though they're aware of it. Despite having multiple complains issued with proof (logs and unlocked achievements) that it exists, they're not actively working on a solution. I'd love to support further expansions, but the lackluster support is disheartening.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												If you want a pretty game that's a charming diversion you can (possibly) play with friends, you might like it.If you like board games, but don't care too much about balance or attention to design details, you might like it.If you like the idea that there's an absolute limit to the number of turns possible in one game, you might like it.I do not fit into any of these categories, so I find it horribly frustrating. I gave it SO MANY chances to keep me interested (hence a played time that I now find rather depressing), but I've finally realized that this will never be a game that I'm happy to be playing.(Also regarding that played time: Many of those hours were spent trying to obtain random dice drops, yet another supremely annoying feature that I now despise. Believe me when I tell you that those were not hours of enjoyment, but rather hours of tedium spent trying to obtain something that I'm not even sure why I ever wanted in the first place.)The game will never be balanced, as there are a couple of ridiculously overpowered paths you can take that may not absolutely guarantee victory, but they will definitely boost your chances. This is a problem to such an extent that some players will quit a multiplayer game if someone else takes the overpowered hero(es) before they get a chance to grab the one they want.The luck factor doesn't bother me as much as it does some people, but it is pretty strong, so if you hate games that are often decided by random events, you'll want to steer well clear of this one.One of the worst design problems is the "rich get richer" effect that plagues so many games created by amateur developers. What may start out as a small gap in power will invariably spiral out of control as the more powerful character just gets more and more bonuses while the one who suffered a bit of bad luck at first will simply never catch up. If you happen to be that unlucky player, the rest of the game becomes a demoralizing torture session.The game was fine for a while, I suppose, and I'm glad I got to play it and see what it's like. But at this point, I'm just so sick of it all, it hard to imagine ever wanting to play it again. Maybe I can recoup the cost of the game by selling all these stupid dice.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												The basic game design is fun, more's the pity because it's sunk by several flaws and mind boggling design decisions.So the AI is terrible, which would be fine, because it's meant to be a tabletop game.  The kind you pull out and play with your friends on a Friday night, but unless you have a ton of friends who own the game you will be playing with strangers...strangers you can't talk to...because the designers think that if they implement in game chat it would need to be moderated.  So great, playing a table top with tons of strangers that I can't even talk to, besides saying one of about 12 preset phrases.Theoretically, you can get around this by adding people as your steam freinds, but if you want to carry on a converstation you will have to alt-tab out of the game constantly to use steam chat.  Imagine having to put your tabletop game back into it's box every time you want to say something other than one of the 12 things the game developers thought of for you.  To make a titanically poor decision even worse, the responses are "personalized" to the characters, so something like "well played" or *laughs* can come off kind of snarky depending on who you're using.  Think one of the other players in the game is nice, or skilled or fun to play with despite the fact that you can barely communicate with them?  Well, hope you memorized their name and they know who you are, because there's no in game friend requesting.  So basically you have the choice between playing with the mind-numblingly bad AI or waiting 5 minuites for your turn to come around while playing with a much more intellegent human, who serves as a proxy for a better AI because you can't really interact with them.  If that's not enough to put you in a straight jacket, the game ends with a summary of your accomplishments using cute little badges for things you accomplished in game.  "What things?" You might ask.  Nobody knows; they aren't described anywhere inside the game or any of it's accompanying material, but since they are just for bragging rights, and there's no bragging (due to the lack of a chat function and the fact that when you finish you get dumped into the lobby with a new batch of strangers) I guess it kind of makes a perverse sort of sense, it just makes me completely indifferent to earning these things, since I have no idea what they are.  To be fair you can kind of guess at some of them, but others are completely opaque, still with no background it's never like, "Wow so and so captured 8 cities!" it's more like, "We all captured cities but so and so edged us out maybe, I can't really tell here, but it kind of sounds like it.  He might as well be an ultra slow AI and I'll never see him again anyway, so I guess it doesn't matter."The final critique I have of the game is that the king will mostly die on his own before you can fight him.  This makes the ending extremely anticlimatic.  Even if it ends in a battle, it will be more like an epic hero bulling a 1-3 hp enemy.  I wish you could turn off the constant life drain, at least in the house rules, but alas another opportunity missed.Sadly, Armello is a solid game with good mechanics and a clever use of the digital board game format.  If I was sitting in the development studio working out the bugs, or playing in a focus group with three other people I would be having a blast, but sitting in my room throwing canned responses into the ether or alt tabbing out and slowing the game down for everyone so I can carry on a conversation completley kills the fun.  It feels kind of like playing Settlers of Catan with a house rule that anyone who speaks has to discard all their sheep.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												Gorgeous aesthetics & cool premise can't conceal the fact that this is, at heart, a hollow Random Number Generator. Strategy? Planning? Risk? Forget about those -- it all comes down to that RNG. And you can pretty much count on one hand the number of times it will favor you over the AI. I literally had one quest i could not complete because no matter how many times I attempted it (at last count it was ~40 attempts) the die always came up in the computer's favor. Even when I burned as many of the "right" dice as I could find. Add to that a cluttered interface, vague instructions/directions, and the fact that enemy turns take FOREVER while your own can go by in 30 seconds*... Well, I'd say this is a game to miss. It's a shame because, again, the art and music are GORGEOUS and the premise is downright nifty, but this probably should have been an RPG or a deeper, more skill/strategy-based RTS of some sort. As it stands, it just feels like a wasted opportunity and a case of serious "style over substance."*At the end of one turn, for instance, I left, took a shower, changed into new clothes, fed the cat, and came back to find that it was ALMOST my turn again. Seriously.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												Never before have I seen a game so wholly devoted to frustrating you.The good things about this game? It's pretty, the system seems very inviting, and the game makes it seem as though there are a number of different strategies and paths to victory.But here's the thing. There's no difficulty setting. The AI will always prioritize attacking and interfering with you over choices that would win them the game. And no matter how many dice you have, what sort of cards and equipment you use, and what path you take, you are 100% at the mercy of RNG. The truth is that the only semi-reliable way to win is through prestige. Using Spirit Stones is possible, especially if you boost your AP and get lucky with your quests or dungeon searching. Slaying the king? No matter what you try, there's a crazy amount of RNG needed to even come close; if you die, you lose, and if you deal just too little damage, you'll also lose.And do not get me started on the Rot victory. I've tried for more than ten hours purely attempting to get it, and it's almost impossible. How amusing they lock the only tiny piece of help for that victory path behind the requirement that you have gotten that victory path first.Long story short, no matter how experienced, strategic, or lucky you may be, this game is entirely RNG. Maybe this'd be better in multiplayer where people behave rationally, but it's highly unlikely given the imbalance between victory methods. So unless you're looking for a game with a similar amount of control and personal influence as LIFE or Sorry!, this is not your game.

number of helpful: 4 of 12 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												I saw great promise in Armello when it was first launched on Kickstarter--so much so, that I became an immediate backer of the project. I actively followed its development and, as an early backer, was able to have hands-on time with the early access versions of the game before its launch. Armello has now been released as a completed product for the masses, but despite really wanting to like Armello, I must be honest and say that I feel lukewarm overall.As a note, I am a fan of Euro-style board games (IE: Catan, Carcassonne, Terra Mystica, etc.) where strategy plays a larger role in determining victory. Player tactics in these sorts of board games are what make them more involving, although, sometimes at the cost of a higher learning curve. Armello falls closer towards the opposite end of the spectrum and positions itself as a more casual and family friendly style of board gaming (IE: Risk, Monopoly, LIFE, etc.) where luck plays in tandem with a light layer of strategy.Armello, however, leans its gameplay tactics a bit too much on luck. Randomization and dice rolls are a significant portion of the games mechanics and include: Randomized card draws Randomized quest locations Randomized outcomes for quest items Randomized dungeon exploration outcomes Randomized spawning of banes and spirit stones Dice rolls for battle outcomes Dice rolls for peril outcomesAs a result, whatever semblance of strategy a player attempts in Armello is unfortunately negated a great majority of the time. The most well laid of plans will be foiled due to mere chance, not an opponent's cunning. I hope that subsequent updates can improve and address the strategic involvement, but as it stands, Armello is currently only good for the occasional, light-hearted game. I have a feeling it will resonate with those who are expecting it to be as such, but for those players expecting a board game that involves deep strategization and tactics, I recommend looking elsewhere or sticking to the tried and true classics.Edit: I have replayed this recently after multiple patches. Armello remains more of a luck-based board game rather than a strategy-based board game. To be clear, this is not to say that Armello does not have strategic elements. It does, but it is in rather light doses. Most of the action involves mitigating uncontrollable circumstances arising from luck. Again, if you are more fond of Euro-style board games like I am, then this is not the game for you. However, it is perfect fun as a casual board game.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												I don't know if the RNG in this game is really bad, or if I am just getting really unlucky. I have played four games so far and all but one of them were aweful. The first one wasn't to bad since I just thought I didn't know what I was doing. The second one, I lost every single combat encounter I had. I thougt that it was because I was playing a less combat focused charater, so I switched to one in the third game.In the third game, I still lost every single combat encounter. On top of that, the quests give you two options when you get to them. Take the stat bonus and prestige from the quest, or go for an item on top of that at the risk of loosing health. Three times the game said I had a 50/50 chance, and every single time I lost.In my fourth, and final, game I chose the most combat centric character possible. In the first few turns I failed to kill a character with three health, failed a quest that I had a 70% chance of getting the bonus from, then was promptly killed by the three health character. The thing that made this even more painful was the fact that I rolled seven dice each time that I fought that character, my opponent only rolled four, I had two guaranteed attacks, and I had six health at the time due to a spell I played the previous turn.Again, this could just be me having terrible luck, but I feel like after four games in a row it has to be the RNG.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												TLDR.:Imagine what you would want from a game that costs 20 euros. You wont get that.This game is average at best. Graphics don't sell a game for me. So why did I buy it. My friends said it was "fun".(its not)Pros:-It has a nice look/atmosphere and character design.-On off-turn(when its not your turn) you can still play cards. Which gives you a chance to zone opponents and secure your position with scouting cards etc.Cons.:-It's slow af.-20 euros. For basicly one gamemode.-RANDOM not in a good way. Cards you get, buffs you get, dices you get. This wouldn't be bad if the gameplay wasnt so slow!- The only thing thats certain is spells.-Solo game might as well be multi player. Rounds don't become faster or more fun.-There is no chat so your interaction with other players is limited to pre-written messages.(so again might as well play bot games)-It doesnt compete with other games/genre. In ANY aspect I can think of.Explanation:-Planning on buying with friends? Get teamspeak or skype.(but then AGAIN you might as well just play any other coop game on steam and use skype while doing it)-You want a board game? Buy The Settlers of Catan. Its an actual boardgame with solid game design elements that doesnt make 80% of the game an RNG fest. Not to mention the actual fun you guys can have while hanging out(in real life)-Want an adventure game?Choose any... ANY from steam's libary.-Want a strategy game?Im pretty sure steam has you covered with that as well.Lets compare two games that both cost 20 euros.Rocket League: gameplay: A beautiful learning curve where its easy to get started with, but hard to master. Next to skillful play you need on the spot strategic analysis to position better.Gamemodes: has multiple gamemodes(of ranked and casual) and several training types to help you get better.Quite a number of cars with each a bunch of customisation options. And flags.Im pretty sure i left some things out but you get the idea.Armello:tutorial: an annoying♥♥♥♥♥point and cilck tutorial. its just text and click where we tell you nowhere else.(horrible design) you wanna know what would have been better pm me.gameplay: get cards, do quests or collect stones or kill oponents or kill wraiths. for these things you get points(except for stone collecting) and if the king dies from the curse(so non player interaction) the game ends. guy with most points win. or if you slay the king you win.. mediocre afgamemodes: story mode that is as annoying as the tutorial so you can assume i didnt finnish.The rest is just the boardgame(randomly generated...must have been hard to program)you get 8 characters 2 per clan so 4 clans. but the game is so random it doesnt matter which one you pick. pick bears. get hp and "spell fuel" and you're set..You're paying for average game design, a bunch of gorgeous 3D sprites and card artwork.I know its an unfair comparrison but hey. Life is unfair and theyre both 20 euros so deal with it.This is an average boardgame. but hey.. HAS NICE GRAPHICS!!!Im pretty sure if you skype with your friends it might be a fun game. But as of now, this is as meh as it gets.. 5/10ps.: buy it if you want to play as a sweet little bunny..

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
												First, I am terrible at writing. Most of my reviews are not very well written, so don't expect J.R.R. Tolkinesk embelishments. I have been playing this game since it came out quite some time ago and have lavishly enjoyed playing it! I have a fondness of games with animals in them and this is no exception. In fact, it has been a joy to engage in this fun little computerized board game. I really like the "Disney" quality animation with the charaters and the beautiful set up of the "board" landscape. It is very intuitive and you can easily learn the game play very quickly! Especially when you start it with playing the "Prologue" which helps teach you the movements and plays from the point of each of the four main characters. To sum Armello up, it's exactly what I mentioned above; a board game. Not a RPG like The Elder Scrolls games or World of Warcraft or Final Fantasy game series, eventhough it has some RPG-like game play. The character you play is a computer animated game peice you play. It moves a certain amount of board spaces and interacts with whatever is in that board space it lands in. Addition, like a boardgame, it is random. It gives you a random set of cards and a random set of plays and no two plays are alike. You have dice that you roll for your battles or for removing "Perils" that you enter into. The cards, also, give you some leverage if you have the right cards in your hand. The type of cards that you recieve are by chance and you can never tell what types (in the three tiers that you can select) of cards you will be given when you pick them. If you get to challenge the King you have three types of victories you can perform. They are "Battle,""Spirit," and "Rot." There is one more type of victory you can obtain without challenging the King and that is a "Prestige" victory. As far as I have played this game, a Prestige victory is the easiest to obtain, while the Rot victory is the hardest. With that, the game is awesome a lot of fun to play. The AI of the "Heros" that you don't play is (in my opinion) astounding. They act as if they are run by an individual person because their moves are so unpredictable. They can attack or choose what to do as if they had a true mind and conciousness of their own! The board's artwork is stunningly gorgious and the changes of the day and seasons are nice additions. The UI is, also, very intuitive and can easily be manuvered. So far, I have not found a "con" I can think of that I can even mention against Armello. For those with families, the game is definitely very family friendly. No blood or gore in the game at all. Which is a nice reprieve from games that do.All in all I find this game a real treasure and hope that the company can make it even better and, hopefully they can create a sequil. The game creators have been working very hard to add new features to the game. The DLC "The Usurpers" is out now and is actully a fine add-on to the game with four new characters to choose to play as well as some additional items. This game will definitely end up a classic!

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												Rabbits, Rats, Wolves and Bears battling against each other to kill the King!! Armello takes place in a beautiful fantasy setting with wonderful weather and lighting effects. It truly is a wonder to behold. I won’t mention so much about the graphics in this game as it is plain to see from videos and screenshots that only a fool would dispute how especially nice this game looks!


YouTube™ Video: Armello 

			Views: 227		

			Last few minutes of a multiplayer game (One AI player due to bad loser!)		

Armello is far from style over substance. The games mechanics, whilst they may take some time to digest fully, are as beautiful as the game looks. Don’t be fooled by the fairy-tale appearance, its gameplay is far more sinister! Players will be poisoning, stabbing, stealing from, reaping revenge and a whole list of other mischievous acts upon their opponents.The acts are carried out by the cards in a player’s hand, or they can be played to hexes on the board or you can just outright attack another player. The Kings guard can also attack players if they upset the King and monsters (Banes) roam the land attacking nearby players.As I mentioned before the objective is to kill the King and the first person to do this wins, if no one manages it before the King dies (I forgot to mention that he isn’t very well!) then the “prestige” leader wins. Prestige is accumulated in a variety of ways including killing other players, the Banes, etc.I’m not going to go in depth into the rules here. The game offers a tutorial, which I found helped a little but going in blind I was quite confused by the end. On the main menu there is also a “Game Guide” that is worth reading as well. Hopefully after that things should be a bit clearer. I gave up twice trying to learn the game due to not understanding the tutorial, then a friend played a game with me using VOIP and it all became clear!I am so glad I persevered. I must say that I haven’t met any example of a board game, either physical or digital that encapsulates so much. If you have any interest at all in turn-based games or even better board games specifically, Armello could become your new obsession! Heed that as a warning if anything!Player numbers are pretty good, you can usually find an online four player game within a couple of minutes. Sometimes it may take a little longer, which isn’t bad considering each match will take around 60-90 minutes.The developers decided to not include in-game chat which I think is a bad decision. Their reasoning behind this is because a few people will troll and insult others. Yes, this is a sad fact of the world and especially the internet but that’s what mute buttons were invented for (well maybe not originally!). The lack of chat means learning the intricacies of the game will take a bit longer and developing friendships with other Armello players may never happen from within the game. Which I think is a shame.Anyhow, that’s enough time away from Armello typing this review up! I’m gonna go find myself another match and hope I can be the one to topple the king this time!!

content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												The setting is interesting, and it looks nice, but.... this is a short game that's incredibly luck based, which makes it extremely frustrating.  Drawing cards and rolling dice determine most of the game and the results are completely random--you could get some really amazing gear, or some really useless spells (or visa versa)The problem is the randomness,  It doesn't make the game fair, it makes it frustrating, and you end up having a pretty huge chance of failing most of the quests unless you pass on having rewards for half the game.Its almost a really good game, but it needs some tweaking to improve the player agency.  Definitely feels like a visually polished board game, but the frustration level is too high.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												I don't know how to contact the developers, so I'm writing this review. I'm going to focus on the interface and presentation. IMPORTANT: The netplay is terrible. If you disconnect AT ALL from a game, even a private one, ther's no way to re-enter, and you're replaced with a CPU immediately. As far as I know, there's no suspend save for single player or turn-a-day type options for multiplayer, or a hot-seat mode. Some people might expect this kind of stuff from digital board games, but you won't get it here.tldr: Is this game bad or good? I don't know. But it gives me eye strain. If the logistics on getting a refund for a 4-pack weren't so complicated, I'd ask for a refund in a heartbeat.Edit: I've played a few games now. It passes the time. It's hard to recommend at a 20 dollar price, though. It feels even more random than Betraryal in the House on the Hill or something, and the pace is glacial. That's not a good combo.Text is very small and in a hard to read, cheesy fantasy font. In particular, the log at the bottom of the screen is piteously small. The default view on the board is sooo zoomed in (I can't find a way to zoom out), but visual elements like the log, gamepieces, and dialogue boxes are TINY! I don't understand it. You can only see about 2-4 whole hexagonal spaces around your character on a huge map.Gamepieces for resources aren't differentiated dramatically enough by color to be immediately recognizable (blue-indigo and purple-blue for two of your main resources at night? really?), and the iconography is weak (hard to differentiate at a glance: squire, body, and fame pieces, in that order, are like a gradient of shape similarity; the silhouettes for most all resources are overly complex).The way things like skill rolls and dice rolls are presented are very weak. They're not very satisfying; the animations move in an unexpressive, constant rate, and the sound effects are soft and unimpactful. Skill rolls show each success and failure result by arranging 10 game pieces in a circle. Each piece fades rapidly until one is left. There is no anticipation; it happens waaaaaay too fast, and the rate of disappearance is constant, even up to the last result. Oh, and dice rolls. It's like they're being thrown in anti-gravity. And the sounds... ugh. So soft and muffled. It's like if you dropped dice onto a stiff pillow. The smallest windowed resolution is too big to even be functional for the highest recommended fullscreen resolution; seemingly, a huge oversight. This is because many important buttons and a lot of game information are at the very bottom and corners of the screen, and these are inaccessible and blocked from view with a Windows 10 taskbar in front of them. It's impossible to play this game in a window with a monitor under ~1600x900.And the graphics are... they have this very fun, colorful, emotionally impacting animated intro in the trailer. The card art is great. Why does the game itself have soft lighting and eye-burningly low color contrast? Seriously, at night, the only two colors that exist are dark blue and dark green-blue. It's ridiculous. On top of making it hard to see, there are many more expressive ways to express night-time through color. Even though the resolution I'm playing at is the exact resolution of my monitor, the board looks all blurry. It's hideous. Not everything benefits from low-grade bloom lighting! To compare this game's visuals outside of card-art to a Ghibli film is a massive insult to Ghibli.So yeah, even though it has pretty art assets, it fails on most ways a board game can fail in visual design.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												So What can I say about this game so I'll just start with my issues with the games 'features'-Easy to play, hard to master: Which is just another way of saying luck decides the winner. No matter how hard you try and outwit your enemy no matter how far you're in the lead one bad dice roll at a critical moment and you lose the game just like that. There really is only 2 valid strategies for each character which in turn is just different executions of the same two win conditions, either kill the king or drag the game out in what is in all essence winning by default or through cowardice( getting an early prestige lead and play keep away until someones low on health). The third win condition which is to clense the king is PURE luck that you get 4 stones before he dies of rot.-It's so called fast and thoughtful gameplay is lacking in both departments. With the amount of luck that the game is based on a 'thoughtful' strategy could just be crossing your fingers and hope the king doesn't B.S. his way into killing you. The game is no way fast-paced with 4 players each getting two turns a day before the king loses 1 health, if by fast paced they ment you constantly get killed because many things are out of control( which is why strategy is weak).-Multiply playable Heroes: but you don't get all the playable heroes unless you kickstarted the game $55, I would've been fine if the Heroes were just alternate skins of the 8 your given, but they aren't they are unique heroes just like the base ones, which is absolutely infuriating when they plan to add the 4 later as payed dlc. To put this in perspective its the same as a fighting game releasing with 12 characters, but 4 are only accessible if you preorder for twice the price of the game and they become dlc later in the year, but were on disc at the launch so you're just being baited into paying more for the rest of the game.Their physics-based dice look nice at first but like actual dice they will fall off the play area and you only know about the reroll at the last minute.The world of the board game is bland which makes sense for a board game, but when people try to call this an rpg, and a turn-based strategy it's like getting slapped in the face.In the long and narrow of this review: if they can actually make the game develop into something where luck isn't the omni-present factor to the game. I might get a second look at the game.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												Let me preface this review by saying that I absolutely LOVE the concept of the game.  It's a table top trading card game that also utilizes turn-based real time strategy.  What's not to love if you're into that sort of thing?Here's why I gave the game a no:The complete random chance.You can have a game going perfectly.  Everything is in your favor down to a T.  And then one player will draw 2-3 spell cards, spam you down and you lose with no hope of ever recovering.Or even better, you play a character such as Zosha who has a very low base health and make it to your first quest in the game halffway through.There's virtually no flow to the game.  You either get extremely lucky or you are bombarded by asinine amounts of bad luck.  You can barely commit to any of the four victory options, as the chances of succeeding at three of the four is dictated by chance. The music is good.  Sound effects?  Great.  The general balance of mechanics?  Awesome.  But the insane potential to have any amount of work you do, especially in one hour or longer PvP games undone by simple RNG is too frustrating to take this game seriously.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												Great idea, but filled with quite a few bugs. The most annoying is the audio bug where the game audio will completely turn off randomly, and won't come back until you restart the game. It's been reported several times from several people but so far they have not acknowledged it.The dev team's refusal to correct the zoomed out display is really odd. The view is zoomed in too far to see what is happening around you, and many spells will have ranges far outside of that view. When you try to zoom out, it only goes out a little bit, and lays a fog layer over the entire screen so you can't actually see what is happening. This is something that people complained about during development and since release, and the dev response was they didn't want people to play in that view, and something about 'meta-gaming'. This is a board game, you should be able to see the entire board at once. All of the information is available at default view if you manually scroll around the board, so this makes no sense.. keeping this UI limit in place only serves to irritate some players. There is absolutely no meta-gaming that can happen from changing this, because any player can see everything on the board if they manually scroll the map.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2015
												Gorgeous looking game and artwork. However, I find its gameplay not intuitive, at all. The lack of an ingame tutorial is really frustrating and left me confused at how or what to do in the first place, as the game threw me right in. Hence it was more fumbling, trying and failing than reallyplaying it. And no, I don't want or have to need to read a whole game's wiki or ingame game guide to understand the gameplay and the basic mechanics of it. That is not good design, imo and why the devs left out a (skippable) tutorial will always be a mystery to me. The slow pace of the game turns isn't helping here as well. Making one turn takes a minute for yourself, but afterwards you are reduced to watch the other AI players, guards and banes for a couple of minutes, which is really NOT fun at all, I have played it for almost two hours now and yet have not reached the round of the king dying due to everyone and their uncle on the board making their turns in real time. This is not only slow, but already reaching into the tedious category.   I might return to this game to a later time since I love its design and general idea, but for now this first impression has left a too bad taste in my mouth to continue playing it.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												This is a very clever, very pretty game. The problem is, it's not actually much fun to play.Armello is essentially a computer moderated board game, in the style of a card-driven-narrative game, like Arkham Horror. And like many games in this style, you just kind of fumble through a story, without having much control over it, or without an over-arching plot coming together.The story of Armello is supposed to be a race for the throne among four contendors. But what you actually do as you play is run from quest to quest, with each quest (and all the other action in the game) being settled by randomization elements which feel barely more strategic than a coin flip. All the rich details the game designers poured so much time into have little outcome on the game, or your tactical decisions as you play.

number of helpful: 6 of 18 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												I'm putting a 'no' in the reccomendation for this game, even though I like it very much.The reason for that is I feel like the game as it stands at release feels like an easy-mode, or intro-difficulty map, and that there should be more maps to progress into.As others have said before, many of this game's aspects are top notch: the music, the card art, the production value of taking each action, and the list goes on.  Even with all of that though, the gameplay experience is so similar each time you play that it gets too repetitive far too fast.Most games have easy maps/levels to start out with, and progress into larger, more complex, and more immersive worlds to play around in as you get farther and gain more experience on how to formulate strats to win.  Sadly, Armello has but one map, and it feels pretty homogenous each playthrough.I could see potential though through DLC expansions or future content additions.  I believe a key to making this a truly great game would be larger maps with a wider variety of tiles and an increased number of action points.  Different maps could have different sets of win conditions, and different events at the start of day and night.   A wider tile variety would be something that could be done with each map, as different areas would have their own tiles unique to that map, and that along with map variation (either choose the map or play one at random) could give players a chance to better customize which type of experience they want each game, and give each playthough a fresh feel.  I know this sounds like a tall order, and maybe even a project for Armello 2 instead of add-ons here, but the point I'm trying to make is that this game has the potential to be great.  Wheather it acheives that potential is up to the developers, and us in helping to fund them.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												I was so excited when I'd first seen promotional materials for Armello a long time ago. The art is beautiful, and the characters are lots of fun. Unfortunately, the mechanics themselves are just layer and layer of random draws. The cards you draw have symbols that may or may not be what you need to match Perils you encounter. The dice rolls don't add up, so there's no interesting bell curve. The AI feels pretty random as well.In the end it feels like there's not a lot of strategy you can bring to bear (heh); it's just riding the luck train and seeing what happens to you.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								I purchased this game because I love table-top games, and the world that this game looked like it was a rich. I was very disappointed. This is not a good game at this point in development.First, it just is not very much fun. The quests are just checks on your character stats. Each has the possibility of an extra reward, but it only comes down to luck if you get that reward or not. But it's not like there is some sort of minigame that you have to win in order to beat the quest or get the extra reward.Throughout the game you will encounter other players, but again, there is no skill here except for die rolling. You don't have any way of knowing what weapons and armor the other player possess to help you determine if you are likely to win the battle or not. The ony strategy I saw in this was to attack players low on health.There is no plot. One of the reviews said it was like game of Game of Thrones. Perhaps this would be the case if Game of Thrones was a coloring book. The animations make it look like there is a story here, like when the frog gets kinnapped or the mouse pays the soldier buringing the town. But these animations are illustrations of these mindless "quests", which take only a few seconds to stat check.Maybe this game will look better when it is finished, but at this point, I regret the purchase. I downloaded it, played it 4 times thinking I was missing something each time. What I miss is the money I paid for this disappointing game.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												I sort of felt like I was playing an overly complicated version of Candyland. Maybe with friends this could be a lot of fun, but it's pretty shallow as a solo experience. Another gripe is that the developers didn't take nearly enough advantage that this is a video game. Everything's handled by dice rolls and card draws. I'm really struggling to recall a real gameplay element that couldn't be replicated in a physical game. The art direction is nice and really pretty for the most part, but the bloom effects were sometimes a little jarring, and I was wondering what the point of the blue fog occasionally blocking my entire vision of the map was. Also, certain animated cards move way too rapidly and are very annoying and distracting on the side of your screen! Why don't they stop moving when you're not hovering over them?!?! I hate to be cruel to something so cute, but these beautiful character designs would fit better elsewhere.

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												(This is not exactly a negative review, but more of a "Meh" review. This game can be nice for you, and i liked it for quite a while. But if you don't like losing in a game, even if you did very well... then this is not a game for you... and so is Mario Kart. Also, I am not talking about every aspect of the game, just about something that has been bothering me)The fact that each player takes their turn one after the other ruins some of the fun for me. At the beginning of the game it is decided who gets to play their turn first each day/night, for the rest of the game. To me, being first gives you quite a list of advantages that outweights the advantages someone might have, that is last.Here are a couple of scenarios where this bothers me: (Note that to win the game, all you can really do is trying to shift the chances to your favor) - You can win the game by having the most prestige of all players. If there is a tie, the person that got this amount of prestige first, wins. Being first to take your turn generally gives you a better chance at getting this prestige first, giving you a better chance at winning like this in general. - You can win the game by collecting enough spirit-stones and then entering the castle. Spirit-stones will spawn each night in one of the stone-circles. The first person to take the stone gets and keeps the stone, no matter what. If the game decides that you are first overall, you have a better chance at grabbing a spirit stone, since noone else can take their turn before you do.  - The two other ways to win the game need you to kill the king. This is where it doesn't bother me just as much, but it still bothers me. Getting into the castle and killing the king is hard, but once you are inside the caste, it is always possible to kill the king. If you go inside the castle and fail to kill the king, maybe even lowering his health, this leaves a gap that everyone else can use to easily get inside the castle. First off: Being first gives you the chance to kill the king first. And it is ALWAYS possible to do so, even if not very plausible. Second off: If the first person fails to kill the king, the second person now has a good chance at entering the castle. So if you are last, you need to wait for the your turn to use this gap. Given that it takes a full day or night until they can actually enter the castle, you can only really use the gap, if someone else kills the person that's trying to get inside the castle... which can definitely happen. It's just the idea that the odds are against you there that bothers me, but it's not a big problem overall, which is why it doesn't bother me that much.Overall, Armello is really not a game that you should play with the intend to win. The odds can be against you really badly, which wouldn't bother me if a game wouldn't last ~1hour!This game is unfair, and skill won't help you out that much.This only really started bothering be after ~40h of gameplay, and it is still fun to play with friends... especially if you like torturing people. But if you play a game to win it, this is nothing for you.The pure existance of a "ranked" gamemode in Armello is just a joke.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								Armello definitely wears its board game lineage on its sleeve, but I would not say it borrows from good board games unfortunately. It's a passable single player affair, moving about the land, gradually growing more powerful, and being largely at the whims of chance. However, I really odn't understand the multiplayer focus of this title. This game has such little player interaction, particularly meaningful player interaction, that it doesn't seem like it'd be a good use of time. I would stay away.On the plus side, this game's production values are quite high. The art and music are wonderful throughout. There are a few UI qualms but for an Early Access title this is a remarkably polished game. I just think it has some fundamental design flaws, unfortunately.

content:
