Early Access Review
								I ended up returning the game for refund. It was very beautiful but it didn't really satisfy me on any level. It wasn't a long and immersive enough game to be like Talisman and it also wasn't fast-paced and exciting enough for a video game. I just felt very limited, not only by the smallness of the map but also by the limited options I had to interact with it. I also felt like all my efforts to improve my character were a total waste when another player just stormed the castle and won. When are the spirit stones ever supposed to help you win the game? There seems to be something unbalanced there. I also found a lot of the cards I was getting to not be very useful, and was just holding on to them to burn through later, which just wasn't very fun and left some of my turns totally useless.Maybe the final product will address some of these issues, but what was presented to me currently wasn't worth the price and mostly just made me want to play Talisman with friends and family rather than this.

Early Access Review
								I think it should be made clear to all potential purchasers of this game that 4 heroes are permanently unavailable to anyone who did not back the kickstarter. More words than action on their part imo. I still think this information should be made obvious to anyone considering purchasing the game and it's incredibly misleading to have such important information not mentioned on the store page and nothing but positive reviews. If the AI is fixed and the majority of heroes weren't locked away from second-class consumers I would absolutely recommend this game. As is, I don't.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Overall I'd recommend the game.... except that its not worth the current cost so I'm voting NO for the game right now. For a $5 game its awesome, for $25 it won't keep my interest long enough.The game has some interesting mechanics as many people have mentioned. The cards are not as awesome as I expected, the followers I've only seen a few of, and there aren't as many cool effects as I'd like most are just a single modifier in combat.  My biggest complaint is that it seems insanely hard to get into the castle to achive any but the easiest win condition. You must roll on 4 dice (unless you add modifiers or play (burn) cards to "set" the results)  4 specific types. If you do not, your turn ends and you must try again the next day. I spent a whole game trying to do that from the start, with +3 dice modifier and failed to do so before the game ended. This fustrates me since I don't see it being multiplayer competitive due to that reason.Battles are very short, a single dice roll and usually end with one or both players dying - defense is so much more important than offense, although the death penalty is very small, just -1 prestige. It adds an interesting element. The map is small, something I didn't realize when browsing through the game before I bought it. All in all, the game has some fun graphics, cool with the heroes being random animals, and a fairly unique game. Once again if it weren't for the cost, I'd recommend it, however it won't keep you interested for a huge amount of time. A nice indie game, not the new CoD.

number of helpful: 7 of 31 people (23%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								It looks like a decent 4 player competitive boardgame, but the actual playing experience is obnoxious.There aren't configurable settings for timers in this game. Drawing cards has an unacceptably short timer, especially if you're trying to read the cards and determine if you want to switch the type you're drawing. Trying to determine if you want to burn cards or roll dice with perils has an unacceptably short timer, and it doesn't auto-roll for you when time runs out, even though it ought to. That seems to be by developers design, and I don't really care how they feel the game should be played. If I'm playing with only friends, I want timers off, period. If I'm playing with strangers, as the game host I at least want to be able to configure the timers from fast to slow. This is a very basic screw-up here.The game lasts 18 turns, and ends otherwise. It's a race, no matter how it's presented. Some people like race games. Others HATE THEM. Unless you want to put up with a stressful and very fast paced race disguised as a board game, avoid this. Without this time limit, the random murderous NPCs traveling the board would be fine. With it, it's unacceptable.Rot is an interesting mechanic, implemented badly. It forces you to take a damage each morning turn, and there are exceedingly few ways to get rid of rot.The battle system is poorly explained. The different icons have different effects at different times, and it wouldn't kill them to display what effect each card would have at the current combat. Cards can take the place of dice, and that's not made very clear. Maybe the singleplayer tutorial covers it, but there should at least be an optional tooltip in multiplayer. Except combat has a timer, so there's no time for that anyway. Again, options to turn off timers.The UI design in this is pathetic. From burning icons, to oddities with dragging and using cards, to unclear rolling buttons, it's kind of an unholy mess.Even if they decide to patch these particular issues later, I recommend you stay away from this game and others by these developers.

								I love board games, so I was thrilled to read the great reviews for Armello. After a couple of games I am a bit disappointed. I thought it had a lot more depth, and would be very much fun to play, but it's just not my thing. Walking around is hard, because of all the mobs, mountains, etc. It's over in a blink, and then it's waiting for other players / mob's to do their things. Killing the king is very hard too, the Perils are very tough and it's easy to get killed when attacking the king.And it can be super annoying sometimes, e.g. you are almost near your quest, a Bane pops up in the night and kills you because you have one rot, he has much more, so he has so many dice it's impossible to win.In the end I had fun the first 1-2 games, but then it was just boring / annoying.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								I enjoyed the concept of Armello, but it was way too fast paced for what I was excepting. I personally would have preferred a slower take on the game working your way towards becoming ruler of the kingdom. If there was time to truly grow your character, ability to roll your stats, armor slots, and better quests. The "story" reminds me of Endless Legend where the whole "story" is driven by script quests, and no gain of knowledge or depth. At this point Armello feels like a good start, but needs refinement. Armello feels too niche too be effective. My thought would be to remove the novice feeling card system, and apply a skill, and equipment system. Graphics are beautiful and breath a breath of fresh air.6/10

number of helpful: 16 of 56 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game rules are quite confusing and a lot of stuff just doesn't get explained. How does testing an attribute work? Why am I losing health on random occasions?The large amount of mechanics don't really mix into a clever bundle of strategic options. You're just clicking around on the map for whatever opportunities you can directly take, there is no real long term plan to be made. The game will also always default to a prestige victory, because you are just not able to collect the resources needed to go after the king for any of the other victory types. Buyers remorse sets in really hard here once you realize that behind the stylish visuals, there is no refined gameplay that would keep you coming back for more board game style matches. The lack of explanation and the arbitrary mechanics don't leave a good impression of Armello.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												This game is a strait piece of garbage in my eyes and little can make me change my thinking. I regualarly play this game with my girlfriend and I see the system that this game has, it doesn't simply run on RNG, but also a favoriting system. She would win countless games back to back just cause of her fantastic good roles on dice, while my rolls would fail completely and wouldn't even dare work in my favor. She wins several RNG quests while I sit here failing to even win one. My cards I roll are garbage and mean nothing to me, while she rolls the best gear possible. I seem to get the stranger, a follower good and bad, but only when I'm going for a corruption victory. While doing so I was killed by the stranger 3 times in a row as he ran me right into stone circles, instant killing me from my corruption. I had a 1/6 chance of running into a stone circle every time, and it seems its 100% of the time. The game looks nice and plays very nicely, but with this horrible favoriting system I can't even bother to open the game up and play it again, knowning my next game will be even worse the more I play. My girlfriend fails to understand half the mechanics in the game, yet she goes on to win every single game, with little to no thought. I have AI's ruining my day every single game, while she runs around the board with little to no thought. Now if you have the RNG of a god you will find this game fantastic as it is made very well, but it's system of full RNG I cannot recommend at all. Now onto one quote from one of the developers. I heard once on the forums somewhat recently that they claimed that some people are a bit rude and don't appricate the free content. Funny thing, there has only been one, count it, one, free dlc. Patches don't count as dlc. One of the dlc was soundtrack, one was just a graphic season change, and one is adding 4 characters, and the last is the old group of characters you get from supporting ages back. I don't know much about the dev team but if that's the attitude for the entire team then it doesn't seem they care to much to the community. Now the post was on a rant from someone, but none the less, it was strait up rude, as there has only been one free dlc.Now, would I recommend it... no unless you want to sometimes bash your head into a wall every so often from the game taking a twist on everything. I would get it if it was on sale, as I said it is a good game, just poorly designed RNG mechanic.

								As a kickstarter backer I'll not do a review because I stopped playing the game when LoG decided to screw the backers in order to win additional sales from the Steam buyers.  For those who do not know the story, this game was made possible by the use of Kickstarter.  One of the perks for backing at a high level was a pack of heroes that only the backers would get.  It wasn't cheap.  However after some steam users (And I mean some) found out they decided that it wasn't fair that they didn't get the world handed to them so they ♥♥♥♥♥ed.  LoG took a look at the numbers and relaized that they were not getting any more money from the Backers so they held a fake vote to get permission from the backers to give into the steam users.  Why do I call it fake...simple....if you were holding a vote that by it's very nature took something away from someone who paid for it...you'd think they'd limit the vote to only those peope....no LoG decided to allow anyone and everyone to vote regardless if it effected them or not.  By that very nature the vote was rigged and unfair.  We backers got screwed and LoG is now able to make more money.  Only bright side is LoG will NEVER be able to run a  kickstarter again, that bridge is burned down, smashed, dropped in a deep hole and will never see the light of day again.Because I cannot do business with a company that breaks it's promises for money and lies about the full details I cannot recommend this game to anyone.  I stopped playing it as soon as they announced the farce of a decision and will never reinstall it again.  So feel free to take my 'Review' how you will.  I should also point out that I'll delete any flame replies from Steam Children.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												Armello is set in a fantastical medieval world where animals rule, and dark magic is at works to corrupt the inhabitants of the kingdom, starting with the king.I love this game, simply put. Its a strategic and backstabbing tabletop game in videogame format. I highly recommend playing with friends over voicechat to listen to their sweet sweet rage. Would you chose to play against the AI, the AI will provide a few enjoyable games until you learn the game and understand how the AI works. The graphical astryle is beautiful, the music is fitting and easy on the ears. The story bits weaved into the game itself are enjoyable to discover and the game is fluid to play, interface works amazingly well and provides all information that you need.There are a few issues to adress. Most importantly some balancing issues, albeit very slight ones but things that I am hoping the developer will adress in the future perhaps. As it stands, combat is the way to go in this game, especially against AI or online players, when you don't have that dimension of talking directly to your opponents/friends and messing with them. Additionally, ocassional sound tearing/repeating appears for me, and I think it has to do with alt tabbing. Thankfully nothing too problematic. I have not encountered any bugs or similiar. Lastly, I think this game needs to grow its player base. While you can find games with patience, you sadly can't log in any time and hope to get a game in a minute.If you're a fan of either strategy, boardgames, animals, backstabbing, fantasy settings or fun, I highly recommend this game.1.2 update: The developer has adressed quite a few of the issues I have mentioned, and is actively working on balancing the game out, as well as adding additional free content. I am glad to see this game didn't just get launched and abandoned!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												Armello is certainly an interesting game, to say the least.We'll start with the story:Armello is a land plague by The Rot, a corruption that feeds on life force. Playing through the prologue gives you a wonderful tutorial, as well as the enjoyable story itself.Gameplay:The game itself is unique, differing from turn-based stragetgy games like Sid Meier's Civilization by adding a dice system. Players can burn cards to ensure they get a roll they like for single dice, and roll the rest, randomly getting fighting results. In addition, you can customize your battles and dice rolls with Equipment cards, and your Party cards.While turns can take a little while, you do have the ability to play cards from your hand during anybody's turn, dealing damage, laying traps, or buffing your own hero. The game generally has a dusk/dawn system, with the game generally ending at the 10th Dawn. Each player acts during the dawn phase, then the time rolls over to dusk, where turns reset, granting new advantages between day and night cycles. The game gets a little repetitive after several games, with only 8 heros to choose from. The tile-randomization on the map is helpful, as well as the starting trinkets you choose to buff your character, but unless new heros are added soon, you might quickly find yourself bored. Multiplayer can provide a different challenge from the story mode AI, and is generally similar to Civ V in that respect. It's fun, but may not be for everybody.Graphics and Sound:The soundtrack is beautiful to listen to, and is relaxing to listen to. The sounds that play during character animations are pleasant as well, and very suiting, especially with the game's art style. The artwork of the game is beautiful. Cards have animated graphics, Heros and NPCs alike have unique animations. The cartoony and furry-esque themed style is adorable, and can easily captivate those who find fluffy creatures cute.OVERALL, I'd recommend getting this game, especially when it's on sale, although I feel the $20 pricing is justified. The game is fun, but it does need a tad more content -- namely, a few more cards and heroes would be nice.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												I have picked this game up in a sale, because it looked like a great game. When I first started it up I was very excited. The music and the artwork were amazing. The animations were smooth and looked nice and the characters were diverse and looked unique.After a few games though I started noticing a rather agitating patern. Almost every game I played ended the same way, a prestige victory. The game is so chance based, in both the rolls and cards that it is incredibly difficult to get enough good gear and stats to defeat the king. Not just that, but try to go for the spirit stone or rot victory and it becomes even harder since you need to collect even more stuff.The dice roll mechanic looks like a fun idea, but with a 1/2 chance of getting an attack and 1/6 chance of getting a defence, with the possibility of getting infinite attacks with the dice-explosion, it becomes incredibly difficult to stay alive. Even with 8 dice you can still easily see yourself losing against 4, which can be infuriating.The world looks amazing and I love the characters, but with every aspect of the game being affected by chance takes away part of the fun. It's a real shame, because the game looks amazing and the music is great. If it wasn't so heavily influenced by chance it would be a way better game than it is now.

												I really enjoy this game, and I plan on playing it ALOT more after I put this review online. When you pick up the game without playing the prologue (Didn't even try that just jumped into it) its a bit disorientating at first, but you learn pretty quickly how to play the game and strengthen your character. What is really nice is that there is a way for everyone's playstyle to win. For the Fighters you can just fight the king (Very tough in the early game) For the Questers you can always go after spirit stones or just gain Prestige. The Cunning or Ruthless theres a Rot battle with the king or just making sure that when the king and his oppenent die you're the one that gets the crown hehe. What I think needs improvement is the amount of characters you can select from, or the power to create your own. Combat is enjoyable though, its really D&D style with the roll of the dice. Overall its a really great game with wonderful animation and artistic style and great gameplay. A good game to play with friends. 9 out of 10 Spirit Stones :3

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
												TLDR: Recommended ONLY if it is on sale for 50% or so, or if you are a fan of playing board games with family/friends. Very pretty game that can be quite engaging the first times you play it. However, stay clear if you are not a fan of "luck based" games, if you just want to singleplay to play it everyday AND if you expect to win every session. That won't happen. Full review:It can be horribly unfair, or it can be downright cake walk, like a lot of board games out there this game will really test your luck. Sometimes you may start out with a lot of gold, thus you then would base your play method on playing a lot of trick cards to troll the other Heroes while you focus on getting prestige or something else. Other times you may get a very rare and strong equipment cards, to the point where (as it happened to me on one session) in a few turns you could get a combo that gives you 9 shields at the start of every battle, making you pretty much unkillable in that way (they can still kill you with spells/traps/etc however). And other times... well, you may get killed before the next dawn over and over. Traps, unlucky dice rolls, getting quest objectives that are on the other side of the map of where you are... and maybe then the King and his "favorite" Hero will decide on next turn to strip you off all your cards or gold! Fun times indeed.No single game session is the same, which is actually a good thing since it won't feel repetitive too fast gameplay-wise, and the game uses a card system for your items and spells, and they all come with animated pictures which are overall beautiful to look at. Overall, the art and design of this game is its best aspect in my opinion.Unfortunately, it does get repetitive on other areas. For example, the game is really lacking on type of "tiles" for the map (maybe something like water tiles which take 2 AP but make you immune to spells? or maybe something like a Dungeon-Fort that awards you with an item/card if you manage to defeat a strong enemy in it? just a few examples out of my mind right now), and on map diversity as well, with there only being 2 map types (normal and winter, which are only for asthetic porpuses), it really gets dull fast and it really feels like more could have been done with these aspects.Length of each session is what I believe "enough". The game has a sort of turn limit since each day the King will get weaker and weaker until his health is depleted which ends the game session unless someone kills/banishes the king before that. This usually takes about 20 turns or so and overall each session tends to last about 2-3 hours depending on how fast players play their turns. After playing it for a while (say, 7-8 full game sessions) it will probably become too repetitive on its visuals, but gameplay should still feel fun and fresh every time you play, especially if you play with other people rather than the AI.Nice game with evident flaws, but nothing that cannot be polished on future updates. And even if they aren't, its still a good game to play once every now and then especially with other people as you would with any board game.

Each player acts during the dawn phase, then the time rolls over to dusk, where turns reset, granting new advantages between day and night cycles. The game gets a little repetitive after several games, with only 8 heros to choose from. The tile-randomization on the map is helpful, as well as the starting trinkets you choose to buff your character, but unless new heros are added soon, you might quickly find yourself bored. Multiplayer can provide a different challenge from the story mode AI, and is generally similar to Civ V in that respect. It's fun, but may not be for everybody.Graphics and Sound:The soundtrack is beautiful to listen to, and is relaxing to listen to. The sounds that play during character animations are pleasant as well, and very suiting, especially with the game's art style. The artwork of the game is beautiful. Cards have animated graphics, Heros and NPCs alike have unique animations. The cartoony and furry-esque themed style is adorable, and can easily captivate those who find fluffy creatures cute.OVERALL, I'd recommend getting this game, especially when it's on sale, although I feel the $20 pricing is justified. The game is fun, but it does need a tad more content -- namely, a few more cards and heroes would be nice.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												Armello's greatest strength is that it is a creative, artistic, and inspiring game that keeps those who love it coming back for more. It's greatest weakness is that not everyone loves it. As obvious as this might sound, it's important to remember that almost every critisism that can be made against this video game is a direct result of the fact that it's not really a video game. It's a board game taking clever advantage of those aspects that make a video game appealing (gorgeous art style, beautiful music, engaging role-play). If you don't like board games, and need to be blowing things up and mowing enemies down in order to enjoy yourself (which is fine) then Armello is not the game for you.Not to say that this game has no action, though; far from it. The wonderful animations and clever and strategic use of dice and cards make every moment of combat a thrill, providing you like games that inspire creativity and tactical thinking. The politics, sabotage and subterfuge of Armello create an atmosphere of cunning and conniving that incite excitement every game. Playing with friends takes things a step further, as you finally find out what it's like to battle so-called friends for the crown of a wonderous but dangerous fantasy world.In short, if you like creativity, board game-style strategy, or political fantasy, Armello will be a sure and certain gaming treat. If not, that's a pity.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												This is a really thematic, enjoyable game to play.  There are three (though the devs say four) different ways to win, combined with eight playable characters (minus the Bandit Clan), which makes for a nice variety of strategy and playstyle options.  If playing against the AI the game is on the easy side (I've only ever lost to the AI once), so at least for me, the challenge comes not from winning but figuring out the best way to maximize my winning potential with the setup I choose.  The randomly generated environments are another nice touch for interesting gameplay and almost infinite replay value.  Visually the game looks beautiful and fits the theme very well, and the music is good, providing a nice audio background.  It's not too exciting but it gets the job done.  Games last about an hour, which is just right for this kind of game; not too short, but not so long it gets burdensome, and if you don't have enough time to get a round in you can save and pick it up later.The game isn't perfect, though.  While I am a big fan of board games in general and this is great for a video board game, it's just the nature of video board games that you're going to spend a lot of time waiting for the other players to take their turn.  It doesn't help that again, if you're playing against AI, even if you're set to fast AI turns and watching the dice roll during battles, the AI players' turns can be boring and take a long time to resolve.  As for multiplayer, the lack of local hotseat multiplayer is a big let-down.   The last potential negative I see is something I don't mind, given that I do like these kinds of games, but others may be annoyed by it:  you do have stats that you build and quests you go on to increase them, but luck remains a sizeable factor in the outcome of the game:  dice are rolled and cards are drawn, and while you can increase your maximum hand of cards or number of dice you have in battle or during trap tests, if the dice don't roll your way or someone else gets the awesome card you're looking for, you may still potentially lose the game.  Part of the strategy and fun for me is figuring out ways to work around that, and it's not too hard to do so and still win, but it can get frustrating when you're trying to win in a certain way in order to unlock a ring or amulet.This game is already great fun, and I would definitely recommend it, though I do see great potential for expanisions in the future to make it even better, adding characters, cards and/or different mechanics and scenarios.  If they do add more expansions (I know there is the Bandit Clan but I don't have it) I'm definitely going to pick it up!  Here's hoping for more in the future!

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Sometimes, you really just want more of the same—as long as it's also different each time. It's why people keep playing chess, for instance. Armello is not chess, to be sure, but like that timeless game, it's easy to learn—thanks to a thoughtfully implemented tutorial—and offers seemingly endless variation. I've not tried the multiplayer yet mind you, and that's largely due to the extremely engaging SP mode. The game's visuals are simply beautiful. Unless anything less sombre-looking than Diablo (I & II) is garish to you, the cute anthropomorphic animals that populate Armello's virtual game board and the charmingly animated playing cards (that's right, the cards are animated, and each one features a unique flavor text to boot) will bring a smile to your face. The hex-based landscape on which your quest for the throne plays out varies with the seasons and features a day/night cycle (with gorgeous sunset/rise) that also affects certain aspects of gameplay. But what makes Armello such a joy is the interesting way all its moving parts come together in your pursuit of victory. Set traps for your rivals, mess with their stats, steal cards and followers from them, fight, sneak, backstab—or become more corrupted than the mad king you're all trying to replace. Of all the titles I've tried that emulate a board game, Armello is easily the most fun and lovingly designed.

												Armello is set in a fantastical medieval world where animals rule, and dark magic is at works to corrupt the inhabitants of the kingdom, starting with the king.I love this game, simply put. Its a strategic and backstabbing tabletop game in videogame format. I highly recommend playing with friends over voicechat to listen to their sweet sweet rage. Would you chose to play against the AI, the AI will provide a few enjoyable games until you learn the game and understand how the AI works. The graphical astryle is beautiful, the music is fitting and easy on the ears. The story bits weaved into the game itself are enjoyable to discover and the game is fluid to play, interface works amazingly well and provides all information that you need.There are a few issues to adress. Most importantly some balancing issues, albeit very slight ones but things that I am hoping the developer will adress in the future perhaps. As it stands, combat is the way to go in this game, especially against AI or online players, when you don't have that dimension of talking directly to your opponents/friends and messing with them. Additionally, ocassional sound tearing/repeating appears for me, and I think it has to do with alt tabbing. Thankfully nothing too problematic. I have not encountered any bugs or similiar. Lastly, I think this game needs to grow its player base. While you can find games with patience, you sadly can't log in any time and hope to get a game in a minute.If you're a fan of either strategy, boardgames, animals, backstabbing, fantasy settings or fun, I highly recommend this game.1.2 update: The developer has adressed quite a few of the issues I have mentioned, and is actively working on balancing the game out, as well as adding additional free content. I am glad to see this game didn't just get launched and abandoned!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Rarely will you find such a magnificent translation of a board game into the video game format. Armello streamlines a lot of the usual rules-crunching required for in-depth board game play, leaving the players of this 4-player king-of-the-hill skirmish with only the task of figuring out the best way to achieve one of the many victory states before the other players do.Wrapped in the aesthetic of what amounts to Game Of Thrones crossed with Disney's Robin Hood, Armello makes for a wonderful competitive 4-player experience. WIth a variety of player characters to choose from, each with their own strengths and challenges, there's something in this game for every kind of player. Whether you choose the combat-centered wolf clan or the sneaky, backstabbing rat clan, there's no doubt that your playstyle will be catered to by the numerous options available to every character.Whether it's with friends, with strangers online or even on your own, the game is easy enough to dive into for single hour sessions at a time, and there are a lot of unlockable trinkets that spice up the gameplay to be earned the more matches you play. (Not win... just play!)About the only criticism I personally have with the game is that sometimes victory can often be decided by a single roll of the dice, negating a whole game's worth of effort in one turn. Luckily this is a two-way streak, as I've often won rounds of this game completely unintentionally simply by sitting idly by and watching the dice toll out defeat for my rivals for me.You'll be hard pressed to find very many more video games that pull off what Armello is trying to do: bringing the multiplayer board game experience into the versatile mutiplayer landscape of Steam and online gaming! Don't miss it!

												Very nice, very niche game, gameplay is a solid RPG-flavored turn-based strategy board game with an emphasis on dice rolling, card/hand management, item collecting and adapting your playstyle on the fly since there is a heavy amount of RNG; how the map is laid out, what quests you get, what items you get, what spawns where, etc. While there isn't much of a story, the setting is immensely thought out, and the art style of the game is undeniably charming and amazingly detailed. I would pay a lot of money for a graphic novel or animated film set in this world.Online multiplayer is somewhat barren, but it's easier to find a game than you might think and if you can convince three friends to buy it for private games, it will last you quite a few - thought, admittedly, the gameplay can get somewhat repetitive as the roster is small and the overall structure of the game is fairly simplistic. Definitely worth it if you're into strategy and/or RPG games, and like multiplayer.  Or if you have an unhealthy obsession with anthro designs.

Posted: June 8, 2016
Recommended: A boardgame with solid mechanics; however, not recommended if playing as a single-player game due to current lack of content.Oh Armello, you have good mechanics that could lend themselves to a solid game experience, but your "board" limits your content. To all those thinking about purchasing this game, I would recommend that you consider if you will be playing multiplayer with friends. If not, then it might not be worth it for you -- unless it is on sale. Here's why:Armello gives you several solid character mechanics, a questing system, multiple victory objectives and a good, quick combat system. The problem is that the board and the rules regarding the king often do not vary enough to make individual games feel "unique" when playing against the somewhat passive AI. When playing the game in single player, you will feel as if you have seen just about all content near the 5-6 hour mark, with only token attempts by the AI to kill you. If you are aiming for a strategy to win the game within 6 or 7 turns, the AI will be entirely helpless and you will win the game easily. In order to vary up the game, I think that a different board design, with some additional rules that are unique to board-types would go a long way.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												Armello not only creates a great board game in the digital space but expands on it in a way that should become the standard of how to take advantage of being digital and not tied down to physical board game restrictions. This great looking board game quickly takes the throne not only in the digital board game place but rivals the physical board game kingdom in many ways. The story is Game of Thrones with animals is the best way I heard it explained and I have to mostly agree with that has some fairy tale elements that help with the story’s background. The story is that the once great king (Who is a Lion of course) has become corrupted from the “rot” that has started plaguing the land. This leaves our heroes from different clans (from rabbits or bears, oh my!) to rise and either fight, sway, or take on the rot itself to become the new king. The graphics are the first thing to grab you and they never let go. From the opening video to the end wrap-up screen, this game is gorgeous. Everywhere from the menus, the board and the cute and deadly creatures hopping and running around. This game is just amazing visually. Even the cards are beautiful and have animations that are capitating. This to me is up there even with Rise of the Tomb Raider or The Division for art direction.The music is well done while there isn’t much in regards to sound effects or voice work. Does it need them? Not really, and honestly depending on how the voices would be handled could of been a negative. There is no doubt the graphics are where the effort was put in with this small studio and I’m quite happy with what has been done with it so far.The gameplay is very solid. It was everything a good board game has plus a few extras that a physical board game would have trouble pulling off well, that is handled flawlessly in this game like the guards and banes actions between day and night rounds. The game starts with you choosing a character that each has their own different abilities and stats. Some share some passive abilities depending on if they are members of the Day or Night clans. They all have a different feel and have you approach things differently during the game. After choosing some rings that give you different bonuses, that are unlocked from playing games and reaching achievements like wins and playing different characters, you with three other players or AI opponents are placed in one of the four starting places on the board. On you turn you have three action points that relate to movement and attacking while also playing cards as equipment, spells, or trickery/diplomatic schemes to pull ahead of the competition. The way you win is mostly two fold with some variations to the situation that you can push your luck to get to a bit quicker. You either defeat the king in combat, and survive, or you gain the most prestige points before the King dies. There is a spirit stone victory that skips the fighting if you have collected four spirt stones that will instantly win you the game or win against the King while having more rot than he does (this seems to be more of a challenge victory type than a practical one). You can improve the ability to get to the king and defeat him by completing quest that require you to reach a place on the board and have a dice roll based on your character’s stats in a given category. These will give you an item and stats increase if you succeed that will help you on your way; but the main reason to complete them is it allows you into the castle to face the King without completing a high risk and difficult event. The game plays well with everything being well explained and straight forward. The multiplayer right now seems a little buggy as I have had disconnects on most of the games I have played and also requires four human opponents (It would be nice to have the AI jump in if needed). There is quite a bit of down time and with the Hearthstone chat feature where you can select predetermined quotes from the characters, you can feel a little lonely waiting for you turn. I would suggest if playing with friends to use Skype or another third-party chat program to help pass the time.In conclusion this is a must buy if you enjoy board games and want something on the PC or home console. It offers good gameplay with a fantastic visual presentation that you will never get tired of, I have put in over fifteen hours into it so far and keep wanting to play more. It is also great the developers continue adding features and content along with community events. I like how more and more developers are using the online space to office this dynamic content to keep their games fresh. Story/Theme – Outstanding fantasy theme with cute animals with a little bit of an edge.Graphics – Currently the best looking digital board game but also on of the best visual designs in games.Sound/Music – Good music not much elseGameplay – Good solid board game mechanics with good use of being digitalPros – Theme/Gameplay/GraphicsCons – not many sound effects and online still could use a little workShould you buy it? – Yes, for anyone that enjoys board games or great looking strategy games.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Armello is a fun, relaxed strategy game, one of those whose rules are relatively simple to grasp, but that allows for a number of viable strategies to emerge. I like it because a multiplayer game takes from 45 minutes to an hour or so to play, making it a good way to relax at the end of a workday or when downtime presents itself. Each of the heroes feels fairly well balanced; although some dominant strategies have emerged in multiplayer games, smart players have multiple ways to disrupt one another's pursuit of the throne. In single player games, the AI is competent, and it's a good way to experiment with different streategies, although the true meat of the game is multiplayer. The art is fantastic and the music quite nice.If you can't stand losing a strategy game due to the luck of the die or the draw of the card, this one might not be for you. Because of these random elements, it's difficult to come into a game with a solid strategy, and adapatability is required. If you could customize your card deck, a more reliable strategy might be possible. For me, these elements are not a problem. Another downnside to the game at this point (Jan 2015) is that it can be difficult at times to find partners for a skirmish match. It would be nice to be able to fill out a random group with an AI player or two as you can in private games.I hope in the near future we'll see ranked multiplayer, bringing a sense of progress to multiplayer games. In the meantime, Armello remains a great way to realx with a lite but challenging turn-based strategy game.

Visually the game looks beautiful and fits the theme very well, and the music is good, providing a nice audio background.  It's not too exciting but it gets the job done.  Games last about an hour, which is just right for this kind of game; not too short, but not so long it gets burdensome, and if you don't have enough time to get a round in you can save and pick it up later.The game isn't perfect, though.  While I am a big fan of board games in general and this is great for a video board game, it's just the nature of video board games that you're going to spend a lot of time waiting for the other players to take their turn.  It doesn't help that again, if you're playing against AI, even if you're set to fast AI turns and watching the dice roll during battles, the AI players' turns can be boring and take a long time to resolve.  As for multiplayer, the lack of local hotseat multiplayer is a big let-down.   The last potential negative I see is something I don't mind, given that I do like these kinds of games, but others may be annoyed by it:  you do have stats that you build and quests you go on to increase them, but luck remains a sizeable factor in the outcome of the game:  dice are rolled and cards are drawn, and while you can increase your maximum hand of cards or number of dice you have in battle or during trap tests, if the dice don't roll your way or someone else gets the awesome card you're looking for, you may still potentially lose the game.  Part of the strategy and fun for me is figuring out ways to work around that, and it's not too hard to do so and still win, but it can get frustrating when you're trying to win in a certain way in order to unlock a ring or amulet.This game is already great fun, and I would definitely recommend it, though I do see great potential for expanisions in the future to make it even better, adding characters, cards and/or different mechanics and scenarios.  If they do add more expansions (I know there is the Bandit Clan but I don't have it) I'm definitely going to pick it up!  Here's hoping for more in the future!

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												This game may or may not be to your tastes, but if this is the sort of thing you're into you'll have a blast.  The artwork and music are beautiful, and they lend a lot of weight to the world and characters (although the lore really is just a flavorful backdrop; don't expect to get sucked in by the story or anything.)  It's a digital board game with some light RPG elements, where your goal is to succeed the current king of Armello, who is suffering from a magical corruption that is driving him mad and slowly killing him.  There are multiple paths to victory, which means there's usually a way for you to pursue victory even if your first choice doesn't work out.  It's not enough to go after the king, though.  You need to be laying traps, making opportunistic attacks, and generally just screwing over the other players as much as possible.Combat in the game is extremely lethal, and there is a heavy element of randomness to the whole game, both of which can cause some frustration; both of those factors do make the game more exciting, though.  Think of it like the board game that it is, not a competitive esport - sometimes victory just goes to whoever rolls best, and that's okay.  You're just there to have a good time.

												Pretty good PC based board game, with (currently) four 'clans' and two heroes in each so there is a fairly varied selection for a 4 person game along with several* win conditions. Start your turn, draw some cards, move a couple of hexes/spaces to either explore dungeons (good and bad item draws), claim towns (+1 gold), cast spells or lay traps, attack players/banes/kings guard or if you have the right stuff the king himself. There are a some issues I have with the game tho, one being the only viable/fun victory conditions are Kingslayer (kill the king) or Prestige (rack up points and wait out the clock). The other two are pretty much a fetch quest or one that relies too much on the games RNG and certain conditions on top of that only like 1 in 100 games are finished that way... Another issue I have is that the heroes/clans are kinda...bland maybe the word im looking for? They all share the same deck of cards without unique cards belonging to certain clans/heros, even if the clans had the same decks but modified amounts of each card I fell would bring some extra flavor to the table. Over all I really enjoy and cant wait to see whats next, but would really like to see something along the lines of an LCG element added to flesh out the world.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												Sometimes, you really just want more of the same—as long as it's also different each time. It's why people keep playing chess, for instance. Armello is not chess, to be sure, but like that timeless game, it's easy to learn—thanks to a thoughtfully implemented tutorial—and offers seemingly endless variation. I've not tried the multiplayer yet mind you, and that's largely due to the extremely engaging SP mode. The game's visuals are simply beautiful. Unless anything less sombre-looking than Diablo (I & II) is garish to you, the cute anthropomorphic animals that populate Armello's virtual game board and the charmingly animated playing cards (that's right, the cards are animated, and each one features a unique flavor text to boot) will bring a smile to your face. The hex-based landscape on which your quest for the throne plays out varies with the seasons and features a day/night cycle (with gorgeous sunset/rise) that also affects certain aspects of gameplay. But what makes Armello such a joy is the interesting way all its moving parts come together in your pursuit of victory. Set traps for your rivals, mess with their stats, steal cards and followers from them, fight, sneak, backstab—or become more corrupted than the mad king you're all trying to replace. Of all the titles I've tried that emulate a board game, Armello is easily the most fun and lovingly designed.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												This is a beautifull imagined strategic board game. each player selects an animal hero to play, which can belong to one of animal clans (2 rabbits, 2 wolves, 2 bears, 2 rats). In the middle stands a corrupted king that will die after a certain amount of turns. You move between the hexes engaging with events in the hex, exploring dungeons for new followers and equipment, or gaining prestige with the animal clans, to help secure your own leadership when the king succumbs. You can also become corrupted yourself and beat the king at his own game, becoming the lord of corruption by killing him.players aren't directly against eachother, and there are some cards that work best on another player you are currently friendly with. Each of the clans lends itself to styles of plays and/or certain victory conditions. the game is very well realized, with very little superfluous mechanics, and very well balanced asymetrical gameplay.if you have ever played talisman, digital or the board game, you will appreciate this game. Where talisman is weak, in its range of poorly balanced classes and superfluous additional content; Armello succeeds on its personality, depth of play and adherence to the core cycle of the gameplay. It is beautiful to look at, listen to and play.the only knock against it, is the lack of voice acting and hotseat multiplayer.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												It got a nice traditional feeling of a strategy board game spot on.I love the characters as they are pretty different and interesting to play around with.There's load of strategy into it and you can really dive deep into planning your strategies.The combat feels nice, rather fluent.It got RNG but also a nice decision making thanks to the burning cards feature.The king doesn't feel weak or way to strong once you've played a few matches you can see that he is a good main objective to try to kill.The ring system feels a tad odd but seems to work well in the game.Gold seems to be the main cost and it makes it feel a bit linear for resource but it actually works well balanced wise (So far what I've seen atleast)The speed up option is really nice for AI games when you're alone and don't want to think to much though to do any good in this game you need to watch what everyone else does.I love the stats system as it works perfectly for making different ways to play and what ways you wanna take in for example quests.A negative point is the AI behaviour in some games are very linear and well for example all three of them will hard focus you when you are already having a hard time winning. Some of the king choices feel a bit weird and there should be more options! It feels like there is to few.The kings guard feel rather weak when you're inside the castle and I feels like they should be a BIGGER threat in the castle and even at settlements.More hereos would be nice, three for every clan would make every game way more different and just add to the fun!The game clearly need more options when it comes to fullscreen/windowed fullscreen/windowed.The game has problems with multiple screens as the cursor moves the overview with the cursor touching the edges of your screen and not the game which makes the mouse leave the game and move over to the other screen and well moves the view but you go out of the game with your mouse.The option to have the game muted while it is in the background would be highly appreciated!

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												Armello is a thematic combination of Game of Thrones and Redwall and as a digital board game its very hard to not enjoy each of your turns as there's almost always something you can do. It is a very polished and enjoyable game. That said I do have some things that bother me about it.It becomes slightly tedious watching each other players' turns at the same speed as you take yours and the veiw limitations of the game board seem strange when veiwing through a large monitor. This essentially means you are spending 3/4 of your time playing the game watching your opponents (if you can even see them). While it is valuable that you pay attention to what your opponents do, sometimes it becomes a chore. The other issue is how the board will not allow you to zoom out and see more of it, and when you try it becomes blurry and unfocused. This defeats the purpose of the board game style.Another issue is that there are far to few settings for video customization. Personally I find it especially irksome that there is no borderless windowed mode.I am eagerly looking forward to any DLC or changes that they make to this game to improve on these faults and polish this gem of a game, however so far the developers have made no effort to rectify these issues I've mentioned. In fact I have been told they refuse to remedy the zooming veiw issue, citing that it is done on purpose to force players to use the ridiculously close zoom.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												Armello is a beautiful game with a fun story and compelling characters, but the RNG makes me not want to play - and I've played nearly 20 hours since I got it. I would've played more if I hadn't had work/school, but recently it's been less fun. I've noticed that in battle the opponent will get many many more rolls of the dice than I will - not that they'll have more dice to start with, but they'll get more Wylds (or rots, if it's a Bane) and more appropriate suns/moons, and more shields. Basically, even though we'll start out with a respectable number of dice each, when it comes down to what hits land and what shields go up, the AI will generally be massively better off than I am. This is not to say that I expect to win every time, but there's a difference between being outplayed and being just ripped off by the RNG. It takes the fun out of the game.It's worth noting that the randomness everywhere else in the game seems even - the quests are spread out, the dungeons yield a fair spread, and so on. It's just the battle RNG, and the perils as well, though to a slightly lesser extent. Armello Devs, please do something about this, because I really love the game and want to recommend it to everyone WITHOUT having to warn them that the RNG is kind of bogus.

Posted: February 11, 2016
												Armello is set in a fantastical medieval world where animals rule, and dark magic is at works to corrupt the inhabitants of the kingdom, starting with the king.I love this game, simply put. Its a strategic and backstabbing tabletop game in videogame format. I highly recommend playing with friends over voicechat to listen to their sweet sweet rage. Would you chose to play against the AI, the AI will provide a few enjoyable games until you learn the game and understand how the AI works. The graphical astryle is beautiful, the music is fitting and easy on the ears. The story bits weaved into the game itself are enjoyable to discover and the game is fluid to play, interface works amazingly well and provides all information that you need.There are a few issues to adress. Most importantly some balancing issues, albeit very slight ones but things that I am hoping the developer will adress in the future perhaps. As it stands, combat is the way to go in this game, especially against AI or online players, when you don't have that dimension of talking directly to your opponents/friends and messing with them. Additionally, ocassional sound tearing/repeating appears for me, and I think it has to do with alt tabbing. Thankfully nothing too problematic. I have not encountered any bugs or similiar. Lastly, I think this game needs to grow its player base. While you can find games with patience, you sadly can't log in any time and hope to get a game in a minute.If you're a fan of either strategy, boardgames, animals, backstabbing, fantasy settings or fun, I highly recommend this game.1.2 update: The developer has adressed quite a few of the issues I have mentioned, and is actively working on balancing the game out, as well as adding additional free content. I am glad to see this game didn't just get launched and abandoned!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												I don't normally write reviews for games, but I felt that I should write one for Armello. A lot of what I'm going to say has already mostly been said by the other reviewers, but here goes anyway.TLDR for the quick-lookers: I recommend this game in CAUTION, with the understanding that while it's a great game, the chances of you becoming frustrated and potentially losing a lot are high. If you don't care about that, go for it.Armello is essentially a game of chess mixed with a little bit of DnD, Blood Bowl, and Settlers of Catan. You choose 1 Hero out of 4 different clans (Rabbit, Wolf, Bear, Rat) in order to compete for the crown of the dying King, which takes place over a certain number of turns as the King's health declines each morning through a day/night cycle. The art style is fantastic, with beautifully crafted cards that come to life with subtle 2D animation, and wonderful 3D animations on the player characters that exude personality.In my opinion, Armello really centers around making the most of a bad situation. You'll die, fail quests, get hurt by Perils (essentially "challenges" which you roll dice to get out of), and get your♥♥♥♥♥♥occasionally handed to you by other competing heroes. The RNG is rather infamous for being crushingly difficult at times - so much so that I've tried really hard to not rage-quit my way out of the game instead of just trying to finish what I started. Notable of the RNG's ruthlessness is the fact that 1 face of a 6-sided die is a shield symbol (1 Shield blocks 1 Attack), whereas 4 other sides are potential attacks (Sun, Moon, Wyld, Sword), with the remaining side being a miss (Rot or Wyld - the symbol that's a miss changes depending on your playstyle). And then if it's night, the Suns count as misses, whereas if it's day, the Moons are misses. Long story short, if your Hero's max health is really low, you have more of a chance of dying unless you have the proper items and/or your fight stat is high enough to protect yourself with.In spite of all this, it's what you do in the given situation that can determine whether or not you can press on and maybe even win, or just make it really difficult for your opponents to win. A lot of it depends on whether or not the RNG is feeling particularly forgiving however, which is one aspect of the game which can be insanely frustrating at best and close-game rage-inducing at the worst.I really would've liked to have seen more story come out of this world that the game has created, and the little tidbits you get from each character's quest is great. But in my opinion there's not enough of it, and I think an expanded story mode added to the game would've been cool. Plus, there could've been more beautiful cutscenes besides the opening movie. This is all personal opinion and I understand the Devs can't work out of their financial constraints, however.Pros:-Great art style, cool character designs, amazing 2D art-While it's only 1 map, it's randomized each time and the season can be either winter or fall, which gives each game a refreshing new look and feel-The AI is competent enough that single player games are fun and exciting-Great fun to play with friends-Can play the Devs on their Twitch channel!-Different paths to victory allows you to create different strategies to winningCons:-RNG can be difficult and punishing, could benefit from some dice balancing-The AI is fickle and will take random personal vendettas against you even when you've done nothing to them (I'm looking at you, River)-Online multiplayer community is very small, so you have to hound your friends to get the game if you want to play with real people-The Prestige victory is WAY too easy to win for characters with high Fight stat - could be balanced a bit-No expanded story mode - would've been cool to see more of the world and the characters interacting

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Rarely will you find such a magnificent translation of a board game into the video game format. Armello streamlines a lot of the usual rules-crunching required for in-depth board game play, leaving the players of this 4-player king-of-the-hill skirmish with only the task of figuring out the best way to achieve one of the many victory states before the other players do.Wrapped in the aesthetic of what amounts to Game Of Thrones crossed with Disney's Robin Hood, Armello makes for a wonderful competitive 4-player experience. WIth a variety of player characters to choose from, each with their own strengths and challenges, there's something in this game for every kind of player. Whether you choose the combat-centered wolf clan or the sneaky, backstabbing rat clan, there's no doubt that your playstyle will be catered to by the numerous options available to every character.Whether it's with friends, with strangers online or even on your own, the game is easy enough to dive into for single hour sessions at a time, and there are a lot of unlockable trinkets that spice up the gameplay to be earned the more matches you play. (Not win... just play!)About the only criticism I personally have with the game is that sometimes victory can often be decided by a single roll of the dice, negating a whole game's worth of effort in one turn. Luckily this is a two-way streak, as I've often won rounds of this game completely unintentionally simply by sitting idly by and watching the dice toll out defeat for my rivals for me.You'll be hard pressed to find very many more video games that pull off what Armello is trying to do: bringing the multiplayer board game experience into the versatile mutiplayer landscape of Steam and online gaming! Don't miss it!

Posted: March 29
												I enjoy this game quite a bit. I've play roughly equal amounts of single player and multplayer games. It's fun to get the mystery chests from multiplayer games but I still think it's worth the money even if you just play single player. The AI isn't bad, and I've won and lost games against it. If you like strategic boards games in general, this is a good one to venture online with. I usually play one game at a time, maybe two, and time varies but I'd say between half an hour and one hour to finish the game. Turns are set so there is a cap on how long a game can be.The visuals are delightful. The board is pretty and the character movements are smooth. It can take a bit of waiting while NPC's resolve their own rolls (which you can choose to watch or not). I'm often spending that time looking through my cards and deciding what I might want to do for my turn. The music is not obstusive, and makes a good ambience for the game.Just the Vanilla game for me right now, I don't have the DLC but I plan to get it. Right now I find the vanilla characters and options are enough to enjoy the game, and so far I don't find myself being drawn to specific characters or playstyles, or feeling like any one character has a heavy advantage over any other. With several ways to win the game, it allows for more options of play.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 9, 2015
												<Please Read Edit 3 as this is my opinion as of right now, 7/10/16>I fully reccomend Armello if you are a fan of Tabletop Adventures or Board Game RPGs. What separates Armello from other board games is that the rules of the game are incredibly simple to learn, yet there is so much you can do with the huge variety of cards and equipment you can obtain throughout the game. As someone who is not into the competitive multiplayer genre, games such as Dota or LoL, Armello has plenty of room for players to develop in all levels of skill. As of this moment, the only real High level grounds for players to lurk around on are the "Devs Vs Community" streams where the LeagueofGeeks challenge members of all skill levels in the community to battle against them. Should Armello be taken to a full competitive level, I would certainly delve further into the amazing world of Armello. Despite that this is a Multiplayer focused game, I appreciate that Singleplayer does a fantastic job preparing you for online play and is still enjoyable to look into even if you might not have any friends to play with/against. Be prepared though if you do get your friends into Armello. This game can and WILL test your friendships, but you will also forge new ones from meeting other members of the Armello community. The Music and Artwork for the game are also incredible. The music completely sets the tone for the heroic battle (Between the Heroes and admitably the Players) for the throne. To be honest, I often head into the Card Gallery just to look at the animated artwork for each card as each one adds its own background to the world of Armello. Regardless of how angry I might get at not getting a quest done in time or having bad combat streaks, I still enjoy playing game after game (Even if something like the following story happens)>Friends think 2v2 is a good idea>We try it out>Get absolutely massacred in game (MMM WHATCHA SAY, THAT YOU ONLY MEANT WELL)>Proceed to get Ice Cream >Sit in Corner for 10 minutes, crying while stuffing face in Ice Cream>Swears to never touch Armello again>Goes back 20 minutes later for another round>10/10 Game Design, would salt againGive this game a shot, get some friends along, I promise you that you will have a wonderful time.<Edit 1> So I have still been playing this game ever since the review, which I wrote at around 110 hours of total time. Now I have a total of 320 hours and I have shown no signs of slowing down. I do not play many multiplayer games, but this one has proven that addiction is guarenteed if you are into this genre of game.<Edit 2> Jeez, we're sitting four months later after the first edit and still going strong. Currently sitting at 570 hours and I still have a blast every time I load up a multiplayer match either with randoms or with friends. Thankfully, the 1.3 update has improved the player count in matchmaking for public queue. Much of that is due to the incentive of cosmetic drops from keys and chests, but I play regardless of those rewards. The game is also much more stable from previous updates and I rarely have matches break once they begin.<Edit 3> I hate to do this even at 615 hours, but I need to change my review to mixed because this is something that needs to be addressed. The new additions that patch v1.4 Battle Tides has offered has made my opinion of Armello dramatically worse. The main issue that has been raised is that experienced players do not like the fact that the special dice for Piercing/Reflect/Poison do not have any priority whatsoever. This is inexcuseable in my eyes as these special effects become near worthless as players are now less likely to use them correctly or to even get them in the first place. Suffice to say, I am rather disappointed with this new patch as it took viable strategies that were strategic in nature and opted instead for more randomness controlling the game when it wasn't there previously. Until this issue becomes resolved in a manner that is explained to the community for gameplay purposes and not for developmental purposes, this review will be placed as negative.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												This is probably the best digital boardgame I've played. And, yes, it includes digital versions of actual board games. I originally Kickstarted it way back when, and it remains one of the very, very, few games that I do not regret Kickstarting.Things I love most about Armello:1 - The visual design---especially character design---is phenomenal. At one glance, even if you're not familiar with the game, you can guess how a character plays. Thane (wolf with sword) is an offensive combat character. Barnaby (bunny with giant hammer and armor) focuses on equipment and combat. Elyssia (who is the best design character of all IMO) is a builder. The king's a lion, and his guards are faithful dogs. All the playable characters ooze personalities, kind of like a dark fairy tale Overwatch. This is actually the reason why I Kickstarted it.2 - Just like how games like Hearthstone does things that CCGs not played on a computer can't do, Armello does the same with boardgames. Things that would be too tedious to keep track of or involve secrecy that's impossible in tabletop play can happen easily here. Some people view that as a bad thing because it means that hotseat Armello will never happen (the devs confirmed this). I find that a plus because with Armello as a hotseat / physical game it means it's slightly easier to choose a board game when I'm playing with friends.3 - It's just a really good board game. I'm not a super board game geek (case in point, I don't even have a Boardgamegeek account) but I've played my fair share of games. And Armello is definitely in the top 10 of my favorite games. Maybe even top 5. The mechanics are interesting and mostly balanced (yes even that stupid bear with his spells). And it makes me say "mmm this is clever" both on plays and mechanics quite often.Biggest problems with this game are game length and NMA (no more action, essentially game ending bugs). It takes an hour or two to play a game with 3 human opponents, and while you can do things offturn things do get slow. I often multitask while playing, which I like but may or may not be a plus for you. The NMA bugs are annoying, especially given the game length, but I've only gotten them in 1/10 games in the past and haven't seen any since a few months ago (after the War chest update). The devs clearly love the game and update it pretty often with bugfixes and new content, so I'm pretty happy.

												Armello is a very fun/addicting computerized board game of light to medium complexity. Great with friends, and one of the few digital table tops to make good use of its medium with mechanics such as stealth. You can sometimes get screwed from dice and card RNG, but the game offers plenty of ways to mitigate chance. Worth noting, is that the Armello has received an impressive amount of support from the devs, with constant tweaks and new content since launch, as well as small events for the holidays. Style of play isn’t for everyone, but if you enjoy board games, Armello is worth checking out.

												This is a really fun game!  There are different ways to win a game so you can use a variety of strategies and change things up each time you play. Multiplayer can be a bit slow.  I realise you can use your offturn to play cards and such but that's not happening all the time so other players tend to be bored waiting - especially when some or all players are stealthed.  I don't have anything to offer as a solution, just that it's an annoying part of the game (all turn based strategy games have this issue, I guess reducing the wait time or giving people something else to do in their offturns could help)3.  The map is great and I realise there are 2 skins and dlc for more, but different maps enitrely would be nice to have4.  Just joined a multiplayer game and at the start of match I couldn't actually do anything after selecting my quest.  I think I was the first to go but I couldn't do anything, no turn timer, could chat but that's about it.  We all had to leave the match and wear the penalty, seems like a bug

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Bought this as a speculative purchase, because the concept seemed nice, and I like tabletop games generally.The game is surprisingly compelling. The concept is reasonably simple, and the art is lovely. You fight to become animal king of the world, building your stats through gear and quests. Combat and danger altimately come down to rolling a handful (or bucket full) of dice, and there's something satisfying in seeing a few dice hit the "succeed and roll again" result several times in one test.You will at some points get destroyed by RNGesus, but overall the game balances out, and has enough for the price to keep you entertained. For me it's not going to be one I'll play obsessively, but I will keep coming back for a bit more fun. Would definitely recommend.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												This game is great I like the story it brings and the art style. The game is a competitive challenge where you can play with or without friends. There are some things in the game that anger me like              - The Stranger always dragging you to horrible places.             - The dice rolls feel like you have to rely on luck just to win a Peril or fight, but cards help.              - I feel that I always get the Stranger, 1 or 2 pieces of gold or gain magic when raiding dungeons.             - Some of the heroes feel like they have too much damage or not enough.Anyways there are some more, but I'm not going to make a big list of pros and cons about the game. Back to my point, the game is a good purchase and might entertain you for hours, and if not there's always steam refund. While on the topic of time I sometimes complain about the game times. An average game is about an hour you can however, change the Kings health to speed up the game. That might only be for multiplayer. Like I keep saying it's a good game though I want a game where I can look at the time and say its 12:00 p.m and not look at the clock after to have it say 1:25 p.m. You also have to account for the multiple games you're going to be playing so, in the end, you look at the clock and say one more game than boom 4 hours of your life gone. Anyhow I'm rambling, and may even be overexaggerating, but if you're still reading this to the end then I appreciate that.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
EDIT 9/2/16A custom feature now exists that provides a great deal of control over the victory conditions! Games can now be as long or as short as you want, and some of the more contentious mechanics can be modified or disabled outright.Very well done, and kudos to the developers! This removes one of my main issues with the game, and changes my review from a "don't buy" to a "buy". I'm still a bit peeved that the prologue sets up a grand universe that's really just a neat board game, but now that it can be customized, I'm less bothered about it.The original review remains below, unaltered.OverviewThis game is beautiful, and perhaps that's actually some of the problem. You play through the prologue, and you get this very slick, almost Civilization-esque board game laid out for you piece by piece, with a very fleshed out and stylish world. Very nice.But then, you go to play a game, and you find out that no, there's no story, and in addition, a single game cannot be any longer than 9 rounds. One of the mechanics is that whoever has the most influence points when the 9th round is over automatically wins (barring the occasional edge case). 9 rounds goes by in a hurry, and the game is over much faster if any of the other victory mechanics are achieved.It feels like they missed the boat here. I personally can't recommend this game due to violated expectations. The talk of "role playing" in the game's description? Almost deceptive. If you go into it knowing that all you're getting is a board game, with the story being a paper thin framing device, then you may be able to enjoy Armello. Otherwise, you may end up disappointed. Decide accordingly.The Good+ Beautiful and atmospheric. You can tell a lot of love went into this title.+ There's nothing wrong with short games per se; it's great way to kill an hour or so with some friends.The Bad- Cap of 9 rounds per game, and this cannot be modified by the player. Certain rare game actions will cause this to be extended, but this is rare.- Games end too quickly- More luck than skill based- Any strategy you'd like to play (perhaps trading off a character's strenghts and weaknesses) is stuck behind an inane achievement-based unlockable system.The Ugly* Realizing that the grand story laid out in the prologue never goes anywhere - it's just a way to frame the tutorial. There is no campaign.* Realizing that the biggest annoyance with this game (the 9 round limit) could be trivially patched out, giving a lot more replay value, and the developers won't do it.OverallToo short, too expensive. Armello is like an ice cream sundae from a very fancy restaurant - looks beautiful on the plate, tastes amazing, but at the end, you're left wanting for more, and wondering why you paid what you did.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												I bought this on a whim several months ago after watching a Youtuber play it, and I'm so glad I did. I love Armello.There are a lot of random, luck based elements to it, but there is some strategy involved. There are several ways to win, which helps balance the game out a bit. The characters are great and each has a unique feel to him/her. I personally really enjoy the battle system and the use of item and spell cards. Multiplayer is definitely more fun and challenging than single player. Just be prepared to have some matches go very, very wrong for you. That being said, Armello has an addicitve quality that might keep you coming back even after your fourth loss in a row. If you lose your mind when things don't go exactly how you imagined, this probably isn't the game for you, lol. If that kind of thing doesn't stop you from having fun, and you're looking for a challenging, whimsical, visually pleasing video game with the feel of a board game, Armello is for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Listen. I'd be here for an action-adventure story driven game with similar combat & gameplay structure set in Armello's world about overthrowing the King, with different narratives for the different clans... I'd die happy. But what we get is pretty damn great too! It's easily one of my favourite titles I own on Steam, and I'd recommend it wholeheartedly, even at full price. I got it on sale, and frankly, I'd pay the full 20 USD for it, even with the terrible AUS currency rate right now. The world is beautiful, the artstyle is fantastic, and the characters are excellent- both design and gameplay. I love the art on the cards. The voice lines update took me by surprise and I'm not sold on the noises the King makes while getting Rot every night. I almost preferred it voiceless, but I'm looking forward to further developer updates- they're friendly and engage with the community well. Also, as an Australian, it is a source of both relief and pride to see such a cool game come out of my country, because there aren't many others I've come across. The gameplay is extremely solid, and the RNG isn't stupidly punishing like some I've come across. You get some bad turns, like activating a bane at a dungeon three turns in a row, but you get some awesome ones too, like getting a 15 attack roll for Zosha and proving to a friend that the statement 'if I die I'm taking you with me' is true. I find it stays fresh and interesting every game, despite the similiar set up, and the characters playstyles are diverse enough to keep you invested. I can't really comment on the state of multiplayer- I don't really play it, because the long, long turns bore me and I get disinterested. I do love playing with friends, though!
