												You play as a animal hero in a fantasy world (Wolf Warrior, Rat Thief, Bear Druid and so on...) and compete against other players to kill the mad king. It plays like one of those very complex board games with RPG elements, only there's a computer making the game run smooth (and avoiding those endless hours of dispute about the rules with your friends) and there's beautiful, gorgeous 3D animation of fantasy characters acting and fighting on the game board. It's good fun and has pretty decent variety, there are many characters to play as, cards and different paths to victory. Also, Armello is constantly evolving, the developers are releasing new elements of the games and new heroes every few months or so. The internet community are quite nice.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												Armello is a compelling turn-based board game with a variety of different ways to win. There are always 3 opponents (human or AI controlled) along with a variety of NPCs that hinder or help your progress. Being tasked with returning the kingdom to normal, you can choose to defeat the king in combat, become more corrupt than him by being tainted by the 'rot', gather 4 spirit stones to banish him or become the prestige leader and keep the king alive. The different heroes you play as all have their own talents and skills. Each clan has their own rings and coupled with the trinkets and artifacts you uncover during the game you can have a wildly varied hand. At first it seems easy but there are many things out to get you. You have to face perils, survive enemy players and mobs and get close enough to the king to stop him. I love the aesthetics of this game, it certainly feels and sounds like a fantasy adventure you'd want to be a part of. The animal motif fits the theme and the range of cards and effects makes this a deeply complex game. Definitely one of the best board games on Steam.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												This is a game of strategy to tip the odds in your favor. Nothing is ever concrete and therefore very replayable. The memories you can make with friends are fantastic as your grand plan either suceeds for epicly fails. Whatever story your character ventures or stumbles down, odds are, you'll come back for more.The art is fantastic and gorgeous to look at. Zooming in and out actually changes the audio you experience. The sound track and ambience are lovely and a joy to listen to.The gameplay is unique and increasingly fun the more familiar you become with the mechanics. Hunting achievements was never something I did until I played this game.My only request is possibly a campaign mode or maybe a new mode that has more in depth quests. I think the quests mechanic can be explored more and be used as a tool to flush out the world of Armello. Maybe even get us emotionally attached to certain characters.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
Product received for free
												I received the game as a gift from a friend some time ago, but held off reviewing it in order to see what direction the development team would take it.  I have to say, that after all this time, I'm pretty pleased thus far. ^^The visuals are nice, and the boardgame-style gameplay is pretty solid.  The random chance elements in the form of the dice and various card decks encourage players to think on their feet and choose their battles carefully.It's easy to learn, difficult to master, and fun all around.If I had to nit-pick, my only gripe would be that there isn't enough story content.  The game only provides you with enough to understand the basic premise, but really nothing concrete beyond that; leaving you to cobble together a -very- loose narrative from the snippets of flavor text you glean from the various cards.  At the very least, they could finish giving all the player characters their back stories.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												I didn't think I would like a digital board game. I'm also allergic to hex tiles. However, Armello is beautifully animated and super fun. I once heard it compared to "what would happen if Disney bought the rights to Game of Thrones" -- while this obviously isn't a completely logical scenario, I think it's a pretty fair comparison. The game is cute, but maintains a mature attitude that makes you take it seriously.On the sliding scale of skill versus randomness, this game sits somewhere in the middle. You need skill to not screw up, but randomness features pretty heavily in determining the winner. As a skilled player, you won't necessarily win a game against three new players. Lots of fun BS happens at the end of the game; "upsets" are frequent and wins are not locked down until you strike the last blow.Also an excellent game to multitask on; while you're waiting for people to take their turn, you can do other stuff. Play games 24/7, even when you have stuff to do!

content:
Posted: January 26
												Very good game to play with friends, awesome if you love animals, the board is randomly generated every game.The game revolves around a corrupted king at the center of the board, while player race to either overthrow him in battle, banish him by collecting spirit stones, or  wait until he dies from the rot and claim a prestige victory. bceause of this, games usually do not last more than an hour, so it is great to play if you're low on time or don't like the endless hours of playing games like Risk or Civilization. Cards have animations on them! Game gets updated continually, and has online multiplayer as well. You can create custom rules for your private games too! Biggest gripe is how expensive the DLC is. Understandable that it is expensive, as the developers are Australian, and most games down there are typically more expensive. The only DLC that can actually affect the game itself if the hero packs. Heros and cards do also get updated and balanced as well. DRM free version available out of Steam!Overall, fantastic game, would reccomend to friends, high replay value, absolutely satisfied with my purchases (I have the Usurpers DLC.)

content:
Posted: January 2
												Armello is the kind of game you sit back relax and have a cup of coffee or tea as you wait for your turn.Pretty easy to pick up, a bit more difficult to master, as some times the hand of cards you get is a bit punishing and you have to make do. As it is in any game like this.Visually it is exactly what it promises. Easy on the eyes and relaxing, good atmosphere for what it is and overall a game worth sitting down and playing. Matchmaking is pretty good. One hour (or so) long matches where you pick your hero and go to work. It offers a balanced roster of heroes and a randomly generated map.The rewards, even though not so great, vary from simple dice skins to rare ones which you can get by unlocking chests with keys you receive from finished matches.Only con I could find is that if a player (in mp) gets too salty he'll try to "milk" the time out of his turn and in an hour-long match this gets from tedious to frustrating, to infuriating.9/10!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 5
												I love this board game.  Great visuals and lighting effects.  I really enjoy the artwork and unique storyline.  I enjoy the varieties of cards you can collect, along with the attention to detail that was put into each of the animations.  The gaming style has many different strategies, tactics, and angles to think about while you play.   Each character you choose has a very unique style that changes the way you think and plan out your strategy.  Its like playing a different game with each character you use.  While waiting for multiplayer match, the game allows you to play single player game, then alerts you with a popup to join when your match is ready.  You do get to unlock unique items to play in future games (dice with unique bonus symbols for fighting, rings with perks, and badges that give you bonuses to certain character traits starting off) These are unlocked by collecting chests and keys in multiplayer matches.  You do not have to purchase keys to unlock chests like in other games with this feature.  You get to win, collect, and unlock these items for free which is nice.  I did however purchase the DLC expansions because I enjoy the amount of artwork that was put into this game and want to support the developer and see where they go with future titles.  I look forward to seeing more cards and animations added to the game.  The cards themselves  are very entertaining.  The game is very replayable and doesn't get boring quickly. (although, I wish the external movement animations and watching other players battle was a little more interesting)  If you like board games, with a bit of depth, and deck building (per game) I definately recommend this title.  ProsUnique StorylineGreat Artwork, Animations, Lighting, and EffectsVery ReplayableEverything you win in multiplayer you get to unlock without having to buy more into the game with micro transactions.  (The micro transaction type of purchasing model just annoys me)Best looking cards and hand drawn animations that I have seen in a game.Lots of depth to Strategy, Tactics, and multiple levels of PlanningMultiple ways to win a game.Unique characters each with different play styles.All traits are not fixed and can be improved by taking quests, acquiring cards, and winning battles.ConsDefault gameplay can feel fairly long.  However they have added options to tweak the speed and pace to your choosing.  You will come out of this game wondering what happened to the last two to three hours of your night.  But, you will enjoy playing it.I felt the price is a bit high (to purchase the title and all the dlc content at once in the bundle package). Its kinda hard to convince friends to purchase a board game for this price (especially one that contains a fantasy genre with enchanted animals that come from a magical forest).  I am willing to purchase all of the content because I appreciate the artwork and overall design of the game.   But, alot of my friends are cheap,  and don't like to buy anything if its over the $15-$20 range.  I myself, don't like to gift to people that are cheap, and that are ok with letting artists and programmers starve.  So, I am kinda stuck in an infinate Catch 22 scenerio.Its hard explaining to others what exactly you are doing when you are caught playing a game with lots of happy colors and magical creatures.

content:
Posted: January 3
												So far after a handful of games I can say this is a great game.  I highly recommend it.  Pros:+Similar to Civ in that there are multiple win conditions, but games only last ~45 minutes+Great art, lore, and overall aesthetic.  Cards are animated too which is a nice touch+Sound is amazing+Players that disconnect are replaced with AI in multiplayer, so no dropped games+I like rolling diceCons:-Games could be much faster if animations/turns were sped up-Pointless unlock system for certain items that should be available from the start with super long requirements.  For instance, you need to play TEN Games with each of the four clans to get all rings?  That's 40 games @ ~45 minutes each, give me a breakOverall:  Definitely worth checking out at the low price point for board game fans and fans of strategy games (that don't mind some RNG)

												While most of the mechanics would translate well into a physical board game there are little touches that are exactly the right way to use the medium of computer games. The most obvious example is the stealth mechanic: other players will not see you when you are hidden, which is hard to replicate in a physical game. I also really appreciate the addition of collectable dice, which is a nice way to reward players without giving them an advantage over other players. I occasionally have difficulty finding online play but that may be due to the part of the world I am in. Clearly this is not a big deal so far, as I keep coming back for more. Overall, I recommend this game!

content:
Posted: February 9
												See My Review Video Below:


YouTube™ Video: Silverain Reviews: Armello 

			Views: 28		

			Three Parts Board Game, one part Fantasy RPG Armello is a beautiful and addictive digital board game created by League of Geeks.		

Three Parts Board Game, one part Fantasy RPG Armello is a beautiful and addictive digital board game created by League of Geeks.While there are some worrying DLC practices regarding the game the price of the core game is rather decent and furthermore has a solid and reliable single player as well as online multiplayer. TLDW: 	Pros: Low Price for core game, often on sale.    Easy to understand and entertaining tutorials.Simple to pick up, deceptively fast gameplay, Single player games take on average 30 minutes and online 1 hour.Beautiful cinematics and overall artstyle with hits of a deeper story.Atmospheric music and sound effects.Decent AI though it is explotable.Unlocks available in single player and regardless of a win or loss.Multiple victory conditions which can allow players to always feel they have a chance of success.Each game is different due to the variations available and the ability to craft custom games. Character each have prefered playstyles but can adapt to any victory type.Steam Cards and Achievements.Cons: Cosmetic DLC rather costly or has distastleful requirements leading to resentment in the community.It is not always clear why a player doesn't have a chance to respond to Perils. Multiplayer is partly unstable at this time with occasional connection drops, though AI take over dropped players should anything happen to a player's connection, there is zero ability to reconnectKey and Chest drops only available in multiplayer.Lack of hardware interface options. (This can be a pro for those wishing a simple setup)The Combat can make turns long in multiplayer.Bot Farming: Due to high cost of cosmetic drops players have been know to join multiplayer and go afk just to earn drops however the reporting system is eay and should be encouraged.Unlike in the tutorials the followers offer no banter which is a bit disappointing and reduces their character a little.Lack of game modes, an adventure or story mode similar to the tutorial or a team V.S. would of been a nice edition.Music can be a little too calm and becomes unnoticeable after a while, consider having your own fantasy playlist on standby.No modding. Final verdict: Worth the price as a solid digital board game, I recommend picking up the core game and Usurpers Hero Pack while on sale but ignore the overpriced cosmetics.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Armello is, quite simply, an incredibly well designed game.It's basically a digital card game / board game hybrid which combines strategic decision making and multiplayer bluffing and politics with a moderate degree of randomness. Yes, most actions in the game are determined by dice rolls but if you use your cards efficiently this can be mitigated to such a large extent that the victor is nearly always determined by strategic play rather than luck (I personally have around a 70% win rate at the time of writing and trust me, I'm not that lucky) .On balance the gameplay works extremely well and creates interesting situations with a surprising amount of replayability. Armello is by no means a game which you binge all day every day (although you could if you wanted to) but it's fantastic for a couple hours of laid back fun every now and then.The game has a theme and art style which somehow immediately reminded me of the Redwall books I used to read when I was younger. It's somewhat cartoony but in an extremely polished, non-comical way. The 8 different characters that can be played all have different playstyles and are, on the whole, surprisingly well balanced. Many CCGs released these days could actually learn a lot from Armello in terms of game balance because the same is true for the cards in the game. Even  cards which are less obviously useful and might sit dead in your hand for a turn or two can still be 'burned' for beneficial effects in combat or in perils (traps basically).The only criticisms I have are that there are still a few bugs here and there (the most annoying one being a bug that freezes the game when a player gains AP using Strategist or Hot-Rot Wine when it's not their turn) and that ranked mode has still not been implemented. This is a real shame as the game definitely has the player base to support it. The amount of players seems to have actually gone up significantly since the game was released on Steam and it rarely takes longer than half a minute to find a game at the time of writing.Overall, highly recommended.

content:
Posted: January 3
												Gameplay 8/10Graphics 9/10Audio 8/10Cons: -Slighlty unfair ranking system-A fair time of waitingArmello is not your average strategy game due to the unique winning conditions and constantly changing board events. In this game you will play as one of the four animal clans seeking to take down the king of Armello who has been corrupted by a evil known as rot, yet there are three other players that also wish to take down the king and steal his throne for themselves. All these players are pushed into one RANDOMLY generated board composed of varying hex tiles that take effect upon the player ( Ex. Moving into a swamp causes you to lose a life while moving into a spirirt circle gives you a life). I personally enjoy the gameplay for there is a hint of cut throat required over multiplayer and in fact many ways to win the game which gives every player a path to take towards victory. The random generation of the board along with the King's Acts that are determined by a player makes no two games alike as players are trying to win the game through their own preffered path. Graphics in the game are rather stunning as the cards actullay have fine detailed art that actually moves upon hvoering over said card. Games can last up to about a hour or more, yet the graphics are thankfully easy on the eyes as you play hours on end. Audio is nothing really to praise nor spit on. The CONS vary in severity to player to player and may effect whether or not you wish to buy this game. Games can last for long hours and demands that you idly wait for your turn as other players take their lengthy turn which can lead you to becoming rather bored after skimming over your cards and planning your next turn if it ever comes. A Multiplayer issue is the ranking system where you maybe a mere level one and end up being paired up with a rank 5 player which seems a bit unfair or poor ranking. I would reccomend this game to those who are fine waiting for their turns over a long lengthy game and are willing to put in time to play a whole game. I give Armello 9/10 Spirit Stones

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 5
												I love this board game.  Great visuals and lighting effects.  I really enjoy the artwork and unique storyline.  I enjoy the varieties of cards you can collect, along with the attention to detail that was put into each of the animations.  The gaming style has many different strategies, tactics, and angles to think about while you play.   Each character you choose has a very unique style that changes the way you think and plan out your strategy.  Its like playing a different game with each character you use.  While waiting for multiplayer match, the game allows you to play single player game, then alerts you with a popup to join when your match is ready.  You do get to unlock unique items to play in future games (dice with unique bonus symbols for fighting, rings with perks, and badges that give you bonuses to certain character traits starting off) These are unlocked by collecting chests and keys in multiplayer matches.  You do not have to purchase keys to unlock chests like in other games with this feature.  You get to win, collect, and unlock these items for free which is nice.  I did however purchase the DLC expansions because I enjoy the amount of artwork that was put into this game and want to support the developer and see where they go with future titles.  I look forward to seeing more cards and animations added to the game.  The cards themselves  are very entertaining.  The game is very replayable and doesn't get boring quickly. (although, I wish the external movement animations and watching other players battle was a little more interesting)  If you like board games, with a bit of depth, and deck building (per game) I definately recommend this title.  ProsUnique StorylineGreat Artwork, Animations, Lighting, and EffectsVery ReplayableEverything you win in multiplayer you get to unlock without having to buy more into the game with micro transactions.  (The micro transaction type of purchasing model just annoys me)Best looking cards and hand drawn animations that I have seen in a game.Lots of depth to Strategy, Tactics, and multiple levels of PlanningMultiple ways to win a game.Unique characters each with different play styles.All traits are not fixed and can be improved by taking quests, acquiring cards, and winning battles.ConsDefault gameplay can feel fairly long.  However they have added options to tweak the speed and pace to your choosing.  You will come out of this game wondering what happened to the last two to three hours of your night.  But, you will enjoy playing it.I felt the price is a bit high (to purchase the title and all the dlc content at once in the bundle package). Its kinda hard to convince friends to purchase a board game for this price (especially one that contains a fantasy genre with enchanted animals that come from a magical forest).  I am willing to purchase all of the content because I appreciate the artwork and overall design of the game.   But, alot of my friends are cheap,  and don't like to buy anything if its over the $15-$20 range.  I myself, don't like to gift to people that are cheap, and that are ok with letting artists and programmers starve.  So, I am kinda stuck in an infinate Catch 22 scenerio.Its hard explaining to others what exactly you are doing when you are caught playing a game with lots of happy colors and magical creatures.
